In Anfeng County, Shouzhou, a man named Wang Wenqing had a daughter, nicknamed Zhaodi. From the age of thirteen, she abstained from meat and fish, devoting herself to virtue and the Dao. One day, a wandering Daoist nun knocked at her door, urging Zhaodi to venerate the Perfected Warrior and True Lord of Numinous Response of the Northern Dipper. Zhaodi replied, "I am but a humble girl and cannot afford to commission a sacred image. If I could only obtain a copy of the *Scripture of the True Warrior*, I would recite it day and night, keeping it close to my heart, meditating on the True Lord’s image, burning incense, and chanting his praises."

By twenty, Zhaodi’s beauty, intelligence, and skill had drawn the attention of wealthy families seeking her hand in marriage, all of whom she accepted in principle—yet she never ceased invoking her master, the True Warrior. One day, she overheard her father, uncles, and brothers lamenting: "Last year’s drought left the villages starving. Now, as the crops desperately need water, Heaven has not sent rain, and the people face despair once more. Though officials have come to our village’s Zhenfu Crag to draw water from the dragon pool, there has been no response."

Upon hearing this, Zhaodi cut off her hair in the open air and vowed that on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, she would burn incense and offer herself in sacrifice to pray for rain across the drought-stricken lands, beseeching a bountiful harvest.

Her family entreated her to abandon the vow, but she would not relent. She then erected a pyre before her home. At that moment, spectators from all directions gathered, encircling her with murmurs of admiration. Zhaodi’s countenance remained unchanged, as serene as ever. Taking leave of her parents and the assembled crowd, she left behind a verse:

*"I came seeking deliverance,
Departing by the old path.
Spring blossoms bloom in splendor,
Yet fade without attachment."*

The verse spoken, she laughed joyfully and stepped into the flames. As the fire consumed the pyre’s center, a single streak of azure light shot straight toward the heavens. After a long while, a sudden downpour descended, and though the flames burned as if drenched in oil or wax, their radiance only grew brighter. When the rain ceased and the fire had burned itself out, another heavy rain fell, lasting two days and a night, until every river, canal, and field was thoroughly saturated.

When the skies cleared, the Wang family and villagers came to gather her ashes, but not a single speck of dust remained. Instead, within the pyre’s ashes, they found a sash tied in a double knot and a scroll of the *True Warrior Sutra* she had held in life—both perfectly preserved. It became clear then that her body had dissolved in the fire, leaving only the sutra and her garments as testament to her sincerity.

In recognition of the miraculous rain and its life-giving bounty, local officials summoned Wang Wenqing to present the fire-resistant *True Warrior Sutra* for verification. The matter was duly reported, and the provincial authorities issued an edict to investigate all drought-stricken regions. It was confirmed that from the fifteenth to the sixteenth day of the seventh month, timely rains had fallen abundantly. Further inquiry revealed that within the state’s borders, a streak of azure light had pierced the heavens—a wondrous omen from an unknown source.

The prefectural authorities memorialized the event, and after deliberation by the Central Secretariat, an order was sent to Shouzhou: using government funds, a small pavilion was to be constructed at Tianqing Temple to enshrine the relics of Wang Zhaodi, along with the *True Warrior Sutra* in a painted casket for perpetual veneration. A stele was erected to commemorate the event, and Zhaodi was posthumously enfeoffed as the *Holy Maiden of Life-Giving Rain*, with a shrine established for offerings. The inscription also included a prayer for clear skies.

In Guozhou, a blind man named Chen Xi once encountered the True Warrior on Shaoguang Mountain, who transmitted a secret method to him. From then on, Chen devoted himself to its practice. Later, when he spoke, his words seemed imbued with divine presence, and whatever he prayed for on behalf of others—whether for their uncles or other matters—always came to pass. His reputation spread far and wide, and though people offered him gifts, he cared little for personal gain, dedicating all to meritorious deeds.

During the *Xianping* era, as summer gave way to autumn, prolonged rains damaged the crops. The prefecture and counties performed rituals to pray for relief, but none proved efficacious. The people collectively recommended Chen Xi, who venerated the True Warrior and whose prayers were known to be efficacious. Prefect Huang Fang thus summoned Chen Xi to the government hall. Chen Xi, however, informed Huang that he must personally compose the invocation, bring the True Warrior’s sacred seat from his home to the prefectural yamen, select seven Daoist priests, and establish a purified ritual space. Slaughter was forbidden, punishments were reduced, and the common people were permitted to burn incense and offer prayers for clear skies in the ritual space daily.

After three days, Chen Xi addressed the officials and assembled crowd, relaying the divine message: “By the True Warrior’s decree, Guozhou was fated by the Celestial Bureau to endure sixty days of rain, reducing the harvest by a full tenth. Twenty days remain, and the rains have yet to cease. Now that you have prayed for clear skies, by the August Emperor’s command, the celestial records shall be revised. By tomorrow’s *si* hour, the rain will gradually recede from the due north, and by the *wu* hour, the sky will clear, the crops will flourish, and the harvest will be secured.” When Chen Xi’s spirit returned, he recalled nothing of the divine pronouncement.

The next morning, heavy rain poured down, but by the *si* hour, the skies cleared, and the clouds dispersed from the north. The prefecture retained the True Warrior for three more days of ritual, preparing incense, flowers, and Daoist implements to escort the deity back to Chen Xi’s home. A separate ritual was then held in the hall to give thanks.

That winter, none of the five counties in Guozhou reported any shortfall in grain yields. The Transport Commission investigated the matter and memorialized the court. An imperial edict was subsequently issued to Guozhou, ordering that an official record be established in the prefectural yamen as permanent testimony. Beyond the provisions of wine, grain, silk, and brocade granted by the prefecture, Chen Xi was specially bestowed the title *Master of Tranquil Response*.

Sun Yin’s Memorial on Locust Plagues
*Remonstrance Gentleman, Minister of Justice, and Prefect of Jiazhou, Yang Hu’s memorial:*

I have observed that Sun Yin, magistrate of E County, has diligently administered his office, demonstrating remarkable efficacy in alleviating disasters and hardships. First, when locusts infested the early crops in the villages, though Emei County suffered from flying locusts, the grain remained unharmed. This was due to Sun Yin distributing enchanted water to the villagers, who sprinkled it with willow branches, causing the locusts to transform into flying ants and perish in the water. By autumn, not a single grain was lost.

Second, when tigers and wolves in Emei Mountain preyed upon people year after year, Sun Yin issued a talisman on yellow paper to the mountain’s spirit-officials, and the beasts vanished without a trace.

Third, when Transport Commissioner Tao Fen suffered an attack of wind-phlegm, Sun Yin administered a decoction of jujube and medicine, restoring him to health.

Fourth, when Prefect Yang Hu’s daughter-in-law, née Dou, faced a perilous childbirth, Sun Yin provided a vermilion birth talisman. Burned to ash and mixed with water, it ensured her safe delivery.

As Sun Yin’s term neared its end, the people of the prefecture wept and petitioned for his retention. Summoned for inquiry into his extraordinary abilities, Sun Yin explained: “My late father, Eunuch Sun Zongdao, once accompanied the late Emperor Taizong on a campaign to Hebei. One night in Jinbing Plain, he encountered the True Warrior Perfected Lord, who transmitted nine talismans, incantations, and methods for consecrating water. Though my father never employed them, I inherited the teachings and have venerated the True Warrior ever since, vowing to use the talismans and water to save others. All successes are due to the True Warrior’s aid—how could they be my doing alone?”

Yang Hu submitted a detailed memorial in support, and Transport Commissioner Tao Fen followed with his own report. The court, after review, determined that while other matters were unremarkable, the suppression of locusts in two towns and the taming of tigers and leopards demonstrated divine protection worthy of commendation. Though Sun Yin held office by hereditary privilege without formal credentials, he was specially promoted to *Attending Secretary of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices* and reappointed to Emei County for another term.

In Jiazhou, the *True Warrior Compassionate Salvation Abbey* was founded by Prefect Yang Hu, Transport Commissioner Tao Fen, and local merchants in gratitude. The abbey served to repel pests and pacify disasters.

**Lin Shouqing’s Veneration of the True Warrior**
During the *Baoyuan* era, a Fujian merchant named Lin Shouqing was sailing from Zhangzhou’s harbor when his ship was caught in a storm surge. As the vessel was about to sink, a divine figure suddenly appeared in the empty air above the prow, calling out: “Shouqing, cease your seafaring henceforth. Today, I shall save your ship from peril. In the future, come to the *Tianqing Abbey* on Min Mountain and seek Daoist Ren in the south corridor.” With these words, the figure vanished in a flash of white light. The wind and waves instantly calmed, and the ship glided smoothly back to Fuzhou.

Lin proceeded to the south corridor of *Tianqing Abbey* on Min Mountain but found no quarters for a Daoist named Ren. An elderly priest informed him: “The character *ren* means ‘person.’ In the south corridor, there is a shrine to the True Warrior Perfected Lord, originally the *King’s Protector of the State Hall*.” Lin then understood. He visited the hall to offer thanks and commissioned a statue of the True Warrior from the finest agarwood, gilded and intricately carved, for lifelong veneration.

When the craftsman selected a piece of agarwood measuring one foot and three inches in circumference, he prepared to carve it. Suddenly, several auspicious rays of light emanated from the wood, growing brighter and unceasing. Once the statue was completed, Lin, together with others, donated over ten thousand strings of cash to sponsor grand vegetarian feasts at temples and abbeys throughout the prefecture and on Min Mountain. The *Tianqing Abbey* and the *King’s Protector of the State True Warrior Hall* were extensively renovated, and repentance rituals were established. Lin vowed that neither he nor his descendants would ever again engage in maritime trade.

That year, Fuzhou suffered a severe drought from spring to summer, and locusts swarmed, ravaging the crops. Prayers for relief went unanswered, and the locusts persisted into the seventh and eighth months. The prefectural government, learning of Lin Shouqing’s devotion to the True Warrior, dispatched officials to invite the deity to the yamen. There, rituals were performed thrice daily with utmost reverence.

After just three days, the locusts wrapped themselves around tree branches and perished. Villagers from the four hamlets broke off the branches and presented them as proof. Sweet rains began to fall daily, and by winter, half of the damaged crops were salvaged. The prefectural government celebrated and gave thanks to the True Warrior, concluding the grand ritual feast. With the same solemnity as before, the deity was escorted back to Lin Shouqing’s household shrine.

Prefect Chen Ciqin, having witnessed Lin Shouqing’s deliverance at sea, the carving of the sacred image, the manifestation of crimson light, and the prayers for rain that dispelled the locust plague, reported these miracles across seven prefectures and nineteen counties, affirming their truth and efficacy in widespread relief. His memorial was duly approved, and an edict commanded that the True Warrior image enshrined by Lin Shouqing be purchased at its appraised value and conveyed to the capital.

Lin Shouqing thereafter presented the image at court. Upon inspection, the throne was found to be crafted of aloeswood, exquisitely wrought, and suffused with auspicious radiance—a marvel of divine favor and numinous response. By imperial decree, it was retained as a treasure to safeguard the realm and enshrined in the inner palace. Lin Shouqing was specially granted the honorary rank of *Sanjie Jiezhi* and later rose to the position of Right Attendant-in-Ordinary. He lived to ninety-six, passing without illness.

*Record of the Divine Manifestation of the Dark Heavenly Emperor*, Scroll Four, concludes.
*Dispelling Calamities and Invoking the Fire Virtue*

In the second year of Xianping, the Bureau of Astronomy memorialized that on the third day of the ninth month, Mars would conjoin the constellation Lou, directly illuminating the celestial division corresponding to Zhengzhou in the Qi region, foretelling a great conflagration. The imperial command was issued to the prefecture, ordering preparatory rites of expiation. As Zhengzhou served as a strategic garrison along the eastern route to the capital, from the fourth month onward, notices were posted at temples and Daoist abbeys to conduct rituals for averting fire, with grand jiao offerings and prayers.

At that time, Li Weixin of the southern market, a broker in the grain trade, would steal away each night at the third watch to burn incense and prostrate himself at a critical thoroughfare on the bridge. By chance, the garrison commander Ren Congyuan happened upon him during a night patrol, arrested him for violating curfew, and sent him under guard to Lizhou. When questioned, Li admitted to his misconduct, explaining that since the seventh night of the first month, he had been burning incense at night after learning of a matter. Asked what it was, he replied: "Last year, I vowed to devote my broker’s earnings for a full year to sponsor a jiao offering to the Heavenly Court, in gratitude for the source of my sustenance, and to host a vegetarian feast. Suddenly, a wandering Daoist—his robes disheveled, his bearing free and untrammeled—entered seeking alms, carrying a scroll painting. It was a silk portrait of the True Warrior. I wished to enshrine it, and the Daoist agreed, asking only for two strings of cash, then partook of the meal. Midway through, a gust of wind howled, and he vanished, leaving behind on the table a living tortoise no larger than a peach pit. I knew then I had encountered a divine manifestation, receiving sacred incense and this wondrous small tortoise, which I treasured and enshrined.

On the seventh night of the first month this year, I prepared paper offerings to burn in worship of the True Warrior. Then, the Daoist who had sold me the scroll years before reappeared, carrying the little tortoise. I bowed to him, asking his name, but he would not say, only declaring: ‘This poor Daoist is versed in calendrical calculations. When the celestial fire star arrives on the third day of the ninth month, it will directly illuminate Zhengzhou in the Qi region, bringing a great fire that will burn ten thousand households. If you find a household surnamed Wan, regardless of the size of their dwelling, do not move a single item or coin from their home. First, record an inventory of all their possessions. At dawn on the third day of the ninth month, have a boy with his hair tied in a topknot, clad in a coarse hemp robe, carry a torch and circle the house three times from the south, then set it ablaze. Afterward, there will be no further fire. Once done, gather the people to restore the house and all its contents to the Wan family, and the calamity will be averted.’

As he departed, he transformed into a streak of white light and vanished. Though I received this divine revelation, I dared not report it. Instead, each night, I secretly offered prayers to Mars at the market’s vital crossroads, beseeching deliverance from disaster. Here is the incense burner I carried as proof."

Upon reviewing the broker’s testimony, the prefectural authorities found it consistent with the recent imperial edict. They dispatched officials to investigate households surnamed Wan, recording an inventory of their property and possessions. The residents were ordered to await the fire’s passage before restoring everything, with the documents filed for the record. Li Weixin was released to return home, where he burned incense in vigilant protection.

When the appointed day arrived, a boy clad in a hemp robe was prepared. The household of Wan Ming west of the prefectural bridge was set ablaze. A southern wind fanned the flames, splitting them into two fierce tongues. The people were seized with terror—when suddenly, a sudden downpour extinguished the blaze. In less than an hour, the fire had passed through the Wan residence. Beneath the True Warrior’s image in Li Weixin’s home, the small tortoise was gone, having vanished with the wind and rain.

The prefecture of Zhengzhou, having witnessed this divine efficacy, had already acted accordingly. Subsequently, in accordance with a memorial from the Chancellery, the Bureau of Astronomy observed that on the third day of the ninth month, the Fire Virtue would descend upon Zhengzhou, striking at the hour of *yin* to burn away the Wan household. Upon inquiry, it was confirmed that no official storehouses, armories, or other public property would be affected.

At the time, Wu Min’gu, Vice Minister of War and Participant in Determining Governmental Matters, served as prefect of Zhengzhou. Upon opening and reviewing the memorial of protection, a subsequent imperial decree was issued for further deliberation. As Li Weixin had encountered the True Warrior and averted disaster, thereby manifesting his accumulated virtue, he was to be bestowed with one hundred bottles of ritual wine, one hundred bolts of silk, ten *shi* of rice, ten *shi* of wheat, and one hundred strings of cash, to be disbursed from the prefecture’s public treasury. Wan Ming, who had previously offered his entire household to be burned in substitution, thereby effecting timely expiation, was likewise granted wine, rice, and other provisions according to precedent. He was urgently ordered to rebuild his dwelling, with compensation for his property, and no delay was to be tolerated.

Moreover, in recognition of the True Warrior’s merciful deliverance and the Southern Fire Virtue’s august stellar benevolence, a seven-day and seven-night Daoist ritual was to be conducted in the Jade Grove Park of the capital, with an offering of one thousand two hundred altar stations in gratitude. To counteract the baleful influence of *Ketu*, in the third year of the Zhihe reign, on the first night of the eighth month, a yellow vapor emerged from the south and persisted for three nights before dissipating. According to a memorial from the Bureau of Astronomy by the Court Gentleman for Attendance Xia Xun and others, the yellow vapor had appeared in the due south, corresponding to the celestial division of the Wu state. This vapor was known by three names: the Yellow Path of Heaven’s Gate, *Tuyang*, and *Ketu*, manifesting in the Celestial Gate of the *Makara* constellation. The Yellow Path foretold internal strife in the state the following year, affecting one person of the *yin* palace. *Tuyang* signified the image of tombs, while *Ketu* was the stellar bridge of the nine heavens. Its untimely appearance outside its proper palace portended that, by the winter’s end, one quarter of the military and civilian population in a certain region would perish from pestilence. However, as this star resided in the *Makara* constellation and trespassed upon the *Kang* mansion, it also served as a stellar force capable of dissolving calamity and bestowing fortune. It was thus hoped that the court would promptly undertake rites of humility and expiation.

Upon deliberation by the court officials, as the matter pertained to the future, it was deemed necessary to take preventive measures. A month-long inner Daoist ritual was accordingly conducted in the Jade Grove Park. Imperial incense was dispatched to all renowned mountains and great rivers, where dragon tablets were cast into the waters, and seven-day and seven-night ritual offerings were established. A general amnesty was proclaimed, and prisoners were to have their sentences reduced or remitted. Additionally, within the imperial palace’s Hall of Flourishing Sagehood, a separate forty-nine-day and forty-nine-night Yellow Register Daoist ritual was held. Each day, the emperor personally attended to pray to the Star Lord *Ketu*, the Eastern *Kang* constellation, and the household True Warrior and Fortune Deity, seeking auspicious confirmation through the ritual.

As the allotted days neared their end, suddenly, at high noon, a fierce wind arose, stirring up swirling yellow sand that obscured the sky. Amidst the haze, a golden-armored divine warrior appeared in the courtyard, declaring, “Your subject is General Ge, Warden of the Western Gate of Heaven, who, together with the True Warrior of the North, oversees the reckoning of good and evil in the yang realm. Recently, the Southern Gate of Heaven’s Yellow Path has opened, revealing *Ketu* as it traverses the nine heavens. Once every seven hundred and twenty years, it completes a grand cycle, and now, encountering its destined phase, it clashes with *Tuyang* of the central region, producing a three-day yellow vapor that entwines the *Kang* mansion before retreating from *Makara*. This portends internal strife in the yang realm, arising from a person of the *yin* palace born in the year of the Boar, who holds sway as a national leader. Within half a year, in the circuits of Jinghu, Jiangzhe, Fujian, Guangnan, and Huaihan, one quarter of the populace will perish, and tombs will line the roads. Though the calamity has yet to arrive, the emperor’s virtue has already elicited a response. The rituals, offerings, and casting of dragon tablets, however, have not yet fully expiated the omen. Only the proclamation of virtue and the release of prisoners have accrued sufficient merit to move the heavens. Through the True Warrior’s intercession, a memorial was presented to the North Culmen, which in turn memorialized the Jade Emperor. By special decree, the Heavenly Emperor personally conducted an investigation, and *Ketu* was pacified on behalf of the imperial house. It was determined that a person of the *yin* palace, aged twenty-nine and born in the year of the Boar, would die in the first ten days of the new year. To avert internal strife and spare the southern circuits from the death of one quarter of their military and civilian population, a tomb should be erected twenty-seven *li* due south to counter the Yellow Path. At that time, no mourning should be observed, for this person’s allotted lifespan has reached its end. I have been entrusted by the True Warrior to report this to the imperial house before returning to the Heavenly Gate.”

In the following year, on the third day of the first month, the Noble Consort Zhang passed away. The Noble Consort was twenty-nine years old, born on the nineteenth day of the first month at the hour of *hai*, her fate palace belonging to the Boar. On an auspicious day for the Yellow Path, a tomb was erected twenty-seven *li* due south. Thereafter, no further disasters occurred, and this fulfillment of the omen was attributed to the True Warrior’s descent and protection of the realm.

Grateful for this divine mercy and the reports from the gods—including General Ge of the Western Heavenly Gate—it was decreed that the relevant authorities should bestow upon all the abbeys and temples within the capital the task of holding three-day-and-night *luotian* grand jiao rites to repay the sagely grace.

**Grain and Wheat Descend from Heaven**

In the two circuits of Hebei, from Zhen Ding and its subordinate prefectures and counties, following the establishment of the *Jianlong* garrison, two years of drought had left not a single grain of rice, wheat, millet, or bean to harvest. Soldiers and civilians suffered from famine and pestilence, with many fleeing or perishing.

At that time, in Cizhou, during the seventh month, guards stationed at the four city gates reported to one another that merchants had arrived with carts, camels, and horses, transporting mats and sacks of grain and wheat, all claiming to seek temporary storage in the official granaries. The prefect dispatched officials to guide these travelers through each gate. Soon after, Captain Zhang Jing and others submitted an official report stating that at the four gates, two thousand sacks of grain and wheat had appeared, with no owner in sight. Local residents keeping watch all testified that those at the western gate had unloaded the mats, stacked them neatly, then led their carts and horses through the right gate of Chongming Abbey and vanished. At the other three gates, no one knew their whereabouts, though yellow paper horses were found tied to the corners of the sacks.

Prefect Chen Yong of Cizhou, along with Vice Prefect Mo Qianzhi, proceeded to Chongming Abbey at the western gate and assembled the Daoist clergy to inquire about the merchants’ names. The clergy replied: “The abbey’s gates are dilapidated; no carts or followers have entered here.” Yong and his party asked: “When was this abbey established, and how many halls does it contain?” They were told: “It dates back to the Former Tang, when the Heavenly Court’s Gan the Perfected was banished to the mortal realm. Here, he instructed the Qingti Daoist in cultivation. Later, as Gan the Perfected ascended in broad daylight and Qingti also departed, the site was granted abbey status. Within, there are four halls: the Hall of the Three Purities, the Hall of the Northern Culmen and Seven Primes, the Hall of Gan the Perfected, and the Hall of the True Warrior’s Divine Response. Apart from the Hall of the True Warrior—which receives offerings from soldiers and civilians on the days of his descent and is thus maintained—the rest have fallen into ruin.”

Yong then ordered soldiers to transport the sacks to the prefectural granary. The grain and wheat from the four gates totaled ten thousand *hu*. As the people of Cizhou were in dire need of relief, this unexpected bounty seemed to descend from heaven. Yet, unwilling to presume, they first memorialized the imperial court through the Central Secretariat.

Reports from over twenty prefectures in the same circuit, including Zhen Ding, also confirmed the arrival of grain and wheat, identical to that in Cizhou, though all claimed it had been transported from Cizhou. Compiling the figures from each prefecture, the total amounted to over one hundred fifty thousand *shi* of grain and wheat. The court promptly ordered all prefectures to sell the grain at low prices without delay. Upon investigation, the gold coins and paper horses presented as offerings were clearly the result of worldly incense-burning rituals, with the True Warrior’s descent marked by the paper horses. Thus, imperial physicians were dispatched with incense and prayer tablets to Cizhou, where they joined the prefect and vice prefect in conducting a vegetarian feast and jiao rites at Chongming Abbey. Furthermore, a Hall of the True Warrior’s Imperial Portrait was established within the palace to offer thanks. The Hebei Transport Commission was instructed to use the proceeds from the sale of the heavenly-descended grain to renovate all True Warrior abbeys and temples across the circuit’s prefectures and commanderies. Chongming Abbey was renamed the Sagely Aid and State-Protecting Abbey, with its Hall of the True Warrior rededicated as the Hall of Divine Response, inscribed with imperial calligraphy in gold. Within the palace, a family shrine for the True Warrior’s imperial portrait was also constructed, and the Hall of the Mysterious Capital of the Northern Guardian was bestowed as a mark of sagely favor.

**Tian Sheng’s Steamed Cakes**

At the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey atop Mount Zitong in Zizhou, the Western Jin Daoist Ye Hua cultivated the Dao. There, the Supreme Venerable Lord descended to instruct Prince Jinque of the King of Zhengle—later known as Master Jinque—who attained the Way. This Prince Jinque of Zhengle was none other than the True Warrior. Within the abbey stands the Hall of the Northern Culmen and Purple Tenuity, built by Ye Hua himself before his ascension to guide the True Warrior’s transformation.

In the first year of the *Huangyou* reign, Zizhou suffered from famine and pestilence, with seven or eight out of every ten people dead or dying. Suddenly, an old villager appeared, pushing a cart to sell steamed cakes. The locals rushed to buy them, and those who ate them felt no hunger all day.

The old villager continued his trade for over a month, seen only entering through the Gate of Good Gardens and departing by the same route. Zhang Sheng, Vice Minister of Personnel and Prefect of Zizhou, dispatched men to stealthily track his comings and goings. Upon their return, they reported seeing only a natural black mist descending near the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey before Mount Zitong. The next day, the old man no longer appeared. Instead, word spread that fifteen *li* outside the Gate of Good Gardens, beside the fields near the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey, *qici* had sprouted in abundance. Enough to feed all the starving people of the prefecture, the tubers sustained them for over sixty days until the new harvest of grain, millet, and beans reached the market. Then, the *qici* in the fields vanished without a trace.

Zhang Sheng prepared incense and silk offerings and personally visited the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey to pay homage. Entering the right wing of the Hall of the Northern Culmen, he found the ground strewn with green grass entwining the True Warrior’s hall. He ordered his attendants to gather the grass from beside the altar platform. Upon inspection, they discovered it was the roots and shoots of *qici*. When they sent for more, it transformed into flying paper ash, leaving only two freshly gathered tubers with their shoots intact. These he sealed in an incense casket, recording the full account before dispatching it to the capital.

By decree of the Chancellery, the memorial concerning the True Warrior’s miraculous *qici* that saved the people was returned with approval. It ordered the tubers to be enshrined in the Abbey of the Four Saints and instructed Zizhou to assemble Daoist priests at a prominent crossroads for a seven-day-and-night *Tiancao* grand jiao ritual and universal vegetarian feast. Additionally, a separate jiao offering was to be held at the True Warrior’s hall in the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey, which was also granted an inscribed plaque reading *"Rescue and Transformation, Salvation of the People."*

**Zheng’s Arrow Slays the Turtle**

In the second year of the *Tiansheng* reign, on the fourteenth day of the eighth month, the Yellow River’s dry-mouth dam at Beijing’s Daming Prefecture burst. The surging waters wreaked havoc, endangering soldiers and civilians alike. During the emergency repairs, the supervising officials—Vice Prefect Hua Dunchen and others—inspected the breach and found a massive black-shelled turtle with crimson eyes at the base of the dam’s rocky foundation. Whenever it surfaced, the currents raged, snapping the dam’s ropes. They reported the matter to the Capital Defense Command.

Later, when Chancellor Wei, Duke Han Qi, was stationed in Beijing, his attendant Zheng Gui was patrolling the area and encountered the turtle again, still causing trouble. Zheng Gui examined it and, recognizing it as a water demon, knew it could be easily vanquished. Donning his court robes and bow, he burned incense and prayed to the Heavenly Court. His arrow struck true, felling the turtle onto the rocks below, calming the waves. The soldiers swiftly completed the repairs.

On the third day of the first month of the third year of *Tiansheng*, Zheng Gui suddenly suffered a stroke and died in his quarters. Two days later, his soul revived and appeared before Duke Han, saying: "Two ghost messengers came for me, claiming King Yama urgently summoned Zheng Gui for wrongfully shooting the five-hundred-year-old turtle spirit of the Yellow River’s dry mouth. It has come to lodge a grievance and demands a confrontation." Upon checking the registers, they found Zheng Gui’s allotted lifespan was not yet exhausted, so the two ghosts escorted him away.

Passing a mountain, Zheng Gui saw a banner planted below and a bustling procession. He asked, "What place is this?" The ghost soldiers replied, "This is the Wind-Ravaged Mountain of the lower realm, where celestial perfected ones often come to review the affairs of the Three Realms." Gazing into the distance, Zheng Gui saw a figure seated on a rock—it was the True Warrior, revered in the mortal world. Zheng Gui hurried forward and bowed, and the True Warrior descended, saying, "How has a mortal like you come here?" The ghost messengers recounted the events.

The True Warrior said, "King Yama acted hastily, failing to discern the truth. That turtle was originally the earth god of Yuanzhou in the Dream Cloud City of the Western Qiang. When the imperial master Chen Zhongyuan conquered Yuanzhou in a previous dynasty, the city god was demoted by decree and reassigned to the Yellow River’s fourth dry-sand water deity, under the jurisdiction of Zhuozhou in the Northern Qiang. With no offerings there, it transformed into a demonic turtle and followed the current upstream to the seventh dry mouth of the Yellow River in the Song territory at Beijing. There, it breached the dam, harming over ten thousand soldiers and civilians. Heaven’s Way does not tolerate such deeds, so it was rightfully slain by Zheng Gui’s arrow. Moreover, the Earth Prison acted without celestial mandate. Have the talisman officer bring the small turtle from my presence, along with Zheng Gui and the two ghost soldiers, to confront King Yama. If the ghost demon disputes this, let the talisman officer release the small turtle. Then report to the Earth Prison: Zheng Gui’s lifespan is not yet over, and his master, Chancellor Han Qi, is a Perfected One of the Purple Palace currently governing Beijing. His future ascension would be inconvenient."

After speaking, the True Warrior dismissed Zheng Gui, who followed the talisman officer and ghost messengers to the netherworld. There, he saw the great turtle caged in iron, an arrow lodged in its left flank, groaning in grievance. The two ghost messengers relayed the True Warrior’s decree. Upon hearing this, King Yama descended from his throne and bowed to the heavens. He immediately ordered the celestial mandate reviewed, verifying the false accusations and the turtle’s crimes. The turtle was condemned to be cast into the rivers and seas, to serve as a tide-pushing, sand-shifting creature—a nameless water beast and formless hungry ghost. The demonic turtle still spoke, demanding a confrontation with Zheng Gui. The talisman officer drew the small turtle from his sleeve, releasing a golden light that struck the demonic turtle, reducing it to a motionless mass. The sacred turtle then scattered its remains into the void, turning them to dust. Zheng Gui thus revived.

To avoid the title of "Perfected One of the Purple Palace," Duke Han had the military commissioner Wang Cong, Vice Prefect Hua Dunchen, and others jointly submit a memorial. A subsequent imperial decree ordered the construction of the Protector-State True Warrior Hall at the Yellow River’s dam breach in Beijing, where a jiao ritual was held and a stele erected.

Zheng Gui was promoted one rank, and Duke Han was granted the honor of having his name inscribed on the hall plaque, with permission to stay at any official lodging along his travels.

**Pei the Sword-Wielder Drives Away Tigers**
In the Heng Mountains of Fenzhou, during the Jiayou era, a tiger suddenly appeared, preying on travelers at dawn and dusk. Whenever officials or hunters attempted to capture it, the beast would multiply into five or seven, resisting them in turn. As this was a vital route from Hedong to the capital, the harm grew severe. When Yang Zongdao, the newly appointed magistrate of Sanshui County, passed through Heng Mountain with his family en route to his post, one of his daughters was devoured. The prefectural and circuit authorities dispatched local patrol officers to guard the roads, increased the bounty for its capture, and called for hunters to slay the beast. At that time, a wandering Daoist named Pei arrived, claiming he could subdue the tiger. The prefecture granted his request, and after seven days, he returned, declaring that the tiger was no true beast but the vengeful spirits of seven members of the Zhang Yi household—a noble family of Zhao during the Han—massacred by Chu soldiers on this mountain. Woodcutters had once discovered their corpses, failing to recognize them, and buried them together behind the mountain’s spirit shrine in a secluded spot where no one trod. Thus, they became spectral beings. On a day of celestial amnesty, they had consumed dew from the Jade Pool of the Jasper Lake, transforming into ferocious tigers that craved human flesh and blood.

When the Daoist requested the prefectural officials to witness his exorcism, Prefect Li Xiangyun and Vice Censor Shao Tang, along with soldiers, proceeded to the slopes of Heng Mountain. The Daoist ventured alone into the wilderness. Suddenly, the sky darkened, and windswept mist rose. Through the clouds, Pei the Daoist appeared, hair unbound and sword in hand, calling out: "Li Xiangyun and the others, do not fear. I have already driven out the seven demonic tigers." The officials prostrated themselves, recognizing him as the True Warrior (Zhenwu), who had once descended into the Pei household during the reign of Empress Wu of Tang, leaving behind this surname. The seven tigers, as if bound by ropes, coiled on the ground, roaring several times before perishing. Then, seven figures appeared in the air, bowing and leaping to address the officials: "We are the Zhang Yi household of the Han, slaughtered by Chu soldiers and long transformed into malevolent beasts, harming countless lives. We deserved annihilation. Now, by the grace of the True Warrior, our sins of devouring lives as tigers have been absolved by celestial pardon. We leave these tiger pelts as offerings to the officials. By imperial mercy, we have been dispatched to the Eastern Peak to await judgment and rebirth." With that, Pei the Daoist vanished into the clouds.

The hunters were ordered to skin the tigers and present the pelts to the authorities. The Fenzhou prefectural and circuit offices memorialized the throne, and by imperial decree from the Chancellery, a True Warrior shrine was established on Heng Mountain. Three Daoist priests were selected to maintain the rites, with the prefecture providing monthly stipends of money and grain to ensure the site’s perpetual guardianship and unbroken incense offerings. A stele was also erected to record the event.

**Testing Magic Before the Court**
During the reign of Empress Wu of Tang, He Quanlong, the Palace Attendant and Military Observer of Nan’an, trained five hundred young boys in the heretical arts of the Fox Woman, claiming they were possessed by the Seven Celestial Spirits of the North and could be commanded at will. He repeatedly demonstrated their powers before the court, summoning clouds, hail, and gales through their incantations. Empress Wu favored him, and many officials fell from grace due to his slanderous accusations.

When the Western Rong tribes rebelled under Zhao Hong’s leadership, their armies clashed with imperial forces. Dark clouds would gather above the battlefield, unleashing fire and lightning, or manifesting dragons, tigers, and grotesque apparitions to scatter the troops. Officials petitioned Empress Wu to employ the celestial arts of the Heavenly Principle School to counter Zhao Hong. She granted He Quanlong a seal of command and dispatched him with two thousand soldiers. However, in the ensuing battle, all two thousand imperial troops and five hundred of He’s sorcerer-boys were wounded, many maimed.

He Quanlong returned to plead for clemency, which the Empress granted. Soon after, Zhao Hong’s forces advanced further. Deeply troubled, Empress Wu was approached by the Vice Director of the Chancellery, Pei Tao, who petitioned: "Your subject has a son, Zhongfang, aged sixteen. Since the age of three, he has spoken in perfect prose, and at nine, he was visited by a celestial being who taught him archery and horsemanship. I humbly offer my entire household as surety and request to lead five hundred foot soldiers to exterminate the rebel Zhao Hong." The Empress interrogated Zhongfang, then appointed him as a Sacrificial Official of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices and temporarily granted him the rank of Gentleman of the Palace Treasury. She entrusted him with command of the troops.

Zhongfang marched directly to Zhao Hong’s encampment. With a mere flash of his sword, he quelled thousands of enemy soldiers and captured Zhao Hong alive. Without slaughtering a single soul, he brought the rebel leader back to the capital and reported: "Zhao Hong’s demonic defenses have been broken by a minor display of my arts. The culprit now stands before Your Majesty."

Empress Wu dismissed her attendants and addressed Zhongfang: "It is revealed that you are the Northern Dipper’s True Warrior, incarnated in mortal form to manifest your divinity. I wonder, how effective were the Seven Celestial Arts employed by He Quanlong before the court?" Zhongfang replied: "He Quanlong trained his boys in the heterodox Fox Woman sorcery, inscribing their soles with vermilion talismans to enable them to ascend clouds and summon hail. Yet his powers pale beside Zhao Hong’s. His favor with the throne has led to the unjust demotion of loyal ministers. If left unchecked, this will fester into outright treason. I propose that He Quanlong and I demonstrate our arts before the court to dispel Your Majesty’s doubts."

The Empress promptly ordered He Quanlong and Pei Zhongfang to perform their magic on the palace steps. He Quanlong commanded his five hundred sorcerer-boys to charge forward in a frenzied display, leaving the assembled civil and military officials in awe.

Then Zhongfang sprayed a mist of pure water, and the five hundred sorcerer-boys vanished from the air, all drawn into the scabbard at his side. Quanlong, left helpless, cried out before the throne: "Spare me, that I may draw one last breath!" The Empress swiftly rose to burn incense and said to Zhongfang: "Out of consideration for Quanlong’s favor with the Queen Mother, spare his life." Zhongfang thereupon released He Quanlong, but the five hundred sorcerer-boys, trapped within the scabbard, were consumed by true fire and reduced to ashes. Zhongfang memorialized the throne, requesting that all officials previously demoted or punished be restored to their posts. He was specially appointed General of Divine Response, and those such as Zhao Hong whom he had captured were also petitioned for release and sent back to the Western Regions.

**Suppressing Sorcery in the Prefecture**
In the fourth year of Taiping Xingguo, Shi Guangsi, Military Commissioner of Wu’an and Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs, was transferred to Hongzhou. Having heard that the region was rife with heterodox arts and sorcery, which persisted despite repeated prohibitions, he learned of a master of the precepts and pure discipline at Xiadao Mountain’s Ancestral Sage Abbey. He invited Master Ling Jumiao of Luofu Grotto to consult on the matter and discovered that the worshippers along the Hong, Heng, Tan, Ding, and E river basins all venerated southern spirits. Officials were dispatched to arrest 116 practitioners of left-handed sorcery, including Ma Yongcheng, who were brought before the assembly for interrogation. Ma Yongcheng pleaded in his defense that he had not originally studied left-handed arts, but because the lands of Jiangnan, Jinghu, and the surrounding waters were plagued by the seventy-two seasonal spirits that harmed souls, spread febrile epidemics, and obstructed all undertakings, he had resorted to left-handed arts—performing rituals of blades, oil, fire, and *vajra* rites—to suppress the afflictions, which brought slight relief. Guangsi ordered that all implements—blades, staffs, oil cauldrons, and fire-woks—be confiscated and destroyed, and the offenders were reprimanded and released after submitting written confessions.

By the seventh month of that year, Hongzhou was indeed struck by a soul-harming calamity. The populace suffered from raging fevers, consuming shards of tile and porcelain, or climbing to hang from roof beams, clinging to trees, or plunging into water and ditches, all while uttering foul words. Guangsi summoned Master Ling Jumiao, who distributed talismanic water to heal the afflicted, and the suffering gradually abated. Fearing future outbreaks, he had over ten thousand plaques inscribed with the sacred title of Zhenwu, the Numinous and Responsive, and distributed them for veneration. On the days of the deity’s monthly descent, the *Mysterious Scripture of Zhenwu* was recited. Over time, the disaster was entirely eradicated, and the people turned from heresy to the true Way.

Stone Guangsi memorialized: "In Hongzhou, though Daoist temples and abbeys existed before the Southern Tang, no halls or incense offerings had yet been dedicated to Zhenwu. The Three Departments and the Ministry of Rites deliberated and determined that Hongzhou should be instructed to construct a proper hall at the former site of the Zhenwu shrine within Tianqing Abbey. The throne was further petitioned to bestow an imperial inscription for the hall’s plaque, to be titled *Protecting the State and Evoking Response*."

Later, Guangsi journeyed to Xiadao Mountain to pay homage to Master Ling Jumiao, receiving the ritual forms of Zhenwu’s Way. He then sought retirement from office and returned to his estate in Zhaozhou, where he lived in seclusion, far from worldly dust, reverently maintaining the incense offerings to the True Sage. He lived to ninety-nine years, passing without illness.

**The Bewitchment of Chai M

To this day, she would arrive at the second watch of the night and depart at the fifth. She wore upon her robe a fragrant pouch, its surface shimmering. When brought forth for examination, it proved to be no ordinary object, and the family kept it. Later, they returned to the Hall of King Liang Zhao at Shengshui Abbey, where upon the wall they found the painted figure of the flute-playing maiden—her beauty unmatched—with one corner of the railing smudged and the colors faded. When the fragrant pouch was held against it, the seams aligned perfectly.

Chai Xun laid out the circumstances in full, submitting his case through the Drum of Direct Appeal. It passed through the Secretariat and reached the imperial ear. By imperial decree, the matter was referred to the Kaifeng Prefecture for action. The prefectural authorities dispatched an official document to Shengshui Abbey, ordering the local earth god to burn the pouch and expel the malevolent spirit, yet the affliction persisted. Another petition was made, and the Daoist Registrar Qian Junping was summoned. He prepared talismans and ritual documents, along with paper money and horses of gold foil. Together with Bao Zheng, Academician of the Dragon Diagram Pavilion and Prefect of Kaifeng, they journeyed to Shengshui Abbey. There, they prayed to Zhenwu and burned the talismans and documents toward the north.

That very night, no laughter or voices were heard in Chai Miao’s chamber. Half a month later, at Shengshui Abbey, every night at the second watch, sounds of flogging and interrogation—like those of a prison—echoed from the western corner, along with the cries of a woman. Suddenly, one night, she wailed outside Chai Xun’s gate, calling out to Chai Miao: *"You have ruined me! Because Zhenwu accepted your complaint, I was seized and interrogated. Sent to the earth god of the capital, I endured half a month of brutal torture, suffering endless agony. Now, by Zhenwu’s mercy, I am spared the punishment of the iron rod and banished to Mount Yin, to serve as an innocent female ghost for three hundred kalpas before returning to the world of the living to be reborn among the spirits. I have come to tell you this."*

From then on, Chai Miao recovered. Prefect Bao Zheng reported the matter in full and presented it to the throne. Chai Miao was summoned and, upon audience, petitioned: *"I humbly request an assignment to accumulate my salary and hold a grand *luotian* ritual, offering it to the Supreme Divinity in repayment."* The emperor approved, granting the Jade Ford Garden for the construction of a ritual altar and the holding of a grand vegetarian feast to give thanks for Zhenwu’s protection of the state and salvation of the people.

**The Bewitchment of Anren**
Sun Jian, Observator of Fuzhou, had a son named Anren, aged seventeen. Granted the title of *Sanban Jiezhi* and appointed Tax Supervisor and Patrol Inspector of Longmen Town in Fengzhou, he took up his post. After half a year, his spirit waned, his speech became erratic, and his duties neglected, leading the prefecture to dispatch an official to replace him. Seeking medical treatment at home, his condition did not improve.

One night, Sun Jian heard women’s laughter and conversation in Anren’s chamber and realized he was bewitched by a malevolent spirit. The next morning, he pressed his son for answers, who at last confessed: *"The earth goddess Xianghua of Mount Hou in Longmen Town has been entangling me. She comes every night at the third watch and remains until sunrise, when she vanishes like dust."*

Sun Jian presented the matter at court. By imperial decree, a master of the Hanlin Academy’s Exorcism Bureau was dispatched to perform rituals, but after half a month, the spirit remained. Another memorial was submitted, and the matter was referred to the chief ministers. They deliberated that Sun Jian’s household had not properly worshipped the protective deities of the home, allowing a mountain spirit from another region to bring misfortune. He was advised to hasten to a Daoist abbey and earnestly beseech Zhenwu for protection.

Following the imperial suggestion, Sun Jian personally wrote a petition and journeyed to the Abbey of the Four Saints, where he made a vow and borrowed a sacred portrait of Zhenwu to enshrine at home. On the seventh night, as the first watch began, sounds of weeping were heard from Anren’s chamber. By dawn, Anren awoke as if from a deep intoxication, his speech no longer erratic.

Anren recounted: *"Upon arriving at my post in Longmen, I was patrolling the horse stations and spent a night at the post station on Mount Hou. At the third watch, I suddenly saw lanterns glowing before the outer woods. Before my tent appeared a beautiful woman, her attire and manner unlike any mortal. Lowering her sleeves, she spoke softly: ‘I am no ghost or demon—do not fear. Our bond was fated long ago, and here we were destined to meet. I am the daughter of the Dragon Lord of Xiangpu, but for my longing for the mortal world, the Eastern Peak demoted me to serve as the earth goddess of this mountain. People call me the Xianghua Goddess, for I possess the essence of a half-immortal. How could I bear to part from you?’

‘Now, because your parents have invited Zhenwu to descend upon your home, countless celestial soldiers and day-patrolling spirits have surrounded the house to search for me. If I am seized, I will be beaten with iron rods and condemned to the lowest ranks of ghosts, forever barred from the mortal world. Thus, I must take my leave and return to Mount Hou.’ With tears, she took a small jade comb from her hair and gave it to me, saying, ‘Hide this in your hair. When we meet again, it will serve as proof.’"*

When examined, the comb was no ordinary object. It was presented to the throne and placed in the Divine Instruments Bureau of the Inner Treasury. Sun Jian further petitioned to hold a grand *luotian* ritual and a grand vegetarian feast at the Abbey of the Four Saints to repay the debt of gratitude. The chief ministers said to him: *"At first, we did not believe, but now the truth is manifest. Truly, households that worship Zhenwu receive responses beyond all imagining."*

**The False Accusation of Lu Chuan**
Pei Zongyuan, Gentleman for Court Service and Vice Director of the Ministry of Merit, was dispatched as Judicial Commissioner of Guangdong. While passing through Mount Hualan in Shaozhou, he fell ill as if afflicted by a miasma. He could not sleep at night, and his speech became disordered. Despite medical treatment, the cause of his illness remained unknown.

An official remarked: *"I have heard that when Your Excellency arrived at Mount Hualan, it was known that this place is haunted by the lingering souls of those who died unjustly, their spirits bound to this mountain. The Fivefold Dao Magistrate of Iron Wind Cave oversees them in great numbers..."*

There was, however, a divine practitioner named Du Guli from the city below, skilled in ritual and healing. He was summoned without delay. No sooner had Du Guli entered the second gate of the Judicial Commissioner’s office than he declared: *“I see an official in green robes, his face twisted with grievance and injustice, clinging to the Commissioner’s life.”*

The assembled officials asked: *“What deity is this?”*

Du Guli explained: *“I was once a scholar, but the True Lord Zhenwu, taking pity on my humble station and my devotion to the Dao, transformed me into a wandering physician. He anointed my eyes with medicine and bestowed upon me a scroll of exorcistic arts. Since then, my remedies have never failed to heal. I set up an altar with fragrant flowers, pure water, and incense to honor Zhenwu, establishing a ritual precinct. I used a bolt of yellow silk twelve feet long, inscribed with cinnabar the talismans of Shangqing, and burned them facing north while reciting invocations. I arranged ritual swords, hung the talismans of the Five Directions and the Six Ding spirits, girded myself with the sash of the altar’s straightway, and prepared forty-nine earthen vessels and forty-nine lamps. I consecrated the brush and ink of the Judicial Commissioner’s scribe, recited the *Willow Sprig* and *Pure Water* incantations, and invoked Zhenwu to descend in spirit. I commanded the attendant talisman-spirits to bear my petition upward and report to Heaven.”*

Once the ritual was complete, he instructed the Commissioner’s household: *“If Zhenwu descends, do not be alarmed.”*

On the third invocation, the deity suddenly manifested. From within, a maidservant was seized and brought before Zhenwu’s altar. Through her, the spirit spoke: *“I am Lu Fu, Judicial Officer of Dezhou. Commissioner Pei Zongyuan was once the Prefectural Judge of my district. Due to a feud with my late father, the Assistant Minister, he conspired with his subordinates to exact vengeance. Under false pretenses, they accused me of administering improper medicine on an imperial mourning day, imprisoned me, and tortured me without cause until I confessed to treason. I died under duress, my grievance unredressed. As my allotted lifespan was not yet spent, I was consigned to Iron Wind Cave on Mount Hualan for custody. I had no means to plead my case—until Pei Zongyuan passed through this mountain and encountered my wronged soul, which has clung to him ever since. Only because his fortune and lifespan remain vigorous have I not yet taken his life. Now that Zhenwu, the Fortune God, has descended to your residence to expel this malevolent affliction, I beg you to take pity on my unjust death. Do not send me back to Iron Wind Cave. Let me be cleansed with ritual water and receive Zhenwu’s decree. I shall face east and pay homage to my original master, the Most High Lord Lao, the Celestial Master of the Golden Portal. Thereafter, I shall be reborn into a prosperous family as a son, and I shall also serve in office. A talisman-spirit will be dispatched to Iron Wind Cave on Mount Hualan to strike my name from the register of wrongful dead, so that no further confrontations may occur.”*

The moment the maidservant was released, Pei Zongyuan immediately recovered. He then took gold, silver, and other valuables from his household and traveled to Tianqing Abbey in Guangzhou, where he sponsored seven days and nights of repentance rites and thanksgiving offerings. He also provided for the abbey’s Daoist priests and rewarded Du Guli. A memorial was submitted to the throne, and an imperial edict soon followed, appointing Du Guli as Assistant Instructor of his home prefecture. Pei Zongyuan, from that time forward, maintained the worship of Zhenwu without fail for the rest of his life.

Wang Hu fell into the scheme.

The Court Gentleman for Summons, Bureau Director of the Ministry of War, and concurrently Military Commissioner of Dizhou, Qian Tingnian, respectfully submits: The Judicial Commissioner of Dizhou, Bureau Director of the Bureau of Operations, Yao Zi, has frequently been on leave due to illness, and at times, he falls into madness. When he quarrels with others, blood flows from his nose and mouth, and he cannot sleep day or night. Upon recovering and being questioned, he claims to have no recollection, only that he felt as though he were bound and seized in the wilds, with someone holding power over his life. This has persisted for three years, and no physician has been able to cure him. Later, when the Transport Commissioner Chen Yuan spoke of the Daoist priest Song Zhicai of the Five Marchmounts Abbey in the Eastern Capital, who treats such afflictions with talismanic water and incantations, Song Zhicai—currently serving as Daoist Registrar of the Right Street—was summoned to the palace for an audience. As he could not be privately requested, the matter of Yao Zi’s condition was duly recorded and submitted to the throne. By imperial grace, Song Zhicai the Dharma Master was dispatched to Yao Zi’s residence in Dizhou. There, an incense altar was set up within the household. First, a talismanic memorial was burned, and a spirit-officer was dispatched with a treasure-talisman to enter the Heavenly Gate and report to Zhenwu, beseeching the granting of divine radiance to descend upon the place of prayer. Then, the brought-along portrait of Zhenwu was displayed, and ritual implements for the water-contesting rite were arranged as offerings. It was the fifth day of the fifth month, and incense was burned in vigil, awaiting Zhenwu’s descent. A scribe was ordered to stand by with paper and brush, ready to transcribe the deity’s words as they were spoken.

At approximately the hour of *you* (5–7 p.m.), Yao Zi was seen with disheveled hair, bursting from his bedchamber with a great cry and rushing out. He knelt beneath the incense altar and transmitted in a spirit-possessed voice:

"I am Wang Hu, formerly Registrar of Tongcheng County in Shuzhou. In the early years of the Qingli reign, Yao Zi served as Magistrate of Taihu. While on official duty, we were both dispatched to Dayun Granary to supervise the weighing of tribute grain. Yao Zi, however, was solely responsible for overseeing the silver and gold. He colluded to falsify the records, shortchanging the official tally of wheat by eighty *shi*. At the time, unaware of his scheme, I merely followed procedure, countersigning the vermilion registers and submitting them to the prefectural and transport authorities.

Later, Yao Zi learned the matter had been exposed. He sent a messenger from Taihu bearing a letter and gifts—six black-lacquered, gilt-iron *chong* vessels. When I asked for the letter, the messenger claimed it had been ruined by waves while crossing the river. Upon inspecting the gifts, I saw they were indeed water-damaged and salt-encrusted. The letter was soaked beyond legibility. The messenger pleaded for me to keep the vessels temporarily while he hurried back to Taihu to fetch a replacement, promising to return with a reply. Unsuspecting, I agreed.

Afterward, no replacement messenger arrived. Suddenly, the Shouzhou Investigation Bureau issued a summons, and I was arrested, imprisoned, and interrogated alongside Yao Zi. We were both charged with colluding to embezzle gold and silver from Dayun Granary. Officials then went to my home and retrieved the six *chong* vessels Yao Zi had sent. After washing and examining them, they found one to be gold and five silver.

Only then did I realize I had been ensnared by Yao Zi’s scheme. With no means to defend myself, I was overwhelmed by rage, which struck my heart. I died in obscurity, and Yao Zi shifted the blame entirely onto me, escaping punishment in the mortal realm. They claimed I had died, leaving no evidence. Yet in the registers of the Eastern Peak’s netherworld, my lifespan was unmarked—I had died wrongfully and was not fated to be taken. Thus, I remained bound in the dusty kalpa, with no way to escape.

Three years ago, I encountered my enemy Yao Zi on the banks of the river in Shuzhou. We have been entangled ever since, and I demanded he accompany me to the Eastern Peak to confront the matter. Fortunately, Zhenwu has descended today. I have received his decree, which will liberate my wronged soul and sever my ties with Yao Zi. By his grace, I am granted documentary proof to register my rebirth in the netherworld. From now on, there will be no further disputes."

After a long while, Yao Zi regained consciousness. Yan Nian and others reported the matter to the throne. Yao Zi was subsequently dismissed from office and returned to Huzhou, where he donated two thousand strings of cash to Shuzhou’s Lingxian Abbey to expand the Zhenwu Pavilion.

**Chen’s Wife Attaches Her Spirit**
On the twenty-first day of the sixth month in the second year of the Chunhua reign, Qin Zhongli, a Court Gentleman for Ceremonial Service and Gatekeeper of the Watch, was dispatched to oversee military equipment in the Qin-Feng Circuit. Zhongli had served Zhenwu faithfully all his life, maintaining morning and evening incense offerings without fail.

Upon receiving his commission, he carried with him a silk scroll painting of Zhenwu. Arriving in Jingzhao Prefecture, he paid his respects to the prefect, Chen Yan, who said:

"I have a son, Jingren, now twenty-four years old. He was married to a woman of the Zhang clan, but after just one year, she died of consumption. Jingren contracted the same illness. At times, he seems deranged—laughing or weeping, singing or muttering to himself. Occasionally, he claims his wife is with him in the chamber, their voices mingling with ghostly wails and spectral speech, accompanied by eerie knocks and crashes. We have sought physicians and exorcists, but to no avail."

Zhongli replied, "For now, return to the post station. I shall purify my heart, and come to examine the case tomorrow morning."

That night, Zhongli took lodging at the post station. He lit incense and hung the silk scroll painting of Zhenwu he had brought with him, first offering sincere prayers. At dawn the next day, Zhongli personally carried the scroll, hastening on foot to the prefectural hall. He set up the painting of Zhenwu before Jingren’s chamber, arranging pure offerings, and instructed Prefect Chen and his entire household to devoutly hold incense and pray. Then, Zhongli entered the room with an incense burner in hand to observe Jingren. He asked about Jingren’s birth year and month, the duration of his illness, and recorded the details in a memorial. That same day, before the image of Zhenwu, he burned talismans, spirit-money, and paper horses as an offering.

On the fourth day, while Zhongli was in his quarters, at the fourth watch of the night, he heard someone knocking at the door. A voice said: "I am Niannu, the granddaughter of the late Vice Minister Zhang Sheng of the capital. I married Chen Jingren, but before a year had passed, I contracted consumption and grew gravely ill. The physician mistook my condition for blood stasis and prescribed the wrong medicine, which wrongfully took my life. Thus, my lonely soul remained ungathered, drifting in the mortal realm—day and night bearing this grievance. Three months ago, Jingren went hunting outside the city, and I was able to attach my spirit to his body, sparing myself from wandering the wilds and being driven away by the local earth deities. Now, with the arrival of Your Honor bearing Zhenwu into this residence and setting up offerings before Jingren’s chamber, I have been pressed by the divine might and have no place to hide. By the mercy and virtue of Zhenwu, his envoys seized my soul and brought me before the august deity. Moved by my grievance, he granted me willow-branch purifying water to cleanse my spirit and bestowed a prophecy, absolving my karmic debt so that I need not pass through the courts of the underworld. Now, I am to be reborn in the household of Marshal Luo Zongfu, once more as a woman. I have come to express my gratitude before departing."

Zhongli recorded every word and went to inform Prefect Chen. Jingren had already recovered as if nothing had ever ailed him. Chen, deeply moved, submitted a memorial detailing the events. He willingly relinquished three ranks of his official position, and both he and his son Jingren were granted imperial grace to retain their titles. Chen further recommended Zhongli for promotion, who was then appointed East Upper Gate Attendant and Defense Commissioner of Xiongzhou. Jingren, originally appointed as an attendant of the Imperial Ancestral Temple, was not demoted. Chen donated five thousand strings of cash to construct the Hall of Zhenwu’s Manifest Merit within the Supreme Clarity Purple Ultimate Palace. He petitioned for an inscribed plaque, and by imperial decree, it was bestowed the name "Hall of Universal Compassion and Divine Response."

**The Ghostly Fetus of the Wang Clan**

Wang Yaonian, Gold Department Staff Supervisor of Shuzhou, had a daughter aged thirty-one who had carried a ghostly fetus for two years. Despite seeking physicians, none could cure her. Not only were her parents deeply worried, but the daughter herself was constantly distressed, even attempting to hang herself in the rear garden. Suddenly, she heard a voice from the air calling out: "Do not recklessly cast away your life. This is your five-hundred-year-old karmic debt. Why not appeal to the household deity?"

The girl looked around, but saw no one. Returning home, she told her mother. The so-called household deity was Zhenwu, though the family had no sacred image of him. They then invited Master Chen Juxun, a Daoist priest from the Lingxian Abbey, to set up a ritual altar in their home. He dispatched talismanic envoys to the celestial courts, beseeching divine descent to absolve Wang’s past karma and relieve her of the ghostly fetus. The entire household waited devoutly for the priest’s response.

On the twenty-first day of the tenth month, at noon, a red glow the size of a rice bowl suddenly filled the house, swirling before the altar. It descended upon the daughter, who spoke: "In a past life, I sold poison to an old medicine woman, who used it to induce abortions. Among those harmed was a noble life, which I destroyed, leaving it with no hope of rebirth. For this sin, I was condemned to be endlessly reborn as a venomous serpent. This lifetime, you encountered this vengeful spirit in your womb, which fed on your blood and flesh, swelling your chest and threatening your life. When you sought death in the rear garden, you encountered my retinue. Now, moved by your family’s devotion, I have descended. I shall permanently remove this grievance, and there will be no further reckoning. Tonight, at the first quarter of the second watch, set out forty-nine lamps in a circle on the ground before the outer grove. Offer fine incense, purifying water, spirit-money, and paper horses as substitutes for your body. At the end of the fourth watch, call out your childhood name, birth year, month, day, and hour, and burn the substitute gold paper for the vengeful spirit of your past life. The fetus will naturally dissipate within days."

Master Chen bowed in gratitude. The red glow gradually dispersed, signaling Zhenwu’s departure. Yaonian burned memorial papers and drew up a vow: once his daughter’s affliction was resolved, he would donate their residence and rear garden to serve as a palace for Zhenwu’s divine descents. Indeed, his daughter’s condition improved within the promised time.

Word spread of how Wang’s daughter had been saved by Zhenwu, and it was said her destiny was now noble. Yaonian was appointed Vice Prefect of Xiangzhou and moved to a new residence. Soon after, Prefect Xie Fangping of Shuzhou, seeking a match for his second son Jingxiang, formally betrothed him to Wang’s daughter.

Yaonian then converted the donated house and garden into a temple complex. Coordinating with local officials and the provincial surveillance commission, he petitioned the court for an inscribed plaque. The Secretariat’s response instructed that as Yaonian’s personal donation was insufficient to complete the project, an imperial decree was issued to construct the Three Pure Ones’ Precious Hall and the Northern Culmen’s Seven Primes Hall. The temple was bestowed the name "Temple of Divine Mercy and Salvation."
