*Records of the Divine Manifestations of the Dark Heavenly Emperor, Volume Six*

In the second year of the Zhihe era, Emperor Renzong fell gravely ill. According to the Ministry of Rites’ verification, the memorial submitted by Master Wang Bochu of Songyang Abbey on Mount Song was to be presented to the Northern Culmen. To ascertain the emperor’s lifespan, the petition had to be offered on a *gengshen* day, with the emperor personally inscribing the memorial. That night at the hour of *xu*, the emperor knelt in earnest supplication beneath the stars. The following morning, Bochu would surely know the details of the memorial.

On the appointed *gengshen* day, the emperor ordered palace attendants to prepare paper and brush, transcribing the petition on his behalf. At the hour of *xu*, it was burned under the open sky. The next morning, when Bochu was summoned, he reported: "Last night, no memorial reached the celestial realm. I fear the emperor did not inscribe it himself, and the petition lacked devotion, thus failing to reach the heavenly court." The emperor then redoubled his sincerity, personally inscribing the memorial and burning it that night in solemn prayer.

The next morning, Bochu was summoned and immediately offered congratulations: "I witnessed the memorial from last night, delivered to the court of the Great Emperor of the Northern Culmen in the Central Heaven. Upon review, it was sent to the Divine Protector Zhenwu’s abbey for verification. After seven days, the outcome will be confirmed." Bochu personally saw the memorial—seven sheets in all—and recited it silently from memory, finding not a single discrepancy. The emperor rejoiced.

Seven days later, Bochu again appeared, dismissing all attendants to report: "Just now, at the Oxherd and Weaver constellation, I encountered the imperial procession. The Divine Protector Zhenwu has graciously extended Your Majesty’s lifespan by one *ji* (twelve years). Upon returning to the Western Gate of Heaven, I saw General Ge stretching his arms, reminding Your Majesty not to forget his merit."

Once the emperor’s health was restored, Wang Bochu was appointed Supervisor of the Two Streets in the capital, abbot of the Five Marchmounts Abbey, and bestowed the title "Purple-robed Master of the Divine Dharma of the Qianyuan Grotto." The emperor, deeply moved by Zhenwu’s manifest grace, ordered the supervising officials to swiftly renovate the ancestral halls and pavilions within the palace. He further instructed the Ministry of Rites to compile and disseminate records of Zhenwu’s protective interventions. In gratitude for the extension of his lifespan and General Ge’s intercession, a Hall of Repaying Grace was erected beside the Zhenwu Hall, where incense and prayers were offered.

**Relieving Disasters Through Scripture Distribution**
In the Southern Capital’s Yingtian Prefecture stood the Supreme Clarity Hongfu Abbey, originally established by Emperor Taizu to honor the first merit of heaven’s favor. During the Dazhong Xiangfu era, Emperor Zhenzong, while on a ritual progress, lodged there and witnessed the nocturnal descent of the Northern Zhenwu, who declared himself the emperor’s guardian. Zhenzong later bestowed upon the abbey a golden statue of Zhenwu and an inscribed plaque in his own calligraphy.

In the winter of the Zhihe era, as plague ravaged the military and populace, a ritual was held at Hongfu Abbey, yet no response was felt, causing widespread unease. One night, Zhenwu appeared in a dream to the abbot, Daoist Ren Kangzhi, saying: "I have observed the winter plague in the Southern Capital. Print and distribute the *Sutra of the Supreme’s Exalted Teachings on Zhenwu* to afflicted households, instructing them to venerate and recite it." Ren Kangzhi complied, and the sick recovered.

Coincidentally, the court was then mobilizing troops for a southern campaign, yet no soldiers were lacking. Shen Li, the capital’s Military Commissioner and Remonstrance Grand Master, memorialized the throne. The Secretariat reviewed the matter, noting that Hongfu Abbey’s Zhenwu Hall was built in response to a prior divine manifestation. Now, the winter plague’s resolution—through the dream-inspired distribution of scriptures—had averted a major disaster and supported the southern campaign. The emperor thus granted the abbey a three-year exemption of taxes and bestowed upon Daoist Ren Kangzhi the privilege of overseeing its incense and attendants. The Southern Capital’s inspector was further charged with repairing any damage to the abbey’s halls. Such was the efficacy of divine power.

Chen Gongchen, Judicial Officer of Huaiyang Commandery, had in his youth acquired a tortoise. Its shell was a lustrous green, overlaid with golden-green down, its eyes crimson, its tail long—about the size of a small cup. He kept it for five or seven years, and by the time he passed the imperial examinations, the tortoise had grown to the size of a basin. It favored jujubes and was kept in a bamboo basket. One bright moonlit night, a family member playfully lifted the tortoise, only for it to shrink its body into its shell, now no larger than a bowl, while a small crimson-spotted snake coiled around it in play. Chen pondered: the tortoise and snake were the celestial gate and earthly pivot, emblems of the True Martial Fortune Deity. The next day, the tortoise had resumed its former size, the snake nowhere to be seen. This occurred for several nights. Chen then commissioned an artisan to cast an image of the True Martial Sage, set a large vat of pure water, and placed the tortoise within as an offering.

Later, while overseeing the construction of earthen walls in Xinyang, Chen commanded two thousand laborers. During a winter of rain and snow, more than half the workers fell ill and collapsed. One day, Chen drifted into a dreamlike reverie and saw his tortoise address him: “For years, you have cared for and revered me. Now, summoned by the Son of Heaven, I am to ascend to heaven. Yet I know the Judicial Officer is burdened by the suffering of these laborers, so I come to express my gratitude. Prepare a bowl of pure water, take a willow branch, face north, and recite this incantation: *‘Celestial Stem, Celestial Pivot, dispel the storm and mist. Bestow your hidden merit—let wild calamity swiftly depart.’* Recite it three times in one breath, then sprinkle the water upon the afflicted. They will surely recover, and you shall receive imperial favor in time.” The tortoise then took its leave.

Chen followed the instructions, reciting the incantation over the water and sprinkling it upon the sick. In no time, they broke into sweat and revived. On the very day Chen received the dream, the great tortoise transformed into a gust of black wind and vanished. The Xinyang wall was completed without loss of life among the laborers, their deliverance attributed to the divine convergence of the True Martial’s tortoise and snake. Fiscal Commissioner Fei Qiang documented the event and memorialized the throne. An imperial rescript followed, permitting the erection of a stele in Xinyang and the construction of a True Martial Hall to maintain its incense and offerings. Chen Gongchen was specially appointed Vice Minister of the Court of the Imperial Regalia and promoted to Gentleman for Fostering Service. The true Dharma spread, and merit flowed like coin.

In Fengxiang Prefecture there lived a wealthy man named Zhong Shou’an, whose entire household was avaricious and bloodthirsty, perverting justice in all matters. Only his great-grandson Jinming lamented his inability to admonish them. On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, as monks held the Ullambana Festival, Jinming saw hell scrolls displayed in the monastery—depictions of karmic retribution in their hideous forms. Stricken with remorse, he began reciting sutras and donated his personal wealth to others. One day, a Daoist appeared, begging for "free-heart coins." His appearance was most peculiar, so Jinming invited him to a teahouse in the market and asked, "What is your surname and native place?" The Daoist replied, "I am Pei Guo of Wudang." He had come to Fengxiang but encountered no one receptive. Jinming said, "I wish to learn a formula to save those lost in delusion." The Daoist picked up a coin from the ground and handed it to Jinming, saying, "Guard it well, guard it well." Then he turned west and departed. Jinming examined the coin and saw it bore the inscription *qian zhong* ("weight of the firmament"). He kept it on his person.

Later, he met a man carrying a sandalwood-carved statue of the True Martial for sale. Jinming spent seven strings of cash to redeem it. Since his grandfather and father despised deities and Buddhas, he entrusted the statue to Daoist Lu Yuanzhi of Tianqing Abbey for safekeeping, visiting daily to tend its incense. After nearly a decade, he found his prayers increasingly efficacious.

One night, Jinming fell into a stupor and collapsed in his chamber. In a vision, the Daoist who had given him the coin called out: "You carry my coin—use it to save those who died unjustly. Soak it in water, and when you see me, administer it; there will be a response." Jinming awoke at dawn and sought out Daoist Sun Junzhi to inquire about the True Martial’s origins. Sun replied: "The True Martial was born into the Guo clan of Zhengle Kingdom, studied under the Most High Lord Lao, and cultivated the Dao on Mount Wudang. During Empress Wu Zetian’s reign in the Tang, he incarnated in the household of Minister Pei, vanquishing demonic youths." Hearing this, Jinming realized he had encountered the True Martial’s divine manifestation.

Thereafter, he patrolled the streets and alleys, seeking those afflicted with fever, thirst, or pestilence—those who raved and threw themselves into wells or rivers. He took the coin to Tianqing Abbey, immersed it in pure water, and burned incense before the True Martial, praying for the descent of sacred qi and true Dharma into the water to heal the suffering. As he prayed, the holy image suddenly radiated a halo of flame, filling the chamber with golden light. He then carried the consecrated water from door to door, administering it to the afflicted, who all recovered. Word spread throughout the prefecture, and the people flocked to pay homage to Jinming. Yet his uncles and cousins, consumed by envy, sought every means to harass him.

Jinming secretly attempted to remove the original True Martial statue entrusted to him, intending to wander elsewhere with it. Yet no matter how he tried, the statue would not budge. Even when more than a hundred men joined to lift it, the image remained fixed to its altar. Unexpectedly, an imperial envoy arrived at the prefecture bearing a decree from the Central Secretariat, based on a memorial from the Bureau of Astronomy: recently, a five-colored auspicious radiance had appeared, ascending to the Gate of Heaven, and was determined to have manifested within the borders of Fengxiang Prefecture—a sacred treasure of wondrous virtue and honor. The prefect, along with all officials down to the magistrates, was ordered to conduct a thorough search. After careful deliberation, the prefectural authorities concluded that only Zhong Jinming’s enshrined True Martial exhibited such divine marvels. Officers were dispatched to retrieve it, and with merely one or two men, the statue—along with its altar—was effortlessly lifted and carried away.

Jinming was then dispatched by the prefecture under official escort to present the offering to the imperial court. When the small sandalwood-carved True Martial statue was unveiled before the throne, several beams of light suddenly burst forth. The emperor rose from his seat, burned incense, and paid reverence, then temporarily enshrined the image in the Upper Clarity Palace of Extended Blessings. Awaiting the deliberation of the Three Departments on the matter’s details, further actions would be taken. Thus was the *Zhenhe Xingfu* [True Martial’s River-Stabilizing, Blessing-Bringing] statue established.

Rén Yuè, an Attendant of the Inner Palace of the Inner Court’s Esteemed Rank, was appointed as Pacification Commissioner of the Qinfeng Circuit’s Cavalry. While crossing the Yellow River at Dizhou, he encountered dense wind and fog at midstream. His attending officials remarked: "This is the first perilous pass of the Yellow River—the northern bank of the parched mouth at Yaomen Gorge. Here stands a hall of the Tianqing Abbey of Youzhou, allocated a share of its incense offerings, named the Protector-State True Martial Sanctuary. All who pass must first cast paper horses as tribute."

Rén Yuè prayed to the empty void, vowing to offer additional sacrifices upon crossing. No sooner had he finished than the clouds and wind abruptly stilled. He and his retinue all beheld a divine figure manifest in the sky, whose form they recognized as the True Martial of Blessing, the very image enshrined in the Four Saints Abbey of the capital. Rén Yuè prostrated himself upon the boat and, rising, received True Martial’s descent in speech akin to mortal conversation: "This hall was established by Emperor Taizong of Tang in honor of his meritorious minister Wei Zheng, who composed the *Pillar-Stabilizing Inscription* for its founding. To this day, this place remains the most treacherous frontier of the sanctuary’s domain. From henceforth, I have been stationed here to safeguard the mountains and rivers for the state. Yet the hall has long stood in disrepair, and my descents to subdue dragons and miasmic spirits find no refuge. Were I not here, the waters and droughts would surely wreak havoc, bringing no small harm to the realm. You must record this without fail, and reveal no secrets—report only to the imperial ear. Speak of this to others, and you shall suffer the karmic retribution of sores and boils." With that, the vision vanished.

Upon returning to court, Rén Yuè presented the matter to the throne, though the emperor remained skeptical. When Rén Yuè imprudently reiterated the account before the court, his voice failed him mid-speech, and he soon suffered the foretold affliction of sores and boils. Thus convinced, the court appointed him to oversee the capital’s palace affairs and ordered the relevant offices to consult the *Veritable Records of the Great Tang*, then dispatch a palace envoy to collaborate with Dizhou’s local officials in rebuilding the hall. The emperor bestowed the name *Pacifying Peace, Blessing-Bringing* as its plaque, establishing it as a permanent site for incense offerings and ritual observances.

At the Fusheng Taiyi Abbey of Longhushan in Xinzhou—a sacred precinct of the Fourth Grotto-Heaven, passed down through the lineage of Han-dynasty Celestial Master Zhang—a fire had ravaged its halls seven years prior. Though repairs had been made incrementally, the vast Northern Culmen Hall remained unfinished. One day, a merchant from Quanzhou arrived to sponsor a vegetarian feast. Calculating the timber and materials required for the Northern Culmen Hall, he pledged to fund its entire reconstruction. When the abbey inquired into his intent, he recounted: "Former Chief Minister Chen, while sailing home to Quanzhou from Guangzhou, was accompanied by his steward Gao Kui. As their ship neared their native shores, a contrary wind set them adrift. The minister burned incense and prayed to the void, vowing to seek deliverance. The storm instantly calmed, and ahead, suspended in the sky, appeared a top-knotted Daoist, who declared: 'Minister, your peril was grave. I have turned the wind to spare you from drowning. Now I shall ensure your family’s safe return to Quanzhou.' The minister burned incense in gratitude and asked which sage had manifested to save them, swearing to engrave the debt upon his heart and bones in perpetual reverence. The figure replied: 'At the Taiyi Abbey of Longhushan in Xinzhou, the Northern Culmen Hall has lain in ruins for seven years, uncompleted. I was dispatched by the Heavenly Marshal to seek one with karmic affinity. Today, having saved you, I need not rely on petitions—you may now fulfill this vow.' With that, he vanished into the clouds. Moments later, the ship reached Quanzhou’s shores. The household reflected that the top-knotted sage must have been the True Martial Sovereign, manifesting to deliver them. Thus, they sent Gao Kui to verify the abbey’s condition.'"

Gao Kui returned with the calculations, and over the next three years, the merchant funded the hall’s construction and its sculptural adornments. Former Chief Minister Chen Zhichun then submitted a memorial, requesting an imperial plaque to honor the deity’s miraculous deliverance. By imperial decree, the request was granted, and ten ordination certificates along with five hundred taels of silver were bestowed to aid the reconstruction, further endowing the abbey’s permanent endowment. The minister also sponsored a grand repentance ritual in the Precious Hall of Thanksgiving and a grand vegetarian feast to repay True Martial’s manifest grace.

During the Sui dynasty, Hé Quán, a garrison soldier of Qianzhou, accompanied Pacification Commissioner Zhāng Yòu to Nankang, where they visited the Grotto of the Great Clarity at Mount Lu’s Taiqing Abbey. There, on True Martial’s birthday, he encountered his parents in the Jasper Jade Heaven. Having received imperial permission to retire at his convenience, Hé Quán thereafter enshrined a silk painting of True Martial. He compounded medicines for sale, and over five to seven years, all who consumed them recovered. Thus, he amassed wealth exceeding two thousand strings of cash. One day, he told his wife: "My brother is young, and I, though lowly—a tattooed soldier—have served the state for thirty years without betraying its trust. By good fortune, I encountered True Martial’s birthday assembly and was granted imperial leave. Now, with ample means, I shall set aside one thousand strings for your daily needs and the sale of my medicines. The other thousand I shall take to the Tianqing Abbey of Mount Lu to construct a seven-bay Dharma Hall."

Upon its completion, an imperial envoy, Chén Bóhǔ, arrived to offer incense and present a golden dragon. Palace Censor Yàn Liángbì and the prefect of Nankang Commandery visited the grotto and, seeing Hé Quán’s donation, expressed admiration. Bóhǔ remarked to Liángbì: "Such deeds should be reported to the throne." Moments later, a white deer darted from behind the Dharma Hall into the mountain forest. Liángbì ordered men to pursue its tracks into the woods. They returned, reporting: "The white deer vanished, but within the forest stands a hermitage where a soldier was sleeping. Roused by our entry, he fled the woods."

The Daoist assembly remarked, "This must have been Hé Quán manifesting as the white deer." Later, the imperial envoy returned to court and reported the matter. By imperial decree, he was ordered to consult with the former Jiangxi Pacification Commissioner, Zhāng Yòu, regarding Hé Quán’s encounter with the True Warrior on his birthday. After review, Hé Quán was posthumously bestowed the Daoist title *Jūshì* (Lay Daoist). A shadow hall was established in his honor, a stele inscribed with his deeds, and the Gǔyán Grotto of Yáoyù Heaven was renamed Yáoyù Cavern Heaven.

Hé Quán lived to eighty-three and passed peacefully in the mountain hermitage behind the hall. The Daoist assembly cremated his remains on the mountain, gathered his ashes and bones as relics, and enshrined them in a sculpted likeness for veneration. Before half a year had passed, by imperial command, Hé Quán’s title was elevated to *Yìngmèng Xūjí Xiānshēng* (Master of Dream-Responding Emptiness). It remains unknown what divine sign from the court prompted this honor.

---

**The Wu Clan’s Karmic Affinity**
Dù Guī, magistrate of Wǔpíng County in Tíngzhōu, lost his sight and returned home for medical treatment, enduring six years of blindness. He had married the eldest daughter of Hào Yù, a minister from Jiànzhōu. During childbirth at twenty-seven, his wife received a talisman and scripture from the Daoist Zhōu Míngyàn, which preserved her safety. From then on, she vowed to venerate the True Warrior, uphold vegetarian precepts, and study Daoist scriptures. Seeing her husband’s blindness, she would, in the stillness of each night, prepare fine incense and pure water, face the northern sky in the open, and prostrate herself seventy times in seven cycles, praying for the True Warrior’s compassion to heal his eyes.

After two years, on the third day of the third month, at the third watch of the night, she dreamed of a Daoist in yellow robes who said: "Sincerity of heart is not as potent as bodily purity; weighty intent is not as profound as karmic affinity. Within seven days, someone will come to treat Dù Guī’s eyes. Once his sight is restored, seek me at Yúncāng to repay your master’s debt." With that, the Daoist vanished.

Seven days later, Hào’s wife saw a Daoist at her gate, his fan inscribed: *"Yúncāng Daoist, skilled in curing eye ailments."* She summoned him, and he examined her husband’s eyes, inserting two needles at the corners and leaving two medicines to be taken thrice daily with water. Once consumed, they would take effect. The Daoist accepted no payment and departed, vanishing without a trace. Following his instructions, she administered the medicine until it was exhausted.

One night, Dù Guī dreamed a small tortoise crawled onto his face and licked his eyes. He brushed it away, awakening to find his sight fully restored. Reflecting on the medicine and the tortoise, he realized the True Warrior had manifested his divine power to heal his blindness.

Later, hearing her father Hào Yù had been appointed prefect of Tàiyuán, she accompanied her husband there. One day, they ventured beyond the western city gates to Tiānzhù Abbey, located on a mountain called Yúncāng. Entering the mountain, they found a hall where a deity’s statue had been defaced—its eyes gouged out. Upon inquiry, they learned it was the sacred image of the True Warrior. Hào’s wife suddenly understood the Daoist’s earlier words: *"Meet me at Yúncāng to repay your master’s eye debt."*

She recounted the story to her father, who then funded the restoration himself. He memorialized the circumstances: how Dù Guī had resigned due to blindness, how the True Warrior’s divine intervention had healed him, and how he had been reinstated through official recommendation. An imperial edict followed, ordering Hào Yù to complete the restoration of the statue on Yúncāng Mountain before submitting a separate report. In recognition of his merit, Dù Guī was promoted to Judicial Officer of Yángzhōu.

---

**Manifestations of Divine Power**
The Central Secretariat, the Chancellery, the Three Departments, and the Ministry of Rites verified the case of Zhōng Jìnmíng of Fèngxiāng Prefecture. He had selected fine sandalwood to carve an image of the True Warrior, which he entrusted to the Daoist Lù Yuánzhì of Tiānqìng Abbey for veneration. Zhōng attended to the statue daily, ensuring incense and offerings were never lacking. The True Warrior appeared to him, teaching him to measure water for healing the sick. A radiant golden light blazed forth, aligning with the celestial river. The Bureau of Astronomy reported the phenomenon, noting its appearance in the region of Qín—present-day Fèngxiāng Prefecture—signifying the presence of an ancient, miraculous, and virtuous sacred image.

Officials were dispatched to investigate and retrieve the True Warrior’s pedestal. By imperial decree, it was sent to the Shàngqīng Yánfú Palace for veneration. Zhōng Jìnmíng was appointed to an honorary position in three ranks, and, while still at home, he performed the rites of gratitude to the court. Within three days, he fell ill and died.

Yet, as the local community attested, after Zhōng’s death, the saint’s miracles became even more manifest, with prayers answered and blessings granted. Later, Sūn Chéngzhī, Hanlin Academician and Vice Minister of Justice, was dispatched as an envoy to the Western Barbarian lands. While passing through Fèngxiāng Prefecture, he encountered a Daoist in hempen robes and straw sandals who approached him, saying: "Your fate, sir, does not align with this journey. When you turn back, you will face peril and distress, and upon returning, you will surely die."

Chéngzhī asked, "Who are you, and how do you foresee such things?"
The Daoist replied, "I was once Zhōng Jìnmíng, a commoner of Fèngxiāng. Now, I am the master of Qiónghú Cave on Sānluó Mountain, overseeing the Jade Peak Dragon Pool. I have attained the rank of a half-immortal. Just now, I saw a black aura above your head, countered by a white aura—an ominous sign. It foretells peril on your journey and death upon your return."

Chéngzhī pressed further: "If such disaster awaits, how may it be averted?"
Jìnmíng said, "In your hour of greatest danger, invoke the sacred title of my master, the True Warrior, the Spiritually Responsive Perfected Lord. You will surely receive his protection. Though you may escape the barbarians, I fear you will still face calamity upon returning home." With that, he vanished.

Chéngzhī entered the barbarian lands and was received by the barbarian king Lǐ Xījìng at a banquet. There, he was asked to compose a short verse on the theme of the seven characters "the sun and moon rise in the east and set in the west," but none could match his response, provoking Lǐ Xījìng’s wrath and threat of imprisonment. In his terror, Chéngzhī silently invoked the sacred title of the True Warrior, the Spiritually Responsive Perfected Lord several times. An official then pleaded on his behalf, gradually calming Xījìng’s anger, and he was released.

Upon Chéngzhī’s departure from the barbarian lands to return to the capital, before even crossing the border, a surveillance envoy traveling with him submitted a full report. Suddenly, an imperial commissioner arrived bearing orders to take charge of the matter. Chéngzhī’s entire retinue, along with the barbarian king’s return gifts and official correspondence, was confiscated. Charged with humiliating the nation during his mission abroad, he was specially granted poisoned wine to drink, with the command to accept his fate without protest. Moments later, another imperial commissioner arrived bearing a decree: Chéngzhī was spared execution but stripped of all previous ranks and reassigned to a remote, undesirable post as a supervisory official.

As the emperor reviewed the account of Zhōng Jìnmíng’s divine intervention, recognizing how the True Warrior’s compassionate virtue had manifested, he ordered the half-immortal to be entrusted with protecting the nation and saving its people. Acknowledging that the True Warrior’s protection had spared Chéngzhī from death, the emperor commuted his sentence. He commanded the construction of a shrine to Zhōng Jìnmíng in Fèngxiāng Prefecture, appointing him an honorary post in the Three Ranks with the title of Acting Officer. After Jìnmíng’s death, his spirit manifested, and he received a prophecy from the True Warrior, confirming him as a disciple of the master. Thus, his shrine was to be arranged with two halls in the front, and the True Warrior’s hall behind. The emperor permitted the original likeness of Jìnmíng to be sculpted, depicting him in the white robes of a commoner to signify his rank as a half-immortal. He further bestowed upon him the posthumous title of *Shàndǎo Ānjì Xiānjūn* ("Virtuous Guide, Serene and Tranquil Immortal Lord") and granted the two auxiliary temples the nameplate *Bàocí Miào* ("Temples of Repaying Compassion"). The prefecture was ordered to commission and erect a stele inscription to ensure his legacy endured forever.

On the fifth day of the third month in the second year of the *Lìqìng* era, the Chancellery and the Secretariat received a memorial from Zhengzhou Prefecture, reporting that Zōu Sù, the Wine-Monitor and Inner Palace Venerable Officer of the prefecture, had served with integrity in his post. He devoted himself solely to the worship of the True Warrior, his devotion sincere and reverent. He never resorted to flattery or deceit in his prayers, nor did he ever act against righteousness—greedy, cruel, or wantonly taking lives. Whenever the people of the prefecture suffered from floods, droughts, or epidemics, and their prayers to other deities went unanswered, if Zōu Sù fasted and prayed before the True Warrior in his own home, his supplications were always efficacious. The people said that Zōu Sù had awakened to the sacred teachings and secretly formed a bond with the divine, and thus Zhengzhou had received his hidden blessings.

One day, at noon, Zhengzhou was struck by a sudden storm of wind and hail, and dark clouds swirled on all sides. At the northern gate, a black mist coiled, and from it descended an uncovered bronze coffin. Ethereal music filled the air. From the magistrate down to the common folk, all changed into ceremonial robes and entered the coffin, yet none were permitted to remain within. Then the Wine-Monitor Zōu Sù arrived, clad in his official robes, and only when he stepped inside did the coffin lid suddenly close with a resounding clang. The coffin then rose lightly into the air, accompanied by the cries of cranes and the celestial decree, while auspicious vapors and heavenly incense lingered, refusing to disperse. The coffin drifted slowly toward the due north and vanished.

Later, the monks of the *Yánshòu* Monastery on White Lotus Mountain, led by the monk Zhìrén, submitted a report stating that the previous evening, the mountain had been enveloped in five-colored auspicious clouds, and celestial music had been heard, along with an extraordinary fragrance. Flowers rained from the sky, and after the mist cleared, sweet dew descended, persisting until the watches of the night had ended. The next morning, the monks gathered and ascended the mountain, where they found that a peak called *Péngcháo* ("Roc’s Nest") had two stone cliffs on either side, originally separated by over fifteen paces, now miraculously joined. At the seam where the northern cliff met, a small stone gate, four feet square, had appeared. Within, a bronze coffin was visible.

The withered trees on the mountain, both above and below, suddenly sprouted fragrant branches, transforming in an instant into a lush forest. Flowers bloomed in profusion, and birds and beasts flew and cried as if in protective vigil. The cause of these events remained unknown. The prefectural authorities deliberated and concluded that the bronze coffin that had descended from the heavens the previous night had indeed borne Zōu Sù away. They assembled the local officials, clerks, Daoist priests, and Buddhist monks to verify the matter, and it was confirmed as true.

The memorial continued, reporting that a subsequent divine decree had descended upon Zhengzhou, stating that Zōu Sù had recently departed in spirit to the Inner Palace to take his leave, saying: *"I have received the celestial mandate to serve as Vice-Judge of the Northern Culmen Longevity Bureau. Once each year, I shall accompany the True Warrior in descending to the mortal realm to tally the good and evil of the people, assess their lifespans, and receive the True Warrior’s protection and prophecies. Having enjoyed the emperor’s salary and favors, I have come to express my gratitude."*

The decree further ordered an investigation into whether Zōu Sù had any descendants to inherit his blessings and continue the line of his kin in service. If he had none, a generous stipend of money and silk was to be provided for their support. Additionally, a shrine was to be constructed for Zōu Sù on White Lotus Mountain, to be named *Shényìng Fǔjūn Miào* ("Temple of the Divinely Responsive Prefectural Lord"), to serve forever as a place for invoking his miraculous traces.

**Heaven-Bestowed Green Dates**
In Lèpíng County of Ráo Prefecture, there lived a certain Zhū Mù, a Judicial Officer of the Jiangzhou Regiment, who had no children. Before his father, Zhū Kàng, passed away, he had instructed him: *"Never forget the incense and offerings to the True Warrior’s sacred hall. On every occasion of his monthly descent, make sincere offerings. On the third day of the third month, the fifth day of the fifth month, the seventh day of the seventh month, and the ninth day of the ninth month—these four days—prepare offerings in triplicate and present them with utmost devotion."*

Zhū Mù had never once disobeyed his late father’s instructions. On one occasion, it happened to be the seventh day of the seventh month, the day of the True Warrior’s sacred descent. That night, after the offerings had been burned, around the third watch, his wife dreamed of a Daoist priest in yellow robes, who presented her with a stone dish bearing a single green date, urging her to eat it. After she did, her mouth was filled with an extraordinary fragrance. The Daoist said: *"This is a date bestowed by the immortals of heaven."* Thereafter, she conceived and gave birth to a son, whose bearing was elegant and whose memory and intelligence were exceptional. By the age of five, he was already remarkably quick-witted.

At the age of seven, his innate brilliance shone through, his name resounding across the four directions—truly a divine prodigy. In accordance with his mother’s dream, he was named Tianxi. When the imperial court investigated and learned of this, officials also put forth recommendations. He was promptly granted the provisional appointment of *Dali Pingshi* and, still in his youthful bonds, was brought by his father, Zhu Mu, to the palace. There, he expounded upon histories and classics without error, discoursing on the annals with such fluency that his responses to the emperor’s questions flowed like a river. The emperor bestowed upon Tianxi the provisional title of *Jia Chengwulang*, along with one hundred strings of cash for purchasing books, and instructed him to return home for further study. At sixteen, he was to present himself at court to await further orders. His father, Zhu Mu, was also granted an official post without the need for repayment, and both father and son received imperial commendations in the form of written edicts.

---

**The Divine Red Tassel**
In Yiyang County of Xinzhou, there lived a silk merchant named Lu Zhongdao, whose wife, Madam Zhang, had reached the age of forty-four without bearing a child. One day, Zhongdao suddenly said to her: *"I have heard that many people make offerings to the True Warrior of the North, and their prayers are never left unanswered."* Thereupon, he redeemed a Sichuanese painting of the True Warrior and brought it home to venerate. Day and night, Madam Zhang prayed with utmost devotion, never once forgetting, even in the bitterest cold or the most sweltering heat. Six years passed in this manner.

One night, Zhongdao and his wife shared the same dream: they were competing with immortal youths to toss a colored ball into the air. As they gazed upward, a red tassel suddenly flew into Madam Zhang’s mouth and was swallowed. From that moment, she conceived. After thirteen months, she gave birth to a daughter. By the age of thirteen, the girl was extraordinarily beautiful, yet she had never spoken, and people called her the "mute girl."

Yiyang County received an official dispatch from Xinzhou, relaying a letter from the central secretariat. The Bureau of Astronomy had reported that a bright star had recently appeared in the southeastern region, corresponding to the celestial domain of Chen, which governed Yiyang County. It was believed that an extraordinary immortal had descended in mortal guise. The county magistrate was instructed to investigate. Upon inquiry, it was discovered that only Lu Zhongdao’s thirteen-year-old mute daughter fit the description. Zhongdao was summoned and, after recounting the circumstances, the county memorialized the matter to the provincial authorities, who in turn petitioned the imperial court.

Upon hearing this, the mute girl suddenly spoke. She demanded fragrant water for bathing, changed into clean clothes, and sat upon a pure mat. To her parents, she said: *"I was originally a celestial maiden from the Palace of Heavenly Transformation, a disciple of the constellation of the Twin Maidens. As the foremost among the heavenly youths and maidens, I was known as the Jade Maiden of Green Mist. Every seven years, I descend in rotation to serve as the vice-director of the Northern Culmen’s Protective Victory Abbey, accompanying the True Warrior on his inspections. Recently, moved by your daily prayers to the heavenly court for an heir, the True Warrior reviewed the ledgers of karmic causes. Though my mother’s destiny did not originally include bearing a child, the True Warrior, considering your lifelong devotion to his altar, first petitioned the Three Heavens on your behalf. Then, he transformed me into a red tassel and sent me into my mother’s womb. For over a decade, I have remained as your daughter, fulfilling your earnest prayers. When I descended into the womb, the True Warrior instructed me never to speak while in the mortal realm. Though I have been by your side all this time, I have never uttered a word. Now that my term is complete and the imperial edict has revealed the celestial secret, I can no longer remain. I must take my leave."*

Zhongdao and his wife then had artisans seal her body in lacquered cloth, fashioning it into a statue, which they placed beside the True Warrior’s image. Daily, they offered incense and performed meritorious deeds, holding vegetarian feasts to repay the True Warrior’s benevolence.

Later, the imperial court bestowed silk and grain as tokens of auspicious omens accompanying the birth of a divine being. The county was instructed to record her words as they were spoken and to report the full account of her transformation. Another edict from the central secretariat was sent directly to Yiyang County, ordering that the intact body of the mute girl be buried in an official plot within the county town. A pavilion was to be built over the grave, and a separate shrine erected, where a statue of the mute girl in plain immortal robes would be enshrined. The shrine was to be named *"The Silent and Radiant Filial Maiden,"* and a stele was to be erected to commemorate the event.

**The Twin Blessings of Prince Jing**
During the Guangming era of the Tang, the Daoist temple of the Empress’s Meritorious Virtues in the Mysterious Capital had fallen into disrepair over the years. The Daoist community repeatedly petitioned for donations, but not a single contribution was received, leaving them at a loss.

A Daoist priest named Wang Zhenyuan remarked: *"This temple houses an image of the True Warrior. Why has he not yet bestowed his favor?"* That very night, Zhenyuan dreamed that someone delivered a pile of gold coins to the temple, stacking them before the True Warrior’s hall—five hundred strings in total—before loading them onto a horse and ascending to heaven.

Less than ten days later, officials from the household of Prince Yan, including the palace attendant Sun Weiyan, arrived at the True Warrior’s hall to make offerings. They presented a stack of paper money, funds to purchase a horse, a censer of aloeswood, and a memorial petition. The offerings were made on behalf of the Prince’s Consort, Lady Yiguo, who was in difficult labor. A Daoist priest had approached the prince with a petition to donate toward the reconstruction of the temple in Xiying Town. The prince had dismissed him, saying: *"My consort is in peril during childbirth."* The Daoist replied: *"There is a method to ensure a safe delivery and the well-being of both mother and child."* Overjoyed, the prince declared: *"If this proves efficacious, I shall rebuild the temple entirely at my own expense."*

The Daoist wrote a talisman on yellow paper with cinnabar, burned it to ashes, and mixed it with water for the consort to drink. Shortly thereafter, she gave birth to a son. The prince submitted a petition, and the Daoist took his leave, vanishing without a trace.

The consort recounted: *"As soon as I drank the talismanic water, I saw officials and attendants before me. In the darkness, a golden-armored, sword-wielding deity with disheveled hair shouted, and at that very moment, my son was born."* She also heard a report: *"This child comes from the Mysterious Capital Temple in Xiying Town. Hasten there to protect Prince Jing."*

Thus, the prince presented the money, horse, and other offerings, verifying the temple’s dilapidated state. He also inquired whether any Daoists had come to the capital to solicit donations.

The Daoist community replied: *"No one has come to the capital to solicit donations."*

Prince Jing then presented a memorial to the throne, dispatching gold, silver, coins, and silks to extensively renovate the temple. By imperial decree, one hundred ordination certificates were bestowed to aid in the reconstruction. Upon completion, a grand jiao ritual of celebration and repentance was held. The consort personally prepared her dowry goods, sold them, and used the proceeds to gild the temple’s Three Clarities sacred images and the True Warrior’s statue. She also commissioned a thousand scrolls of silk paintings depicting the True Warrior, which were distributed to the palaces of imperial kinsmen, the entire court, and the households of civil and military officials for reverent veneration. The temple, favored by imperial grace, was renamed the *Venerable Numinous Response Sage Temple*, and a stele was erected to record the event.

Lady Jiao—wife of Wang Zhi, Successor to the Military Commissioner of Wu’an Army and Grand Commandant of the Palace—had borne no children. By nature, she delighted in goodness and yearned for the Dao, devoutly maintaining incense offerings. One day, while strolling in the rear garden, she noticed a withered branch on a pomegranate tree spontaneously engulfed in smoke and flame. Alarmed, Lady Jiao rushed to extinguish it, and the fire vanished. Before the tree appeared a divine figure, radiant with a halo, disheveled-haired and sword in hand, treading upon tortoise and serpent—unmistakably the True Warrior Perfected Sovereign. Lady Jiao prostrated herself: *"Today, I am blessed to encounter the Supreme Perfected. I humbly beseech your compassion and deliverance."* The True Sovereign asked: *"You have seen me—what is your heart’s desire?"* Lady Jiao replied: *"I wish for an heir."* The True Sovereign said: *"On the third day of the third month, come to Zuozhen Temple outside the Xuanhua Gate. I shall grant you an heir, who will attain future nobility."*

As Lady Jiao bowed again, the deity vanished. She returned and recounted the encounter to Wang Zhi. On the third day of the third month, they journeyed to Zuozhen Temple. That day, a vegetarian feast was held to celebrate the True Warrior’s birthday, drawing throngs of men and women. Suddenly, a shaven-headed boy of six or seven tugged at Lady Jiao and Wang Zhi, begging for money. Upon closer inspection, his appearance was extraordinary, unlike ordinary folk. When questioned, he said: *"I have no parents, no kin. For years, I have wandered among temples, seeking shelter and food."* Lady Jiao took him home to raise, and he proved naturally intelligent.

At eight years old, Wang Zhi petitioned to recognize him as his own son. The emperor summoned him and asked: *"You once claimed to have no children—how now do you have a son of your own flesh?"* Wang Zhi could only recount the encounter with the True Warrior and the granting of the child. The emperor marveled in astonishment for a long while, then inquired about the boy’s birth date. Uncertain of his origins, they took the day he was found at Zuozhen Temple—the third day of the third month, at the *si* hour—as proof. By imperial order, he was sent to the Bureau of Astronomy to determine his fate.

The divination revealed that at eight years old, Wang Zhi’s destiny aligned with the five stars and the *Room* constellation, foretelling sixteen military achievements on the frontier. His fortune would arise from the *Deep Ditch* water star, flowing from due north, granting him authority and power. Thus, the emperor bestowed upon him the name *Wang Yuan* and appointed him as *Right Attendant Forbidding Guard* and *Inner Palace Venerable Rank*. He was further betrothed to the Third Princess of Yue, with the wedding to be solemnized at sixteen, upon the granting of separate betrothal gifts.

At fourteen, Wang Yuan was honored with the title *Gatekeeper of the Palace* and accompanied his father to court audiences. He underwent the palace examination, passed the military examination, and was awarded the *Rite of Accompaniment*. At sixteen, the betrothal gifts were presented, the marriage rites completed, and he was enfeoffed as *Defense Commissioner of Binzhou* and *Commandant-Escort to the Princess*. He petitioned the throne to use his salary and dowry funds to construct the *True Warrior’s Precious Pavilion* at Zuozhen Temple and requested an imperial plaque for its dedication.

**The Child Attendant’s Dream-Response**

East of Mount Kuaiji in Yuezhou lies the *Yangming Grotto-Heaven*. Since King Wenmu of the Qian lineage established the *Dragon Auspice Palace* there, it had fallen into deep ruin over the years. Within it stood the *True Warrior’s Hall*, most dilapidated of all.

On the first night of the second month in the first year of *Chunhua*, the *Wenyi Empress* dreamed in the *Jade Florescence Palace* of a young attendant with unbound hair, clad in a plain robe, who approached and said: *"I am a child attendant of the Dragon Auspice Palace in Yuezhou. Our temple has grown so impoverished that we have no clothes to wear, no shelter to dwell in, and suffer exposure to the elements. Only the Empress can save us—I shall repay this kindness in time."* Then he transformed into a radiance and vanished.

At dawn, she recounted the dream in full and memorialized the throne. An emissary was dispatched bearing incense to investigate the Dragon Auspice Palace. The eunuch in charge questioned the temple’s caretaker, who reported: *"This palace was built at the end of the Tang dynasty. Over the centuries, it has fallen into complete ruin. Only the True Warrior’s hall remains, its retinue of deities left exposed to rain and sun, toppled to the ground."*

The Empress then realized that the dream of the previous night was a divine manifestation of the True Warrior, who had come to beseech the imperial harem to restore the palace and revive its incense offerings. She memorialized the throne, and permission was granted for her to devote her dowry treasures to the cause. These were exchanged for ordination certificates, purple robes, gold, and silver, and an eunuch was dispatched to oversee the reconstruction in Yuezhou, with a year allotted for completion—rebuilding the halls and refurbishing the sacred images.

Once the work was finished, the Empress suddenly fell ill, afflicted with *counterflow stomach* for over forty days, resistant to all medical treatment. Then, one day, she slipped into a trance, her breath faint and shallow. As her qi gradually returned, the retching ceased, and she recovered naturally.

She recounted: *"Just now, I saw the True Warrior descend from the clouds to express his gratitude for the restoration of the Dragon Auspice Palace. Though my life was not yet forfeit, the illness had lingered long. He commanded a child attendant to bring a pure vase and a clean bowl, then poured the *Five Directions’ Sweet Dew Jade Nectar* from the vase into the bowl and urged me to drink. As I did, I felt a soothing warmth suffuse my heart, my chest and diaphragm cleared, and the malady vanished at once. When I opened my eyes, it was as if the dream had never ended—only the strange fragrance lingering in my mouth and the lightness in my limbs remained. I rose and moved as before, a clear sign of divine responsiveness."*

The court, in gratitude, twice offered grand sacrifices and augmented the rites, repaying the god’s favor. The *August Sage descended to the mortal realm*.

The Jade Flower Palace of Great Purity atop Great Luo Mountain in Qingcheng, Chengdu Prefecture of Yizhou, ranks as the fourth of the nation’s sacred mountains and cavern-heavens of august blessings. Each year, golden registers and jade talismans—scriptures left behind by the Perfected Lord of the True Realm upon his ascension—bestow twelve annual edicts of divine grace. During the *mingdao* era, on the fifth day of the fifth month, the medicinal market of Chengdu Prefecture convened, and by the sixth day, Daoist wanderers from the ten directions, clad in cloud-and-water robes, flocked to the palace to attend the seventh-day feast celebrating the Heavenly Ascent of Zhenwu. It was customary for immortals to descend and manifest transformations, ascending to heaven in broad daylight.

At that time, a certain Daoist, his robe hem trailing a turtle’s tail, was deemed a spectral aberration, and all shunned him. Suddenly, this man appeared with Kou Keming, son of Kou Tong, the prefecture’s commander of horse and foot, atop a high peak. The crowd suspected the youth had been bewitched by the uncanny figure and sent soldiers to seize him. The Daoist vanished in a flash of white light, and Keming, unaware, plummeted. From that moment, his heart ceased its beat, he refused all food and drink, and fell mute. His father, Kou Tong, was later transferred to serve as garrison commander of Yuanliang Stockade. For seven years, Keming lived with his family in Xingyuan Prefecture.

In the third year of the *qingli* era, on the fifth day of the fifth month, before dawn, Keming slipped away from home and vanished without a trace. Later, he was found at the Jade Flower Palace in Yizhou, walking alongside the same turtle-tailed Daoist from the previous year. The palace invited both to the feast. As the meal progressed, only Keming remained visible; the Daoist had disappeared, much to the astonishment of all. By the ninth course, a great turtle suddenly appeared beneath Keming’s seat. As he rose, the turtle bore him aloft into the empty sky, where auspicious clouds gathered, and Keming ascended seated upon its back.

Later, at Yuanliang Stockade, his father Tong saw his son Keming come to bid farewell: “I have now been appointed as the adjudicator of the Seven Primes’ Lifespan Bureau in the Lower Northern Culmen. By the grace of my master Zhenwu, I was carried to heaven upon this great turtle.” Subsequently, Chengdu Prefecture submitted a memorial reporting the name of the ascendant from this year’s medicinal market. In response, an imperial decree ordered an inquiry into Keming’s meritorious deeds. According to Kou Tong’s sworn statement, Keming was originally a boy purchased with money and silk from a passing Daoist. Daily, he cultivated his conduct, studied the *Daodejing* of Laozi, burned incense at night, paid homage to the Northern Culmen, and ceaselessly recited the sacred name of his master Zhenwu. He abstained from forbidden foods, observed frequent fasts, and never engaged in the slightest deceit or dishonesty.

Following a rescript from the Chancellery, it was decreed that in various regions, such manifestations of august sages descending to the mortal realm to deliver souls and enable their ascension were not uncommon. Chengdu Prefecture was thus ordered to construct a shrine and hall, appointing Daoists to conduct rites and erect a stele in commemoration. Keming was specially enfeoffed as *Lingxian Zhenjun* (“Perfected Lord of Numinous Manifestation”), and the shrine was named *Lingxian Ci* (“Shrine of Numinous Manifestation”). Upon verifying Keming’s ancestral origins in Qianhao Township of the Western Capital, a shrine was also established there.

Additionally, Chen Chou, concurrently serving as Vice Minister of Justice in the Ministry of Punishments, Prefect of Yingzhou, and Commander-in-Chief of the Gaoyang Pass, submitted a memorial: In the fourth year of the *xingyuan* era of the former dynasty, seven brothers from the Northern Barbarian lands, led by the barbarian official Yishouxian, arrived at the border with a cartload of credentials and goods—felt, silk, incense, and merchandise worth over fifty thousand strings of cash—to be sold at the government’s trade office. They requested that the proceeds be temporarily deposited in the official treasury, with the understanding that upon their return to the barbarian lands, they would arrange for the remaining goods to be transported and the money retrieved. Fifteen years passed with no word.

Later, when the Great Ancestor ascended the throne and performed the suburban sacrifice to Heaven, Yingzhou lacked the funds—over fifty thousand strings—to reward the troops. Unexpectedly, Yishouxian and his brothers reappeared, submitting a petition offering their deposited money to the government for the troop rewards. Thus, Yingzhou drew upon these funds, and the distribution was completed without deficit. Zheng Du, the prefect of Gaoyang Pass, summoned Yishouxian and his brothers to inquire into the matter. The money they had deposited was not their own property but had originated in the *xingyuan* era, when the Great Ancestor, then serving as a commander under Emperor Shizong, was stationed in Yingzhou. One day, the Star of Venus descended and transformed into a white-robed Daoist, who admonished the Great Ancestor to accumulate virtue and benevolence, foretelling that his future eminence would be extraordinary.

The Great Ancestor asked, “What numinous efficacy does Heaven possess to aid my rise to eminence?” The Daoist replied, “Along the frontier, there are rebellious barbarians and treacherous ministers whom the court has entrusted you to suppress. The present pacification of these rebels is due to the unseen protection of Zhenwu of the Northern Culmen.” With these words, the Daoist vanished in a flash of white light.

Thereupon, the Great Ancestor held a grand seven-day-and-night jiao offering in Yingzhou, burning paper money to the celestial bureaus and over fifty thousand strings’ worth of gold paper. However, the celestial ledgers revealed that this sum of gold paper was not to be accepted and was instead forwarded to the Northern Culmen for disposition. The Office of Zhenwu of You Sheng Monastery issued a memorandum to the Seven Primes of the Northern Dipper, who oversee accounts. The seven brothers—Yishouxian and his kin—were in fact the seven attendants of the Seven Primes.

At the founding of the Great Song, with the establishment of the imperial enterprise, Zhenwu memorialized the Three Heavens, detailing how the unclaimed jiao money from the former dynasty was to be returned to the new Song for frontier troop rewards. The Seven Primes were dispatched, assuming the guise of barbarian officials under the name Yishouxian, to convert the money into felt, treasures, and other goods worth approximately fifty thousand strings, which were then deposited in the prefectural treasury. A hundred li beyond the barbarian frontier stands a temple named Shouxian Temple, a shrine to the Four Saints, where the seven attendants of Zhenwu’s retinue are depicted. Each wears a headband, a yellow robe, holds a green fish, girds a white silk sash, and wears boots. Representing the five directions and five colors, the Seven Primes and Seven Celestial Bodies, they assist Zhenwu in overseeing the karmic affairs of good and evil throughout the world—such is the true form of Yishouxian and his six brothers.

Upon questioning, Yishouxian and his companions vanished before the hall like a sudden gust of wind. At that time, Prefect Tong and others submitted a joint memorial to mitigate their offense, and a subsequent imperial decree ordered that the money first be allocated for frontier troop rewards, with further investigation to follow.

**The Manifestations of the Two Perfected Ones**
Shi Guangzu, Grand Master for Assisting the State and newly appointed Prefect of Zhen Ding Prefecture, concurrently serving as Military Commissioner and Pacification Commissioner of the Hebei West Circuit, was en route to assume his post when he stopped for the night at Yuantong Temple in the prefecture of Chan. There, he heard of a Daoist in the temple, originally from Wudang County in Dengzhou, surnamed Guo. For fifteen years since his arrival, he had never spoken to anyone, tending only to rare and novel vegetables each season to supply the temple’s vegetarian kitchen. Guangzu, accompanied by the temple’s supervising monk, visited his hut that night, where the Daoist emerged to greet them. Once seated in his quarters, the Daoist suddenly spoke, addressing Guangzu: “Grand Master, do not proceed to Zhen Ding. The appointed time has come, and your facial qi portends only a few days remain.” The temple monks, overhearing this, were astonished and doubtful. By the following morning, the Daoist had vanished without a trace, and all his vegetable seeds had reverted to common varieties.

Thereupon, Guangzu declined the appointment to Zhen Ding and submitted a memorial requesting retirement to return to Zhaozhou. That very day, at the hour of *chen*, he suddenly called for hot water to bathe, changed into his court robes, and passed away in a purified chamber. Before the prefect of Chan’s memorial could reach the capital, Guangzu’s form dissolved into emptiness and appeared first before the Hall of Sagacious Governance, where he addressed the emperor: “Your servant, upon reaching Yuantong Temple in Chan, encountered the Perfected Guo, an old companion who had concealed himself as a vegetable-tending Daoist for fifteen years to await me. Now he departs. Your servant Guangzu is in truth the Deputy Strategist, Perfected of the Middle Prime, under the True Lord Zhenwu of the Northern Culmen. The Perfected Guo is the Northern Culmen’s Inspector-General, though he was fated to fall at the age of fourteen. I myself was banished for sixty years and, upon the return of the *jiazi* cycle, restored to my original rank. Had I not come to bid farewell to Your Majesty for over thirty years of generous favor, I might never have faced the throne again. Moreover, I have a son, Shi Tingzhi, who, though holding office, fears his foolishness renders him unfit for duty. I humbly implore Your Majesty’s compassion.” With that, he bowed and vanished.

Shortly after, the Secretariat presented the memorial from Chan, which aligned precisely with the recent manifestation, its details clear and unambiguous. Guangzu was posthumously honored as Grand Preceptor to the Heir Apparent, and a hall dedicated to the two Perfected Ones, Shi and Guo, was erected at Yuantong Temple in Chan. By imperial decree, Yuantong Temple was renamed the Imperially Bestowed Hidden Perfection and Heaven-Receiving Abbey, and a stele was commissioned to record the event.

**The Sum of Twenty Thousand Strings**
At Songyang Abbey on Mount Heng in Hengzhou, a True Warrior hall and pavilion—built with funds donated by the Tang scholar Liu Zongyuan—stood as the most exquisite and towering structure in the region. Since the tenure of Abbot Hao Jun, the hall’s daily offerings and alms had accumulated over twenty thousand strings of cash. The former Vice Fiscal Commissioner, Qian Cao, devised a plan and memorialized the throne to temporarily borrow twenty thousand strings from the True Warrior hall’s alms funds, allocating them to Tanzhou, Lizhou, and other prefectures as capital for tribute silk. Five years later, as Qian resumed his duties as Fiscal Commissioner, a Daoist submitted a petition claiming to be a disciple of Songyang Abbey and requesting the return of the twenty thousand strings to repair the leaking True Warrior hall. Qian replied, “This money was borrowed by the state—how could it be reclaimed with a mere petition? Moreover, the True Warrior hall at Songyang Abbey remains grand and sturdy. Though it has recently tilted of its own accord, no disciple has come to the Fiscal Commission to petition for the funds.” Soon after, Qian fell ill, his body covered in white scabs, wracked with pain and groaning. Half a year into his retirement, he dreamed one night of Abbot Hao Jun, accompanied by divine attendants, demanding the return of the twenty thousand strings. Only then did Qian awaken to his error. He sold his property to repay the full sum, vowing to secure his well-being. No sooner had he formed this resolve than his scabs began to heal, and the dreams of debt collectors ceased. Within a month, he fully recovered. He personally journeyed to Songyang Abbey to pay homage to the True Warrior. Before the money was delivered to the abbey, the hall remained tilted, but once the funds were returned, a night of wind and rain culminated in a great thunderclap, and the hall stood straight once more.

Qian Cao was reinstated as a Hanlin Academician and presented the above account of divine response to the throne. By imperial decree, Songyang Abbey’s True Warrior hall was granted an honorary plaque, and a miraculous golden inscription was bestowed. Henceforth, any accumulated funds were forbidden from being borrowed by officials. **Four Thousand Strings of Paper Money**...

In Raozhou’s Poyang County, the Daoist of Minghua Abbey, Huang Zonggu, had once accompanied his master Zhu Shiyuan to Mount Xiadao in Hongzhou. There, he awakened to the Dao and secretly departed for the western lands of Shu, wandering for eight years. In the tenth month of the fifth year of the Dazhong Xiangfu era, Minghua Abbey was struck by a devastating fire, reducing all to ashes—save for a single corridor and a small hall, the True Warrior Hall, untouched by smoke or flame.

Suddenly, an official dispatch arrived from the prefecture, ordering the collection of four thousand strings of official money to compensate Minghua Abbey. Huang Zonggu, who had previously deposited paper money in the capital’s treasury for the abbey’s construction, was summoned upon receipt of the decree. The Daoists of Minghua Abbey, including Zhu Shiyuan, were questioned, and they testified: *"Though we have a disciple named Huang Zonggu, he has been wandering for eight years, and we know not whether he lives or has perished. How could he have foreseen the abbey’s fire? And how could he possess money in the treasury? We cannot readily accept this."*

Within ten days, Huang Zonggu returned in person, bearing the official receipt for the exchanged money from Raozhou. He also brought over a thousand strings’ worth of gold, silver, and ritual vessels from the Bureau of Sacrifices. Addressing his master, he recounted: *"After abandoning you to wander, I entered Ziyan Mountain, where I encountered a Daoist who invited me to his thatched hut for conversation. He said, ‘I have long held a vow, yet it remains unfulfilled. Hear my instructions: I know that in the tenth month of the fifth year of Xiangfu, the Star Lord of Fire Virtue will traverse the celestial division of Chen, casting its light upon Raozhou’s prefecture and counties. All are fated to suffer fire. But the True Warrior petitioned the Northern Emperor and the Fire Star, saying, "The land of Raozhou is kind, its people merciful. Now, as the fire tribulation approaches, I beseech your compassion to mitigate its severity." Gazing upon the map of Raozhou’s counties painted on the rear wall of Minghua Abbey’s Three Clarities Hall, I saw that if the abbey’s Daoist community were spared destruction, the prefecture’s fire disaster might be averted through prayer and supplication. The Fire Star, hearing this, dared not refuse. He asked the True Warrior, "Does this place have a hall dedicated to your worship?" The True Warrior replied, "It does." Thereupon, the Fire Star sighed and declared, "The True Warrior is a disciple of the Most High Lord of the Golden Tower in the Upper Clarity, and thus subject to the Heavenly Lord of the Forest of Suffering. On the day Minghua Abbey is to be consumed by fire, I shall spare its hall." At that time, flee to avoid the flames. Yet I fear no one will remain to restore the abbey. I bid you journey to the Bian River region to raise funds. Once in the Eastern Capital, gather wealth and return to rebuild. I am an old acquaintance from Poyang. When you return to Minghua Abbey, we shall meet again.’ With that, he sent me from the hut. After a few steps, I turned back—only to find the hut vanished, with no trace of the Daoist. Emerging from Ziyan Mountain as if from a mist, I made my way to the Biankou in Sizhou.*

*From then on, I carried the one hundred and twenty divination slips of the Twelve Perfected Lords of the Western Mountains and a portrait of the True Warrior. Resolving to sell divinations, I charged four coins per slip. My arts flourished, and after daily expenses, I often earned five to seven hundred in gold. With the proceeds, I purchased gold and silver wherever I went, entrusting them to others. Over six years, I amassed over five thousand strings of cash, depositing them at the Five Marchmounts Abbey. One day, I met a merchant from Raozhou who informed me of Minghua Abbey’s destruction by fire. Thus, I delivered the money to the capital’s treasury, obtaining an official receipt to reclaim it upon returning to Poyang County. When I arrived home, the abbey had indeed burned—only the True Warrior Hall remained. Examining the statue’s face closely, I saw it was identical to the Daoist I had met on Ziyan Mountain."*

Daoist Zhu Shiyuan and the others then traveled to Poyang County to claim the deposited money and sell the ritual vessels from the Bureau of Sacrifices. Within five years, they had fully restored Minghua Abbey. Huang Zonggu’s account, from beginning to end, was recorded at Raozhou’s request. At the time, Prefect Xie Mao and others submitted a memorial to the throne, attesting to the truth of the matter. Later, an imperial rescript renamed Minghua Abbey as Ning’an Abbey. Daoist Huang Zonggu was honored as Master Tongxiang, granted the purple robe, and the surviving True Warrior Hall was bestowed the additional title *"Guardian of the State."*

At Shuiyunhubo, a beggar woman from Shanzhou named Yang Suzhen had frequented the home of Yuan Qing, a minor official in the Ministry of Revenue. Observing that she had no family but possessed a dowry, he lured her away from her hometown. They boarded a boat on Mengyang Lake and spent the night along the reed-lined shore. Yuan Qing plied Suzhen with drink, then pushed her into the deep waters, assuming she had drowned. He hastily summoned the boatmen, claiming, *"The lady, drunk and thirsty, leaned over to fetch water and fell in."* He ordered them to search, feigning grief with hollow wails. Then, he hastened back to the prefecture to arrange a memorial service for her.

Upon arriving in Puzhou, Yuan Qing pawned and sold Suzhen’s dowry items, valued at over a thousand strings of cash, and spent the proceeds, residing there for half a year. One day, in the marketplace, he suddenly saw a plain-clothed woman reciting scriptures and begging for alms. Yuan Qing, believing her to be the ghost of Yang Suzhen, was struck dumb and unable to speak. At that moment, Suzhen cried out to the patrol officers, who escorted her to the prefectural court for investigation. Based on Yuan Qing’s confession, the authorities questioned Suzhen about how she had survived and come to Puzhou. She recounted that her ancestors had served in the imperial bureaucracy, but after the deaths of her parents, she had lived in Shanzhou, drifting into destitution. Though her body had fallen into prostitution, her heart longed for goodness, and she had always venerated the True Warrior, daily reciting Daoist scriptures. At Tianqing Abbey, she had received a donation of a small, gold-lettered copy of the *True Warrior’s Wondrous Sutra*, which she kept in a silk pouch tied within her hair, never parting with it. That night, when Yuan Qing pushed her into the deep waters, she felt as though she were enveloped in mist, her body floating in empty space, while above her head, a wheel of divine light spun, and a voice cried, *"Protect the precious topknot!"* By dawn, the spirits had dispersed, and she found herself on a grassy path by the lake, her body drenched but the sutra and talisman in her hair untouched by water. A nearby household took pity on her, brought her home, and revived her. When she asked where she was, she learned it was Mengzhou territory. From then on, she sold her clothes, exchanged them for plain garments, and recited Daoist scriptures to sustain herself. Passing through Heyang and Puzhou, she unexpectedly encountered her enemy. Had it not been for the sutra in her hair at that moment, she would have sunk to the water’s depths, becoming a wronged and homeless spirit with no hope of deliverance.

The Puzhou authorities, having reviewed the case and found Yuan Qing guilty on both legal and moral grounds, memorialized the throne. By decree of the Central Secretariat, Yuan Qing was denied official pardon and executed according to the law. Suzhen was granted the remaining items from her dowry, which she used to purchase ordination credentials from the Bureau of Sacrifices. She changed her name to Zhongyan and took refuge under the Daoist nun Tang Jintong at Ciqing Abbey, where she took vows and donned the religious habit. Thereafter, she dedicated herself to begging for alms in the streets, raising funds to construct the Three Clarities and Seven Primes Halls, as well as the True Warrior’s Precious Pavilion. Through the celestial mercy of the *Dharma Treasury* as revealed in the gold-lettered scripture, she had saved herself. She printed and distributed five thousand copies of the *True Warrior Sutra*. Later, by memorial of the chief minister Xiang, an imperial edict was issued, bestowing upon Yang Zhongyan the purple robe and the title *"Grand Master of Compassionate Blessings,"* while the abbey’s name was changed to *"Abbey of the Guardian Sage."*

*Wind and Mist Lay Down the Letter*
Wang Yibiao, Director of the Bureau of Imperial Carriages, retired to Suzhou. Reflecting on the taking of life, he resolved to copy a complete canon of scriptures.

Having recruited fourteen individuals, including Chen Fang, they were each tasked with transcribing the scriptures daily before the image of the True Warrior, ensuring meticulous neatness and accuracy without a single character amiss. Among them, Zhou Weiji was notably swift, outpacing the others. Suddenly, however, Weiji’s right hand was afflicted with a wind-borne malady—his sinews stiffened, his fingers clenched, and his brush could no longer move. Though his scrolls remained unfinished, the others pressed on. The thirteen, including Chen Fang, completed their transcriptions, each carefully proofread, while Zhou Weiji’s seventeen volumes were entrusted to Wang Yibiao without further review. All were uniformly bound and prepared for donation to the Abbey of Great Clarity and Extended Blessings.

As this was an inner abbey sanctuary, the matter was first memorialized to the throne. By imperial decree, the eunuch Ren Qi and others were dispatched to oversee the transfer of the scriptures to the Abbey of Extended Blessings. Since no proper canon repository yet existed, the scrolls were temporarily housed in the True Warrior Hall. The moment the hall doors opened, a black mist swirled forth, and a violent wind howled in spirals. Though the storm eventually subsided, when the scriptures were arranged upon the altar, an entire volume slipped free, repeatedly resisting all attempts to stack it. Wang Yibiao examined the fallen scrolls and found them all to be Zhou Weiji’s work. Suddenly, he heard a voice beside him declare, *"All was done in deceit, hastened for gain—errors abound, and the merit is incomplete."* Yet no one stood near, save the clay statue of the *Zhifu* spirit, its back turned. Realizing the impropriety, Wang borrowed an authentic copy to compare and found numerous omissions. He then sought a scribe to fill in the gaps before rearranging the scrolls in the hall.

Zhou Weiji’s affliction worsened—his right hand festered, oozing pus and maggots. Begging in the marketplace, he cried, *"I deceived Master Wang while transcribing the canon, cheating the karmic cause. Now I reap the retribution."* When the eunuch Ren Qi learned of this, he reported it to the throne. By imperial decree, a repository was constructed at the Abbey of Extended Blessings to house the scriptures Wang Yibiao had presented.

**The Fulfilled Divination**
During the Yongxi era, Yang Fang, the diviner-official of the Great Yu Temple in Yuezhou, had devoted his life to venerating the True Warrior. He regularly burned incense and paper offerings on behalf of the townsfolk, and his prayers were never unanswered. When Chen Chou, Vice Minister of Revenue, was unexpectedly summoned to court while governing Yuezhou, he grew anxious, uncertain of fortune or misfortune. Summoning a diviner, his attendants recommended Yang Fang, who served the True Warrior and was most reliable in interpreting divinations. They proceeded to the True Warrior Shrine at Qianming Abbey, where Yang drew the fourth yellow slip of the Perfected Lord Huang. His interpretation was thus: *"This divination foretells a violent death within one hundred and twenty days. Beware the Ghost Gate in the northeast—do not accept authority or lead troops in that direction."*

Chen Chou flew into a rage. He had Yang Fang imprisoned, vowing that if even the slightest misfortune befell him within the allotted time, he would petition to transfer his own office to Yang as a favor. If nothing occurred, Yang would be charged with fraud, spreading panic, and embezzlement, then exiled by law. Yet as the days passed uneventfully, Yuezhou officials released Yang, appointing him as an assistant instructor and reinstating him as the temple diviner.

Meanwhile, Chen Chou arrived at court and was appointed Pacification Commissioner of Zouzhou, concurrently serving as Military Commissioner of the circuit. His mission was to suppress the rebels led by He Qing of Hutou Mountain. As he prepared to depart, he recalled Yang Fang’s divination—though not entirely fulfilled, it seemed ominously accurate. Zhengzhou lay precisely in the Ghost Gate of the northeast, and his new role as Military Commissioner entailed commanding troops. At his audience before departure, he recounted these events to the emperor, then set out for Hutou Mountain to apprehend He Qing. En route, he was ambushed at night. His forces scattered, and in the darkness, Chen fled on horseback—until the beast stumbled, casting him into a deep moat. As he awaited his end, he felt as though a long-haired spirit had seized both him and his horse, lifting them to the bank. Regaining his bearings, he rejoined his troops.

The next day, they regrouped and advanced, slaying He Qing and his rebels. Chen returned to the capital, declining his post in Yezhou. From that day forth, he was stricken with terror, his mind unhinged, and he fell gravely ill. Later, he submitted a memorial, acknowledging Yang Fang’s divination and crediting the True Warrior’s protection for his deliverance. Thereupon, the emperor granted Yang Fang the promised favor and ordered Yuezhou to construct a True Warrior Hall outside the city. Chen Chou, at his own expense, sponsored a grand ritual feast at Qianming Abbey to repay the sagely favor.
