**The Soothsayer’s Warning**
Wang Zhong, retired Director of the Bureau of Imperial Carriages in Suzhou, was recalled to serve as Vice Minister of the Directorate of Education. Before departing, he sought a divination before the True Warrior in his family shrine and, receiving an auspicious sign, set forth. Along the Bian River embankment, he encountered a Daoist who merely bowed and introduced himself as a master of physiognomy. Wang invited him aboard his boat and offered tea.

*"Where does the reverend master reside?"* Wang asked.
*"I am a disciple of the Cloud Terrace Abbey on Mount Hua,"* the Daoist replied. *"My surname is Pei."*

Wang offered one hundred and twenty taels of silver for a reading. The Daoist observed, *"Your complexion is radiant—you will soon be promoted to a compilation post."*

*"I already serve as Vice Minister, which involves state compilation,"* Wang replied.

He then inquired about his future rank and longevity. The Daoist rose to leave, turning back to say, *"Remember this: in the future, do not accept any post in the Historiographer’s Pavilion, nor undertake matters in the *geng-xin* direction. If you do, you will die in hunger and snow, your bones left unburied."* With that, he departed eastward, refusing the silver.

Wang Yibiao dismissed the warning. Later, when unrest arose in the Western Regions, the entire court recommended Wang for a diplomatic mission. Though he had been appointed Vice Minister of the Directorate of Education, he was now temporarily elevated to Grand Master of the Palace with Purple Robe and concurrently appointed *Hanlin* Academician of the Celestial Chapters Pavilion. Overjoyed, he had forgotten the Daoist’s words.

Proceeding to the western frontier, he was feasted and questioned by the barbarian lord Li Wanquan, whose words carried veiled mockery, subjecting him to repeated humiliation. As he neared the border on his return, fearing the shame of reproach, he deceived his retinue and fled on horseback into Sheep Mountain, where he was buried by snow in a rocky cave, going ten days without food. Suddenly, the Daoist Pei reappeared, saying, *"I am no ordinary man—I am the Perfected Warrior whom you have long venerated. Had you heeded my instruction and refused the post of Grand Master of the Palace and Academician of the Celestial Chapters Pavilion, this fate might yet have been averted. The *geng-xin* direction is the western barbarian quarter, where you were destined to die of hunger in the snow—today, no less. What can be done now? I shall depart."* Wang, his regret too late, perished in Sheep Mountain, his bones left abandoned. His attendants, fleeing for their lives, returned to the capital, where the authorities interrogated them. Upon investigation and verification, it was confirmed that Wang Yibiao had not been officially dispatched as an envoy, and his failure was thus deemed predestined. Though the Perfected Warrior had protected him and clearly pointed out the path of delusion, he had obstinately refused to avoid it, and so forfeited his life. As for his prior temporary appointment as Grand Master of the Palace and concurrent Academician of the Celestial Chapters Pavilion, no posthumous revocation was issued. Instead, he was granted posthumous rank and emoluments in accordance with the standard protocol for officials of his grade, and his soul was summoned and interred with funeral rites.

Hu Qing of Xianping County in the Eastern Capital abandoned his trade. Hu Qing of Xianping County in the Eastern Capital had made his living selling prepared foods.

Upon the fifth day of the fifth month, as Hu Qing bound and slaughtered a parrot and a goose, his knife suddenly snapped in his hand. The creatures’ lives were spared, but the blade recoiled and gashed his palm, causing blood to gush forth. Recognizing that the wanton killing of fowl and beasts was unjust, Hu Qing abandoned his trade and set out for the capital to seek another livelihood.

Along the way, night fell, and a heavy rain began to pour. Seeking shelter, he took refuge in an ancient temple. Around the third watch, a divine figure clad in golden armor, brandishing a sword and with unbound hair, appeared and roused Hu Qing, saying: *"Know that countless wronged spirits of creatures follow at your side, and dare not enter this gate. You still have thirty years of celestial favor ahead—guard it well."* With these words, the figure trod upon a tortoise and serpent and ascended into the void.

Hu Qing awoke in alarm to find the sky clear and the moon bright. Turning back to the temple, he saw neither statues nor painted images—only a stele bearing the name *Shrine of the Perfected Warrior Who Guards the Realm*.

After more than a month in the capital, his meager funds were exhausted. Reflecting on the Perfected Warrior’s warning of thirty years of celestial favor, he reasoned that military service must be his destined path. He thus devoted himself to mastering martial arts. Within two years, when the imperial court held its grand military examination, he demonstrated unparalleled skill in archery, horsemanship, and the wielding of spear and staff. Among a thousand competitors, he was chosen by the emperor’s brush as first in rank. He was first granted the rank of Palace Attendant of the Third Class, then summoned before the throne. The emperor inquired as to what extraordinary guard he served and where he had honed his martial prowess to such excellence. Hu Qing truthfully recounted his encounter with the divine manifestation and the fulfillment of its prophecy.

Thereafter, he was promoted to Attendant of the Third Class with Duties, later serving long tours on the frontier. He rose to the rank of Workshop Commissioner and once held the post of Chief Military Inspector of Runzhou. For the remainder of his life, Hu Qing reverently tended the incense and flame of the Perfected Warrior.

Zhonghe Resigns Office.

In the eighth year of Tiansheng, Yang Zhonghe, a clerk from Xuzhou in Jingxi, was dispatched to Caizhou to investigate and adjudicate a case of judicial corruption. He sentenced Zhu Xijie to thirteen strokes of the cane. Later, when the supervising official, Vice Prefect Xu Yi, reviewed the case for performance evaluation and promotion, Zhonghe’s merits were deemed insufficient for reward. While in Xuzhou, he arranged a Daoist jiao ritual at Tianqing Abbey to secure divine assistance for his promotion. He invited the Daoist priest Pei Junsou to present a "blue-green memorial" to the Celestial Emperor. Junsou held the memorial in hand, prostrating to the left of the altar for nearly two hours before rising. He then told Xu Yi: "I have reverently delivered your petition to the Jade Emperor’s golden palace. Upon reaching the Gate of the Three Heavens, I encountered the North Pole Purple Tenuity Great Emperor, who was accompanied by the Perfected Warrior, Divine Marshal of the You-sheng Institute, Vice Judge of Good and Evil. The Perfected Warrior, upon seeing your memorial, deigned to speak: 'Xu Yi, while investigating the case of Qian Ju and others in Caizhou, concealed over two hundred thousand in family wealth, colluded with officials to pervert justice, and coerced a blood relative into adopting an alien surname. Yang Zhonghe, for this, falsely implicated the witness Zhu Xijie and unjustly subjected her to corporal punishment. Such grievous wrongs have barred his promotion. Now, his crimes and those of others have been determined, and I shall report them to the Jade Emperor. You are to deliver this memorial at once and return immediately.'"

Thereafter, when Xu Yi’s term ended and he departed, Yang Zhonghe resigned from officialdom and returned home, vowing to atone for his sins through virtuous deeds. He redeemed a sacred portrait of the Perfected Warrior, maintaining perpetual incense and vegetarian offerings, and daily invoked the Perfected Warrior’s sacred name. He welcomed monks and Daoists, as well as the destitute, into his home. When families lacked the means to bury their dead, Zhonghe would sell his possessions to provide funeral funds. Over time, his household declined; his wife fell ill and died. He then sold his youngest son to the household of Squire Li for six thousand coins, which he also distributed to others. Within the prefecture, he earned the reputation of a lay devotee. For twenty years, relying on the support of relatives and friends, he lived in a secluded alley, wholeheartedly devoted to the Perfected Warrior.

One day, a destitute Daoist priest visited and said: "You were once an official, and your sins remain unexpiated. Why have you repented, abandoned your home, and embraced poverty to serve the Perfected One without respite? Yet, your remorse has moved Heaven’s mercy. I possess a text that I entrust to you; propagate its teachings, and it may sustain you." With that, the priest vanished. Zhonghe opened the scroll to find the *Divine Stems of the Twelve Perfected Lords of Mount Xi*. He then prepared one hundred and twenty bamboo lots, storing them in a bamboo tube before the image of the Perfected Warrior. Within ten days, the local populace flocked to consult the oracle, whose responses proved divinely accurate. Each divination commanded a fee of thirty to fifty strings of cash, or at least one hundred coins. Even prefectural officials sought his counsel.

One day, Li Chengdao, the newly appointed Registrar of the Prefecture, sought out Yang Zhonghe, claiming to be his son, sold at the age of seven or eight to a neighbor, Li Fu. At thirteen, he had received an official appointment through the grace of his adoptive grandfather, Assistant Minister Li Zhongli. At nineteen, he passed the selection examination and was assigned to his current post. Learning that his birth family had perished, save for his father Yang Zhonghe, he sent men to search, only to be told that Zhonghe had recently died. All his belongings, aside from funeral expenses, had been confiscated by the authorities. Li Chengdao wept upon hearing this and commissioned rituals at temples and abbeys to offer prayers for his father’s soul.

One evening, as Li Chengdao sat alone in his study, an elderly Daoist appeared in midair and said: "I am your birth father, Yang Zhonghe. You have risen to honor; remain loyal and upright. I repented my sins and took refuge in the Perfected One, receiving the transmission of the *Divine Stems of the Twelve Perfected Lords of Mount Xi* to aid the suffering. My life has now ended. The Eastern Peak recorded my merits, declaring my heart and conduct upright, and appointed me Registrar of Lu Records at Maxi. The Perfected Warrior has further ordained that, upon fulfilling this duty, I shall be granted the office of the Seven Primes. Only one matter remains unresolved: the sacred portrait of the Perfected Warrior I once venerated, along with the divination tools and other items, were confiscated and now lie neglected in the military provisions depot. Retrieve them, enshrine them in your home, and honor them with sincerity; they will assist your virtuous endeavors." With that, he vanished.

Later, when the authorities auctioned the confiscated items, Chengdao redeemed them and enshrined them in his private chapel, offering daily devotion. One day, an imperial emissary, Yuan Liangbi, was dispatched by the court to present a golden dragon and jade tablet at Mount Xiantu in Wu-sheng Commandery as part of a grand jiao ritual for the Empress, who had long suffered from a heart ailment. Passing through Xuzhou, he and Prefectural Vice Governor Luo Zongmeng noticed a crimson glow enveloping a building in the southwest of the yamen. Upon inquiry, they were told that in the Registrar’s office, officials and commoners were burning incense before an old portrait of the Perfected Warrior and a tube of divination lots, the glow lingering unceasingly. Luo Zongmeng and Yuan Liangbi went to observe. Liangbi, testing the oracle’s intent, drew a lot and received the Tenth Auspicious Stem of Perfected Lord Zhong. He personally transcribed the response and memorialized the throne. The Empress Dowager, who had already dreamed of this, gradually recovered. The transcribed lot’s message aligned perfectly with her dream.

An imperial edict was issued to Xuzhou for verification. Li Chengdao was then pressured by Yu Fu, the Regional Judicial Commissioner, who used his authority to demand the Perfected Warrior’s portrait and associated items. Upon arrival at Fu’s residence, the painted silk crumbled into fragments, transforming into butterflies that fluttered into the sky. The bamboo lots, previously claimed by the court, now reside in the Baoying Pavilion of the imperial palace. Chengdao was granted imperial permission to resume his birth surname, Yang, and was promoted to Registrar of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices.

Still, Yang Zhonghe was posthumously enfeoffed as Lord Wuben of the Prefecture. No sooner had Yang Chengdao been promoted than he, too, passed away. Today, in Xuzhou, the ancestral shrine of Lord Yang and his son remains, where prayers are answered with signs.

**Auspicious Responses to a Pious Descendant**
Sun Liangsi, Left Attendant Gentleman of Jingnan Prefecture, devoted his life to the worship of the Perfected Warrior, his reverence profound and sincere, and often received the god’s favor. Observing the mundane world, he saw how many took lives, and each time he reflected: all are bound in the wheel of rebirth—how could one bear to do such a thing? Whenever he went to the market and saw creatures for sale, he would buy them, whether birds to be kept in cages or fish and turtles to be gathered in water vessels, and at dawn, before others had risen, he would release them. For fifteen years, Liangsi naturally attained understanding and awakened to principle; all his deeds were met with wondrous responses, and people called him Master Sun.

One day, he died without illness. His burial was divined to be on the southern slope of Mount Ji. When the grave was opened, a flock of crows carried mud in their beaks. As the earth was piled, a pool of water welled up from the pit, and fish and turtles emerged within it; lingzhi mushrooms grew like canopies upon the ground. As the inner coffin was lowered, five-colored auspicious clouds enveloped the site in all directions. Monks, Daoist priests, and officials of Jingnan Prefecture gathered at the grave, offering incense, flowers, food, and performing conch-and-cymbal rituals.

At the ancestral offering, Prefectural Remonstrance Grand Master Zhang Tinglao, himself a devotee of the Dao and the Perfected Warrior, walked to the graveside. There, a small opening appeared, from which a tortoise and serpent emerged, coiling and leaping in joy. Thus it was known that Master Sun had ultimately become an attendant of the Perfected Warrior of the Northern Culmen. The numinous creatures lingered for a time before vanishing of their own accord.

Since the prefecture had witnessed such a remarkable person and manifold auspicious signs, it was fitting to memorialize the throne. Subsequently, an edict from the Secretariat ordered that a temple be built at Master Sun’s grave, a stele erected to record his holy responses and deeds, and the temple bestowed the name "Shrine of Lord Sun." Thus concludes *Record of the Divine Manifestations of the Dark Heaven Thearch*, Scroll Seven.

*Record of the Divine Manifestations of the Dark Heaven Thearch*, Scroll Eight.

In Yuan’s era of awakened transformation, the annual custom of Tanzhou required households to contribute funds for the establishment of release-life societies on the third day of the third month, the eighth day of the fourth month, the sixth day of the sixth month, and the eighteenth day of the eighth month. On the third day of the third month in the first year of Kangding, coinciding with the birthday of the Perfected Warrior, living creatures—fowl and aquatic life—were purchased in advance and kept in cages and vessels. On the appointed day at Xiangfu Abbey, they were paraded through the markets and brought to the great river, where hymns were chanted as the creatures, both winged and finned, were set free. Some, once released, plummeted from the sky, while others floated belly-up on the water. The society members, with the help of attendants, retrieved them one by one for inspection. The birds bore wounds—some ensnared in glue nets or withered traps, others struck by arrows or slingshots. The aquatic creatures, caught by hooks, seines, or woven baskets, had their scales, heads, or tails broken and torn. The crowd was filled with sorrow. After the rites concluded, the creatures were dispersed to quiet, secluded outskirts, where they would no longer be seen by the eyes of city-dwellers.

The society members returned to the abbey for the feast, where the presiding Daoist, Zhou Yuanyan, ascended the hall and expounded the *Scripture of True Warrior* once through. During the assembly, a wandering Daoist suddenly arose and addressed Zhou Yuanyan: "Fortunate to address this gathering of the four seas, I humbly request your instruction on the karmic causes of this rite, that all may attain understanding and awakening."

Yuanyan replied: "In Tanzhou, there are four such assemblies each year. Today’s is held in honor of the birthday of the Divine Responsive True Lord of True Warrior. The others are: the eighth day of the fourth month, the birthday of Śākyamuni Buddha; the sixth day of the sixth month, the birthday of the Lord of Destiny of Mount Tai of the Eastern Peak; and the eighteenth day of the eighth month, the festival of the Dragon Lords and Divine Mother of the Four Seas and Nine Rivers, when the aquatic creatures are tallied. On each occasion, birds and fish are purchased alive, released from cages into the water—this is called a *fangsheng* assembly."

The wandering Daoist pressed: "It is not *fangsheng*—it is deliberate killing, deceitful killing, ignorant killing, and greedy killing."

Yuanyan asked: "What do you mean?"

The Daoist answered: "If it were not killing, why do those released today neither fly nor leap? Birds are born in forests and wilds, while fish, turtles, clams, and mussels thrive in rivers and lakes. These creatures of land and water share the same nature as humans. Those destined to die repay their debts in kitchens and cauldrons—such is their fate. But because of these assemblies, countless lives are wrongfully taken. The ignorant, heedless of sin, pursue profit by any means, trapping day and night. Starving and desperate, ten thousand perish for every ten spared, and ten die for every one that lives. Those that survive are all wounded—this is deliberate, deceitful, greedy, and ignorant killing. Year after year, this is nothing but the accumulation of karma. How can it be called *transforming life*? Moreover, True Warrior is the upright and impartial celestial deity of the Northern Culmen, governing the world’s blessings. Would he accept offerings of private slaughter?"

Yuanyan had no reply. He descended from his seat, bowed to detain the Daoist, and sought his name, but the figure had vanished without a trace. Then, before their eyes, the creatures that had failed to flee transformed within their cages and vessels, each emitting a white light that ascended into the sky. The assembly witnessed this and knew it was True Warrior, moved by compassion for living beings, manifesting to teach and admonish them against killing. From that day, Tanzhou abolished the *fangsheng* assemblies and replaced them with almsgiving to the poor. Prefect Chen Xiang memorialized the court, and by imperial decree, the matter was verified and submitted to the authorities. An edict was issued, condemning *fangsheng* as harmful and futile, and printed copies were distributed to officials, abbeys, and monasteries for observance.

**Wang Gun Burns Turtles**
In Suzhou, there was a Vice Director of the Ministry of Justice named Wang Gun, who was appointed magistrate of Wuhu County in Taiping Prefecture. Stubborn and gluttonous, he relished rare delicacies. He would burn live turtles with fire to extract their flesh, then cook it in porcelain vessels. His eldest son, Wang Changxiu, repeatedly pleaded with his mother to admonish his father against this, but Gun remained obstinate.

One day, it happened to be the third day of the third month, when the *fangsheng* society gathered in the county to parade and present paper offerings at Zhaoyuan Abbey. Changxiu went to observe and asked the abbey’s presiding Daoist, Cheng Zijian: "I often see *fangsheng* societies gather at temples on the eighth day of the fourth month. Why do they come to a Daoist abbey on the third day of the third month?"

Zijian replied: "The third day of the third month is the birthday of True Warrior. The devout gather on this day to make proper offerings and release carp, turtles, and freshwater clams—these are the very creatures True Warrior most abhors. Carp belong to the northern *gui* transformation; at night, they face north and bear seven spots on their heads. Turtles resemble divine tortoises, and clams are akin to sacred serpents. Releasing these three creatures signifies a heart free of harm, repenting sins, dispelling calamities, and seeking blessings and protection."

Changxiu returned home and recounted this to his mother, who relayed it to his father. But Gun, ever obstinate, refused to heed their counsel.

Longxiu secretly sought from Daoist Master Cheng a portrait of True Warrior, along with transmitted taboos and prohibitions for his veneration, and returned home to set aside a separate chamber with his mother and wife’s elder brother to make offerings. As the years passed, Wang Gun was promoted to Director of the Bureau of Carriages and appointed to oversee Xingzhou, departing alone for his post.

Nearing the halfway point of his journey, a Daoist appeared before his horse and said: "Are you not Director Wang Gun, bound for Xingzhou? That place is precisely where you will forfeit your life." Before Gun could question further, the Daoist vanished without a trace.

Upon arriving in Xingzhou, Gun longed for turtle and fish in his kitchen. But as Xingzhou did not produce such creatures, he grew furious with his attendants, beating them mercilessly. Soon after, he fell ill, his condition worsening until no medicine could cure him. One night, he cried out in agony, claiming countless shelled water spirits, bearing grievances, had surrounded him to demand his life. His throat burned, his breath grew ragged, his limbs ached, and he could neither sit nor lie down, with no escape between life and death.

In his anguish, he suddenly felt something bite the fingers of his right hand, the pain unbearable. He cried out "True Warrior, Perfected Lord!" and felt his choked breath ease, his chest clear, and his breathing slowly return. After a long while, his qi settled, and he said: "Gun’s nature has always been stubborn and unyielding. From childhood, I relished the taste of roasted turtle meat, ignoring my wife’s elder brother’s warnings and failing to honor True Warrior. Later, I received this appointment, and midway, a Daoist told me my destination was where I would lose my life. Foolish and obstinate, I did not heed the warning and now suffer this torment. In my delirium, I called out repeatedly to the Perfected Lord for salvation."

Suddenly, he found himself on a mountain, standing before True Warrior. Rows of wronged creatures—those he had roasted and eaten—lined up, bearing grievances and demanding his life. True Warrior pointed at Gun and said: "You recklessly took lives to satisfy your appetite. Your accusers, the karmic ghosts, will never release you. The Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water have investigated and found you guilty, reducing your lifespan by twenty years. You were fated to die in Xingzhou. However, your wife and children have practiced austerities, maintained devotion, and made offerings to me. Morning and night, they have vowed repentance, all for your sake—because of the lives you took and consumed. I have petitioned the Three Officials on your behalf, allowing your accusers to be reborn in the water realm, freeing you from their claims. I have also memorialized to restore your lifespan as before."

The moment True Warrior granted this revelation, Gun’s suffering vanished. He later reported these events to the court and requested retirement. He vowed to abstain from killing, to uphold the香火, to recite the *Wondrous Sutra of True Warrior* one hundred thousand times, and to copy and donate the Daoist Canon to the Taiqing Yanfu Abbey in the Eastern Capital.

**Hua’s Slaughter of Fish**

Cheng Sichang of Xinghua Prefecture began as a merchant in his youth. Proud and hot-tempered, he scorned the "Two Treasures" (the pestle and mortar, symbolizing labor) and distanced himself from his hometown friends, earning their disdain. In his business dealings, he never cheated on weights or measures, nor did he shortchange others. He paid no mind to bargaining or assessing goods, nor did he delight in fine cooking, and he rarely ate living creatures.

Once, while staying in the western outskirts of Banqiao in Mizhou, he noticed that the locals consumed vast numbers of pigeons, turtledoves, magpies, and other birds daily, slaughtered in the streets. During a walk in the countryside, he saw people carrying hawks, wielding bows and slingshots, or setting nets—sights he could not bear to witness. Returning to the city, on a quiet night under the stars, he resolved to adopt a vegetarian diet. He commissioned artisans to carve woodblocks and printed a thousand copies of the *Illustrated Precepts Against Killing*, distributing them widely.

On the seventh day of the tenth month, True Warrior descended, and through his sacred power, he inspired a universal change of heart. A tax collector named Peng Jing, known for his love of meat and wine, received a copy. Upon returning home, he read it to his wife, Hua Sanniang, who grew furious, tore the booklet apart, and cast it into filth.

The next day, Hua bought a black fish. As she raised the cleaver, her hands were suddenly restrained as if held by an unseen force. The fish leapt up, its tail stabbing her eye like a blade. Blood dripped onto the ground, transforming into ants that swarmed up the table and bit her face. The incident spread through the market, and all knew it was retribution for her disrespect of the *Illustrated Precepts Against Killing*.

One day, Peng Jing, drunk, encountered Sichang in the marketplace and hurled abuse at him: "Banqiao has always lived in peace without your meddling. You, an outsider from Xinghua, spread these texts and ruined my wife’s eye!" He lunged at Sichang, intending to cause a scene. Sichang fled and, upon returning to his room, reflected on his remorse.

At that time, the garrison commander Xiang Shu and the patrol inspector Xuan Dan were gathered in the hall when they saw Sichang’s feet hovering three inches above the ground as he floated through the air. He stood before the hall, speaking in a possessed voice: *"I am the Perfected Warrior Lord. Xiang Shu and the others swiftly prepared incense and prostrated themselves, whereupon they received this revelation: ‘I see that the people of this land have for kalpas delighted in consuming winged creatures, their karmic obstructions profound. There is one, Cheng Sichang of Xinghua, who prints and distributes the* Illustrated Precepts Against Killing—*this is the highest good deed. Yet Hua Sanniang refused to believe and accept it; for killing a black fish, she instead harmed her own eye. Not only she but all who take life without awakening to their karmic bonds shall not escape calamity.’*

Sichang then vanished in a daze, his form and shadow gone. As they were investigating the matter, a report suddenly arrived from the town: the traveler Cheng Sichang had died without illness. The garrison commander and others heard this and sighed in astonishment. Hua Sanniang’s eye affliction lingered for half a year before she finally perished. Xiang Shu and Xuan Dan, upon returning to the capital after their terms ended, had the account of these events carved onto printing blocks and distributed to exhort people against killing. For the rest of their lives, they revered the incense offerings to the Perfected Warrior, ensuring the tale reached the sagely ears of the emperor. By imperial decree, the matter was entrusted to the relevant authorities, and it was recorded in *The Miraculous Efficacy of the Perfected Warrior*:

*Three Origins, one divine spirit,*
*Responsive through ten gates.*
*Majestic, radiant, and auspicious,*
*All true, all banishing harm.*

**The Śarīra of the Zhu Clan**

In Yuanzhou, there was a palace attendant of the left guard, Zhu Lianggong, who served as a tax supervisor in Junzhou. After a year in office, he died, leaving behind a poor household with no sons—only a daughter who, with her mother, escorted his coffin home. Before a year had passed, the mother also died. The family had long worshipped the Perfected Warrior, and the daughter, Zhu, paid no heed when neighbors sought matches for her. The neighbors, however, slandered her with accusations of impropriety. Zhu then swore before the Perfected Warrior that she would never marry, vowing to suffer a disability to sever all external pursuits. At forty, she suddenly went blind in both eyes and refused to seek medical treatment, after which no one proposed marriage. She died on the ninth day of the ninth month in the sixth year of Tiansheng.

With no surviving kin, the authorities were obliged to inspect the body. In Yuanzhou, Judicial Officer Zhao Ping was assigned to verify the case. When they attempted to examine Zhu’s corpse, it was shielded from view—before it lay a black tortoise, and behind it coiled a crimson serpent, both guarding her remains. Prefect He Jue and Vice-Prefect Wang Yaochen, who witnessed this marvel in person, summoned Buddhist monks and Daoist priests to pray and beseech the creatures to withdraw, so that the body might be properly encoffined. The tortoise and serpent vanished at once. The officials then ordered the neighbors to purchase a coffin and prepare her for burial.

Upon questioning the servant girl Chen Juxiang, they learned that Zhu had been pressured by suitors and, when she refused, slandered with accusations of impropriety. This had driven her to swear before the Perfected Warrior that she would never marry, vowing to bear a disability to sever all worldly ties. Daily she had prayed, and the Perfected Warrior had descended in spirit to watch over her. After losing her sight, she soon died without illness, her flesh and complexion unchanged from life. At her final hour, she had only said, “Cremate my body in the north, toward the *ren-gui* direction.”

Prefect He, upon careful consideration, noted that the ninth day of the ninth month was precisely the day the Perfected Warrior descended. Zhu’s sudden death, the tortoise and serpent guarding her, and her request for cremation in the *ren-gui* direction—all were to be obeyed. As soon as the fire was lit, her form ascended into the clouds, where she addressed the crowd: “I shall not enter the Six Paths but will be reborn in the household of Liu Ji in Yizhou. Before twenty years have passed, remember: there will be a Liu son whose name will spread across the land. If anyone still slanders me as unchaste, let them burn my remains in fire—only then will the truth be known.” With that, she departed.

After the fire had consumed her bones, five-colored, indestructible *śarīra* relics appeared, radiant with light. The crowd all sought to receive and venerate them. Those who had previously spread slander and defamation now suffered from mouth ulcers, hemorrhoids, and festering sores, their bodies reeking with pus and filth. Each came to the Perfected Warrior’s hall to repent and confess their sins, gradually finding relief and healing. Households in Yuanzhou warned one another against careless speech and false accusations, and they took up the practice of burning incense before the Perfected Warrior. The prefect memorialized the court, which in turn decreed an investigation in Yizhou. It was confirmed that on the ninth day of the ninth month at the hour of *chou*, the wife of Liu Ji, *yuanwailang* of the Bureau of Military Fields, had indeed given birth to a son—no falsehood was found. Following the imperial secretariat’s directive, the prefecture allocated official funds to hold a grand *jiao* ritual at the Perfected Warrior’s hall in Tianqing Abbey. A temporary shrine was also erected at the original site of her cremation in the north, to be preserved for future verification and further action.

**Lord Liang’s Hairpin**

In Cizhou, there was a female Daoist priest of the Qingquan Abbey, which stood within the city walls. Her precepts were pure, and her cultivation sincere. The people of Cizhou held her in deep reverence, and her abbey maintained ties with Tianqing Abbey. Whenever the people of Cizhou held *jiao* feasts, scripture recitations, or other ritual affairs, they would invite the female priests of Qingquan Abbey. However, the Daoist priests of Tianqing Abbey grew envious. They bribed a gang of ruffians to blockade the abbey gates daily, disrupting and harassing anyone who came to request their services, while also spreading slanderous rumors. As a result, fewer and fewer people came to invite them.

Among the female priests was Liang Jizhen, aged seventeen, who had received the Register of the Northern Dipper and maintained a devout practice that yielded spiritual responses. Day and night, she burned incense before the image of the Perfected Warrior, weeping as she pleaded for swift karmic retribution.

Soon after, Huang Mian, newly appointed *yuanwailang* of the Ministry of Justice and magistrate of Cizhou, was traveling to assume his post. As he neared the city, he spent the night at the post station in Pingyuan Town. In a dream, he saw a man clad in a purple robe with a golden belt, who declared, “I am the Record-Keeper of the Northern Dipper Hall at Qingquan Abbey. I have observed that the officials assisting the magistrate of Cizhou are inexperienced and only seek to deceive and distort. For instance, the female priests of Qingquan Abbey are being slandered and obstructed by the Daoist priests of Tianqing Abbey, cutting them off from their patrons. When you take office, you must rectify this injustice.”

Huang Mian awoke with a start and recorded the dream. Over two months into his tenure, he happened to pass by Qingquan Abbey and entered the Northern Dipper Hall. There, he recognized the face of the purple-robed official as the man from his dream. Returning to his yamen, he ordered the military patrol to investigate the matter involving Qingquan Abbey, setting a deadline of half a month to produce a report.

As the deadline approached, a group of over sixty villagers, following their annual custom, came to Qingquan Abbey to hold a *jiao* ritual for safeguarding fields and silkworms. That night, a mob of vagabonds gathered, driving the villagers away. The military patrol apprehended fourteen of them, including Zhuang Huasan and others, and brought them in for interrogation. After summoning twenty-six Daoist priests from Tianqing Abbey, including Chen Youzhang, for questioning, the prefectural authorities meted out appropriate punishments. The ringleaders, Chen Youzhang and Zhuang Huasan, were to be exiled pending imperial review.

That night, Huang Mian dreamed again of the Record-Keeper, who told him, “Tianqing Abbey also venerates the incense of the Four Saints of the Northern Dipper. If Youzhang is exiled, it will bring disgrace upon our teaching. There is no need to memorialize the court.” Huang Mian then ordered the case closed, releasing Chen Youzhang, while Zhuang Huasan was exiled to another prefecture.

Not long after, Liang Jizhen fell ill with festering sores and died, her body reeking of decay. She was buried in an official plot outside the eastern gate. Half a year later, as Vice-Magistrate Su Yingzhi left the city to inspect saltworks, he was assailed by a foul stench. The locals informed him that Liang Jizhen of Qingquan Abbey was buried there. Su Yingzhi immediately summoned the abbess of Qingquan Abbey, Yao Jichong, and others to relocate the remains to a secluded spot. When they opened the grave, they found the coffin lid floating above the ground, with no body inside—only a hairpin and a red serpent and green turtle. The stench had transformed into an extraordinary fragrance. Su Yingzhi burned incense and bowed in reverence, then took the serpent and turtle to present to Huang Mian.

Upon investigation, it was revealed that during her life, Liang had reverently cultivated the incense of the Perfected Warrior, thus attaining the Dao of *shijie* and manifesting the wondrous signs of the serpent and turtle. It was deemed fitting to enshrine them in the Perfected Warrior’s hall at Qingquan Abbey. However, three times they were placed inside the hall, and three times they coiled their way back out, their mouths agape as if threatening harm. Huang Mian then burned incense and prayed, asking if they required additional incense offerings or a separate hall, to be established upon memorializing the court. The serpent and turtle then circled back into the hall, and with a gust of wind, they vanished.

The prefecture submitted a memorial, and the court subsequently issued a decree ordering the local officials to allocate funds from the tribute tax to construct a proper hall for the Perfected Warrior. A shrine was also built for Liang Jizhen, who was posthumously honored as the Perfected Master of Wondrous Transformation. Thereafter, the abbey flourished, and its teachings spread widely, as heaven and earth bore witness.

In the Guangnan Binzhou government offices, a malevolent spirit of a hidden corpse had long lingered, causing successive officials to refuse their appointments—either falling ill themselves or seeing their children die. During the Yongxi era, the Assistant Director of Ceremonial Affairs, Yang Congxin, had devoted his life to the Dao, inscribing talismans and registers to heal the sick and plague-stricken. He diligently tended the incense offerings to the Four Saints of the Northern Dipper, and each act bore spiritual response.

Just three days after assuming his post, his subordinates approached him, asking whether he would take his meals and lodging at Yanfu Monastery, for the prefectural offices were often inauspicious, and they feared some nocturnal disturbance might alarm his attendants. Confident in the protection of the Perfected Spirits, Yang instead chose to reside in the prefectural offices. He prepared fresh fruits, tea, wine, and pure water, and set up his personal icon of the Perfected Warrior for veneration.

When night fell, between the hours of *xu* and *hai*, he took a bolt of yellow silk twelve feet in length and, with cinnabar, inscribed upon it the *Talisman of the Six Ding Spirit Generals for Summoning the Soul*. He presented this before the Perfected Warrior in prayer. Once the rites were complete, he burned the talisman along with paper money as offerings. For seven days and nights, the prefectural offices remained undisturbed, and no one experienced fear or alarm.

By the tenth day, Yang still received no response. He earnestly beseeched the Perfected Warrior once more, praying for swift retribution. That night, at the second watch, he heard the windows and walls tremble as though buffeted by wind and rain. The lamps and candles all snuffed out, and flashes of lightning flickered before the scene finally stilled.

At the fifth watch, two *ke* past midnight, Yang heard someone knocking at his chamber door. He rose and peered cautiously, only to find the lamp before the Perfected Warrior’s icon burning as before. Before the altar stood a gaunt, disheveled woman, who rapped at the window and cried: *"Have pity on your sister—I am the daughter of Minister Zhang Chen of the Zhou dynasty, betrothed to Prefect Yao Wenji of Binzhou. This man favored his concubine, Fan Xiangchun, and together they strangled me with a silk sash, then buried my body beneath the floor of this very chamber. Soon after, Yao Wenji and his accomplices were sent to oversee repairs at Tong Pass. For their misdeeds, they were trampled to pieces by a herd of horses on the mountainside, their bones scattered beyond recovery. My soul has languished here, bound to my corpse, unable to escape. But now, thanks to your prayers to the Perfected Warrior, the Six Ding Spirit Generals, along with the City God and Earth Deity, have seized me and dragged me to Fengpiluo Mountain, where I am condemned to wander as a lowly ghost. I have come to plead my grievance, and through the Perfected Warrior’s compassion, I have been granted a prediction of rebirth among gods and men. Yet my remains still lie beneath the southern wall of this chamber, buried six feet deep. If they are exhumed, I may finally attain liberation. I beg you—be my advocate!"*

At daybreak, Yang ordered men to dig with shovels. Sure enough, they unearthed a complete skeleton, which they placed in a wooden coffin and interred at Yanfu Monastery. From that day forth, the prefectural offices knew peace.

Yang thereafter exhorted the people, urging them to reverently tend the incense fires of the Perfected Spirits to seek their protective blessings. He declared: *"Good and evil have no fixed gate—they are summoned by one’s own deeds. If one acts with impartiality and without deceit, Heaven and Earth bear witness. How then could demons dare to bring harm? For those who aspire to the Great Dao and honor Heaven and Earth, divine guardians attend their every step. What fear is there of malevolent spirits? Through devotion to the Perfected Warrior, one attains the true Dao, forever subduing all demons, welcoming auspicious omens, and ensuring peace within the household."*

The people of Binzhou all heeded his words with utmost reverence. Later, when Yang returned to the capital, he was appointed Inspector of the Imperial City and concurrently served as Commissioner of the Treasury. Once, while accompanying the emperor in sacrifices to the household deities, he presented this account. By imperial decree, the matter was referred to the relevant authorities for investigation. As Binzhou had no Daoist abbeys, the emperor ordered the Bureau of Transport to assess the site and, within five years, construct two abbeys, selecting Daoist priests to conduct rituals while the state provided funds for their upkeep. The abbeys were bestowed the names *Fusheng* and *Qianxi*, in honor of the divine favor thus acknowledged.

In the capital’s Xiangan County, there lived the Vice Minister of Revenue, Pei Zongmin, who had three sons: Yanxian, Yanxiu, and Yanhe, all of whom had received official rank through their father’s influence. Yanxian was cautious and reverent, diligently upholding the Daoist teachings, while Yanxiu and Yanhe were deceitful and crooked, showing no regard for Heaven and Earth. When the time came for them to register for official appointments and sit for the imperial examinations, only Yanxian visited the Zhenwu Hall of Chongfu Abbey, where he burned incense and prayed, beseeching protection for his brothers so that all might succeed in the examinations. He drew the fourth divination slip of the Yellow Perfected Lord, and upon interpreting its meaning, found it foretold misfortune and sorrow among brothers. He thus warned his brothers to conduct themselves with care, but Yanxiu and Yanhe instead reproached him, saying, “Why should we place our trust in clay statues and painted images?”

Later, when they sat for the examinations, Yanxiu and Yanhe failed, while Yanxian alone passed and was appointed Evaluator of the Supreme Court, serving as Assistant Magistrate of Mingzhou. Yanxiu was assigned to Binzhou and later promoted to the post of County Constable in Jiang County, while Yanhe was appointed Supervisor of Wine in Jinzhou. From then on, Yanxiu and Yanhe grew envious. Seeing their brother attain high rank, they railed against Heaven and Earth for their lack of impartiality, complaining that the examiners had not judged their abilities fairly, their hearts filled with resentment.

After Yanxian departed for his post in Mingzhou, not only did he cease his devotions, but when his two brothers set out for their own appointments, they took the family altar’s icons of the Three Pure Ones and the stellar deities and burned them before leaving. Yanxiu, upon arriving in Jiang County as Constable, had been in office for only two months when, while patrolling to suppress the pirate Meng Junsan and his band, he was captured. They spared his life but cut out the tip of his tongue before releasing him. Yanhe, upon taking up his post as Supervisor of Wine in Jinzhou, after two years was found to have embezzled four-tenths of the tax revenue. When the Surveillance Commission impeached him, an official was dispatched to investigate, but Yanhe feigned illness and death.

Yanxian, in Mingzhou, submitted a memorial to the throne, offering to resign his post and forfeit his salary to atone for his brothers’ transgressions. The court replied that he should await further instructions upon completing his term. Yanxian conducted himself with integrity, earning the praise of officials and commoners alike, and was unanimously recommended for promotion by the local authorities. Later, the Secretariat issued an order that upon Yanxian’s return to the capital after his term ended, he was to be presented to the emperor for an audience, though the imperial intention remained unclear.

When Yanxian was received at court, the emperor inquired about his background and whether he had any esoteric learning. Yanxian replied, “My ancestors have always revered the gods and the heavens, maintaining unbroken incense offerings, but I possess no esoteric learning.” The emperor then said, “Last year, on the ninth day of the ninth month, I dreamed that the Perfected Lord of Domestic Felicity from the Hall of Household Governance appeared to assist me, commending your name. He said you had rendered service to the state and always upheld loyalty and filial piety. He also mentioned that though your two brothers held official rank, they were men who would bring ruin to the state and their family. They were unworthy of their celestial appointments, and it was decreed that their names be stricken from the registers, cutting short their lives and emoluments. This was to demonstrate that Yanxian’s conduct aligned with the Dao, answering to the divine above and earning the unanimous recommendation of court officials below. As for Yanxiu and Yanhe, their recent misdeeds have provoked the gods to send down calamity. Whether one does good or evil, retribution is always manifest, serving as both warning and admonition.”

Yanxian was then promoted to Gentleman of the Palace and granted an imperial robe before being appointed Magistrate of Yuzhang County in Hongzhou.

**The Divine Well Discerns the Strange**

In Huaizhou, there were two brothers, Xie Jingyuan and Xie Jingxiu, who ran a tallow shop in Kaisheng. The elder brother was fond of gambling and dissipation, while the younger revered the family’s ancestral altar to Zhenwu. In all matters, he prayed for divine aid, and his prayers were never unanswered. Jingyuan, however, was addicted to drink and gambling, and his household gradually fell into ruin. Recalling his brother’s claims of the altar’s efficacy, he entreated Zhenwu, saying, “If I am to gamble with others and win their money, I must receive a favorable omen.” After several such invocations, he won one or two hundred strings of cash. Later, he sought another sign and departed with an auspicious omen, only to lose over a hundred thousand coins. Enraged, he returned home and tore down the entire Zhenwu Hall. Jingxiu later restored it.

As Jingyuan continued to lose at gambling, suffering one misfortune after another, his resentment grew. One day, while Jingxiu was in the capital on business, his brother destroyed the sacred hall, hacking the statue of Zhenwu to pieces with a knife and casting the fragments into a well. Three days later, Jingyuan suddenly broke out in sores and scabs, his body oozing pus and blood, leaving him neither dead nor alive. Meanwhile, in the capital, Jingxiu dreamed of a barefoot boy with disheveled hair, his entire body yellow, wearing a stone tray on his head. The boy wept and cried out, “My limbs are wounded, the pain unbearable!” Upon closer inspection, Jingxiu saw that the boy was made of several broken pieces of blackened wood. Startled awake, he realized that the family’s Zhenwu altar must have been desecrated.

Upon returning to Huaizhou, Jingxiu saw that the family hall had indeed been destroyed, and his brother lay gravely ill with festering sores. He hired craftsmen to rebuild the hall and retrieved the wooden fragments of Zhenwu from the well, piecing them back together into a whole. Unexpectedly, the water drawn from this well was amber in hue, exuding an extraordinary fragrance unlike any other, and word of its wonder spread throughout the prefecture.

At the time, Magistrate Ma Xun of the Historiography Bureau heard of this marvel. That very day, he led his officials to Jingxiu’s home, where they had the water drawn and examined its unusual scent. After hearing the full account of Jingyuan’s karmic retribution and his affliction with foul sores, Ma Xun ordered a cup of the well water to be drawn for Jingxiu to drink. As soon as he finished, clouds and mist gathered on all sides. Jingxiu was seen standing in midair, enveloped in auspicious clouds, with cranes leading the way. He bowed in gratitude to Ma Xun and bid farewell to the crowd, declaring, “Today I behold the Golden Gates and ascend in broad daylight.”

Ma Xun submitted a detailed memorial, and by imperial decree, Huaizhou was ordered to construct an official residence to exchange for Jingxiu’s property, including the well and its foundation. The funds saved were used to build a temple in honor of Jingxiu’s ascension, named the *Temple of the Ascended Perfected One*, complete with halls to enshrine the sacred well. Drawing water was henceforth forbidden, except for healing the sick when requested by the people. The temple was granted the imperial plaque *Temple of the Sacred Well*, and annual allocations of imperial grace were bestowed for its upkeep.

Two novice Daoist acolytes were assigned to tend the temple, and imperial grants of farmland, housing, and funds were bestowed to serve as its permanent endowment. Jingxiu’s sole surviving elder brother and sister-in-law were entrusted to Jing Yuan for lifelong care. Thereafter, the family prospered, with one son passing the imperial examinations—later generations would witness even more extraordinary events.

**The Retribution of Jiao Lake**

Among the people of Chaozhou in Huaixi, regardless of wealth or poverty, all indulged in devouring giant turtles, heedless of the foul stench, thereby offending the celestial courts. The sun and moon grew dim, and the stars lost their luster. The Nine Heavens’ Investigative Envoys conducted their inspection and submitted a memorial, moving the Jade Emperor to command the North Polar Purple Tenuity Emperor, along with the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water and the Sacred Mountain Deities, to interrogate the people of Chaozhou regarding their accumulated sins and the retribution they were to receive.

The North Polar Emperor memorialized: “This land has long indulged in wanton slaughter, and the wronged spirits of aquatic creatures cling to their grievances. Since repayment is due, the entire region must be eradicated to resolve their grievances.”

The Jade Emperor declared to the North Polar Emperor: “The evil amassed by these beings is truly intolerable. Only by submerging the entire city and transforming it into a vast lake can purity be restored.”

Thereupon, the North Emperor issued a decree to Zhenwu: “As the roving inspector of the Three Realms, recording the good and evil of mortals and determining their blessings or punishments, you must be aware that the people of Chaozhou, for kalpas uncounted, have delighted in slaughtering dragons and giant turtles, thereby offending the Jade Emperor’s sacred excursions. Their crimes are unforgivable. Command this entire prefecture to be drowned and turned into a watery expanse. You shall carry this out with all haste.”

Zhenwu memorialized the North Emperor: “Though the people of Chaozhou bear grave sins, not all have partaken in the slaughter of aquatic life. If the land is summarily submerged, many innocent souls will suffer unjustly. Allow me to investigate and proceed in due order.”

Zhenwu then dispatched his celestial officers and divine generals, who transformed into a colossal turtle and floated upon the waters of Chao Creek, blocking the city’s bridges and markets. The prefectural magistrate sent officials to butcher the beast, distributing its meat to the local administrators. Soon after, the people of Chaozhou all partook of the flesh.

The Celestial Stalwarts reported back to Zhenwu: “The very earth of Chaozhou is fated to be transformed into a vast lake.” Even as the people were turned into great fish, their corpses floated in the shallows, yet none rejected the foulness—all devoured the flesh without discrimination.

Zhenwu sighed: “The sins of these beings run too deep; they cannot be saved.” He then transformed into a wandering Daoist priest and descended to Chaozhou, seeking pure water for alms. For seven days, he traversed the city, but every household’s bowls and vessels reeked of filth, leaving not a single clean place. At last, in a narrow alley, he came upon an old woman and once more begged for water. The crone filled a bowl and offered it to him.

He then asked the crone her surname and livelihood. The woman replied: “My surname is Jiao. Originally from the land of Wu, I have lived here for over twenty years, making my living by selling rice-flour foods. My household consists of a son, his wife, and myself—three in all.”

The Daoist priest inquired: “Why is the water in your bowl not foul?” The crone answered: “Since arriving in Chaozhou, I have witnessed the people’s cruelty and this land’s malevolence—every household slaughters aquatic creatures, heedless of sin or blessing. I have forbidden killing and partaken only of vegetarian fare, so my water and bowl remain pure.”

The Daoist declared: “I am no ordinary man, but a celestial deity. Moved by your virtuous deeds, I have come to deliver you. Soon, Chaozhou will be engulfed by a great flood. Take your son and flee at once. As you have not yet reaped the fruits of your actions, I grant you one of three boons: first, that your descendants may hold office and enjoy stipends; second, that you may instantly attain wealth and glory; third, that you may forever receive offerings and reverence. Choose as you will.”

The crone bowed and said: “How dare I seek excessive wealth or rank? If only the incense at my hearth may burn without end, that alone is my wish.”

The Perfected Lord replied: “From this day forward, go each morning and evening to the side of the prefectural yamen and observe the stone tortoise beneath the stele. When you see both its eyes turn red, take your son and daughter-in-law and flee through the southern gate. When you reach Mount Sacred Maiden, stop there.” With these words, the Perfected Lord transformed into a beam of white light and vanished.

From then on, Madam Jiao went daily to the prefectural yamen to inspect the stone tortoise’s eyes. After nearly a month, people began to call her mad, and in jest, some daubed the tortoise’s eyes with red pigment. Seeing the eyes crimson, Madam Jiao gathered her son and daughter-in-law and rushed out the southern gate. After ten *li*, they came to a mountain called Sacred Maiden. Ascending the slope, she turned to look back—Chaozhou was already swallowed by surging floodwaters, vast and boundless.

Suddenly, amidst the clouds, she beheld a divine figure—hair unbound, feet bare, clad in a dusky robe—his form identical to the Daoist who had begged for water. He called out: “Madam Jiao, these waters shall be under your care, that the incense smoke may never cease.” With these parting words, he vanished from sight.

Madam Jiao then bade her son gather thatch to build a shelter, and she forgot all about sleep and food.

During the Jin dynasty, upon hearing of the inundation of Chaozhou, officials were dispatched to investigate, but none in the surrounding regions could ascertain the cause. Gazing toward Sacred Maiden Mountain, they saw but a single household. The officials ascended the slope and came before Madam Jiao, inquiring into the matter, which they then reported in full. First, they provided Madam Jiao with provisions for sustenance, ordering neighboring prefectures to deliver supplies without delay. Before long, Madam Jiao, along with her son and daughter-in-law, passed away in succession.

The imperial court erected a temple in her honor, bestowing upon her the title *Lingxian Shengmu* ("Numinous and Manifest Holy Mother"), and decreed that the waters henceforth bear her surname, calling them Jiaohu ("Jiao Lake"). With waterways now traversed by boats and barges, offerings and prayers to her have never ceased, and none have failed to receive her efficacious response. Today, the lake falls under the jurisdiction of Wuwei Commandery in Huaixi Circuit, Chao County, its waters connecting the transport routes of Lu, Shou, Shu, and He prefectures.

Upon careful examination, the retribution for good and evil is starkly evident. Chaozhou, once spanning over two hundred *li* in circumference, was engulfed by the floodwaters, its former name *Chaoyuan* now replaced by *Jiaohu*, with only Sacred Maiden Mountain remaining at its center. Madam Jiao was specially enfeoffed as *Lingxian Shengmu*. Later, when winds and waves arose, capsizing boats and drowning travelers, officials and common folk could only beseech the Holy Mother’s grace, yet the storms grew ever more fierce.

An elderly female physician in Xijin City submitted a memorial, claiming to be a descendant of Jiaohu’s original settlers. Witnessing the lake’s winds and waves claim lives and vessels, she lamented that the authorities sought only the Holy Mother’s intercession, unaware that the Holy Mother herself had once been an ordinary mortal. Having observed the precepts, abstained from killing, and eaten only vegetables, she encountered Zhenwu, to whom she offered pure water, and was thus elevated as the local earth deity of Chaozhou’s waters. Though the state renamed the lake *Jiaohu* and honored her as *Lingxian Shengmu*, bestowing upon her the grace of Heaven and Earth, she had yet to repay this debt—how then could she stir up winds and waves to harm others? The truth was that the drowned souls of Chaozhou’s former inhabitants, along with the vengeful spirits of aquatic creatures, remained bound in unresolved grievance, perpetuating their enmity. Thus, they conjured malevolent winds and vicious waves, capsizing boats and exacting retribution in turn. To quell this, only Zhenwu could intervene.

As she finished speaking, she vanished from sight.

Upon reviewing the petition submitted during the Jin dynasty, it was revealed that the elderly woman was none other than the local earth deity of Jiaohu, the incarnate form of Lingxian Shengmu. The court was urged to act swiftly: dispatch envoys and Daoist priests to the Lingxian Temple to establish a ritual altar, offer imperial incense, and implore Zhenwu to beseech the cessation of winds and waves, ensuring safe passage for all. After a month-long ritual, the storms on Jiaohu abruptly subsided. As the envoys prepared to depart, a talismanic messenger suddenly appeared amidst the clouds and mist, declaring: *"I am the Direct Talisman Officer of the Middle Realm, sent by General Zhenwu to report to the court. The waves of Jiaohu arose from the unresolved vengeance of Chaozhou’s slain inhabitants and the grievances of the aquatic creatures, their enmity unbroken, thus spawning calamity. Now that the court has prayed for peace, Zhenwu has petitioned the North Pole Star Lord, and through the audience with the Three Clarities, the Jade Emperor has issued his decree. Auspicious sweet dew has descended, dissolving the knots of the vengeful spirits and aquatic beings of Jiaohu. They have been sent to the Eastern Peak’s Tai Mountain Prefecture and the underworld’s nether bureaus, where their names are recorded, their deeds weighed, and their debts repaid before rebirth. Jiaohu is now at peace."* The talismanic messenger then withdrew.

The Jin court once more dispatched envoys to offer incense and conduct rituals on Sacred Maiden Mountain, giving thanks to Heaven and Earth. There, they erected a Zhenwu Hall, bestowing upon it an imperial plaque, and further honored Lingxian with the title *Shunsheng* ("Obedient and Sagely"). *Vain wealth turned to gravel...*

At the Mingyang Palace in Shaozhou, there lay a grotto heaven known as the Azure Net Blessed Land, where the immortal Zhang Yue once cultivated the Dao. Each year on the fifth day of the fifth month at noon, multicolored birds would gather before the grotto, dancing and clamoring in flight—people claimed they were avian attendants accompanying the phoenix’s arrival. Thus, a "Scattered Birds Vegetarian Feast" was held, where offerings of money and paper horses were prepared in this name to repent before the stellar deities of the heavens. The burned paper offerings accumulated in the celestial treasury, unclaimed and unrecorded, until the North Pole Purple Tenuity Great Emperor questioned the Four Sacred Generals before his hall.

Zhenwu stepped forward and reported: *"These are not offerings the celestial treasury should accept. They are fraudulent claims from the Mingyang Palace in Shaozhou, who falsely assert the arrival of phoenixes to deceive the celestial court."* The Emperor then asked: *"If the Mingyang Palace’s offerings on the fifth day of the fifth month are false, why do the birds gather there on that day?"* Zhenwu replied: *"At noon on that day, I descend to that place, and the birds flock to receive my qi of the Dao, dissolving their karmic burdens of past lives in feathered form. Thus, they dance and cry out in joy before departing."*

The Emperor inquired: *"What use does the celestial treasury have for these unclaimed paper horses?"* Zhenwu proposed: *"A decree may be issued to the Eastern Peak, where they can be stored for future use. By next year, no one will burn such offerings."* The following year, the Mingyang Palace held the feast again, and people from afar gathered before the grotto. Yet as the hours passed beyond *shen* and *you*, not a single wing stirred.

Suddenly, a Daoist with unbound hair stood motionless, pointing at the palace gate. When summoned, he declared: *"This year, the birds will not gather for the assembly—it shall be abolished forever."* He further instructed the previous matters be heeded: the palace should, on the fifth day of the fifth month at noon, burn incense before the grotto and pray to the Perfected Lord Zhenwu to dissolve the accumulated sins of past years—vain offerings, wasted wealth, and the offense of deceiving the celestial treasury. *"If you doubt this,"* he said, *"wait three years for retribution."* The Daoist then rose and entered the Azure Nether Grotto, never to emerge from the palace gates.

The following year, the assembly was held again, yet no birds arrived. By the third year, as paper offerings were being burned, a fierce wind whipped the flames into a blaze that spread from the storehouse, consuming the palace in roughly two hours, reducing the halls to rubble. The prefecture recorded the case, and Abbot Daoist Zhang Anxiang was interrogated. He confessed to defying the imperial decree, bringing divine fire upon the palace. The matter was reported for judgment.

By imperial edict, on the fifth day of the fifth month at dawn court, the Bureau of Astronomy reported observing celestial fire destined to burn the heretical palace in Shaozhou. Meanwhile, the eunuch Ling Zhaoqing, possessed by a spirit, declared: *"Zhenwu has also decreed the burning of Mingyang Palace for leading the people astray, squandering wealth on useless offerings, and repeatedly offending the celestial treasury despite warnings. The retribution now comes to pass."*

Thus, Mingyang Palace was stripped of its name. Only a Zhenwu Hall and a small Daoist abbey were rebuilt, with ten ordained Daoists selected for cultivation. Zhang Anxiang was spared punishment but defrocked and released. A proclamation was issued to all Daoist and lay communities across the land, commanding them to revere Heaven and Earth and never stray from the true and upright Dao.

In the Kaiyuan Abbey of Nan’an Prefecture, originally the ancestral estate of the Celestial Lord of the Supreme Non-Ultimate Pure Void, the local people venerated Zhenwu above all. Whenever he descended, they flocked to burn incense, paper money, and candles in offering. Before the abbey stood a general goods shop where the abbey purchased supplies for its assemblies, particularly candles. The shop sold foul-smelling tallow and dyed rags disguised as pure beeswax candles, polluting the sacred rites and defiling the prayers for blessings.

The stellar deities and mountain spirits reported this to the Three Pure Ones, the Jade Emperor, and the Celestial August, prompting the Northern Dipper to order the celestial bureaus to investigate. One day, a novice tending the incense in Zhenwu Hall dreamed of a divine messenger who said: *"The candle-seller before the abbey has committed evil for three lifetimes. Now named Huang Yu, he still sells filthy tallow as fake candles, offending the celestial treasury. His sins are boundless; he shall lose the Six Paths and be reduced to dust. As Zhenwu of the Protector Saint Abbey oversees good and evil, I have received the celestial mandate to punish Huang Yu. Tomorrow, he will know his fate."*

The novice awoke in alarm and told the Daoist community. Before he finished speaking, an old man appeared at Huang Yu’s shop, asking to buy ten candles to offer to the celestial treasury, insisting they be genuine. Huang Yu grew furious: *"I’ve sold these candles for over twenty years, all offered to the celestial treasury. Why do you call them fake?"* He demanded the old man buy one first and test it with fire. Suddenly, a gust of wind fanned the flame, igniting the house. The old man vanished. Huang Yu, desperate to save his goods, was trapped by the fire and burned to ashes. Within an hour, only his shop was consumed, leaving not a single coin. When the fire died, a pillar in the shop remained untouched, its surface split as if by an axe, revealing hidden celestial script.

Scholars and Daoists gathered to examine it, recognizing the hand of the Perfected Lord Zhenwu. Officials had the script copied, but as soon as the transcription was complete, fire erupted from within the pillar and consumed it. The event mirrored the novice’s dream, exposing Huang Yu’s sins and hastening his karmic retribution.

The prefect of Nan’an, unwilling to conceal the matter, recorded the incident and submitted two memorials to the throne. The imperial response read: *"In this world, good and evil arise from the heart. Good deeds are like the waves of rivers and seas—coming without trace, leaving without root. Evil brings swift retribution, like the products of Heaven and Earth, manifesting everywhere. How can one not be cautious?"* It ordered a stele to be erected at the abbey gate, proclaiming Zhenwu’s unerring retribution, and a proclamation issued throughout the realm as a perpetual warning.

*Recorded by [Shu] Gong, with conferred titles.*

The Pavilion of Responding Treasures was favored by the deity’s unseen aid. In manifesting such evident numinosity, [Shu] Gong is deemed worthy. By special decree, Zhenwu is appointed to the Hall of Unobstructed Compassionate Governance for the Perpetual Pacification of the State, conferred the supreme title: *Primordial Marshal of the Three Heavens’ Five Quarters, Supreme Commander of the Nine Heavens’ Vanguard, Great General of the Left Celestial Hosts Guarding the Northern Pole, Great General of the Right Celestial Ramparts Stabilizing the Heavens, Zhenwu the Spiritually Responsive Perfected Lord.*

Further honored as: *The Venerable, Rectifying, Serene, Illuminating, and Radiant Jeweled Combatant of Heaven, Protector of the State and Pacifier of the People, Longevity-Responsive Blessed Deity; Sagely Marquis of Wisdom, Virtue, Filial Piety, and Martial Brilliance, Who Quells Chaos with Holy Merit and Compassionate Wisdom.*

The essence of Water is bestowed the title: *Co-Administrator of Shared Virtue, Aiding Governance with Supreme Dao, Manifesting Martial Might to Nourish Yin and Assist the Sacred, Left Vanguard Cloud Cavalry Defender of the State, Guardian of Tranquility, and Grand Marshal of the Supreme Primordial Unity of the Great Heaven.*

The essence of Fire is bestowed the title: *Co-Administrator of Shared Virtue, Assisting Governance with Supreme Benevolence, Profoundly Responsive and Universally Compassionate, Discerning Martial Sage of Yang, Right Vanguard Cloud Cavalry Defender of the State, Guardian of Serenity, and Grand Marshal of the Supreme Primordial Unity of the Great Heaven.*

All aforementioned titles are conferred as before. By imperial edict, a eulogy is composed for the pavilion’s dedication, its text inscribed upon the treasure. *"Of all things the origin, its盛 virtue may be entrusted. Its essence pierces the Dark Heaven, its numinous radiance resplendent. The wellspring of flourishing benefit, it safeguards the Great Harmony. With incense and reverence offered, the Five Fortunes follow in its wake."*

*Record of the Divine Manifestations of the Dark Heaven Thearch, Scroll Eight—End.*

chunks.original_text: 按《三宝大有金书》云：一炁分形，灵虚生，五劫之宗。 三清出，号神景，化九光之始。 太初溟涬，玄极冥蒙。 中有虚皇，分置五劫，曰龙汉，曰赤明，曰上皇，曰延康，曰开皇。 当斯时也，天光未分，清浊未判，则知三炁为天地之尊，九炁为万真之本。 是故元始象先天，开明三景，造立天根。 五文开廓，普植神灵。 太极一判，天地始明。 束分青九，南受丹三。 西成白七，北归玄五。 中生黄一，号为五老，即玄黄植象之根也。 五老各布始炁，化成四灵，以定四隅。 周环六合，两仪运乎其中。 推成万物，以此考源，明玄帝果先天始黑，五灵玄老，太阴天一之化。 按混洞赤文所载，玄帝乃先天始炁，太极别体。 上三皇时，下降为太始真人。 中三皇时，下降为太初真人。 下三皇时，下降为太素真人。 黄帝时，下降符太阳之精，托胎於净乐国王善胜皇后，孕秀一十四月，则太上八十二化也。 净乐国，乃奎娄之下，海外之国，上应龙变梵度天也。 王宫诞圣 是时，正当上天开皇，初劫下世，岁建甲辰三月戊辰初三曰，甲寅庚午时，玄帝产母左胁当生之时，瑞云覆国，天花散漫，异香芬然，身宝光焰，充满王国，地土皆变金玉，瑞应之祥，莫能备载。 经书默会 玄帝生而神灵，举错隐显。
chunks.translated_text:
From the *Great Golden Book of the Three Treasures* it is said: One qi divides its form, giving rise to the Numinous Void, the origin of the Five Kalpas. The Three Clarities emerge, styled the Divine Radiance, the inception of the Nine Lights. In the Great Beginning’s primordial vastness, the Dark Ultimate was shrouded in obscurity. Within it dwelt the Void Sovereign, who apportioned the Five Kalpas—named Dragon Han, Crimson Brightness, Supreme August, Extended Peace, and Inaugural August. At that time, celestial light had yet to separate, purity and turbidity had yet to be distinguished; thus was it known that the Three Qi stand as the honor of Heaven and Earth, and the Nine Qi as the root of the Ten Thousand Perfected.

Therefore, the Primordial Commencement emulated the precelestial, unveiled the Three Luminaries, and established the root of Heaven. The Five Scripts expanded the expanse, universally planting the divine spirits. When the Supreme Ultimate first divided, Heaven and Earth began to clarify. The Azure Nine coalesced in the east, the Vermilion Three received in the south. The White Seven formed in the west, the Dark Five returned to the north. The Yellow One arose in the center, styled the Five Elders—the very root of the Dark and Yellow’s planted image. Each of the Five Elders dispersed the primordial qi, transforming it into the Four Numinous Beings to fix the four directions. Encircling the Six Harmonies, the Two Modes revolved within. Propelling the myriad things to completion, by this we trace the source: it is evident that the Dark Emperor indeed preceded the precelestial blackness, the Five Numinous Dark Elders, the transformation of the Great Yin Heavenly One.

According to the *Crimson Writ of the Chaotic Abyss*, the Dark Emperor is the primordial qi of the precelestial, the alternate embodiment of the Supreme Ultimate. During the era of the Upper Three August Ones, he descended as the Perfected of the Great Commencement. In the era of the Middle Three August Ones, he descended as the Perfected of the Great Beginning. In the era of the Lower Three August Ones, he descended as the Perfected of the Great Simplicity. In the time of the Yellow Emperor, he descended in accord with the essence of the Great Yang, incarnating in the womb of Queen Good Victory of the Pure Joy Kingdom. After fourteen months of pregnancy, this marked the eighty-second transformation of the Supreme. The Pure Joy Kingdom lay beneath the Astral Enclosure, a land beyond the seas, corresponding above to the Dragon Transformation Brahma-Passage Heaven.

When the royal palace gave birth to the Sage, it was precisely the Inaugural August Kalpa of the Upper Heaven, the first kalpa descending to the world. In the year marked *jiachen*, the third month, the third day of the *wuchen* cycle, at the hour of *jia-yin* and *geng-wu*, the Dark Emperor emerged from his mother’s left side. At the moment of his birth, auspicious clouds enshrouded the kingdom, heavenly blossoms scattered in profusion, and wondrous fragrance suffused the air. His body radiated precious light, filling the royal domain; the very earth transformed into gold and jade. The auspicious omens were too numerous to record in full.

As the scriptures silently attest, the Dark Emperor was born divine and numinous, his actions concealed and revealed in turn.

chunks.original_text: 聪以知远，明能察微。 年及七岁，经书一览。 仰观俯视，靡所不通。 港心念道，志契太虚。 愿事上帝，普福兆民。 辞亲慕道 玄帝长而勇猛，不统王位，惟务修行。 辅助玉帝，誓断天下妖魔，救护群品。 曰夜於王宫发此誓愿，父王不能抑志。 年十五，辞父母而寻幽谷，内炼元真。 元君授道 玄帝念道专一，遂感玉清圣祖紫元君，传授无极上道。 元君告玄帝曰：子可越海，东游历，於翼轸之下，有山自乾兑起迹，盘旋五万里，水出震宫。 自有太极，便生是山。 上应显定，极风太安。 皇崖二天，有七十二峰，三十六严也，子可入是山，择众峰之中，冲高紫霄者居之。 当契太和升举之后五百岁，当上天。 龙汉二劫中，披发跣足，蹑坎离之真精，归根复位。 上为三境辅臣，下作十方大圣，方得显名亿劫，与天地曰月齐并，是其果满也。 告毕，元君升云而去。 天帝锡剑 玄帝乃如师言，越海束游。 又感丰乾大天帝，授以宝剑。 天帝告曰：此剑，名曰北方黑驰裘角断魔雄剑，长七尺二寸，应七十二候。 抚三辅，应三台。 重二十四斤，应二十四炁。
chunks.translated_text:
With wisdom he perceived the distant, with clarity he discerned the subtle. By the age of seven, he had mastered the scriptures at a glance. Gazing upward and downward, there was nothing he did not comprehend. His heart longed for the Dao, his aspiration aligned with the Great Void. He vowed to serve the Supreme Emperor, bestowing universal blessings upon all beings.

**Renouncing Kin to Pursue the Dao**
As the Dark Emperor matured, he grew fierce and valiant, yet he did not ascend the royal throne, devoting himself solely to cultivation. He pledged to assist the Jade Emperor, vowing to sever the world’s demons and save all beings. Day and night within the royal palace, he made this oath, and his father could not restrain his resolve. At fifteen, he bid farewell to his parents and sought the secluded valleys to refine his primordial essence within.

**The Primordial Lady Bestows the Dao**
The Dark Emperor’s devotion to the Dao was unwavering, and thus he moved the Jade Purity Sage Ancestor, the Purple Primordial Lady, to transmit to him the Supreme Dao of the Limitless. The Primordial Lady spoke to the Dark Emperor: “You must cross the sea and journey east. Beneath the *Wing* and *Axletree* constellations, there is a mountain whose traces rise from *Qian* and *Dui*, coiling for fifty thousand *li*, with waters flowing from the *Zhen* Palace. Since the birth of the Great Ultimate, this mountain has existed. Above, it corresponds to *Manifest Stability*, the *Ultimate Wind*, and *Supreme Peace*. Within the *August Cliff* and *Two Heavens*, there are seventy-two peaks and thirty-six cliffs. You must enter this mountain and dwell among its peaks, choosing the loftiest, the Purple Empyrean. When five hundred years have passed since attaining harmony and ascension, you shall ascend to Heaven. Amidst the *Dragon Han* and *Two Kalpas*, with unbound hair and bare feet, you shall tread the true essence of *Kan* and *Li*, returning to the root and regaining your position. Above, you shall become a minister of the Three Realms; below, a great sage of the Ten Directions. Only then shall your name be renowned for countless kalpas, equal to Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon—this is the fulfillment of your fruition.” Having spoken, the Primordial Lady ascended upon the clouds and departed.

**The Heavenly Emperor Bestows the Sword**
The Dark Emperor followed his master’s words, crossing the sea and journeying east. There, he moved the August Heavenly Emperor of Abundant *Qian* to bestow upon him a sacred sword. The Heavenly Emperor declared: “This sword is named the *Northern Black Galloping Horned Demon-Severing Heroic Sword*. It measures seven feet and two inches, corresponding to the seventy-two seasonal nodes. It governs the Three Assistants, aligning with the Three Terraces. It weighs twenty-four *jin*, corresponding to the twenty-four *qi*.”

chunks.original_text: 阔四寸八分，应四时八节。 子可佩此，居山修炼，降伏邪道，收斩妖魔。 告毕，天帝升云而去。 玄帝受讫，历翼轸之下，果见是山，山藏水没，皆符师言。 於是入山渡涧，择地，隐居内修。 其山在均州之南三舍，先名太和，一名仙室，一名大岳也。 玄帝升真之后，谓曰：非玄武不足以当之。 故更名曰：武当。 嵩高之储，副五岳之流辈也。 周回八百里，七十二峰，三十六严，二十四洞，五台五井，三潭三泉，四石三天门，三洞天一福地。 风穴雷洞，药圃丹炉。 霄馆龙宫，庆云彩雾。 幽兰清葱，葛乳天花。 石露金银之星，树有松萝之秀。 骞林叶尤能愈疾，灵寿杖可以扶衰。 神兽呈祥，仙禽奏乐。 御宝宸翰，护教镇山。 黑虎巡廊，乌鸦报晓。 艾名千岁，广施博济之功。 松号万年，彰美报恩之德。 茂林修竹，人杰地灵。 得道神仙，不可胜计。 囿山圣迹，莫能备陈。 敛万古之姻霞，归一原之造化也。 涧阻群臣 父王思慕太子，不能弃舍，令大臣领兵五百众，根寻太子回朝。 探逐所往，渡涧入山。 遇涧水忽涨。 不能前进。 八次渡遇水泛，第九次，方得渡。 至紫霄岩面，见太子，启传王命。 自是部众，足忽僵仆，不能举。 相谓曰：太子愿力，所至如是。 回国且遥，乃同声告曰：愿从太子学道。 语毕，跬步如故，於是俱隐山中。 帝升真之后，皆证仙道。 今武当有五百灵官者，是也。 涧名九渡阻，其意焉。 童真内炼 玄帝登山，首於太子岩栖隐。 帝修真时，有灵鸦报晓，黑虎卫岩，每食必饵之。 至今，二物通灵，皆证大神，时隐时见。 乌鸦喙赤，见之者昌。 黑虎驱奸，逆之者殃。 按《总真集》云：武当黑虎大神，乃北方天一之所化。 护教守山之灵，正直威显，变化不一。 或托相为人，金甲皂抱，若将军之状。 或现真相，玄鬃黑色，如狮子之形。 或大如厘，或小如豹，或雪裹而现其迹，或泥中而显其踪。 见之者不祥，梦之者获庆。 夜巡廊废，灵迹昭垂，不善之人，立为屏斥。 《丹经》云：虎向水中生，是也。 有秘法传之於世行焉。 今天一真庆宫嘉庆阁下，有黑虎岩，灵乌者，秉北方之黑色，为武当之灵神，预报吉凶，验其慈厉，靡不应者。 旦则群噪，为之报晓。 然物我相忘，略不惊避。
