chunks.original_text: 为昨来与本朝两军未决克伏间，忽有卫士误入营寨，货卖伤筋折骨风药，四向军寨买药。 皆遍三日，吃药者三万余众，尽皆手足软弱，倒卧不起。 又探得帅将岑元宥行营，正乏粮草，亦有道士货药，人马服之，三日不饥。 蕃中播云：宋朝多感召北极真武真君保护。 今本蕃又详真武本传，既属太清金阙真人，化身为北极天将，行恩普及天下，宋朝得获恩福，本蕃却受殃祸，为蕃中不曾传得真武圣像，并供养法式。 谨遣使臣奏请，望赐真武圣相，一行侍从，并供养格式，降付本蕃，依禀供养，自后通和，誓无侵掠。 门下看详，国家社稷天神，难议尽行传赐。 寻令翰院依家神殿式，彩画立身真武一轴，内不得画龟蛇，并录应干下降供具法式，回答来使。 其蕃王李氏，不明内少龟蛇，此二物最为真圣之先锋将，谓已获全实，宣诏供养，一依宋朝体式崇敬，不事征伐。 每三年一次，遣使进奉，皆真圣应化之恩也。 灵阁真瑞 端明殿学士，知陕州充本路兵马都钤辖钱延年，奉称本府天庆观，有道士千众，厨供约近一千五百余人，每日收聚真武圣阁灵签，开殿香钱，相兼支用。 其阁是开宝年中，太祖皇帝为届潼关诏令使陶珏，因获是观灵坛天文，下河东未胜，承天花远黄河堤岸，夜迎二十万马步军兵入府。 从此，知真武救驾，遂建报恩护圣之阁。 近来香火寂寥，厨库荒冻，无人兴营诸殿并真武灵阁。 取问住持道士刘印真，据称，昨自太宗皇帝大驾，因取河东回国，为太祖恩赐遗诰，御书加赠真武，於下降日特添祭其斋醮，令於军资库赐给，施钱一百二十贯。 后至真宗皇帝时，为西蕃不宁，沿边支备急用，从此将添赐停，倚是致道众起离云游，自然无人到殿抽签，所以堂厨不给。 忽数日前，有龟蛇出现於真武阁下，盘旋台座之间，时出时入。 识者云：此乃真瑞，拟虑国家有文字到观。 延年为闻太祖皇帝留心重道，未及三纪，顿成废弃。 欲不避降责，奏请兴续。 未曾表奏，忽有御割到府，委长吏勘会天庆观。 见今实迹为昭应宫，近有庆诞，偶睹金冠紫服真人告言曰：臣陕州天庆观勾当，主者为见本观道众飘乏，全乏供给，绿陛下殊不以先朝置立为念，幸与早复存济。 乃辞而去，可体访诣实回申。 延年已先知其事由，具状保明闻奏，奉圣旨，先依太祖朝元赐，遂件恩给。 仍召集本额道众归观焚修，并建醮三昼夜，普答真灵，及真武福神慈悲，教主广大恩威。 五人现相 益州孙亨甫，攻画水墨真武诸相，可谓绝笔。 忽有云游道士五人，来见亨甫云：在华山云台观住，闻足下名，欲求真武一轴，须候我自带本来。 亨甫曰：本家画此功德，天下传名，何用别本。 道士曰：尔画得第一，到了未曾得遇真本者。 且留钱在此买绢，后月初七日取本来画。 道士从西而去，至期，五人复来，即无卷轴，卸云：请备笔砚，就裹面无人见处看本而画。 亨甫邀入，请本下笔，却教亨甫背身看之，不觉如火光运转，忽．然通明，五人各变相於云端内，有一身红光龙罩，披头跣足，全带金甲械冑，着昏皂袍，手执绦鞭，骑青鬃白马，面部纯秀，眼长眉坚，鼻耸耳朝，口方颐蝉。 前有龟蛇，后有貂脚早旗，认是真武游奕真相。 又一人捧旗，一人擎剑，皆冠服，颜貌厅陋，如武士，名天呈河魁。
chunks.translated_text:
During the recent standoff between our two armies, when victory or submission remained undecided, a guardsman inadvertently entered the camp, peddling medicines for wounds, broken bones, and wind-induced ailments. For three days, he sold his remedies throughout the military encampments. Over thirty thousand men consumed them, only to find their limbs weakened, leaving them prostrate and unable to rise. Meanwhile, scouts reported that in Commander Cen Yuanyou’s forward camp, where provisions were scarce, a Daoist also sold medicine. Both men and horses partook of it, and for three days, none felt hunger.

Rumors spread among the frontier tribes: *"The Song dynasty enjoys the protection of the Perfected Lord Zhenwu of the Northern Culmen, summoned by their devotion."* Upon further inquiry into the *Biography of Zhenwu*, we learned that as the Perfected One of the Golden Portal of Grand Clarity, he had manifested as the Celestial General of the Northern Culmen, bestowing his grace universally. The Song have reaped his blessings, while we suffer calamity—for our lands have never received the sacred image of Zhenwu, nor the rites of veneration.

We humbly dispatch envoys to petition: grant us the sacred likeness of Zhenwu, along with his retinue and the proper forms of worship, that we may enshrine and honor them as prescribed. Henceforth, we vow to maintain peace and forswear all raids. Your ministers have deliberated: the celestial deities of the state and altars cannot be indiscriminately bestowed. Accordingly, the Hanlin Academy was instructed to paint a standing portrait of Zhenwu in the style of the ancestral temple, omitting the tortoise and serpent. The requisite rituals for offerings and descent were recorded and conveyed to the envoys.

The Li ruler of the frontier, unaware that the tortoise and serpent are Zhenwu’s vanguard generals, believed he had received the complete and authentic image. He proclaimed an edict to venerate it in strict accordance with Song ritual, renouncing warfare. Every three years, envoys are dispatched to present tribute—all by the grace of the Perfected One’s transformative power.

**Auspicious Marvels of the Sacred Pavilion**
Qian Yannian, Grand Scholar of the Hall of Enlightenment and Military Commissioner of Shanzhou, reported: The Tianqing Abbey in this prefecture houses a thousand Daoists, with daily provisions for nearly fifteen hundred. The funds for incense and divination slips from the Sacred Pavilion of Zhenwu are pooled for shared use. This pavilion was built during the Kaibao era, when Emperor Taizu dispatched Envoy Tao Jue to Tong Pass. Upon discovering the abbey’s sacred altar and celestial omens, he learned that the Hedong campaign had faltered. Yet, by the Yellow River’s banks, twenty thousand cavalry and infantry were miraculously guided into the prefecture at night. Recognizing Zhenwu’s intervention to save the imperial carriage, the emperor erected this pavilion in gratitude, naming it the *Pavilion of Repaying Grace and Protecting the Sacred*.

Of late, incense offerings have dwindled, kitchens lie barren, and no one tends to the halls or the Sacred Pavilion. Upon inquiry, the abbey’s custodian, Daoist Liu Yinzhen, stated: When Emperor Taizong returned from the Hedong campaign, he honored Taizu’s legacy by issuing an edict to augment the sacrifices on Zhenwu’s descent day, allocating 120 strings of cash from the military treasury for the ritual feast. Later, during Emperor Zhenzong’s reign, as the western frontier grew restless and border defenses required urgent funds, the additional grants ceased. Consequently, Daoists dispersed, and none came to draw divination slips, leaving the halls and kitchens unsupported.

Days ago, a tortoise and serpent appeared beneath the Sacred Pavilion, coiling around the altar’s base, emerging and retreating at intervals. Those versed in such matters declared it an auspicious sign, presaging an imperial decree for the abbey. Yannian, recalling Taizu’s devotion to the Dao, lamented that within three reigns, the abbey had fallen into ruin. Risking censure, he petitioned for its restoration.

Before the memorial could be submitted, an imperial rescript arrived, ordering the prefect to investigate Tianqing Abbey. Now designated as the Zhaoying Palace, it had recently celebrated a festival when a golden-crowned, purple-robed Perfected One appeared, declaring: *"I oversee the affairs of Shanzhou’s Tianqing Abbey. Seeing its Daoists destitute and unsupported, I marvel that Your Majesty has forgotten the foundations laid by former emperors. Restore its provisions swiftly."* With that, he vanished. The matter was to be verified and reported.

Yannian, already aware of the circumstances, submitted a detailed account to the throne. By imperial decree, the original grants of Taizu’s reign were reinstated. The abbey’s Daoists were recalled to resume their rituals, and a three-day feast was held to honor the Perfected One’s boundless grace and Zhenwu’s compassion as the merciful and mighty Teacher of the Dao.

**Five Manifested Forms**
Sun Hengfu of Yizhou, renowned for his ink paintings of Zhenwu and other deities, was approached by five wandering Daoists. They claimed to reside at the Yuntai Abbey on Mount Hua and, having heard of his fame, sought a scroll of Zhenwu—but insisted on providing their own model. Hengfu replied: *"My works, painted as acts of merit, are celebrated across the land. Why seek another model?"* The Daoists countered: *"Your skill is unmatched, yet you have never beheld the true original."*

Leaving money to purchase silk, they departed, promising to return on the seventh day of the following month with the authentic image. On the appointed day, the five reappeared—without a scroll. Instead, they requested brushes and ink, asking to view the model in seclusion. Hengfu invited them in, and as he prepared to paint, they instructed him to turn away. Suddenly, a radiance like fire swirled, illuminating the room. The five transformed within the clouds: one figure, wreathed in crimson light, appeared with unbound hair and bare feet, clad in golden armor and a dark robe, wielding a tasseled whip. He rode a white-maned black horse, his face refined, with long eyes, straight brows, a prominent nose, and a square jaw. Before him coiled the tortoise and serpent; behind him, a banner and a standard. This was Zhenwu in his true martial form.

Another held a banner, a third a sword—both wore armor, their faces stern and coarse, like celestial warriors. They were named *Tiancheng* and *Hekui*.

**Vanguard of the Sacred Image**

chunks.original_text: 又一人青衣调带，掌事童女。 一人绯衣巾带，抱籍判官。 此五人真相既现於虚空，忽然不见。 亨甫记笔，祗画得一轴。 装背了毕，上有金色圆光，自然隐现，面相不常。 亨甫惊惶，自以私家难留，资呈州府。 时知州苏易简，录其词，封其画，差指使刘通，同亨甫赴京进奉。 蒙宣公卿看验，委宝。 除已留纳为镇国遇圣名画，充御殿香火家宝外，其孙亨甫，特赐三班奉职，听从举注施行。 二士化光 京东路青州镇海军，祖来虽有宫观，未有北极真武殿。 因节度使张操出海，青州乃召内道职谕曰：北极管注人间寿夭，富贵贫贱。 真武是北极神将，逐月下降，察人善恶，以定罪福。 凡有祈求，无不倚赖。 而民问不为建殿，何也。

Another wore a blue-green robe with a sash, a serving maiden. One more, clad in crimson with a kerchief and sash, held registers as a recording official. Once the five revealed their true forms in the void, they suddenly vanished. Hengfu committed their likenesses to brush, completing but a single scroll. When mounted, a golden halo naturally shimmered upon it, its countenance ever-changing. Alarmed, Hengfu deemed it too sacred for private keeping and presented it to the prefecture.

At the time, Prefect Su Yijian recorded the account, sealed the painting, and dispatched Attendant Liu Tong with Hengfu to present it to the capital. Upon inspection by the court’s ministers, it was deemed a treasure. Beyond its retention as a revered imperial painting—*The True Form of Zhenwu, Protector of the Realm*—to grace the palace’s incense altar, Hengfu’s grandson was specially granted the rank of *Sanban Fengzhi*, eligible for official appointment.

**Two Transcendents Radiant with Light**
In Jingdong Circuit’s Qingzhou, under the jurisdiction of Zhenhai Commandery, though temples and abbeys had long existed, no hall had been dedicated to the Northern Culmen’s True Warrior. When Military Commissioner Zhang Cao set sail, Qingzhou summoned its inner Daoist officials, instructing them: “The Northern Culmen governs the span of human life, wealth, honor, poverty, and lowliness. Zhenwu, its divine general, descends monthly to scrutinize good and evil, determining reward or retribution. All who pray to him find their pleas answered. Yet the people have not built him a hall—why?”

chunks.original_text: 张操发心，自为劝缘，欲就天庆观，建此二殿，首得其疏题注，舍钱五百贯。 次及官员士庶，乐然舍施。 兴工塑造，不日而成。 奈青州为无红塑之人。 张操一日焚香，对天祷祝，愿得名手，圆备功德。 不旬日间，有二人来揽塑二殿圣像，称是昊人。 月余，皆已具备。 张操见众官等前来瞻仰，除圣相部从皆已圆备，秪有真武未开光明。 匠者二人，欲各开一目，分左右。 方用笔填出睛瞳，秪见威容凛烈，喜色异常，於两目开进出金光一道，二士遂於光中，随化不见，以显真武垂慈，亲降尘凡，圆备二殿功德。 张操率官属士庶，就北极真武二殿廷醮设斋，报谢上真降临之恩。 从此，香火兴盛。 后来，青州遍行眼疾，张操令道职汤鉴，先当殿咒水，散施洗涤，俱酸。 张操备述保奏，蒙遣使降香建醮，及赐嘉应殿为额，令立碑记。 唐宪宝像 宣州市户，唐忠、唐愈、唐宪、唐愿，兄弟同居。 忠愿充州衙干当，愈攻行医，宪守闲在家。 自祖父在日，相续供养真武一堂。 父亡，兄弟皆疏慢，惟唐宪心向香火，将妻糙奁典卖，添备下降香火纸马等用。 岂期兄弟嫌妬，称宪端坐无功，全房吃用众兄弟衣食，更以神道为由，破用钱物入己。 宪云：既欲分张，任便拣选所有之物，唐宪秪愿於众，求此祖上侍奉真武一堂，受持供养。 其忠、愈、愿无心供养，乐然允从。 忠、愈、愿私营钱物，各自富庶。 惟宪柢留住屋，其余产业，尽卖与人，开一小杂当铺，随缘遣日。 偶值雨雪，有一贫汉背绾布袋，手擎铜釭坐身真武一尊，脚踏龟蛇，极是工巧，要当钱一贯。 宪请以钱三贯就赎，亦便相允。 其时，凭僧用祥作见人，谢臻充保，刘坦写约。 交钱去后，贫人却转告宪，留下二贯七百文，少时来取。 宪将功德顿在家堂供养，遇下降日，再用香水洗诤，渐觉色变沉重，手台不起。 用净帛揩拭，出於明处细视，见其貌相微有烁烁圆光晃耀，认来，却是真金像，手约重五十余两，元卖人又不来取钱。 不期兄弟三人意生欺拓，同状经州，论宪於未分已前，藏隐大家金铸真武五十余两，分后方始将出供养。 州府遂勾唐宪，宝所隐金像出头。 据唐宪供吐，元买到贫汉功德。 及勾到保见人，并索元卖文字，分明显是唐忠等妄状，各行科决，忠等因此，家业沦落，日逐来宪家行凶作闹。 与妻隔夜拜辞金像，明早潜将投纳州库。 后因监司刻刷上供钱帛，因见官库内有金像真武一身，微发祥光，显属异宝，遂申奏朝廷。 后降指挥，仰宣州起发入京进奉，奉圣旨取入内庭，充镇国宝像仰於本州夏税头子钱内，支五百贯文付唐宪，充还金直，唐宪因兹大富，子孙昌盛。 其唐忠等三人，各家饭食不给，皆先死亡，子孙零替，尽是宪置宅存养。 宣州太极观，系唐宪一力舍钱建造。 朱氏金砖 隰州陆谅，嗜酒好杀，恣餐鳗鳝。 其妻朱氏，力戒不改，自将妆奁潜托父母家，命工彩画真武一轴，请道士钱应方，转经安奉，并受持下降法式。 应方曰：供养福神，第一，须是虔诚发心，不可等闲，每月下降日，烧献金钱云马，或有余力，请道诵经。 第二，不得於酒后归家，高声触渎。 第三，大忌啖食犬、鳌、鳗、鳝、蒜、韮等物。 第四，怜贫、恤老，孝育骨肉，事涉公私，心莫欺谄。

Zhang Cao, moved by devotion, personally initiated the fundraising effort. He first selected the Tianqing Abbey as the site for constructing these two halls, beginning with his own donation of five hundred strings of cash. Officials, scholars, and commoners followed, contributing gladly. The construction and sculpting were swiftly completed. However, Qingzhou lacked artisans skilled in red sculpting. One day, Zhang Cao burned incense and prayed to heaven, vowing to find a master craftsman to perfect the merit of the halls. Within ten days, two men arrived, offering to sculpt the sacred images for the two halls, claiming to be from Wu. In little over a month, all was prepared. When Zhang Cao and the assembled officials came to pay their respects, they saw that while the divine retinue and attendants were complete, only Zhenwu’s image remained unopened in its radiance. The two artisans each wished to open one eye, dividing the task between left and right. As they filled in the pupils with their brushes, the divine countenance suddenly appeared awe-inspiring and stern, its expression unusually joyful. From the two opened eyes burst forth a single beam of golden light, and within that light, the two artisans vanished without a trace—thus revealing Zhenwu’s compassionate descent to the mortal realm to perfect the merit of the two halls. Zhang Cao led the officials, scholars, and commoners in holding a grand jiao offering and vegetarian feast at the Northern Culmen’s True Warrior Hall to repay the grace of the Perfected One’s descent. From then on, the incense and offerings flourished.

Later, an epidemic of eye ailments spread throughout Qingzhou. Zhang Cao ordered the Daoist official Tang Jian to consecrate water before the hall, which was then distributed for washing—all were cured. Zhang Cao reported the matter in a memorial, and an imperial envoy was dispatched to present incense and hold a jiao offering. The hall was also bestowed the name *Jiaying* ("Auspicious Response") as its plaque, and a stele was erected to record the event.

**The Tang Brothers’ Precious Image**
In Xuan Prefecture’s market district lived four brothers—Tang Zhong, Tang Yu, Tang Xian, and Tang Yuan—who dwelled together. Zhong served as a clerk in the prefectural office, Yu practiced medicine, and Xian remained at home in leisure. Since their grandfather’s time, the family had continuously enshrined and worshipped an image of Zhenwu. After their father’s death, the brothers grew negligent, except for Tang Xian, who remained devoted to the incense and offerings. He sold his wife’s dowry chest to purchase additional incense, paper horses, and other ritual supplies. His brothers, however, grew resentful, accusing Xian of idleness, living off their shared resources, and squandering money on the pretext of divine worship. Xian replied, “If you wish to divide the household, choose whatever possessions you desire. I ask only for our ancestors’ Zhenwu image to continue its veneration.” His brothers, having no interest in its upkeep, readily agreed.

Zhong, Yu, and Yuan privately amassed wealth, each growing prosperous, while Xian retained only the house. He sold the rest of their property, opening a small pawnshop to sustain himself. One snowy day, a poor man arrived carrying a cloth sack on his back and a bronze lamp in hand, atop which sat a small statue of Zhenwu trampling the tortoise and serpent, exquisitely crafted. He offered it for a pawn of one string of cash. Xian bargained to redeem it for three strings, and the man agreed. A monk named Yongxiang acted as witness, Xie Zhen as guarantor, and Liu Tan drafted the contract. After the money was exchanged, the poor man told Xian to keep two strings and seven hundred coins, saying he would return shortly to collect them. Xian placed the image in his family shrine. On the next descent day, he washed it with fragrant water, and it gradually grew heavier, its base too weighty to lift. When he wiped it with a clean cloth and examined it in the light, he saw its features faintly shimmering with a golden radiance. Realizing it was a solid gold statue, he estimated its weight at over fifty taels. The seller never returned for the remaining money.

Later, his three brothers, scheming to seize it, jointly filed a lawsuit with the prefecture, accusing Xian of concealing a fifty-tael gold Zhenwu statue from the family estate before the division and only producing it afterward for worship. The prefectural authorities summoned Tang Xian to surrender the hidden golden image. Xian explained that he had purchased it from a poor man. When the guarantor and witnesses were called, along with the original sales contract, it became clear that Tang Zhong and the others had fabricated the charges. They were each punished accordingly, and their fortunes declined. Thereafter, they daily came to Xian’s home to cause trouble. That night, Xian and his wife bid farewell to the golden image, and the next morning, they secretly deposited it in the prefectural treasury.

Later, when the surveillance commissioner reviewed the tribute funds, he noticed the golden Zhenwu statue in the official vault, its features faintly emanating an auspicious glow—a rare treasure. He reported it to the court. An imperial edict ordered Xuan Prefecture to dispatch it to the capital, where it was received into the inner palace as a *Protector of the Realm* treasure. The court also decreed that five hundred strings of cash be drawn from the prefecture’s summer tax funds and given to Tang Xian as compensation for the statue’s value. From then on, Xian grew wealthy, and his descendants prospered. As for Tang Zhong and the other two brothers, their households fell into poverty, and they died one after another, their descendants dwindling. All were later supported by Xian’s estate. The Taiji Abbey in Xuan Prefecture was built entirely through Tang Xian’s donations.

**Zhu’s Golden Brick**
In Xizhou, Lu Liang was addicted to wine and fond of killing, indulging in eels and loaches. His wife, née Zhu, repeatedly admonished him to no avail. She secretly entrusted her dowry to her parents’ home and commissioned an artisan to paint a scroll of Zhenwu. She invited the Daoist priest Qian Yingfang to perform scripture recitations and install the image, along with the rituals for the descent days. Yingfang instructed her: “In worshipping the福神, first, one must be sincerely devoted, not treating it lightly. On each descent day, burn and offer golden paper money and cloud horses; if possible, invite Daoists to recite scriptures. Second, do not return home drunk or raise your voice in disrespect. Third, strictly avoid consuming dog, soft-shelled turtle, eel, loach, garlic, or leeks. Fourth, show compassion to the poor, care for the elderly, honor your kin, and in all public and private matters, never deceive or flatter.”

Though her livelihood had dwindled to mere daily sustenance, one day a single flower-patterned tile in the main hall of her home became exposed. Mistaking it for a stray street paver, Zhu-shi paid it no mind. That night, a radiance emanated from it, so she retrieved it—only to find it too heavy to lift alone. With her son’s help, she carried it home, scrubbed away the green moss, and discovered it was pure gold, gleaming with the deep luster of refined *zimo*.

Astonished, she dared not keep it, wrapping it instead in silk and brocade before presenting it to Prefectural Secretariat Censor Jiang Tingjian. She declared, “Since my husband’s death, I have been a destitute widow. I know not whence this gold came.” Tingjian, aware of her devotion to Zhenwu, understood it as a celestial gift. When weighed, it measured fourteen *jin*. Zhu-shi steadfastly refused to accept it, insisting it be turned over to the authorities. Citing the statute on found treasures, officials proposed dividing half for the state.

As goldsmiths were summoned to hammer and chisel the ingot, countless tiny crimson serpents and jade-green tortoises suddenly swarmed around the anvil. A larger serpent coiled upon the gold itself, lingering for some time before vanishing. Even as they lifted the gold to examine it, a thread-like serpent remained faintly visible within its surface. The prefectural officials, recognizing this as a divine sign, ruled the gold rightfully belonged to Zhu-shi. Yet she declined to keep it, leaving its disposition to the state. Prefect Jiang Tingjian and Vice Prefect Tian Kui jointly drafted a memorial, securing the gold in a casket and submitting it to the imperial court.

Upon review, it was noted that in Xizhou, Lu Liang had met his karmic retribution for reckless slaughter, serving as a warning to others. His wife, however, had devoted herself to virtue, and Zhenwu, moved by her sincerity, had bestowed this gold—a clear sign of heavenly favor, untainted by mortal alloy. The gold was then sent to the imperial workshops to be forged into a complete set of Zhenwu’s sacred images. These were entrusted to envoys and conveyed to the Jade Immortal Abbey atop Mount Wudang, where they were placed under the care of an imperial edict inscribed in gold. An annual endowment of ordination certificates was granted to sustain the abbey’s incense and rituals.

Zhu-shi herself was awarded an ordination certificate, along with two hundred *guan* of cash and bolts of silk from Xizhou as recompense. With the funds, she commissioned woodblock prints of Zhenwu’s *Illustrated Admonitions Against Killing*, distributing them to repay the nation’s grace and offer prayers for her late husband, Lu Liang. Her sons and daughters married, and she reopened her silk and cotton shop, restoring its former prosperity.

At the age of eighty-nine, Zhu-shi bathed one day, donned fresh garments, and intoned the sacred name of Zhenwu. Without illness, she passed away.

chunks.original_text: 皂背显圣 扬州江都县白砂村昊元嗣，家豪积善。 每秋冬间，用师巫烧献三界醮纸，内用鹅鸭血肉活命杂供祭祀。 有泰州天庆观道士唐庆余到来，抄注斋粮，偶见本家赛愿，称云：何得天曹众圣与中下界神道，用物命交杂供养，莫非触犯诸天，如何获福。 元嗣问曰：天曹如何供养，愿赐指教。 庆余录出仪式，柢用明香灯烛、酒果净茶、素钙饮馔、柳枝法水、五彩散花、金纸云马，楷书奏状，令备一席，外方裹圆，不得夹带中下界神位。 若能七年依此醮祭，看有何应验。 元嗣次年，改除中下界神道，凭师巫赛愿外，其天曹，请法箓道士醮赛。 将及数年，忽於醮日，有二十余人游化求斋。 元嗣留斋毕，因间从甚处来，作何营业。 内一人答云：我等住无间天，来从无间路来，本业无间所营，去从无间道去。 今日特知此处有祈天之会，故来赴其醮献。 言讫，二十余人，尽化为云雾不见。 内一位椅背上，留下花纹金缕早纱短袖背子一领，极有奇异，已悉天真降临，留此天衣，显其圣验。 遂用绣彩帕，裹藏匣内，永为家传供养。 才遇逐月真武下降日，其衣隐隐有光芒，元嗣子孙皆寿。 后扬州依禀朝旨，括贵老人，召赴圣节宴席。 惟元嗣家子孙寿年八九十百岁以上，兄弟八人内，昊琬寿过一百，步履康健，视听不衰。 州府问劳，据称翁父元嗣在日，义聚不分，及醮祭因依。 及赍到真武早背为验时，太傅陈叔平守杨州，备录申奏。 续蒙指挥，特赐昊瑰立为义门，除授本州摄长吏，恩泽於大门，置义顺土台二所，立华表鹤柱，旌表门闾。 并收真武遗迹衣袍，乃是镇家显圣之物，不得损毁。 净巾结缘 西京善济禅院，有徒弟僧蕴方，自幼年参礼住持僧。 用勤为师，累因勾当缘事，欲来披剃，阻节不圆。 忽有人货术蕴方，求一卦断云：不四十岁，须得披缁。 蕴方后为院门点差，缘化众僧夏浴手巾四百条。 偶到西沟曲阜山下，於涧边，见青衣童子临水濯足。 蕴方近前，又却俱走。 蕴方随后赴之，前者一林，华叶茂盛，见无数六道群魔，坐围四向，其童子立处，却是人间供养。 真武真君活身，坐於石上，检校善恶解怨执对，送东岳转生。 蕴方不敢近前，方欲回转，被适见童子相召云：真君唤蕴方。 既面拜真君，蒙问抄注手巾，收上疏目，恐尔难寻吾之住所，令童子将随身净巾一条与蕴方，略充结缘。 言：秪不得乱与诸色人，称是见吾於此所得。 若泄天机，必招喑痖立报。 蕴方拜谢，将净巾归院纳上，秪称於曲阜山，不识姓名人家，求化得来。 用葱接看，其巾长八尺，非凡俗布，入手如纯缨，遇玲处觉热，暖处却冻，丝纹无接经蔻眼，反覆有金光异香。 用懃带去谒昭文馆大学士，知西京留台司李中孚商量，进奏进奉。 续承诏书来，宣僧用葱童行，蕴方赴阙。 以致临殿根问，称其巾，除圣府天仙可有外，诸国龙宫海藏皆无。 差宝藏库官牙看验，并谓上天虹龙，白凤缨鬓，玉机天女手工之宝、何绿凡世有此。 臣僚上言，若欲本人指说，愿先赐披剃蕴方为僧，必须肯通。 奉圣旨，依其蕴方。 为受恩，推讳不能，即依前据实面奏。 尚未句终，不觉口坠声咽，语渐喑痖，其报果是立应。 除留元物赐赴内道场供养，宜令僧用懃看待蕴方，秪就在京，与赐住院。

**The Black-Backed Manifestation of the Sage**

In Baisha Village, Jiangdu County, Yangzhou, there lived a man named Wu Yuansi, whose family was wealthy and steadfast in accumulating good deeds. Each autumn and winter, they would employ spirit-mediums and shamans to burn offerings of *jiao* paper to the Three Realms, using the blood and flesh of living geese and ducks as sacrificial provisions. One day, Taoist Tang Qingyu of Tianqing Abbey in Taizhou arrived to register for alms-grain. Upon witnessing the family’s vow-fulfilling rites, he remarked: “How can the celestial courts of the heavens and the deities of the middle and lower realms be offered such mixed sacrifices of living beings? Would this not offend the gods of the heavens? How then could blessings be obtained?”

Yuansi asked: “How should the celestial courts be properly offered to? I humbly seek your instruction.”

Qingyu produced a ritual manual, prescribing only pure incense, lamps, candles, wine, fruit, clear tea, vegetarian dishes, willow branches, dharma-water, five-colored scattered flowers, golden paper *yunma* (cloud-horses), and neatly written memorial petitions. A single altar was to be prepared, round on the outside and square within, with no inclusion of the deities of the middle or lower realms. “If you perform these rites for seven years,” he said, “observe what signs may appear.”

The following year, Yuansi removed the deities of the middle and lower realms from his rites, continuing to rely on spirit-mediums for their festivals while inviting ordained Taoist priests to perform the *jiao* rites for the celestial courts. After several years, on the day of the *jiao* ceremony, over twenty wandering mendicants arrived seeking alms. Yuansi hosted them for a meal, then casually inquired where they had come from and what their livelihood was. One replied: “We dwell in the Boundless Heaven, come by the Boundless Path, engage in the Boundless Trade, and depart by the Boundless Way. Today, we learned of this celestial-prayer assembly here and have come to attend the *jiao* offerings.”

As they finished speaking, the twenty-odd men all transformed into clouds and mist, vanishing from sight. On one of the chairs, however, they left behind a short-sleeved, gold-threaded gauze vest with floral patterns—an object of extraordinary wonder. Realizing that celestial immortals had descended and left this heavenly garment as proof of their manifestation, Yuansi wrapped it in an embroidered silk cloth and stored it in a casket, preserving it as a family treasure for perpetual veneration. On the days when Zhenwu descended each month, the garment would emit a faint radiance. Yuansi’s descendants all enjoyed long lives.

Later, in accordance with imperial decree, Yangzhou conducted a census of venerable elders to invite them to the imperial birthday banquet. Among them, Yuansi’s family boasted descendants aged eighty, ninety, and even over a hundred. Of eight brothers, Wu Wan lived past one hundred, his steps still steady, his sight and hearing unimpaired. When the prefectural authorities inquired, they reported that in Wu Yuansi’s time, the family had lived in undivided harmony, faithfully observing the *jiao* rites. When the early vest of Zhenwu was presented as proof, Chen Shuping, the Grand Tutor and governor of Yangzhou, recorded the details and memorialized the throne. Subsequently, an imperial edict was issued, designating Wu Gui as the head of a “Righteous Household” and appointing him acting magistrate of the prefecture. Benevolence was bestowed upon the family’s main gate, where two “Righteous Compliance” earthen platforms were erected, along with ornamental pillars and crane-topped columns to honor their gate. The vest left by Zhenwu—a relic of the deity’s manifestation—was to be preserved as a household treasure, never to be damaged or discarded.

---

**The Pure Kerchief for Karmic Affinity**

At the Shanjian Chan Monastery in the Western Capital, there was a novice monk named Yunfang who, from a young age, had served the abbot with diligence. Due to various duties and circumstances, his tonsure had been repeatedly delayed. One day, someone offered Yunfang a divination, declaring: “Before you turn forty, you must take the tonsure.”

Later, while assigned to the monastery gate, Yunfang was tasked with soliciting donations of four hundred handkerchiefs for the monks’ summer baths. Passing by the foot of Qufu Mountain near the Western Ditch, he saw a youth in black robes washing his feet by the stream. As Yunfang approached, the youth fled in alarm. Yunfang pursued him until they reached a grove dense with blossoming trees, where countless demons of the Six Paths sat encircling the area. The youth stood where mortal offerings were laid, while the True Lord Zhenwu, incarnate, sat upon a rock, reviewing good and evil, resolving grievances, and dispatching souls to Dongyue for rebirth.

Unwilling to draw near, Yunfang was about to turn back when the youth he had seen earlier called out: “The True Lord summons Yunfang.” Approaching and bowing before the deity, Yunfang was asked about the handkerchiefs he had been collecting. The deity recorded the names in a memorial scroll, then said: “Lest you struggle to find my abode, I shall have this youth give you one of my personal pure kerchiefs as a token of karmic affinity. But you must not recklessly give it to just anyone, nor claim it was obtained from me here. If you reveal heavenly secrets, you will immediately be struck mute.”

Yunfang bowed in gratitude and took the kerchief back to the monastery, claiming it had been donated by an anonymous benefactor at Qufu Mountain. When he unfurled it, the kerchief measured eight *chi* in length, unlike any ordinary cloth. It felt as smooth as silk tassels, warm to the touch in cold places and cool in warmth. Its threads were seamless, its weave flawless, and when turned over, it shimmered with golden light and emitted a rare fragrance.

Yunfang carefully carried it to the Hall of Illustrious Literature to consult with Li Zhongfu, the University Scholar and overseer of the Western Capital’s administrative office, who advised him to memorialize the throne. Soon after, an imperial edict arrived, summoning Yunfang to the capital with the kerchief. Upon reaching the palace, he was questioned at the foot of the throne. The kerchief, he was told, was a treasure found nowhere else—neither in the celestial palaces, the dragon abodes, nor the oceanic vaults—save in the hands of heavenly maidens or the phoenix-crested dragons of the skies.

The ministers proposed: “If we wish to learn the full account from this man, we must first grant him tonsure as a monk; only then will he speak freely.” The emperor assented. Overcome with gratitude, Yunfang could no longer conceal the truth and began to recount the events. Before he could finish a single sentence, his voice faltered, his speech slurred, and he was struck mute—proof that the divine retribution had been immediate.

The original kerchief was retained for use in the inner palace’s ritual hall, while Yunfang was ordered to remain in the capital, where he was granted a monastery residence.

The Song dynasty unified the realm and established its supreme rule. Later, at Yingzhou’s Gaoyang Pass, the court received a divine gift of over fifty thousand strings of cash from Zhenwu, the Perfected Warrior of Profound Kindness, which were duly allocated as rewards for Emperor Taizu. Mindful of this, and learning that among the foreign merchants of Yingzhou was a man named Yishou Xian, one of seven brothers—Yishou being the name inscribed on the temple plaque at the frontier shrine—the emperor noted that the seven were celestial spirits descended from the Seven Luminaries, though the meaning of their shared surname, Yi, remained unknown. He promptly ordered Yingzhou to select a site and construct a temple hall dedicated to the Northern Culmen’s Seven Origins and Four Saints. Once the heavenly courts had been painted and adorned, he dispatched a high minister bearing imperial incense to offer sacrifices.

One day at the hour of chen, as the assembled officials accompanied the emperor to the Hall of Illuminating Virtue to deliberate on the submission of the various kings and marquises who had yet to yield their territories, a sudden storm of wind, hail, and swirling clouds arose. The ministers scattered in flight, leaving only Chancellor Zhao Pu at the emperor’s side. Two youths then appeared, guiding them into the Filial Accomplishment Hall. After Taizu had sat for some time, a divine figure materialized in the clouds before the hall: crowned with a starry diadem, robed in embroidered gold, and bearing a tablet, the deity bowed deeply and addressed the emperor:

*“A new era dawns for your august foundation,
Like Yao and Shun, you must rely on worthy men.
Beware the folly of later rulers who seize the throne,
Lest treacherous rebels stain and disrupt your reign.”*

“I am Zhenwu, the Numinous and Responsive Perfected Lord of the Northern Culmen in the Heavenly Capital. I have received your gracious gift of a temple hall in Yingzhou and your subsequent offerings of thanksgiving. Passing by on my celestial patrol, I have come to express my gratitude. I hear that some kings and marquises still cling to their domains, refusing submission. Recently, I witnessed the Supreme Emperor’s decree: all under heaven is fated to be unified under the Song, ensuring an eternal imperial legacy. Beyond the Huai and Han rivers, which have already been reclaimed, the remaining regions are destined to fall in sequence, each within its appointed time—no more than twelve years in all. The order shall begin with Hedong, followed by Southern Tang, Western Shu, Guangdong, Fujian, and finally the Two Zhe. Each must be brought under the realm in turn.”

With that, Zhenwu took his leave and returned to the celestial precincts. Taizu and Zhao Pu then rejoined their attendants, who had been guarding the Hall of Illuminating Virtue in anticipation. The emperor’s heart swelled with joy and reassurance. He selected an auspicious day to hold a grand offering within the inner palace, in humble gratitude for the divine favor. Thereafter, every event unfolded precisely as the sacred counsel had foretold. The imperial fortune was renewed in splendor.

chunks.original_text: 淮东扬州进士傅鸿，一生戒行，供养真武三十余年。 所作所为，常行方便，人人称誉。 贤士大夫，俱以歌诗文墨赠鸿，门前轿马如市。 傅鸿思之，如此应物，甚妨道业，乃弃家云游，至陕西终南山上清太平宫，求一庵寮出家。 知宫张守真，见鸿形貌清古，遂留於本观，为修真上士，别治一室延之。 在观三年，修奉上真，香火虔敬恭恪。 忽夜道众停息寝睡，张守真潜往，叩鸿本寮，闻鸿睡中，似与人语。 忽有火光一道，从鸿寮内进出，守真异之。 明早会鸿试问，夜来火光情由。 鸿曰：今当限至，不任申延。 遂至沐浴易衣，升道堂，听受真武真君托身降言：今为吾传报宋朝天子，一三二月桃花景色天，般真瑞一时妍。 金枝宝运重新令，节当迎赤脚仙。 真语云：柢言此二十八字，吾去矣。 傅鸿一如睡醒，莫测其意。 次日傅鸿潜自遁去，不知踪由。 张守真既得真君降言，不敢沉隐，遂往陕西，经略安抚司，面禀使相张希古，凭委具表奏闻。 时皇帝御览，惊喜交集。 后果於庚戌年辛巳月辛丑日，明德宫降庆太子，即仁庙是也。 向玉城天主赤脚大仙下降，已应真武降言。 预报胜因，奉圣旨下凤翔府，搜寻傅鸿，不知去。 后续奉圣旨，就上清太平宫，重建真武宝阁，及立傅鸿祠堂，赠号胜因真人。 并给赐银绢各一百匹两，酬赐本人家属。 天罡带箭
chunks.translated_text:
The scholar-official Fu Hong of Yangzhou in Huaidong, a presented scholar, had observed the precepts all his life and had served Zhenwu for over thirty years. In all his conduct, he practiced convenience for others, earning universal praise. Eminent gentlemen and great officials all presented him with poems and calligraphy, and carriages and horses thronged his gate like a marketplace. Reflecting on this, Fu Hong thought that such worldly engagement greatly hindered his Daoist cultivation. He therefore abandoned his home and wandered as a cloud-rover until he reached the Supreme Clarity Great Peace Palace on Mount Zhongnan in Shaanxi, where he sought a monastic cell to take up the religious life. Zhang Shouzhen, the superintendent of the palace, seeing Fu Hong’s refined and ancient bearing, kept him at the abbey as a master of transcendental cultivation and prepared a separate chamber for him. For three years, Fu Hong reverently served the Highest Perfected Ones with incense and devotion. One night, after the Daoist assembly had retired to rest, Zhang Shouzhen secretly approached Fu Hong’s cell and heard him speaking in his sleep as if conversing with someone. Suddenly, a streak of firelight issued from within the cell, and Zhang Shouzhen marveled at the sight.

The next morning, he gathered the assembly and questioned Fu Hong about the firelight of the previous night. Fu Hong replied, “My allotted time has now come, and I cannot prolong it.” He then bathed, changed his robes, ascended the Daoist hall, and received the embodied descent and message of Zhenwu the Perfected Lord: “Now convey this to the Son of Heaven of the Song: *In the first, third, and second months, peach blossoms paint the sky in hue; / All at once, the true auspice shines bright and new. / The golden branch renews the mandate’s splendor grand; / The season calls to welcome the barefoot immortal’s hand.*” The true words declared, “Convey only these twenty-eight characters; I depart now.” Fu Hong awoke as if from sleep, unable to fathom their meaning.

The following day, Fu Hong secretly fled, his whereabouts unknown. Zhang Shouzhen, having received the Perfected Lord’s descended message, dared not conceal it. He traveled to Shaanxi and reported in person to the military commissioner and pacification envoy, Zhang Xigu, who then submitted a memorial to the throne. When the emperor beheld it, astonishment and joy mingled in his heart. Later, on the *gengxu* year, the *xinsi* month, and the *xinchou* day, the Crown Prince of Auspicious Descent was born in the Hall of Illuminating Virtue—this was Emperor Renzong. The barefoot immortal, Heavenly Lord of the Jade City, had descended, fulfilling Zhenwu’s prophecy. In anticipation of this blessed cause, an imperial edict was issued to Fengxiang Prefecture to search for Fu Hong, but he was nowhere to be found. A subsequent edict commanded the reconstruction of the Zhenwu Precious Pavilion at the Supreme Clarity Great Peace Palace and the establishment of a shrine to Fu Hong, who was posthumously enfeoffed as the Perfected One of Victorious Karma. One hundred bolts of silk and one hundred taels of silver were bestowed upon his family in recompense. The celestial spear bore its mark.

chunks.original_text: 明道中贝州，王则反逆。 据枢密院选委，保信军节度使尚书兵部侍郎文彦博，前去招捉。 今承相帅回奏：王则叛寇，尽已诛灭，非臣功力。 臣自到梅州，见南城门路东，有一华表，柱题圆通，观额内是真武殿，遂赴殿备，愿垂圣助。 寻到贝州，近城二十，先令将佐问罪其三则。 对敌时，第四将凌耸出军迎敌，赶王则复入贝州，闭门不出。 试待打城搜擒，缘是本朝州土，不欲遽坏，更且守候。 计二十日，忽见贝州城上，迅发暴风，乱飞砂雹，如弓弩发箭。 时见寇军从空中坠下城脚，微死微活。 不觉城门大开，大军竞入，除留居民外，遇有器甲兵仗者，尽行诛戮。 王则就擒马前，尸首异处。 遂委官权行知监，臣获胜回。 复往圆通观，谒谢真武，备醮报赛。 细观真武左畔，立塑一从官员，被械冑，名曰天罡神将，左臂上带箭一只，入探三寸，有王则军号。 才除其箭，随有脓血流出。 寻和香泥，修茸箭疮。 并收元箭一只，见到候进上，送三司礼部看详。 差使宝御香前去祭奠，乃赐修盖殿宇。 候毕，别降御衔醮谢。 其贝州承斯保护重恩，特改为恩州。 河魁擎鞘 南康军庐山太清观，有隋朝张佑之奏请，建真武并神父圣母降真殿。 自后，显应甚多。 是时，烈祖会群臣，欲求福建归明。
chunks.translated_text:
During the *Mingdao* era, Wang Ze rebelled in Beizhou. The Bureau of Military Affairs selected and commissioned Wen Yanbo, Minister of War and Pacification Commissioner of the Baoxin Army, to suppress the uprising. Upon his return, the Grand Preceptor reported: "The rebel Wang Ze and his band have been utterly exterminated—not by my own merit. Upon arriving in Meizhou, I saw to the east of the southern city gate a *huabiao* pillar inscribed with 'Perfection of Rounded Response.' The plaque above the hall read 'Hall of Zhenwu,' so I entered to offer prayers, beseeching divine aid. Upon reaching Beizhou, twenty *li* from the city, I first dispatched my generals to demand the surrender of three of Wang Ze’s lieutenants. During the battle, my fourth commander, Ling Song, led the vanguard to engage the enemy, driving Wang Ze back into Beizhou, where he shut the gates and refused to emerge. Though we prepared to besiege and storm the city, I hesitated to destroy it outright, as it was imperial territory, and so we waited. After twenty days, a sudden violent storm erupted over Beizhou, hurling sand and hail like arrows loosed from bows. The rebel forces were flung from the walls, some dead, some barely alive. Before we knew it, the city gates swung open, and our troops surged in. All who bore arms were slaughtered, sparing only the civilians. Wang Ze was captured before my horse, his head severed from his body. I then appointed an official to oversee the city’s governance before returning in triumph. I revisited the Hall of Perfection of Rounded Response to pay homage to Zhenwu and offer a grand *jiao* sacrifice in gratitude. Upon closer inspection, I saw to Zhenwu’s left a statue of an armored attendant, bound in fetters, named the Celestial Stem General. An arrow pierced his left arm to a depth of three *cun*, bearing Wang Ze’s military insignia. When I removed the arrow, pus and blood flowed forth. I mixed fragrant clay to dress the wound, then retrieved the arrow itself. Upon returning, I presented it to the court for examination by the Ministry of Rites under the Three Departments. An envoy was dispatched with imperial incense to offer sacrifices, and the hall was ordered to be repaired and expanded. After its completion, a separate imperial decree commanded a *jiao* rite of thanksgiving. In recognition of Beizhou’s deliverance by this profound grace, it was renamed Enzhou.

The *River Chariot* bore the scabbard.

At the Supreme Clarity Abbey on Mount Lu in Nankang Commandery, a petition by Zhang You of the Sui dynasty had established the Hall of Zhenwu and the Hall of the Divine Father and Holy Mother’s Descent. Since then, its numinous responses had been manifold. At that time, Emperor Liezu convened his ministers, seeking to secure the submission of Fujian."

chunks.original_text: 群臣奏云：福建地刚、人狡，除是动兵取之。 烈祖从此统兵征伐。 人马届涂，忽狂风黑雾，有毒蛇、猛兽拦道路，兵仗不能前进。 烈祖乃焚香祷空，忽於云霭中，立一神人，鞠躬至前曰：臣是福州闽山仙源观土地，蒙本观真武，点来界首迎接，为知－大王举兵，欲取福建。 缘福建世业未终，已自注定庚午岁，合径归俪极，不当大王收取。 特将此意迎谏，大王人马度山、越水，戈刃之下，死伤性命。 良久，神人不见，风雾顿息。 烈祖因此回军，至庐山降真殿祭献。 见右立一从官，手擎剑鞘者，烈祖指问，道众奏曰：是河魁也。 烈祖叹曰：柢此便是在路中现者神人，相貌一同。 后来烈祖归国上清宫，依庐山太清观式样，盖造真武、神父、圣母三真宝殿，－令本官修奉香火。 福建探知，李王兵马将至本界，因何回转，尚虑李王设伏。 遣使赴南唐审问，烈祖於回文内，具述中路逢一神人，言是仙源宫土地，蒙真武差来，迎报福建世业未竭，自注下庚午年，合归俪极，不当南唐取之。 感此神言，更不进兵。 其马氏已知仙源宫委是通灵，保护国界，却为来书，云已注庚午岁，合归俪极，因此怀疑，集诸局商议，若谓岁次庚午，尚有年深，未委俪极，因依合属，何所之兆，竟不测其理。 择日集百官，往闽山仙源宫，祷于真武，愿降灵应，欲闻庚午归俪极之意。 果荷圣恩响应，已知俪极是周后兴运，天水之姓，一统天下，列国皆纳土。 其龙兴殿，名俪极故也。 福王马氏遂与南唐讲和，无复相侵。 蜀王归顺 磁州崇明观，真武显圣，遍及真定等二十余年，皆获圣赐，斛斗共一十五万余石，出耀救饥。 除磁州收到价钱，支付崇明观修造讫，余诸州价钱，亦及万数。 别无支费，奏取旨施行。 续降指挥，下河北转运司，起发上件栗麦价钱，就京城创四圣观，赐额为四圣紫极观，特设普天大醮，并降赦恩，上达四圣，通凡降鉴。 朝廷因用兵取蜀未次，忽夜有狂风一阵，过於殿庭。 时太祖皇帝，於灯烛之下，见一黄衣武士，告谓是北极四圣殿下直日符吏，言西川若非四圣降灵，卒未有意归顺。 今已献上地钦图经，付使相侯元质等讫，相将回京进呈，不消圣虑。 臣奉真武差报陛下，天蓬天猷黑杀既见蜀王归顺，已回云驭。 惟有真武，恐西事别有悔意，今在云空守候，陛下急差官兵前去迎接，立便委诸司库兵，交割蜀地疆界。 言讫，符吏不见。 次日早朝，果有急报，蜀王归顺。

The ministers memorialized: "Fujian’s terrain is rugged and its people cunning; only military force can subdue it." Thereupon, Emperor Liezu personally led the campaign. As the army neared its destination, a sudden gale arose, blackening the sky with fog, while venomous serpents and fierce beasts blocked the road, halting the advance of weapons and troops. Emperor Liezu then burned incense and prayed to the heavens. Suddenly, amidst the clouds and mist, a divine figure appeared, bowing deeply before him and saying: "Your servant is the local earth deity of Xianyuan Abbey on Mount Min in Fuzhou. By order of Zhenwu of this abbey, I have come to the frontier to receive you. I know that Your Majesty has raised an army to take Fujian. Yet Fujian’s allotted destiny is not yet exhausted—it is already decreed that in the *gengwu* year, it shall directly submit to the Supreme One. It is not for the Southern Tang to seize. I have come to admonish you: if Your Majesty’s troops cross mountains and rivers, countless lives will be lost beneath the blades of war." After a long while, the deity vanished, and the wind and fog instantly cleared. Emperor Liezu thus withdrew his forces and, upon reaching the Hall of Descent on Mount Lu, offered sacrifices. There, he saw a retainer standing to the right, holding a sword scabbard. Pointing, he inquired, and the Daoist assembly replied: "That is the *River Chariot*." Emperor Liezu sighed: "This must be the same divine figure who appeared on the road—their appearance was identical."

Later, upon returning to the Shangqing Palace in the capital, Emperor Liezu had halls built for Zhenwu, the Divine Father, and the Holy Mother, modeled after those of the Supreme Clarity Abbey on Mount Lu, and ordered officials to maintain their incense and offerings. When Fujian’s spies learned that the Southern Tang army had reached their border but then retreated, they suspected an ambush. They dispatched envoys to the Southern Tang to investigate. In his reply, Emperor Liezu detailed his encounter on the road with a divine figure who claimed to be the earth deity of Xianyuan Abbey, sent by Zhenwu to report that Fujian’s allotted destiny was not yet exhausted—it was fated to submit to the Supreme One in the *gengwu* year, not to the Southern Tang. Moved by these words, he had abandoned the campaign.

The Ma clan of Fujian, learning of Xianyuan Abbey’s manifest numinosity in protecting their borders, received the letter and grew doubtful. Though the *gengwu* year was still distant, they convened their ministers to deliberate: if the year had already been decreed for submission to the Supreme One, what omen foretold its allegiance? Unable to fathom the matter, they chose an auspicious day and assembled all officials to pray at Xianyuan Abbey before Zhenwu, beseeching a divine response regarding the meaning of submission in the *gengwu* year. By the grace of the deity, the answer came: the Supreme One was the rising fortune of the Zhou dynasty, of the Tian Shui surname, who would unify the realm, and all states would yield their lands. The Dragon Ascendancy Hall was thus named for the Supreme One. Thereupon, King Ma of Fujian made peace with the Southern Tang, and hostilities ceased.

**The King of Shu Submits**
At Chongming Abbey in Cizhou, Zhenwu’s divine manifestations had blessed Zhen Ding and over twenty other prefectures for more than twenty years, bestowing sacred gifts of grain totaling over 150,000 *hu*, which were distributed to relieve famine. After deducting the funds received by Cizhou for the abbey’s repairs, the remaining sums from other prefectures also amounted to tens of thousands. With no other expenditures, a memorial was submitted to the throne for approval. A subsequent imperial decree ordered the Hebei Transport Bureau to forward the grain and wheat payments to the capital to establish the Abbey of the Four Saints, bestowing upon it the name *Four Saints Purple Ultimate Abbey*. A grand *jiao* rite for all under heaven was held, and an amnesty was proclaimed, its blessings reaching the Four Saints and all divine observers.

At that time, the court was preparing to conquer Shu, when suddenly one night a fierce wind swept through the palace halls. By lamplight, Emperor Taizu saw a yellow-robed warrior, who declared himself a *fushi* attendant of the Four Saints of the Northern Ultimate. He said: "Were it not for the Four Saints’ divine intervention, the King of Shu would not yet have considered submission. He has now presented the *Revered Atlas of the Land* to Envoy Hou Yuanzhi and his party, who are returning to the capital to present it. Your Majesty need not worry." The warrior continued: "By Zhenwu’s command, I report that the Heavenly Marshals Tianpeng, Tianyou, and Heisha, having witnessed the King of Shu’s submission, have already returned to the heavens. Only Zhenwu remains, fearing further hesitation in the west. He now waits in the clouds; Your Majesty should swiftly dispatch officials and troops to receive him. Immediately order the relevant bureaus to take charge of Shu’s borders." With that, the *fushi* vanished.

The next morning at court, an urgent report arrived: the King of Shu had submitted.

chunks.original_text: 由是，太祖继於四圣观设醮报谢。 藩镇通和 河北雄州，有摧场要切关口，除屯马步军二十万外，有敢勇白身指使二千。 内有张琪，居常供养真武，得悟遁甲行军之事。 康定年中，北鄙浅蕃胡知从等，侵雄州摧场。 时王耐为经略安抚使，乃令敢勇前去抵敌，果获胜捷。 张琪取覆，今夜主有蕃兵复来侵犯，云有巽风起，顺壬癸，立应其兆，兼防火灾。 有司差兵将守护，果至二更，蕃兵数万犯界濠。 张琪解下遁甲秘文，上告真武神灵，作法隐形。 於摧场，致遭捉获，知远蒙恩放归。 当时入场，却觉头热身寒，被宋朝家神真武真君，降圣护持。 本蕃亦曾供养，为触犯不灵。 今西梁城已是招伏通和，更无作乱之意，再犯神怒。 所献地里，愿求授真武，分降入蕃，依例供养。 奉圣旨，令四圣观编录真武下降，一切供养仪范回答。 及下雄州，交割所进地里入籍，拘收其胡知从、知远，至今通和，兵革永息，以致雄州喊退三分兵级支赐。 命，往西北方名山洞天，修建金箓斋醮，庶表宸衷，愿回圣鉴。 瓢倾三万 徐州陈昭倚，任明州通判时，因游天童山，见镌真武一身，用朱绿装填，立山路尘秽处，一龟四足皆折，过者不顾。 昭倚备钱募匠，接续圣相，添修龟足，盖造殿屋一间。 昭倚得替，在西门湖塘，见道人从水面来，叩船求相见。 昭倚失於出迟，却回身而去，云：特来报谢成立我身之恩。 昭倚追思，是真武降灵，为修天童山石像报应耳。 乃画真武一轴供养，官至太常少卿，守徐州。 偶患脚寻医，寄居滕县。 忽蒙朝廷察访，疾愈，差充秦凤路运副。 昭倚知西鄙，以计运为重忧，将带真武随身供养。 时经略总管岑元宥，因乏粮给，欲责运司。 忽有道流，在军营卖食药。 军人恐是西蕃细作，面见场内。 良久，有人称东库火发，即灭。

Thus, the Grand Ancestor subsequently held a grand jiao offering at the Four Saints Temple to express gratitude. The feudatories made peace, and at Xiongzhou in Hebei—a critical pass at the Cui Barrier—beyond the garrison of two hundred thousand cavalry and infantry, there were two thousand *ganyong* brave commoners serving as personal aides. Among them was Zhang Qi, who regularly made offerings to Zhenwu and had gained insight into the arts of *dunjia* and military strategy.

During the Kangding era, the shallow tribes of the northern frontier, led by Hu Zhicong and others, invaded the Cui Barrier at Xiongzhou. At the time, Wang Nai served as Military Commissioner and Pacification Envoy. He ordered the *ganyong* to resist the enemy, and they indeed achieved victory. Zhang Qi divined that the barbarian troops would return that very night to invade, predicting that a *xun* wind would rise, following the *ren* and *gui* directions, and that this would be an omen, along with the threat of fire. The authorities dispatched troops to guard the area. As expected, at the second watch, tens of thousands of barbarian soldiers breached the border moat. Zhang Qi unfastened his *dunjia* secret texts, invoked the divine power of Zhenwu, and performed a ritual to conceal their forms. At the Cui Barrier, the barbarians were captured, and Hu Zhiyuan, having received mercy, was released.

Upon returning to the camp, Zhang Qi felt his head grow hot and his body cold, realizing he had been protected by the divine presence of Zhenwu, the Perfected Lord of the True Warrior, of the Song dynasty. The barbarians, too, had once made offerings to Zhenwu, but their transgressions had rendered the deity unresponsive. Now, with Xiliang City having submitted and made peace, they harbored no further intent to rebel, lest they again incur divine wrath. They presented their lands and requested that Zhenwu’s presence be bestowed upon them, to be enshrined and worshipped according to custom.

By imperial decree, the Four Saints Temple was ordered to compile records of Zhenwu’s descents and to establish all rites and offerings in response. The lands presented were to be registered in Xiongzhou, and Hu Zhicong and Hu Zhiyuan were to be detained. From then on, peace prevailed, and warfare ceased. As a result, the garrison at Xiongzhou was reduced by a third, and the troops were rewarded. The emperor commanded that golden registers and grand jiao offerings be held in the renowned grotto-heavens of the northwest to express his imperial devotion and seek the favor of the sagely gaze.

When Chen Zhaoyi of Xuzhou served as Vice Prefect of Mingzhou, he traveled to Tiantong Mountain and saw a statue of Zhenwu carved into the rock, painted in red and green, standing in a dusty and neglected spot along the mountain path. The tortoise at its base had all four feet broken, and passersby paid it no heed. Zhaoyi provided funds to hire craftsmen to restore the sacred image, repairing the tortoise’s feet and constructing a small hall to shelter it.

After Zhaoyi was relieved of his post, he was by the West Gate Lake when he saw a Daoist priest approaching across the water, knocking on his boat to request an audience. Zhaoyi was slow to emerge, and the priest turned away, saying, “I came only to express my gratitude for restoring my form.” Zhaoyi realized this was Zhenwu’s divine manifestation, a response to his restoration of the stone statue on Tiantong Mountain. He then painted a scroll of Zhenwu to enshrine and worship. Later, he rose to the rank of Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices and was appointed Prefect of Xuzhou.

While suffering from a foot ailment and seeking medical treatment, he stayed in Teng County. Suddenly, the court sent an inspector, and upon his recovery, he was appointed Vice Transport Commissioner of the Qinfeng Circuit. Zhaoyi, aware of the critical importance of logistics in the western frontier, carried the image of Zhenwu with him for protection.

At the time, Military Commissioner Cen Yuanyou was short of provisions and intended to hold the Transport Bureau accountable. Suddenly, a Daoist priest appeared in the military camp selling medicinal food. The soldiers, suspecting him of being a Western barbarian spy, brought him before the camp authorities. After some time, someone shouted that a fire had broken out in the eastern granary, and it was quickly extinguished.

chunks.original_text: 相持至晓，北蕃折兵一万余众，张琪亲擒到蕃将胡知远，招认是北蕃西梁土主，节度使胡知从亲弟，与兄知从，分割一千二百里，接连雄州界，其兄为属北蕃。 人俱在雄州摧场，卖买课利，竞归大朝，有此心忿。 凡二年，聚兵欲坏摧场，不得其便。 知远献计，动十万兵，至夜抢劫。 缘知远入场放火时，觉头如斧斫，身似水淋，秪见云中鬼神撮其火焰，半扬半灭，散於空中。 又见一神将，披发仗剑，喝令不得走。 知远走出前，被大蛇拦截，后遇一龟衔定，被张琪捉下，若得一命回蕃，限一月日，与兄知从，同赍誓书来降。 王勔会集众官面议，遂放胡知远归蕃。 保明申奏，蒙降指挥，谨就在京四圣观设醮一会。 仍於雄州摧场，建造报恩真武殿，令选道士焚修，许令刊碑，为记其敢勇。 张琪特授右班殿直，雄州据北蕃。 西梁城节度使胡知从，遣赵继明入国进奏。 雄州差官，就界接伴，续具剖，差使星夜准闻准中书看详。 胡知从是分土浅蕃，节镇诸侯，近因动兵来劫摧场，若非敢勇张琪精通遁甲，告现真武福神，生擒胡知远，却放归蕃，克伏甘降。 今再有使臣，秪令就雄州，接待审问申奏。 经略王勔，遂引赵继明入城，称欲割献粟地一百四十里，有六百户植利，并进表一通。 近因抢劫摧，帅首却称是陈昭倚亲随人，姓裴，传得此方，曾救天下无限饿人。 为见招讨，正此嗔责本官，又恐粮草应副失时，故来货散灵丹，定不误事。 岑元宥试分数服，与伤中临死人吃，皆云胸腹饱满。 其流取一瓢子，付无宥告云：我亦有此药一囊，欲往西阵李大王处货卖。 岑元宥惊异，将此药瓢子倾表，其药约三万有余，夫足人马，兼瓢子底有衬纸一片，题字云：是太常少卿陈昭倚家神，裴真人救愿之法，士马服此，三日不食，省免粮草。 次又西蕃李大王来问，称令奸人来卖接骨风药，数万人服之，皆如瘫痪倒外，不敢约战，情愿回蕃。 元宥安坐获胜，并写纸昭应，曾於唐则天时，生裴侍郎家，留此姓氏。 今岑元宥几通闻奏，蒙三司参详，除将校依次给赏，其陈昭倚升礼部侍郎，所有岑元宥收到药瓢子、纸上文墨，收寄天章阁，宜诏天下。 天庆观普设醮箓七昼夜，及系真武观宇，许支官钱修茸。 壶表一京 东京紫极四圣观，童行洪知辩，舍俗出家，逐日扫并三门殿廊。 夜问打铺，宿於廊下。 缘四圣画於紫极殿两轩四壁，除本观常行香火外，知辩逐日自打化钱，收买笺檀，焚诵供养，二十年不报。 至和二年，京城雨雪。 夜深，忽见门下有货药道人，用蒲袋枕头，外於湿地。 知辩恐风雪相逼，遂唤他起，引入铺席内同睡。 至晓，道士辞去，知辩告日：才食后，便困倦人，说是脾疾，愿求一二服。 蒙将壶芦子摇动，裹有药数丸，连壶芦付与知辩，令候子时，用净水面北，念金阙真人七遍，吞下一丸，余留备急救人。 道士出门不见。 知辩当夜吃一服，更不思饮食。 在京，皆云知辩遇仙绝粒。 以致亲王宰执臣僚，委证诣实，遂达圣聪，蒙委开封府及御史台，抚问元遇情由，内有金阙真人之语。 详解，即真武本师，太上老君之号。 时京城军民，久遭雨雪，多患瘟疫，知辩遂将壶芦内药丸施散，秪图略救数人，其壶芦直至倾偯一京，约四万余人，其药尚未尽，而患者安全。

At dawn after the prolonged standoff, the Northern Barbarians had lost over ten thousand troops. Zhang Qi personally captured the barbarian general Hu Zhiyuan, who confessed that he was the lord of Xiliang in the Northern Barbarians’ territory and the younger brother of Hu Zhicong, the regional military governor. The two brothers divided a stretch of twelve hundred *li*, bordering Xiongzhou, with his elder brother now subject to the Northern Barbarians. Both had long resided in Xiongzhou’s border market, profiting from trade and tribute, but their allegiance had shifted to the Great Dynasty, inciting resentment. For two years, they had gathered troops to disrupt the market but found no opportunity. Zhiyuan then devised a plan to mobilize a hundred thousand soldiers for a nighttime raid. Yet when he entered the market to set fires, he felt as though his head were split by an axe and his body drenched in water. He saw ghostly spirits in the clouds seizing the flames, half-extinguishing them and scattering them into the air. Another divine general, disheveled and wielding a sword, shouted at him to halt. As Zhiyuan fled, a giant serpent blocked his path, and from behind, a tortoise clamped onto him, allowing Zhang Qi to seize him. Zhiyuan pleaded for his life, vowing that within a month, he and his brother Zhicong would present a sworn oath of surrender. Wang Mian convened the officials to deliberate, and they released Hu Zhiyuan to return to his territory. A memorial was submitted to the throne, and an imperial decree ordered a grand jiao ritual at the Four Saints Temple in the capital. A Hall of Gratitude to Zhenwu was also built at Xiongzhou’s border market, with Daoist priests appointed to conduct rituals, and a stele was commissioned to record Zhang Qi’s valor. Zhang Qi was specially appointed as *Youban Dianzhi*, while Xiongzhou remained a bulwark against the Northern Barbarians.

The military governor of Xiliang, Hu Zhicong, dispatched Zhao Jiming to the court with a memorial. Xiongzhou sent an official to the border to receive him, and after further deliberation, a messenger was dispatched posthaste to report to the Chancellery. Hu Zhicong, a minor chieftain ruling a frontier region, had recently launched an attack on the border market. Had it not been for Zhang Qi’s courage, mastery of *dunjia*, and invocation of Zhenwu’s divine aid—capturing Hu Zhiyuan before releasing him to secure his surrender—this outcome would not have been possible. Now, with another envoy arriving, he was to be received and interrogated in Xiongzhou before a memorial was submitted. Commissioner Wang Mian escorted Zhao Jiming into the city, where he offered to cede a hundred and forty *li* of millet-producing land with six hundred households, along with a formal memorial.

During the raid on the market, the leader of the raiding party turned out to be a former attendant of Chen Zhaoyi, surnamed Pei, who had learned this method and saved countless starving people. Fearing punishment from the military commissioner for his master’s actions and concerned about delays in grain provisions, he had come to sell miraculous elixirs, assuring them it would not disrupt operations. Cen Yuanyou tested the medicine on several critically wounded men, who reported feeling satiated. The Daoist took a gourd ladle and handed it to Yuanyou, saying, “I also have a bag of this medicine and intend to sell it to General Li of the Western Front.” Yuanyou, astonished, examined the ladle and found over thirty thousand doses—enough to sustain an entire army. At the bottom of the ladle was a slip of paper inscribed: *“This is the divine method of Pei the Perfected, from the household of Vice Minister of Rites Chen Zhaoyi. When consumed by soldiers and horses, it allows three days without food, sparing the need for grain provisions.”*

Later, General Li of the Western Barbarians sent word that a spy had sold him a “wind medicine for setting bones,” which, when taken by tens of thousands of his men, left them paralyzed and unable to fight. He pledged to withdraw his forces. Yuanyou, having secured victory without effort, wrote a report on the miraculous response. The Daoist, surnamed Pei, had been born in the household of Minister Pei during the reign of Empress Wu of Tang and had retained the surname. After several memorials from Yuanyou, the Three Departments deliberated and rewarded the officers in order of merit. Chen Zhaoyi was promoted to Vice Minister of Rites, and the gourd ladle and inscribed paper received by Yuanyou were deposited in the Tianzhang Pavilion, with an edict issued for their nationwide dissemination. A seven-day jiao ritual was held at Tianqing Temple, and funds were allocated for the renovation of Zhenwu temples. A memorial was presented to the court.

In the Eastern Capital’s Purple Ultimate Four Saints Temple, a young acolyte named Hong Zhibian had renounced the secular world. Daily, he swept the temple gates, halls, and corridors, and at night, he laid out his bedding to sleep in the corridor. The Four Saints were painted on the walls of the Purple Ultimate Hall, and beyond the temple’s regular offerings, Zhibian daily begged for alms to purchase sandalwood and incense for his devotions, though twenty years passed without recompense.

In the second year of the Zhihe era, the capital was blanketed in snow. Late one night, Zhibian saw a Daoist selling medicine outside the gate, resting his head on a rush bag on the damp ground. Fearing the wind and snow would harm him, Zhibian called him inside and shared his bedding. At dawn, the Daoist prepared to leave, and Zhibian said, “After eating, I grow drowsy—it must be a spleen ailment. Might I have a dose or two?” The Daoist shook his gourd, revealing several pills, and handed it to Zhibian, instructing him to wait until midnight, face north, recite the name of the Golden Portal Perfected Seven times, and swallow one pill, keeping the rest for emergencies. The Daoist vanished upon leaving.

That night, Zhibian took one dose and no longer craved food. Word spread through the capital that Zhibian had encountered an immortal and ceased eating. Princes, ministers, and officials verified the account, which reached the emperor’s ears. The Kaifeng Prefecture and the Censorate were ordered to investigate the circumstances, particularly the mention of the Golden Portal Perfected. Upon inquiry, it was revealed to be the title of Zhenwu’s original master, the Most High Lord Lao. At the time, the capital’s populace had long suffered from snow and pestilence. Zhibian distributed the pills from the gourd, intending to save a few, but the gourd’s contents never diminished, healing over forty thousand people. The medicine remained inexhaustible, and all who took it recovered.

The Censorate memorialized, requesting that Hong Zhibian be specially granted a monastic ordination certificate and permitted to wear the robes. Additionally, a grand Daoist ritual and vegetarian feast were to be held at his home temple to repay the grace of his encounter with the divine. **Clearing the Snow and Aiding the Journey**

The defense commissioner of Xiongzhou, Dai Kui—concurrently deputy commander of the Palace Armies—was dispatched to lead one hundred thousand troops to Annam. Upon reaching Yongzhou, they were met with heavy snow, forcing them to halt for half a month. Provisions ran short, and many froze to death. A military aide named Fang Zong reported: "In the depths of winter, the roads are buried under six feet of snow, and transport is cut off. To save the lives of men and horses, we must pray to the Perfected Warrior, the Blessed Divinity, for clear skies." Fang Zong had brought a painted image of the deity with him. Dai Kui prepared offerings and, facing the portrait of Zhenwu, made a sincere vow. No sooner had he burned the memorial paper than the skies cleared, clouds dispersed, and the sun shone, opening the roads. They reached Annam and achieved complete victory. By imperial decree, a seven-day ritual was held at the newly built Baoying Pavilion of Zhenwu to give thanks.

**Calming the Storm and Rescuing the Fleet**

In the twelfth month of the second year of Tiansheng, Long Mengxi, a patrol inspector of Meijiang in Laizhou, illegally carried weapons while suppressing smuggling. Conspiring with his soldiers, he extorted wealth from coastal residents for personal gain. When his crimes were exposed, officials were sent to investigate. Instead of submitting, he plotted rebellion with his troops, fled to sea with his family, and began pillaging merchant ships, killing and wounding many. He disrupted markets and gathered hundreds of pirates, making suppression nearly impossible. Local authorities reported the emergency, and the court dispatched Lu Feng, the chief patrol inspector of Dengzhou, with a thousand elite naval soldiers to quell the uprising. Later, Lu Feng was cornered by Gong Mengxi in the deep waters near Mount Jianshan. After five days without provisions, they found no escape. Recalling his family’s devotion to Zhenwu, whose prayers were always answered, Lu Feng, in desperation, cried out: "Zhenwu, come to our aid!" That night, as the soldiers sat in their boats, the tide suddenly surged, and winds whipped the waves into a frenzy. From Gong Mengxi’s fleet came shouts and the clamor of battle, but a thick fog obscured Lu Feng’s ships. By dawn, floating corpses lay before Lu Feng’s vessels, along with wrecked warships half-sunk in the shallows. Upon inspection, they were Gong Mengxi and his family, all dead. Twenty-odd survivors were captured and bound, their leader’s head severed by Lu Feng’s sailors. The prisoners were taken to the Qingzhou Pacification and Surveillance Commission for interrogation. That night, amidst dark clouds, divine generals, ghostly soldiers, venomous snakes, and fierce beasts filled the sky in indescribable chaos. The prefectural authorities, recognizing the descent of sacred power, reported the event to all relevant offices. Pacification Commissioner Liang Jia memorialized the throne, and by imperial decree, Lu Feng was promoted to *Chongyi* Envoy. Additionally, a decree ordered the construction of a temple at the Meijiang patrol station in Laizhou, where an image of Zhenwu and his divine generals and celestial soldiers would be enshrined, named the "Temple of Battle and Gratitude."

**Divine Arrows and Falling Dust**

During the Tianxi era, Fang Zicai, Vice Minister of War and concurrently Military Commissioner of Yingzhou and Gaoyang Pass, memorialized his arrival at his post three months prior. On the night of the sixteenth day of the eighth month of the first year, over two thousand men led by Lu Jicheng, chieftain of the Qiantan Pingwu Stockade, invaded the border and seized over four thousand *shi* of grain and fodder from Qingmu Fortress. The pass dispatched Commander Zou Shu and Aide Liu Yi with two thousand troops to demand an explanation. The next day, ten thousand tribal soldiers arrived, led by a general who declared: "I am Yan Lianxin, sent by the Northern Yan King Nie Huqi. Qingmu Fortress annually collects over ten million *shi* of military grain and fodder, so twenty thousand troops were dispatched to seize it. Upon reaching Pingwu Stockade, its chieftain Lu Jicheng proposed raiding Qingmu Fortress on the night of the sixteenth, when they would be unprepared." Zou Shu replied: "The Great Yan Emperor has made peace. How dare the Northern Yan King Nie Huqi act without authorization? We do not wish to report this to the court. Instead, send envoys to Yan to return the stolen grain and fodder to Qingmu Fortress." Yan Lianxin refused, leading to battle, in which the tribal forces were routed. Nie Huqi then led over two hundred thousand troops to encircle the northwest gates of Yingzhou, halting half a mile from the moat for six days. On the seventh day—the ninth day of the ninth month—a sudden ground-level gale arose, accompanied by swirling rain and mist. The tribal forces could be heard retreating in panic. Pursuing soldiers found Zou Shu and others in the grassy paths, along with several wounded tribesmen. Fang Zicai interrogated one, who said: "We do not know what deity resides in your city. At the northwest gates, a ground-shaking gale kicked up sand and dust, blinding us. We heard the sound of arrows raining down like a storm, and countless pythons chased and bit men and horses. Nie Huqi cried out once from his horse before ordering a retreat. We were bitten by snakes and struck by arrows, unable to flee, and were captured." Upon examining the wounds, they found only snakebites and arrow wounds, with no visible entry points—clear signs of divine intervention. Within ten days, a border patrol brought two tribal officers with a sealed leather tube addressed to "Fang, Vice Minister of War and Military Commissioner of Yingzhou and Gaoyang Pass." The message read: "Henceforth, we dare not dispatch troops without authorization."

Zhibian distributed the pills from the gourd, intending to save a few, but the gourd’s contents never diminished, healing over forty thousand people. chunks.original_text: 聂胡祈於右眼暗中一箭，及取落箭锋，於手中化为灰粉。 如壁画者及风尘内变现毒蛇神鬼，赶败蕃兵二十余万，不知本关供养何神，如此灵验。 今封去神箭一只，诸将定验名祠，回报责要，祈求保安眼目。 房之才将箭细看，委是粉壁者。 遍往宫观寺院及庙宇，并无此壁画。 后往州南新创寿先庙内，正壁画北极紫微大帝，两畔画四圣，皆挂金甲立身，各带箭筐，至真武箭箧当中，阙昼箭一只，继将蕃中送到者，灰壁画色比对一同。 房之才焚香，复将壁箭亲手逐廊揩上箭箧阙处，辏依画壁如故，但有丝痕微露为验。 本司已具缘由，遣使回蕃，奏取照会。 朝廷遣降御香，往瀛州寿先庙建醮。 仍告命天下宫观，如无真武殿，即仰建立，及下高阳关推赏。 神枪竹刃 知宾州苏咸，投遗表，论柱州安抚司不发救兵来拒蛮寇，致守臣身死。 其苏咸死后，有监税王褒被差巡城。 半夜，越墙濠私遁，值雷雨，走入林中，被数神人擒捉，问：何人潜窜。 应曰：宾州监税王褒畏惧，而逃其主者。 乃喝王褒曰：太平时贪利禄，滥受国家。 当其急难，畏避奔走。 合与一死。

Nie Huqi was struck by an arrow in his right eye. When the arrowhead was retrieved, it crumbled to ash in his hand. As if from a mural or amid the whirling dust, venomous serpents, divine spirits, and spectral beings manifested, routing over two hundred thousand tribal soldiers. We know not which deity this pass venerates, yet its efficacy is beyond doubt. We now seal and send one divine arrow, that your generals may verify the temple’s name and report back, beseeching protection for our eyes and well-being.

Fang Zhicai examined the arrow closely and found it indeed matched the mural’s depiction. He searched all palaces, Daoist abbeys, temples, and shrines, yet none bore such a painting. Later, at the newly built Shouxian Temple south of the prefecture, he found on the central wall a portrait of the North Star’s Purple Tenuity Emperor, flanked by the Four Saints—all clad in golden armor, standing erect, each bearing a quiver. In Zhenwu’s quiver, one arrow was missing. Comparing the arrow sent from the tribal lands with the mural’s hue, they matched perfectly. Fang Zhicai lit incense and personally fitted the mural’s arrow into the vacant slot in the quiver, where it settled seamlessly, leaving only the faintest seam as proof.

His office documented the circumstances and dispatched an envoy to the tribal lands to present the findings. The court sent imperial incense to Shouxian Temple in Yingzhou for a grand jiao offering. It further decreed that all abbeys nationwide lacking a Zhenwu Hall must construct one, and rewarded Gaoyang Pass accordingly.

**Divine Spears and Bamboo Blades**
Su Xian, Prefect of Binzhou, submitted a posthumous memorial accusing the Anfu Commissioner of Guizhou of failing to dispatch reinforcements against the southern barbarians, leading to the death of the garrison commander. After Su Xian’s death, the tax supervisor Wang Bao was assigned to patrol the city. At midnight, he scaled the walls and moat in a clandestine escape. Caught in a thunderstorm, he fled into the forest, where several divine figures seized him and demanded, “Who dares sneak away?” He replied, “Wang Bao, tax supervisor of Binzhou, fled in fear of his lord’s peril.” They rebuked him: “In times of peace, you coveted rank and emolument, recklessly accepting the state’s bounty. In its hour of crisis, you fled in cowardice. You deserve death.”

chunks.original_text: 缘一城人民，不忍枉遭屠戮，目即未有救兵，今特借汝枪一条，步兵五十人，乘今夜雷雨之势，赶去蛮寇。 王褒曰：自来不学武，瓦蛮虏数千赤脚凶恶之徒，五十余卒，何以当之。 亦不明是甚方圣贤，愿垂指示。 神中部从云：汝但执其枪，领五十众，急速用事。 若得此功，他日荣显。 欲国家知委，但云北方三元游奕大将军也。 王褒暗中受枪，领兵出林，随后电光相逐。 到蛮子寨，秪闻霹雳一声，震惊蛮众，阖寨竞相斗敌。 至晓，蛮队已临海口，离宾州城二百五十余里。 当夜，天兵到时，蛮寇大半先乘筏过海逃遁，惟阴兵赶散，不留一寇。 宾州一城，生灵不遭涂炭。 时军将知得因依，具奏朝廷，检会苏咸遗表，量与恩例。 其王褒，系真武威德教令，护国救民，可加授崇仪使，并交点本人所遇神枪看验，即是蛮队中所用火钢竹刃，以显福神於仓卒间，有夺胜之权宜。 令宾州建立报恩护国观，修奉真武香火，岁度焚修道士一人，用答阴相。 神兽驱电 天佑元年二月一日，兴元府观察留后钱公偃奏称，蒙枢密院选差充墉延路安抚招讨使，退除西蕃赵天佑兵革，遂依禀交割兵马四万余众，却抵西域三十万众。 校其势力，显有优劣，实抱忧惧，不兔告急於朝廷，亦虑事有迂回之故。 时有随军虞候袁政，素习北斗玄刚法，奉侍一北极游奕真武将军，诚心习行二十余年，愿於元帅帐前铺设供养。 钱公偃即自虔诚，撰奏词线，具述西域因依，欲仗阴助。 是夜，土展政将背挂真武供养，至三更行法烧化，并醮献北极四圣元辰诸司讫。 次日，赵天佑以十万兵，索令调战，方遣指使孙亿出马，与西将交枪，继发兵大战。 到二更以来，两向有万道火光迸烁，军阵逼逐干戈，西蕃人马，各各枪旗断折，弓弩落弦，金鼓错乱，走如奔鹿。 诸军乘势赶进。 似觉天明，乃见随军第六将钱从吉，挟到蕃帅赵天佑首级。 诸兵将皆言，夜来阵上，见无数鱼腮乌赀丑恶异相，披头铣足，或驱风电，或赶蛇兽，是以接势剪伐，蕃军卧尸数万。 惟有一道火光，驱逐一马骑，落路而走。 钱从吉认是赵天佑，乃得首级。 且以四万人马，往敌二十万众。 若非虞候袁政献陈道法，任以至诚，蒙真武降临兵阵，现火光万道，露神兽万形，大败蕃众，仍获渠魁。 如此显应，三司礼部，定到虞候袁政，出给公据放，今逐便又奉圣旨赐酬，奖钱五百贯。 就在京上清灵应宫，建道场一月，仍设普天醮。 其钱公偃转一官，除宣徽院使。 毒蜂霭云 西京崇福宫，有北极紫微阁。 唐则天时，建仿效天宫，有二胜四将之院，有前后帝代御书。 每年系故老重臣监提，并使命管掌，非同常处。 近为右角一檐倾坍，渐伤圣像。 寻报判府侍郎富弼，偕诸官来验，见一椽斜坠，损真武右肩，不敢擅修，合具申取旨。 却有内侍岑静，奉勑赍香，诰献崇福宫诸殿，委提辖及判府等，计验北极紫微阁真武福神身相，有无动损。 近为皇帝於寝室，见神人紫绶金带，端笏缨，称：臣是西京崇福宫北极紫微阁传奏土地，今为本殿真武灵应真君，因与皇帝助战西蕃赵元昊，化黑蜂遍满军前，特助元帅庞籍获胜。 为施神功护国，右臂伤中，不可尽言。 臣若不奏闻，陛下无绿得知。

**Divine Spears and Bamboo Blades (continued)**

The city’s people could not bear to suffer unjust slaughter, yet no reinforcements had arrived. Thus, the gods lent Wang Bao a divine spear and fifty foot soldiers, commanding him to pursue the southern barbarians under the cover of the night’s thunderstorm. Wang Bao protested, “I have never trained in martial arts. How can fifty men withstand thousands of barefoot, ferocious savages?” Unsure which sage or deity addressed him, he begged for guidance. A voice from the clouds replied, “Take the spear, lead the fifty men, and act swiftly. Should you succeed, glory and honor await. If the state demands an account, say it was the Northern Three Yuan Patrol General who aided you.” Wang Bao accepted the spear in the dark, led the soldiers from the forest, and followed the lightning’s glow. Upon reaching the barbarian camp, a single thunderclap struck terror into the enemy, sending the entire encampment into chaotic infighting. By dawn, the barbarian forces had fled to the sea’s edge, two hundred and fifty *li* from Binzhou. When the celestial troops arrived that night, over half the barbarians had already escaped by raft across the sea, but the divine soldiers scattered the rest, leaving not a single foe behind. The city of Binzhou was spared from bloodshed.

The military commanders, learning of these events, reported them to the court. After reviewing Su Xian’s posthumous memorial, the throne granted Wang Bao an imperial reward. As he had been acting under the authority of Zhenwu, the Martial and Virtuous Deity, in his role as Protector of the State and Savior of the People, Wang was promoted to *Chongyi* Envoy. The divine spear he had wielded was examined and found to be identical to the bamboo blades used by the barbarians—proof of the福神 (*fúshén*, fortune deity) seizing victory through swift, decisive action. The court ordered the construction of the *Bao’en Huguo* Temple in Binzhou to honor Zhenwu, with annual rites performed by a Daoist priest in gratitude for the unseen aid.

---

**Divine Beasts and Lightning**

In the first year of *Tianyou*, Qian Yan, Acting Military Commissioner of Xingyuan Prefecture, submitted a memorial reporting that, by order of the Bureau of Military Affairs, he had been appointed Pacification and Campaign Commissioner of the Yong-Yan Circuit to repel the Western Tibetan forces of Zhao Tianyu. Upon assuming command of over forty thousand troops, he faced an enemy host of three hundred thousand. The disparity in strength filled him with dread, and though he had urgently petitioned the court, he feared the situation might yet take an unfavorable turn.

Among his officers was Yuan Zheng, a military inspector well-versed in the *Xuan’gang* method of the Northern Dipper. For over twenty years, Yuan had faithfully served the Northern Pole Patrol General Zhenwu, and now he requested permission to perform rites before the marshal’s tent. Qian Yan, devout in his own right, composed a memorial detailing the dire circumstances and his reliance on unseen aid. That night, Yuan Zheng hung the Zhenwu icon on his back, performed the ritual burning of petitions, and offered prayers to the Northern Pole’s Four Saints and the Stellar Deities of the Primordial Epoch.

The next day, Zhao Tianyu sent ten thousand troops to challenge them. Qian dispatched his envoy, Sun Yi, to engage the Tibetan general in single combat, followed by a full-scale battle. As the second watch approached, both sides saw ten thousand streaks of fire flashing across the field. The Tibetan ranks were thrown into disarray—spears and banners snapped, bowstrings slipped, drums and gongs clamored in confusion, and soldiers fled like startled deer. The imperial troops pressed their advantage. By what seemed like dawn, the sixth commander, Qian Congji, returned with the severed head of Zhao Tianyu.

The soldiers recounted that during the night battle, they had seen countless grotesque figures with fish-gill faces and black, tattered robes, their hair wild and feet bare. Some drove winds and lightning, others herded serpents and beasts, cutting down the Tibetan forces with relentless fury. Tens of thousands of enemy corpses littered the field. Only one streak of fire pursued a lone rider, whom Qian Congji recognized as Zhao Tianyu, thus claiming his head. With a mere forty thousand men, they had faced two hundred thousand. Had Yuan Zheng not offered his rituals with utmost sincerity, invoking Zhenwu’s descent upon the battlefield—manifesting as ten thousand streaks of fire and myriad divine beasts—they would never have crushed the Tibetan host and captured its leader.

In recognition of this miraculous intervention, the Three Departments and the Ministry of Rites issued Yuan Zheng an official certificate of merit and awarded him five hundred strings of cash. A month-long Daoist ritual was held at the *Shangqing Lingying* Palace in the capital, along with a grand universal *jiao* offering. Qian Yan was promoted to *Xuanhui* Envoy with a concurrent rank.

---

**Toxic Bees and Misty Clouds**

The *Chongfu* Abbey in the Western Capital housed the Purple Tenuity Pavilion of the Northern Pole. Built during the reign of Empress Wu of Tang to emulate the celestial palace, it contained the Hall of Two Victories and Four Generals, adorned with imperial calligraphy from successive dynasties. Each year, it was overseen by venerable elders and high-ranking officials, its stewardship far from ordinary. Recently, the right eave of the pavilion had collapsed, damaging the sacred image within. Upon receiving the report, Minister of the Bureau of Judicature Fu Bi inspected the site with other officials and found a beam askew, striking Zhenwu’s right shoulder. Unwilling to authorize repairs without imperial approval, they prepared a memorial to request the throne’s decree.

Soon after, the eunuch Cen Jing arrived bearing incense and an edict, instructing the abbey’s administrators and the ministerial officials to assess the condition of Zhenwu’s sacred image in the Purple Tenuity Pavilion. The emperor, while in his private chambers, had seen a divine figure in a purple sash and golden belt, holding a tablet, who identified himself as the *Chuanzao* Earth Deity of the Purple Tenuity Pavilion in the Western Capital’s *Chongfu* Abbey. The deity declared, “I am the Numinous and Responsive Perfected Lord of the Northern Pole. During the campaign against the Western Tibetan chieftain Zhao Yuanhao, I transformed into black bees that swarmed the battlefield, aiding Marshal Pang Ji in securing victory. In performing this divine service to protect the state, my right arm was wounded. Had I not reported this, Your Majesty would have remained unaware.”

In its hour of crisis, you fled in cowardice. You deserve death.”

chunks.original_text: 神将教法 乾兴二年正月，据忠州团练使充黔州兵马铃辖张孝宁状奏，近为南戎溪洞蛮子龙氏，群集万众，尽习标枪，实难准敌。 蒙枢密院差充此任，於安抚司抽军五千，及指使三人。 孝宁因见故父宣徽文，立供养真武一堂在家，凡事求签乃行，件件灵感。 孝宁效父供养，专诚不违。 昨为朝廷放试武学，预曾夜梦，受真武殿下河魁神将，亲教枪法弓马事艺，顿然神悟。 至殿前呈试，於二百人中，唯孝宁第一，当授三班殿侍出身，是真武保护至此。 孝宁军队，约行一百余里，遇夜路，次护国观。 有一小殿，香灯微明，见牌是真武之殿。 孝宁焚香，求一签，大吉。 暗对真武发愿，此去若得一阵灭除蛮寇，当以本身官资，兑换恩赐，报斯灵既。 越明，孝宁领兵前行，以五千雄郎步军临蛮界，乃逢龙氏万余人，孝宁并输三阵。 至夜，立寨於秦风山，汉伏波将军马援庙。 尚闻蛮兵追逐，方二更时，相望百步间，忽风雨四起，兵马啖杀。 是时，孝宁顿兵伏波庙不动，闻啖声渐远。 至晓，领兵再往迎敌，见前路伤中蛮子，尸首相枕。 直向蛮界九阳溪去，探知蛮子龙氏，有赤脚寇一万二千，今无二千回，各伤中鬼箭，龙氏亦折右臂，见归深洞。 人人皆言，大朝有神圣鬼兵护助，举声叫云：自此降伏，更不敢作乱。 后来取问，得龙氏定伏情状，申奏朝廷看详。 宜赐修盖护国观真武诸殿，以三年给度牒，披戴焚修。 每年赐二百贯，充常住用。 其张孝宁，除授瀛州防御使。 符吏借兵 内殿承制卢守聪，因往河北三关边廷察探契丹动静，於黄河岸西，遇二人，各斋实封文字一角。 守聪问之，言：我二人，今日巡察世问，因到定州，冲见北极真武灵应真君队仗，云：北蕃戎卒，渐加万数。 为宋朝兵马稍少，难为拒敌。 缘下降时，不曾将带天兵力士随行，今差某二人斋驰文字，限剎那间，往东岳计会炳灵公，急关借鬼兵神将一万众，定壬子月戊子日丙子时，布设一阵，欲助南朝杀蕃，肃宁边境。 二符吏言讫，便过河。 守聪回国面奏，权令有司附口记录。 后刑部侍郎充三关都总管富弼回朝参贺，奏称：北蕃契丹，今皆灭戮，更无举战意。 曾擒到燕国黎王赵殷，供下克伏文状，却放回蕃。 取问获胜时日，系岁庚午壬子月戊子日丙子时，与内臣卢守聪预奏同辞。 除兵将等酬转赏给外，持行德音，赦天下罪。 仍於定州，建圣佑观一所，告成日，别降御衔词表答谢。 书显魏家 中书门下枢密院三司礼部同承尚书兵部侍郎，参知政事，充定州侍卫兵马都招讨兼经略安抚使王着，札子契勘，雍熙三年七月，百万蕃兵已近界河，因部军上将观察使潘仁美，与老臣太尉扬继业，不相和睦，并为帅出军，一阵赶趁蕃兵六十余万，直入北幽狼山，被潘仁美潜收军回寨，独遗继业军马深入。 契丹添兵，拥入虎口堡，继业失阵身死。 次男延朗，赴阙理雪。 除已差官监伴潘仁美候动外，据束头供奉官杨延朗，经登闻鼓院，抱冤投状称，潘仁美与朝廷奸臣结连，私有文字往返，教令北蕃违逆先皇嘱付，谋杀父命。 奉圣旨，令左右监察司，限三日探察，管要显露，并委全台用心根究。 三日将满，两班文武尽知秘书监丞王允从，本是蕃人，疑其机构，却为宠用，不见彰露，难以收捉。
