**Divine Generals and Their Teachings**

In the second year of Qianxing, first month, Zhang Xiaoning, Loyalty Prefecture Militia Commander and Qianzhou Brigade Marshal, submitted a memorial stating: Recently, the southern Rong tribes of the Xidong Man, led by the Long clan, had amassed tens of thousands, all trained in javelin warfare, presenting a formidable challenge. The Bureau of Military Affairs had appointed him to this task, assigning five thousand troops from the Pacification Office along with three adjutants.

Xiaoning recalled that his late father, the former Director of Palace Administration, had enshrined a hall dedicated to the Perfected Lord of the Northern Pole at home, seeking divination before every undertaking, each time receiving miraculous responses. Following his father’s example, Xiaoning maintained unwavering devotion. Previously, when the court held military examinations, he dreamed one night of receiving instruction in spear techniques, archery, and horsemanship from the River Marshal, a divine general under the Perfected Lord, awakening with sudden divine insight. At the palace examination, among two hundred candidates, Xiaoning ranked first, earning the title of Third-Class Palace Attendant—all through the Perfected Lord’s protection.

After marching over a hundred *li* with his troops, they encountered nightfall near Huguo Abbey. In a small hall, the faint glow of incense and lamps revealed a shrine to the Perfected Lord. Xiaoning burned incense and drew a lot, which foretold great fortune. Silently, he vowed before the Perfected Lord: if he could annihilate the Man bandits in a single battle, he would dedicate his official salary and rewards to repay this divine favor.

At dawn, Xiaoning led his five thousand valiant infantry toward the Man border, where they encountered over ten thousand of the Long clan. Xiaoning lost three consecutive engagements. That night, they encamped at Qin Feng Mountain, near the temple of General Ma Yuan of the Han. As the Man forces pursued, around the second watch, when they were barely a hundred paces apart, a sudden storm arose, and the sounds of battle and slaughter filled the air. Xiaoning’s troops remained motionless at Ma Yuan’s temple, hearing the clamor gradually recede.

At daybreak, they advanced again and found the path strewn with the corpses of slain Man warriors. Pushing toward the Man territory at Jiuyang Creek, they learned that the Long clan’s twelve thousand barefoot raiders had been reduced to two thousand survivors, all wounded by spectral arrows. Long himself had lost his right arm and fled deep into the caves. The survivors declared that the great dynasty was protected by divine and ghostly soldiers, crying out: “We surrender and will never rebel again!”

Later, upon verifying the Long clan’s submission, Xiaoning reported the details to the court. It was decreed that the halls of the Perfected Lord at Huguo Abbey be renovated, with three years’ worth of ordination certificates granted for Daoist rites, and an annual stipend of two hundred strings of cash allocated for temple upkeep. Zhang Xiaoning was promoted to Defense Commissioner of Yingzhou.

**Borrowing Troops from the Spirit Officials**

Lu Shoucong, Palace Attendant of the Inner Court, was dispatched to the Three Passes along the northern frontier to scout Khitan movements. By the western bank of the Yellow River, he encountered two men, each carrying a sealed document. When questioned, they replied: “We are patrolling the mortal realm today. In Dingzhou, we encountered the divine procession of the Perfected Lord of the Northern Pole, the Miraculous and Responsive True Lord. He said: ‘The northern Khitan troops are growing by the tens of thousands. As the Song dynasty’s forces are insufficient to repel them, and since he descended without his celestial soldiers and warriors, he has dispatched us to deliver this message in an instant to the Lord of Bright Spirit at Mount Tai, urgently requesting the loan of ten thousand ghostly soldiers and divine generals. On the *wuz*i day of the *renzi* month, at the *bingzi* hour, they will array a formation to assist the southern court in slaughtering the Khitan and pacifying the frontier.’” The two spirit officials finished speaking and crossed the river.

Shoucong returned to the capital and reported this in person. The relevant authorities were ordered to record it orally. Later, Fu Bi, Vice Minister of Justice and Commander-in-Chief of the Three Passes, returned to court and reported: “The northern Khitan have all been annihilated, with no further intent to wage war. We captured Zhao Yin, Prince Li of Yan, who submitted a written confession before being released back to the Khitan.” Upon inquiry, the date of victory was the *bingzi* hour of the *wuz*i day in the *renzi* month of the *gengwu* year—matching the prior report by the eunuch Lu Shoucong. Apart from rewarding the soldiers and generals, an imperial amnesty was issued to pardon the realm’s crimes. A temple, Shengyou Abbey, was constructed in Dingzhou, and upon its completion, a separate imperial edict was issued to express gratitude.

**The Revelation of the Wei Family**

Wang Zhao, Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs, concurrently serving as Participant in Determining Governmental Matters, and Commander-in-Chief of the Imperial Guards, Pacification Commissioner, and Military Commissioner of Dingzhou, submitted a memorandum for verification: In the seventh month of the third year of Yongxi, a million Khitan troops neared the border river. The military commissioner, Inspector-General Pan Renmei, and the veteran general Yang Jiye, who were at odds, jointly led the campaign. In a single engagement, they pursued over six hundred thousand Khitan troops deep into Lang Mountain in northern You. Pan Renmei secretly withdrew his forces, abandoning Jiye’s troops. The Khitan reinforced their position, trapping Jiye in Hukou Fortress, where he lost the battle and perished.

His second son, Yanlang, appealed to the court to clear his father’s name. After officials were dispatched to monitor Pan Renmei’s movements, Palace Attendant Yang Yanlang submitted a petition to the Drum Tower of Petitions, accusing Pan Renmei of colluding with treacherous ministers, exchanging secret correspondence, and instructing the northern Khitan to defy the late emperor’s commands, leading to his father’s murder.

By imperial decree, the Left and Right Surveillance Commissions were ordered to investigate within three days, ensuring full exposure of the truth, with the entire Censorate instructed to pursue the matter diligently. As the three-day deadline approached, civil and military officials all suspected that Wang Yuncong, Secretary of the Palace Library, a Khitan by birth, was involved in the conspiracy. However, no evidence emerged, making it difficult to apprehend him.

The assembled officials arrived at Wei Huaixin’s residence and reverently awaited the divine intercession of the True Saint.

Suddenly, a gray-haired servant appeared in the hall and abruptly bowed, declaring: “I am but a humble bondsman from the northern Yan household. I witnessed Wang Yuncong, originally a merchant trading among the Khitan, lodging in Buzhou under the guise of a candidate for office. Later, he took ten men like myself as household servants, entered the capital to sell books, and upon encountering the Golden Dragon Festival, passed the examination for the Brilliant Scholars cohort, now serving as Secretary of the Palace Library and Inner Instructor of the Academy. This man is in truth a Khitan spy, long embedded in the Song court, concealing his machinations and covert actions. I now present ten letters exchanged between him and the northern Yan, and humbly petition the emperor, hoping for imperial favor and reward in return.” With that, the gray-haired servant took a step and vanished without a trace.

Thereupon, Prime Minister Wang Zongdan and the others exposed Wang Yuncong’s treason, producing ten letters to submit to the throne. Envoys were immediately dispatched to seize Wang Yuncong, who was interrogated before the court. He confessed to all charges but denied that the gray-haired servant had stolen the Khitan correspondence. When the letters were examined, one bore the cryptic line: *“The imperial carriage must not leave the capital; the troops must not depart the frontier.”* The meaning of these words remained unclear. Wang Yuncong was remanded to the Censorate for further interrogation and subsequently executed. His head was preserved and sent back to the northern Khitan.

Palace Attendant Yang Yanlang was promoted to Inner Palace Venerable Rank and appointed Chief Patrol Inspector of Liangmen Fortress. Upon further investigation into Pan Renmei’s crimes, it was determined that he had been an old minister and maternal relative of the late emperor. By imperial decree, he was stripped of his mourning attire and demoted to Supervisor of Wine in Taiyuan.

As for Yang Jiye, he had been a loyal and heroic confidant of the late emperor, tragically ensnared by treacherous ministers. The court and the realm mourned his fate, and he was posthumously enfeoffed as *Minister of Loyal Assistance, Co-Governor, Pacifier of Rebellion, and Stabilizer of the State*. A temple, the Loyal Aid Monastery, was erected at Liangmen Fortress, where rituals were conducted in his honor. A general amnesty was declared throughout the realm.

The Ministry of Rites, upon reviewing the matter, reported in gratitude to the True Warrior. By imperial decree, a seven-day-and-night Daoist ritual was commissioned and conducted before the sacred presence of the True Warrior at Wei Huaixin’s residence. Wei Huaixin was promoted to Gentleman for Court Service and reassigned as Prefect of Yangzhou.

---

**The Divination at Wang’s Residence**

Prince’s Goodness Attendant Wang Chou, serving as a confidential secretary in the Jinglue Pacification Commission of Guizhou, had an officer named Liang Mu who forcibly distributed fruits and vegetables from the leper garden to soldiers, colluding with the Tiger Wing Battalion commander Yuan Sheng and others. Under the pretext of adjusting prices, they embezzled the soldiers’ bonuses, pocketing the funds for themselves, inciting widespread resentment. One night, the soldiers seized arms and fled into Lv’er Mountain.

Upon receiving the report, the court first instructed the Confidential Secretariat to investigate Liang Mu’s misconduct, then urgently relayed the findings to the Pacification Commission for further action and submission to the throne. Liang Mu evaded capture, and the rebels in Lv’er Mountain declared their sole grievance to be against the military officer Liang Mu.

The court dispatched an envoy bearing official patents, posthumous honors, brocade robes, and an amnesty edict. Fearing further unrest if Liang Mu remained at large, Wang Chou was troubled. That night, he heard a resonant clatter in his hall. Startled, he rose with a lamp and discovered a pair of divination blocks near the central gate, inscribed with the name of the Hanyang Abbey in his prefecture.

The next morning, Wang Chou visited the abbey and presented the blocks to the Daoist clergy, who confirmed: “How did these come to be in your residence? They are used in the True Warrior Hall of our abbey.” Reflecting deeply, Wang Chou realized the True Warrior had responded to his plight. He entered the hall, offered devout prayers, and used the blocks to petition the divine power, recounting the circumstances and beseeching swift resolution. Three casts yielded unobstructed omens.

As Wang Chou bowed in gratitude and exited the hall, word suddenly arrived that Liang Mu’s entire household was wailing in the leper quarters. Upon investigation, Liang Mu had been seized by a malevolent force, vomiting dark blood before collapsing, lifeless. Wang Chou, upon learning of the matter, ensured no one else was informed. He selected capable soldiers and rushed to Liang Mu’s residence, where they carried out the bloodied corpse.

Wang Chou then assumed the guise of an imperial emissary, falsely declaring that he had come to welcome the body by imperial decree. Over twenty soldiers hoisted Liang Mu’s corpse, summoning the troops to witness it. He announced: “By the emperor’s grace, I was sent with medicinal wine, though it was not meant for you. Do not forget the emperor’s profound benevolence. Now that the oppressive officer is dead, Yuan Zhen, leader of the rebel troops, follow my command.” The rest knelt to receive pardon, their crimes absolved.

They then accepted the amnesty edict, posthumous honors, and brocade robes, returning to Guizhou to resume their duties as before. The Jinglue Pacification Commissioner Shao Mi subsequently memorialized the throne, recommending that the Hanyang Abbey of Guizhou be granted funds for reconstruction and an inscribed plaque. In gratitude for the divine response, Wang Chou was promoted to Gentleman for Court Service and appointed Prefect of the prefecture.

---

**Ke Cheng’s Discernment of Treachery**

In the capital, Ke Cheng, a commander of the Divine Valiance Battalion, suffered from blindness and was deemed unfit for training duties, resigning his post. Once, by the Wei River, he attempted to drown himself at night but was unexpectedly saved at the brink of death by a divine figure who called to him from the water’s edge, applying medicine and washing his eyes, restoring his sight completely.

From then on, his eyes could discern all external deceit, treachery, and unrighteousness. Later, in a dream, he learned that the savior had been the True Warrior in disguise.

chunks.original_text: 次被西蕃李克渊，曾发细作赵可大，为卖昼枣，推广角车子入庆州，逐日看认城池围脚，归房用白矾水抄画地图，被柯诚眼认破，捉到庆州。 一向抵讳，及搜出所画地图，又作白纸。 柯诚用水蘸出，勘问招伏，取斩。 柯诚酬转十将，替满归京。 又值钱去盈权判南省，抽差柯诚充京城捉事。 因魏王宅被人改形，装作行火使者，入醮会上，掺出硫黄火卫，惊吓宗．室亲宫，强盗去浑银酒器六百两，并御赐金香球约一百两。 见奉动，限堆探赏钱，及右班殿直诰牒一道，招人首捉。 柯诚既蒙旨，令缉捕。 归家焚香，祷告真武福神，愿收捕前项奸盗。 方祈告了当，出门，如得人引路，直行到蔡河湾西真寂院前，有数人赌博。 柯诚前看，内一人身畔，有棱道银子露出於胸怀。 柯诚指定，搜出数件银器，照证解赴南省鞠勘，元是酆州配军周诠。 已依法行遣外，申奏朝廷。 蒙圣旨，其柯诚，除授右班殿直，及支赏钱。 仍降指挥，於玉津园，修建报恩大醮。 并於四圣观，遣官降香，释其礼仪献谢。 洞真认厌 在京上清延福宫，天禧中，有云游道士罗洞真，寄挂三年不语。 因随道录入内持课一保扶文母皇太后刘氏痁疾，对圣驾蓦语云：观见宫庭有赤气，临於宫阁正西面东之位，主有厌魅咒诅发毒之兆。 若於此方位，认有如赤，蒸裂破处，开掘七尺，须有名目阴人厌禳之法於其下。 缘文母为受此毒，致日发寒热。 时宣谕宰执大臣参详，赐令罗洞真入内认踏。 至正西方，有官号禧圣阁，是先太祖皇帝花蕊妃子之室，已空静年深。 至第四帏幛，据罗洞真於此，令人掘深七尺，下有石花方砖一片，背面用胶生朱写咒诅术文，及太祖年月日时，又用罗帛包成人物，逐色不祥之类，被罗洞真取东南方桃木为剑，编镇左手，草绳缚系，钉於北方鬼门空野之处，以火烧过。 自后，太后疾臧。 因昼睡梦，见七人披头赤体，身挂金纸，来告太后：念某七人是受法土魂，昨被妇人花蕊行奸，欲亏害太祖世祚，作天魔七返还尸术，用某七般咒诅之物，埋在御榻地底七尺。 无何，太祖立极，感动天地，五岳万灵扶助。 其花蕊却遭灭除，以致厌睨之物，在地不能出脱，遂成影魂。 因击着太祖，缠绵不豫。 今日蒙道士罗洞真，与某等解释出土，虽得离太后圣体，奈无所归，除得罗道师为某等持行北极真武灵应法箓，令消散，却归本物，各求往生。 太后依此，再宣罗洞真，入内行法，奏告真武，救此七般魂形托化。 后经三日，七人又於梦裹来告：已蒙真武授记，各得归真本托生，故来告辞而去。 寻特面奏皇帝，奉圣旨，就延福宫，启建三坛法醮三昼夜，及赠罗洞真紫衣师号，并延福宫住持焚修，听候宣唤。 圣帧化妇 颖州西安县，因勘劫盗黄狗三等因，探知朱守成家，极有金银财帛。 其家口少，先来近处陆二公家停下。 於庆历七年四月十一、十一不十三夜，黄狗三各持火罐器仗，往朱守成门首，狂风大雨，群犬号吠，疑怯遂回。 於十四夜又去，遂越墙入朱守成围内，方欲穿换第二重门壁，其门自开，忽有二十余人，披甲执刀持棒，出来赶捉。 黄狗三等，先次搬出墙外急走，被一人随后赶，狗三心急，更不回顾，覆手用枪尖独杀半路中。

Subsequently, the Western Tibetan Li Keyuan dispatched a spy named Zhao Keda, who, under the pretense of selling day-market jujubes, expanded the axle carts to enter Qingzhou. Each day, he surveyed and memorized the city’s defenses and encampments, returning to his lodging to transcribe the details onto a map using alum-water. Ke Cheng, however, saw through the deception with his discerning eyes and apprehended him in Qingzhou. Zhao initially denied everything, but upon searching his belongings, the map was found—though it had been altered to appear as blank paper. Ke Cheng moistened it with water, revealing the hidden markings, and upon interrogation, Zhao confessed. He was executed accordingly. Ke Cheng was rewarded with a promotion to the rank of *Shijiang* and, upon completing his term, returned to the capital.

At that time, Qian Qumying was acting as the provisional director of the Southern Bureau, and he selected Ke Cheng to serve as a city-wide apprehension officer. During this period, someone at the residence of Prince Wei altered their appearance to impersonate a fire-prevention officer and infiltrated a Daoist ritual assembly. There, they surreptitiously introduced sulfur and fire implements, startling the imperial clan and royal consorts, and made off with six hundred taels of solid silver drinking vessels and approximately one hundred taels’ worth of imperial gold incense orbs. Upon discovery, a decree was issued offering a reward for information leading to the arrest, along with a commission as *Youban Dianzhi* and an official certificate. Ke Cheng, having received the imperial mandate, took up the pursuit. Returning home, he burned incense and prayed to the True Warrior and the Fortune God, vowing to capture the treacherous thief. No sooner had he finished his prayer than, upon stepping outside, he felt as though someone were guiding his path. He walked directly to the western bank of the Cai River, near the Zhenji Monastery, where several men were gambling. Approaching, he noticed one man with a sliver of silver protruding from his chest. Pointing him out, Ke Cheng searched him and recovered several silver vessels. The suspect was taken to the Southern Bureau for interrogation, where he was identified as Zhou Quan, a convict exiled from Fengzhou. After legal proceedings were carried out, the case was reported to the throne. By imperial decree, Ke Cheng was appointed *Youban Dianzhi*, granted the reward money, and ordered to oversee the construction of a grand thanksgiving ritual at Yujin Garden. Additionally, officials were dispatched to the Four Sages Temple to offer incense and perform rites of gratitude.

---

**Hong Zhen’s Detection of Malevolent Hexes**

At the Shangqing Yanfu Palace in the capital, during the *Tianxi* era, a wandering Daoist named Luo Hongzhen had resided for three years without speaking. When the palace’s Daoist registrar entered the inner court to perform divination for the ailing Empress Dowager Liu, who suffered from malarial fever, Hongzhen suddenly addressed the imperial presence, saying: “I perceive a crimson *qi* lingering over the palace, concentrated at the western side of the halls, facing east. This portends the activation of malevolent hexes, curses, or poisonous sorcery. If one examines this direction and finds a place where the crimson *qi* appears scorched or cracked, digging seven feet deep should reveal the hidden implements of a woman’s clandestine hexing ritual. It is due to this poison that the Empress Dowager suffers from alternating chills and fever.”

The emperor summoned his chief ministers to deliberate, then ordered Luo Hongzhen to enter the palace and investigate. Upon reaching the western side, they found the *Xisheng Pavilion*, once the chamber of Consort Huazu, beloved of the late Emperor Taizu, now long abandoned. Beneath the fourth curtain, Luo Hongzhen instructed laborers to dig seven feet deep. There, they uncovered a square stone tile, its reverse inscribed with a curse in cinnabar glue, bearing the date and hour of Emperor Taizu’s reign. Wrapped in silk was a bundle of inauspicious effigies. Luo Hongzhen took a peach-wood sword from the southeast, wielded it in his left hand, bound the objects with straw rope, and nailed them to the northern *Ghost Gate*—a desolate place—before burning them.

Thereafter, the Empress Dowager’s illness abated. One day, as she napped, she dreamed of seven disheveled, bare-chested figures draped in gold paper, who addressed her: “We seven were once earthbound spirits subjected to sorcery. Recently, the woman Huazu, seeking to undermine the imperial succession of Emperor Taizu, employed the *Sevenfold Reversion Corpse Technique*—a demonic art—and buried seven cursed objects beneath the imperial bed at a depth of seven feet. By chance, Emperor Taizu ascended the throne, his virtue moving heaven and earth, and the Five Peaks and myriad spirits came to his aid. Huazu was destroyed, but the hexing objects remained trapped underground, becoming shadowy specters. They afflicted Emperor Taizu, causing his prolonged illness. Today, thanks to the Daoist Luo Hongzhen, we have been unearthed and freed from the Empress Dowager’s sacred person. Yet we have nowhere to go. We beg the Daoist master to perform the *Lingying* ritual of the Northern Dipper’s True Warrior, allowing us to disperse and return to our origins, seeking rebirth.”

The Empress Dowager, following this dream, summoned Luo Hongzhen once more to perform the ritual. He petitioned the True Warrior to deliver the seven spectral forms. Three days later, the seven figures reappeared in her dream, announcing: “We have received the True Warrior’s decree and been granted rebirth in our original forms. We come now to bid farewell.” The Empress Dowager promptly reported this to the emperor. By imperial decree, a three-day, three-altar ritual was held at Yanfu Palace, and Luo Hongzhen was bestowed the title of *Ziyi Master*, permitted to reside at Yanfu Palace for continued cultivation, awaiting further summons.

---

**The Sacred Portrait’s Transformation**

In Xi’an County of Yingzhou, during an investigation into the robbery committed by Huang Gousan and his accomplices, it was discovered that the household of Zhu Shoucheng possessed vast quantities of gold, silver, and valuables. As the family was small, they had previously lodged with a local man named Lu Er. On the nights of the eleventh and twelfth of the fourth month in the seventh year of *Qingli*, Huang Gousan and his men, armed with fire pots and weapons, approached Zhu Shoucheng’s door. A fierce wind and torrential rain arose, and the howling of dogs deterred them, forcing their retreat. On the fourteenth night, they returned, scaled the wall, and entered Zhu’s compound. As they prepared to breach the second gate, it suddenly swung open, and over twenty armored men wielding blades and clubs emerged, giving chase. Huang Gousan and his gang hastily tossed their loot over the wall and fled. One pursuer gave chase, and in his panic, Huang Gousan, without looking back, reversed his grip on his spear and struck, killing the pursuer mid-path.

Upon arriving at Lu Er’s home, they discovered that Chen Banxiong was missing from their number—he had been mistakenly killed along the way. When the local elders reported the matter to the authorities and a reward was posted for the capture of the culprits, Chen Banxiong’s wife filed an official accusation, stating that her husband had joined Huang Gousan in banditry but had been singled out and killed by the gang. She revealed that Huang Gousan and his nine accomplices were now hiding in the concealed compartment of Lu Er’s home. The authorities dispatched constables to apprehend them in secret, but when they arrived, both the gang and Chen Banxiong’s wife had vanished without a trace.

According to Huang Gousan’s confession, he had indeed killed Chen Banxiong by mistake. Chen was originally from Qizhou in Shandong and had no family. Zhu Shoucheng, meanwhile, testified that on the nights of the eleventh through the thirteenth of the fourth month, there had been no wind or rain at his home, nor had any dogs barked. On the fourteenth night, though he had heard of a murder on the main road—now known to be Chen Banxiong—he had been unaware that Huang Gousan and his men had scaled the wall and entered his compound. Furthermore, he insisted that the second gate had no brothers, sons, servants, or hired hands, nor had he privately kept any armored men or weapons to pursue the intruders. His household consisted of only seven members in total.

Prefect Han Ji examined the case in detail but found the circumstances perplexing. He questioned Zhu Shoucheng further, asking if his home contained any sacred shrine that might have provided supernatural aid, or how the woman had come to report Huang Gousan’s gang. Zhu replied that his family had only a hall dedicated to Zhenwu the True Lord, where three generations had maintained unbroken incense offerings. Han Ji then ordered the sacred portrait to be brought forth and displayed to the assembled officials. The painting depicted sixteen divine generals in armor, bearing weapons, along with a woman identified as a former disciple of the temple.

Han Ji suddenly understood. After sentencing Huang Gousan and his men, he compiled a detailed report and submitted it to the imperial court. The Ministry of State reviewed the case and noted that Zhu Shoucheng, though a common villager, had maintained a virtuous heart and received divine protection, sparing his home from robbery. His family’s devotion to the Daoist rites of incense and worship was renowned throughout the empire. Moreover, the capture of the bandits had spared the authorities the trouble of pursuit—was this not a service to the state? The court dispatched an envoy to command that all Zhenwu temples in Yingzhou hold grand rituals and offer thanksgiving sacrifices.

**Divine Manifestation**
In Zizhou, there lived a spirit-medium named Lu Qian, whose family had served the deities for three generations, maintaining incense offerings to a hall dedicated to Zhenwu the True Lord. Whenever he divined fortunes or interpreted omens, his readings proved accurate. In the same prefecture lived three men, all prominent pawnshop owners: the first was Feng Chongda, the second Gao Shaolang, and the third You Xinger. Though they appeared to be traveling merchants, they were in truth thieves, their crimes never exposed nor suspected by anyone.

One day, Feng Chongda arrived at Lu Qian’s home with incense and paper offerings to pray before Zhenwu and seek a divination slip. He whispered his entreaties in secret, returning the next day and again on the third. When Lu Qian pressed him for his true purpose, Feng grew enraged, stomped on the incense table, smashed the ritual implements, and stormed off.

Half a year later, the three men returned from their travels. That night, several officials from Kuizhou, who claimed no prior acquaintance with Lu Qian, arrived at his home. They addressed him as if they had met before, saying he had once traveled to Kuizhou to report a robbery in his prefecture, identifying the culprits as Feng Chongda, Gao Shaolang, and You Xinger. Since Lu Qian had not been found in Kuizhou at the time, the officials had been specially dispatched to locate him and ascertain the whereabouts of the three men for arrest.

Lu Qian replied, “I serve only Zhenwu, divining fortunes at home. I have never traveled to Kuizhou to report any official matter. Moreover, these three men are all wealthy and respectable—how could they be thieves?” The officials, hearing this, withdrew to their lodgings.

The next morning, as they prepared to question Lu Qian again, he suddenly appeared before them. He led them to the front of Longxing Temple, where they spotted Feng Chongda and the other two men examining a horse’s hoof. Lu Qian seized their hands, and the officials promptly arrested them.

The officials then sent two men back to Lu Qian’s home, where they found him still asleep. They took him to Kuizhou for interrogation. Within ten days, another notice arrived from Zizhou: Lu Qian had claimed a reward posted in Fuzhou for the capture of the murderers of the tribal chief Guo Zhujiao—once again, the culprits were Feng Chongda and his accomplices, with the confession as evidence. When the authorities summoned Lu Qian, he had vanished without a trace.

Based on this evidence, Feng Chongda and his men confessed to all charges and were sentenced to death by *lingchi*. After the case concluded, the total reward money from various jurisdictions amounted to two thousand *guan*. As the informant, Lu Qian was entitled to seven-tenths of the sum. The authorities in Kuizhou issued a document to Zizhou, dispatching the funds for Lu Qian to claim, with a receipt to be returned as proof.

Lu Qian had never left his home before, nor did he know the circumstances of Feng Chongda’s robberies or the details of the officials’ previous inquiries. Prefect Zhang Shiming of Kuizhou carefully considered the matter and suspected that Lu Qian, or perhaps his family, had accumulated virtuous deeds, making him a vessel for divine intervention. The gods had manifested through him to aid the authorities in capturing these vicious criminals. Zhang proposed awarding the reward money to Lu Qian and submitted a detailed report to the imperial court. The court approved, ordering that the entire sum be given to Lu Qian, along with additional provisions of rice, salt, wine, and silk.

Lu Qian donated all the money and goods to the Yuansheng Temple in his prefecture to construct a Hall of the Four Saints of the Northern Dipper in gratitude for the divine favor. He lived to the age of ninety-nine and passed away without illness. The pirate ships dispersed and withdrew.

chunks.original_text: 东上阁门使，眉州防御使，新差京兆府兵马钤辖谢柔立，自天禧年中，差西域路顿勾当，於黄河岸，际遇真武真君飞渡黄河，谓柔立言：西蕃奉使李希孟入国，切宜缉捉能画者，即是奸人。 柔立察命，果至东京，捉获传画慈孝寺皇后御容一行。 蕃使败露，寻送大理寺，已行赐罪讫。 柔立蒙朝廷推赏，转职，逐日於家堂香火报谢。 每夜二更，备香露天，朝北礼拜，将及一年。 忽蒙朝廷诏，充交趾回礼副使，同国使吏部侍郎燕宿波海。 未及中路，名白林山，於午时问，遇寇船四十余只，叫瞰施阅枪弩，意欲劫夺财货。 为防送不备器械，是时，谢柔立於水际，奠酒抛纸悬空，泣告真武降灵。 海寇头领，称是陈广秀才，方擎枪欲害柔立，忽发一箭，中陈广前心落海，钩褡上船，斫州｀其首级，悬竿令众。 却见群寇五百余人，竞船相附，发怒欲来酬杀。 其寇船方努力摇上，被抵头风吹退，如此相拒三昼夜，忽望见交趾国不远。 已临女仙城界，有人来迎接，众寇退散。 燕宿与柔立等，赖蒙真武，救护回国。 以上件感应面奏，特奉圣旨，就王津园，赐设黄录大醮道场七昼夜。 散日，差近侍遍诣名山洞天，再建道场，投放龙简，虔谢恩德。 劫院就擒 登州辛山白云资庆禅院，有维那僧晓初，不惟奉佛，而留心道教，常於寮舍静处，供养真武，专诚勤恪。 其院临近海岛，有邵武军周应等百余人，於海道强劫杀人放火，所属州县，堆垛赏钱，召人收捕。 日久，徒党转多，难以除克。 一日，周应等欲入本院劫夺。 其夜，晓初梦见院门土地来报，将有惊劫，被真武指挥令放黑风，吹逆舟船，来之未及，可速报官，不得运也。 晓初趁夜发人，告报巡检，即时兵甲到院，四散埋伏。 果於次日，周应等数百人，执枪杖入院，柢云借此一宿。 主事出迎，周应等共到法堂点茶。 院门已将关闭，晓初哀告，许下钱物。 至晓临行，当得献纳。 周应曰：何须候晓，急令般出。 应蓦然惊惧云：何故眼前乱花，头如火烧，四肢不举。 续后，西辛山巡检裘皋一行人马，拥出擒捉，并不走透一人。 解押入登州禁。 奏已各行遣外，所有赏钱，七分合给僧晓初，三分支与巡检兵级。 据晓初状称，所获海寇，非院门功劳，因真武降灵，使令众寇手足不遂，各就擒缚。 愿朝廷报答真武。 州司备奏，寻降旨，其辛山白云资庆，虽是释教禅院，特赐真武殿一所，并赐御书《太上真武经》一卷，永充奉安香火。 仍赐晓初紫衣，并真应大师，充焚修本殿，掌管御经，仍给七分赏钱，添造宝殿。 舍身求雨 寿州安丰县王文庆，有一女子，小字招弟，从十三岁不吃腥鱼活物，好亲道德。 因遇一化缘女道流，叩门劝招弟，令受持北极真武灵应真君。 招弟告云：为有上下，恐无力可供圣像，但只求得真武经一卷，日夜念熟，行坐藏於胸怀，逐日遥望，想存真像，烧香称诵。 年至二十，其性巧丽聪敏，富贵之家欲求为亲，并为允意，唯口不住称念本师真武。 一日，忽闻父叔兄弟聚话，嗟叹云：去年大旱，诸乡缺食，今田苗正要水浆，上天不降甘雨，民间又将失望。 虽本村真孚岩有龙潭，官吏到来取水，略无应验。 是时，招弟闻此，自露天剪髻，发心取七月十五日，焚香舍身，为天下遭旱处，保求雨泽，愿祈丰稔。
chunks.translated_text:
The Eastern Pavilion Gate Commissioner, Defense Commissioner of Meizhou, and newly appointed Military Commissioner of the Jingzhao Prefecture, Xie Rouli, was dispatched to the Western Regions during the Tianxi era to oversee matters along the Yellow River. There, he encountered the Perfected Warrior and True Lord flying across the river, who told him: "The Tubo envoy Li Ximeng is entering the country—you must apprehend any skilled painter, for that man is a traitor." Xie Rouli heeded the command and, upon reaching the Eastern Capital, captured a group transporting a portrait of the Empress Dowager from the Cixiao Temple. The Tubo envoy’s plot was exposed, and he was sent to the Supreme Court for sentencing. Xie Rouli was rewarded by the imperial court with a promotion. Thereafter, he daily offered incense and prayers at his family shrine in gratitude. Every night at the second watch, he prepared incense and knelt beneath the open sky, bowing to the north, continuing this for nearly a year.

Suddenly, the court issued an edict appointing him deputy envoy for the return mission to Jiaozhi, accompanying the chief envoy, Minister of Personnel Yan Su, to cross the sea. Before reaching the halfway point at Mount Bailin, at noon, they encountered over forty pirate ships. The pirates brandished spears and crossbows, shouting threats as they sought to plunder their cargo. Unprepared for defense, Xie Rouli stood by the water’s edge, pouring wine and scattering paper money into the air as he tearfully implored the True Warrior to descend. The pirate leader, a scholar named Chen Guang, raised his spear to strike Xie Rouli when suddenly an arrow struck Chen Guang in the chest, sending him into the sea. His body was hauled aboard, and his head was severed and displayed on a pole to the crew. Yet the remaining five hundred pirates, enraged, rallied their ships to exact revenge. As they rowed fiercely forward, a headwind drove them back. For three days and nights, they struggled in vain, until at last they sighted the shores of Jiaozhi not far ahead. As they neared the borders of the City of Female Immortals, officials arrived to welcome them, and the pirates scattered and fled. Yan Su and Xie Rouli, by the grace of the True Warrior, returned safely to the capital.

Upon reporting these divine responses to the throne, an imperial decree was issued to hold a seven-day Yellow Register Grand Offering at Wangjin Garden. On the final day, attendants were dispatched to renowned mountains and grotto-heavens to conduct further rituals, casting dragon tablets into the waters in solemn thanks for the divine favor.

---

At Baiyun Ziqing Chan Monastery on Xinshan in Dengzhou, the monastic officer Xiao Chu not only upheld the Buddhist teachings but also devoted himself to Daoist practices. In the quiet of his quarters, he reverently worshipped the True Warrior with unwavering devotion. The monastery stood near a coastal island where a band of over a hundred men, led by Zhou Ying of Shaowu Commandery, had been pillaging, murdering, and setting fires along the sea routes. The local authorities amassed a reward for their capture, but as time passed, the gang grew larger and more difficult to eradicate.

One day, Zhou Ying and his men planned to raid the monastery. That night, Xiao Chu dreamed that the monastery’s earth deity came to warn him of an impending attack. The True Warrior had commanded that a black wind be unleashed to repel the pirate ships before they could land, urging Xiao Chu to swiftly alert the authorities. Xiao Chu immediately dispatched a messenger to the patrol inspector, who arrived with armed soldiers and set up ambushes around the monastery.

The next day, Zhou Ying and his hundreds of followers, armed with spears and cudgels, stormed the monastery, claiming they only sought shelter for the night. The monastery’s abbot welcomed them, and they gathered in the Dharma Hall for tea. As the gates were being shut, Xiao Chu pleaded with them, offering money and goods if they would leave at dawn. Zhou Ying scoffed, demanding the valuables be handed over at once. Suddenly, he cried out in terror: "Why do my eyes see only chaos? My head burns like fire, and my limbs will not move!" Moments later, Inspector Qiu Gao of Xixinshan and his troops rushed in, capturing every last pirate without a single escape. They were taken to Dengzhou’s prison, and after sentencing, the reward was divided—seven parts to Monk Xiao Chu and three to the patrol inspector and his soldiers.

In his report, Xiao Chu stated that the capture of the pirates was not due to the monastery’s efforts but to the True Warrior’s intervention, which rendered the bandits helpless and ensured their capture. He petitioned the court to express gratitude to the True Warrior. The provincial authorities submitted the report, and an imperial decree soon followed: though Baiyun Ziqing was a Chan Buddhist monastery, it was granted a True Warrior Hall, along with an imperial copy of the *Scripture of the Supreme Perfected Warrior* for perpetual veneration. Xiao Chu was bestowed a purple robe and the title "Great Master of True Responses," tasked with overseeing the hall and safeguarding the imperial scripture. He was also granted the seven-part reward to expand the sacred hall.

---

In Anfeng County, Shouzhou, a man named Wang Wenqing had a daughter, nicknamed Zhaodi. From the age of thirteen, she abstained from meat and fish, devoting herself to virtue and the Dao. One day, a wandering Daoist nun knocked at her door, urging Zhaodi to venerate the Perfected Warrior and True Lord of Numinous Response of the Northern Dipper. Zhaodi replied, "I am but a humble girl and cannot afford to commission a sacred image. If I could only obtain a copy of the *Scripture of the True Warrior*, I would recite it day and night, keeping it close to my heart, meditating on the True Lord’s image, burning incense, and chanting his praises."

By twenty, Zhaodi’s beauty, intelligence, and skill had drawn the attention of wealthy families seeking her hand in marriage, all of whom she accepted in principle—yet she never ceased invoking her master, the True Warrior. One day, she overheard her father, uncles, and brothers lamenting: "Last year’s drought left the villages starving. Now, as the crops desperately need water, Heaven has not sent rain, and the people face despair once more. Though officials have come to our village’s Zhenfu Crag to draw water from the dragon pool, there has been no response."

Upon hearing this, Zhaodi cut off her hair in the open air and vowed that on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, she would burn incense and offer herself in sacrifice to pray for rain across the drought-stricken lands, beseeching a bountiful harvest.

chunks.original_text: 骨属劝之不从，遂就家前起立柴塔。 是时，四方观者，围绕赞叹。 招弟形容永不改，止如常，告辞父母众人，留偈云：来时寻度，去即旧路。 三春花艳，开谢无固。 偈毕，嘻笑入於火中，既透发於柴棚中心，有青光一道，直冲天门。 良久，骤雨倾降，其火有如油蜡浇灌，光艳转盛。 雨过烧毕，又降大雨，凡两日一夜，应河渠田苗，尽皆沾足。 至晴，王氏泊乡众来取骨灰，并无纤毫尘迩，却於柴灰中，拾得栏子一条，双带结定，在生受持真武经一卷，俨然如故。 方知其尸火解，惟留经卷衣服，以表诚心。 因其雨水通济灵感，所致州县，前来唤王文庆，资火内焚烧不坏真武经一卷看验，诣实施行。 次却准省符照会天下应缺雨处，已於七月十五日至十六日，天降甘泽周足，及勘会本州境界，有青光一道冲天，系是何处，是何祥瑞。 州司具奏，准中书省详，宜下寿州，以官钱就天庆观，建立小阁一所，收王招弟遗迩，真武经一卷，用彩匣盛藏，永充供养，立碑为记。 仍封王招弟为济泽圣姑，置祠香火。 附语祈晴 果州有失目人陈希，於少广山，夜遇一真武传诀，逐日专奉。 后觉出言如附神语，为人求保事叔，皆合来意。 四远响驰，人所施惠，多不恋己，用为功果。
chunks.translated_text:
Her family entreated her to abandon the vow, but she would not relent. She then erected a pyre before her home. At that moment, spectators from all directions gathered, encircling her with murmurs of admiration. Zhaodi’s countenance remained unchanged, as serene as ever. Taking leave of her parents and the assembled crowd, she left behind a verse:

*"I came seeking deliverance,
Departing by the old path.
Spring blossoms bloom in splendor,
Yet fade without attachment."*

The verse spoken, she laughed joyfully and stepped into the flames. As the fire consumed the pyre’s center, a single streak of azure light shot straight toward the heavens. After a long while, a sudden downpour descended, and though the flames burned as if drenched in oil or wax, their radiance only grew brighter. When the rain ceased and the fire had burned itself out, another heavy rain fell, lasting two days and a night, until every river, canal, and field was thoroughly saturated.

When the skies cleared, the Wang family and villagers came to gather her ashes, but not a single speck of dust remained. Instead, within the pyre’s ashes, they found a sash tied in a double knot and a scroll of the *True Warrior Sutra* she had held in life—both perfectly preserved. It became clear then that her body had dissolved in the fire, leaving only the sutra and her garments as testament to her sincerity.

In recognition of the miraculous rain and its life-giving bounty, local officials summoned Wang Wenqing to present the fire-resistant *True Warrior Sutra* for verification. The matter was duly reported, and the provincial authorities issued an edict to investigate all drought-stricken regions. It was confirmed that from the fifteenth to the sixteenth day of the seventh month, timely rains had fallen abundantly. Further inquiry revealed that within the state’s borders, a streak of azure light had pierced the heavens—a wondrous omen from an unknown source.

The prefectural authorities memorialized the event, and after deliberation by the Central Secretariat, an order was sent to Shouzhou: using government funds, a small pavilion was to be constructed at Tianqing Temple to enshrine the relics of Wang Zhaodi, along with the *True Warrior Sutra* in a painted casket for perpetual veneration. A stele was erected to commemorate the event, and Zhaodi was posthumously enfeoffed as the *Holy Maiden of Life-Giving Rain*, with a shrine established for offerings. The inscription also included a prayer for clear skies.

In Guozhou, a blind man named Chen Xi once encountered the True Warrior on Shaoguang Mountain, who transmitted a secret method to him. From then on, Chen devoted himself to its practice. Later, when he spoke, his words seemed imbued with divine presence, and whatever he prayed for on behalf of others—whether for their uncles or other matters—always came to pass. His reputation spread far and wide, and though people offered him gifts, he cared little for personal gain, dedicating all to meritorious deeds.

chunks.original_text: 咸平年中，夏接秋序，久雨伤禾，州县祈禳，皆无感应。 众状举陈希，，供养真武，祈求有灵。 知郡黄房，遂令陈希赴厅。 陈希却告黄辰，须得亲制祝辞，迎请陈希家真武宝座至州衙，选道士七人，启立清净道场，禁屠减刑，逐日放士庶烧香，瞻祷祈晴道场。 已对三日，陈希对知通官众，附传圣语：蒙真武降言，果州为天曹注定六十日雨，减除禾颗，十分不收。 今更有二十余日，连雨未息。 今既要求晴，奉天皇勃旨，消臧元注日分，至明日巳时，雨脚渐从正北而收，午时，天色晴明，禾株茂盛，必获成熟。 其陈希精神复回，适来降灵所说之事，皆不知之。 明早大雨如倾，巳时便晴，於正北方，云霭顿收。 本州复留真武，展三日道场，备香花道具，迎送真武归陈希家。 又於本堂启建道场答谢。 至冬间，果州五县，并无检放苗数。 后转运司体问因依，奏闻朝廷。 续降回命下果州，宜令置立照应记录，於州衙大厅，永远为验。 陈希除本州支与酒钙彩帛外，特赐静应居士为号。 孙隐遣蝗 朝奉郎尚书，刑部郎中，知嘉州杨扈札子：伏见峨县令孙隐，县治公勤，有数卫，救济灾苦。 第一，考乡村虫蝗伤害早禾，峨媚县虽有飞蝗，不伤禾穗，柢因孙隐付下咒　水，分偯逐乡人，用柳枝散洒，其蝗尽化为飞蚁，投水而变。 至秋收，不失分毫。 检放峨媚山，递年有虎狼伤人，孙隐发黄纸符牒一封，给付峨媚山诸管击神司，自后绝踪。 第二，考本路转运使陶汾，经历偶风诞气中，孙隐将枣汤调药灌之，乃安。 第三，考知州杨扈有新妇窦氏，临产惊危，孙隐付到生朱符一道，烧灰用水调下，即获平安。 缘孙隐任满，本州百姓涕泣，举留再任，特召孙隐审问，何术以成异功。 孙隐乃云：先父太监孙宗道，曾随先皇太宗帝驾取河束，夜在锦柄川，遇真武真君，传授九件符箓咒水科目。 先父虽不行用，隐从受恩，一向供养真武，欲誓行符咒　水救人。 皆承真武扶助，岂孙隐之能。 杨扈具剖保奏，运使陶汾续有奏闻，朝廷看详，未言余事，柢将消遣蝗虫二镇伏虎豹，乃是灵法护为褒显。 其孙隐，系荫赐恩，本无出身，令特转授光禄寺丞，再就峨媚县一任。 其嘉州，有真武慈济观，是知州杨扈，运使陶汾，及市户报恩创立。 守卿禳虫 福州百姓林守卿，宝元年中，因为海商至漳州海口遇风潮，其船看即沉溺，不觉船头空中现一神人，叫言：守卿，今后休更贩海，今救尔一船惊危。 他日来闽山天庆观，寻南廊任道士相见。 言讫，化白光不见。 其风涛顿息，舟橄轻稳，回归福州。 遂入闽山天庆观南廊，询问，即无任道士房。 据一老道士云：任字即人，着王南廊有真武真君，旧系人王护国殿。 守卿方悟，诣殿礼谢，因求极好沉香，雕装金缕真武一堂，终身供养。 匠者方取沉香，方圆可一尺三寸，试欲斧凿，忽进数道祥光，渐渐光明不断。 其功德完备，守卿共约舍钱万余贯，於州境及闽山宫观寺院，普设大斋，重新修盖天庆观，并人王护国真武殿奉安庆忏，更不令子孙贩海经商。 当年，福州春夏大旱，虫蝗飞集，侵害禾苗，遍祈无应，直至七八月间，虫蝗不息。 州府访闻林守卿家，真武祈求有感？ 率州官来迎请真武，就州厅，逐日三时行道，执礼虔恳。

During the *Xianping* era, as summer gave way to autumn, prolonged rains damaged the crops. The prefecture and counties performed rituals to pray for relief, but none proved efficacious. The people collectively recommended Chen Xi, who venerated the True Warrior and whose prayers were known to be efficacious. Prefect Huang Fang thus summoned Chen Xi to the government hall. Chen Xi, however, informed Huang that he must personally compose the invocation, bring the True Warrior’s sacred seat from his home to the prefectural yamen, select seven Daoist priests, and establish a purified ritual space. Slaughter was forbidden, punishments were reduced, and the common people were permitted to burn incense and offer prayers for clear skies in the ritual space daily.

After three days, Chen Xi addressed the officials and assembled crowd, relaying the divine message: “By the True Warrior’s decree, Guozhou was fated by the Celestial Bureau to endure sixty days of rain, reducing the harvest by a full tenth. Twenty days remain, and the rains have yet to cease. Now that you have prayed for clear skies, by the August Emperor’s command, the celestial records shall be revised. By tomorrow’s *si* hour, the rain will gradually recede from the due north, and by the *wu* hour, the sky will clear, the crops will flourish, and the harvest will be secured.” When Chen Xi’s spirit returned, he recalled nothing of the divine pronouncement.

The next morning, heavy rain poured down, but by the *si* hour, the skies cleared, and the clouds dispersed from the north. The prefecture retained the True Warrior for three more days of ritual, preparing incense, flowers, and Daoist implements to escort the deity back to Chen Xi’s home. A separate ritual was then held in the hall to give thanks.

That winter, none of the five counties in Guozhou reported any shortfall in grain yields. The Transport Commission investigated the matter and memorialized the court. An imperial edict was subsequently issued to Guozhou, ordering that an official record be established in the prefectural yamen as permanent testimony. Beyond the provisions of wine, grain, silk, and brocade granted by the prefecture, Chen Xi was specially bestowed the title *Master of Tranquil Response*.

---

Sun Yin’s Memorial on Locust Plagues
*Remonstrance Gentleman, Minister of Justice, and Prefect of Jiazhou, Yang Hu’s memorial:*

I have observed that Sun Yin, magistrate of E County, has diligently administered his office, demonstrating remarkable efficacy in alleviating disasters and hardships. First, when locusts infested the early crops in the villages, though Emei County suffered from flying locusts, the grain remained unharmed. This was due to Sun Yin distributing enchanted water to the villagers, who sprinkled it with willow branches, causing the locusts to transform into flying ants and perish in the water. By autumn, not a single grain was lost.

Second, when tigers and wolves in Emei Mountain preyed upon people year after year, Sun Yin issued a talisman on yellow paper to the mountain’s spirit-officials, and the beasts vanished without a trace.

Third, when Transport Commissioner Tao Fen suffered an attack of wind-phlegm, Sun Yin administered a decoction of jujube and medicine, restoring him to health.

Fourth, when Prefect Yang Hu’s daughter-in-law, née Dou, faced a perilous childbirth, Sun Yin provided a vermilion birth talisman. Burned to ash and mixed with water, it ensured her safe delivery.

As Sun Yin’s term neared its end, the people of the prefecture wept and petitioned for his retention. Summoned for inquiry into his extraordinary abilities, Sun Yin explained: “My late father, Eunuch Sun Zongdao, once accompanied the late Emperor Taizong on a campaign to Hebei. One night in Jinbing Plain, he encountered the True Warrior Perfected Lord, who transmitted nine talismans, incantations, and methods for consecrating water. Though my father never employed them, I inherited the teachings and have venerated the True Warrior ever since, vowing to use the talismans and water to save others. All successes are due to the True Warrior’s aid—how could they be my doing alone?”

Yang Hu submitted a detailed memorial in support, and Transport Commissioner Tao Fen followed with his own report. The court, after review, determined that while other matters were unremarkable, the suppression of locusts in two towns and the taming of tigers and leopards demonstrated divine protection worthy of commendation. Though Sun Yin held office by hereditary privilege without formal credentials, he was specially promoted to *Attending Secretary of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices* and reappointed to Emei County for another term.

In Jiazhou, the *True Warrior Compassionate Salvation Abbey* was founded by Prefect Yang Hu, Transport Commissioner Tao Fen, and local merchants in gratitude. The abbey served to repel pests and pacify disasters.

---

**Lin Shouqing’s Veneration of the True Warrior**
During the *Baoyuan* era, a Fujian merchant named Lin Shouqing was sailing from Zhangzhou’s harbor when his ship was caught in a storm surge. As the vessel was about to sink, a divine figure suddenly appeared in the empty air above the prow, calling out: “Shouqing, cease your seafaring henceforth. Today, I shall save your ship from peril. In the future, come to the *Tianqing Abbey* on Min Mountain and seek Daoist Ren in the south corridor.” With these words, the figure vanished in a flash of white light. The wind and waves instantly calmed, and the ship glided smoothly back to Fuzhou.

Lin proceeded to the south corridor of *Tianqing Abbey* on Min Mountain but found no quarters for a Daoist named Ren. An elderly priest informed him: “The character *ren* means ‘person.’ In the south corridor, there is a shrine to the True Warrior Perfected Lord, originally the *King’s Protector of the State Hall*.” Lin then understood. He visited the hall to offer thanks and commissioned a statue of the True Warrior from the finest agarwood, gilded and intricately carved, for lifelong veneration.

When the craftsman selected a piece of agarwood measuring one foot and three inches in circumference, he prepared to carve it. Suddenly, several auspicious rays of light emanated from the wood, growing brighter and unceasing. Once the statue was completed, Lin, together with others, donated over ten thousand strings of cash to sponsor grand vegetarian feasts at temples and abbeys throughout the prefecture and on Min Mountain. The *Tianqing Abbey* and the *King’s Protector of the State True Warrior Hall* were extensively renovated, and repentance rituals were established. Lin vowed that neither he nor his descendants would ever again engage in maritime trade.

That year, Fuzhou suffered a severe drought from spring to summer, and locusts swarmed, ravaging the crops. Prayers for relief went unanswered, and the locusts persisted into the seventh and eighth months. The prefectural government, learning of Lin Shouqing’s devotion to the True Warrior, dispatched officials to invite the deity to the yamen. There, rituals were performed thrice daily with utmost reverence.

After just three days, the locusts wrapped themselves around tree branches and perished. Villagers from the four hamlets broke off the branches and presented them as proof. Sweet rains began to fall daily, and by winter, half of the damaged crops were salvaged. The prefectural government celebrated and gave thanks to the True Warrior, concluding the grand ritual feast. With the same solemnity as before, the deity was escorted back to Lin Shouqing’s household shrine.

Prefect Chen Ciqin, having witnessed Lin Shouqing’s deliverance at sea, the carving of the sacred image, the manifestation of crimson light, and the prayers for rain that dispelled the locust plague, reported these miracles across seven prefectures and nineteen counties, affirming their truth and efficacy in widespread relief. His memorial was duly approved, and an edict commanded that the True Warrior image enshrined by Lin Shouqing be purchased at its appraised value and conveyed to the capital.

Lin Shouqing thereafter presented the image at court. Upon inspection, the throne was found to be crafted of aloeswood, exquisitely wrought, and suffused with auspicious radiance—a marvel of divine favor and numinous response. By imperial decree, it was retained as a treasure to safeguard the realm and enshrined in the inner palace. Lin Shouqing was specially granted the honorary rank of *Sanjie Jiezhi* and later rose to the position of Right Attendant-in-Ordinary. He lived to ninety-six, passing without illness.

chunks.original_text: 咸平二年，司天台奏定，九月初三日，火星合踱娄宿，正照齐国郑州分野，大生火灾。 行下本州，预宜禳谢。 缘郑州系京束西路屯兵津要，从四月间，告示宫观禳火，道场设醮祈祷。 时市南李惟信，充斗子牙人，每夜三更，潜於桥道要会之处，烧香设拜一夜。 偶值都监任从远出巡，作犯夜收，解郦州。 据称，在外为不肖，犯夜。 自正月初七日夜，因知一事，遂烧夜香。 乃问何事？ 惟信曰：昨发心，将一年解得牙钱，醮献天曹，答谢衣食来处，作散席斋会。 忽有云游道士，衣冠不整，风韵飘逸，手挈图画一轴，入来求斋。 是绢画真武像，惟信欲求供养，其道士便允，秪取价钱两贯，乃就斋食。 至中半，忽一声风鸣，不见其人，但於坐卓上，收得活龟一枚，如桃核大。 惟信明知遭遇圣真显化，降授香火，兼得小龟灵异，因宝惜供养。 今年正月初七夜，方备下降纸礼，烧献真武。 又见数年前卖画轴，遗下小龟道士入门，惟信便拜，欲问姓氏，不说，秪称贫道能攻历数，等得上界火星至，九月初三日，正照齐地郑州，主火灾，烧至万家。 如得一家姓万，不拘屋宇大小，全门什物财宝，不得移动分文，先与抄录见数，至九月初三日天明，用一火，命男子头分丱髻，身着腓衣，手携火把，从正南方绕屋三匝，以火烧之，至后，更无火灾。 候毕，即众备上件屋宇，种种等物，酬还姓万之人，方可消禳。 贫道出门，化白光不见。 惟信虽得圣降报说，不敢申诉，惟夜后，从市中要处，礼祝火星，愿兔其灾。 今有随身香火炉照证。 州府据牙人供状看详，与近降朝旨一同，遂差公吏缉问姓万人家，将家产什物抄札见数。 责下众户，候火过，填备文状在案。 放李惟信归家，焚香保护。 既时日至，装一着诽衣童子，将市西府桥万明一家焚烧，被南风吹驾，焰起势猛，火分二边，人心惊骇，不觉青天骤雨一阵，火势因息，不经一时，烧过万家。 李惟信家真武座下，不见小龟。 是时，趁风雨化去。

In the second year of Xianping, the Bureau of Astronomy memorialized that on the third day of the ninth month, Mars would conjoin the constellation Lou, directly illuminating the celestial division corresponding to Zhengzhou in the Qi region, foretelling a great conflagration. The imperial command was issued to the prefecture, ordering preparatory rites of expiation. As Zhengzhou served as a strategic garrison along the eastern route to the capital, from the fourth month onward, notices were posted at temples and Daoist abbeys to conduct rituals for averting fire, with grand jiao offerings and prayers.

At that time, Li Weixin of the southern market, a broker in the grain trade, would steal away each night at the third watch to burn incense and prostrate himself at a critical thoroughfare on the bridge. By chance, the garrison commander Ren Congyuan happened upon him during a night patrol, arrested him for violating curfew, and sent him under guard to Lizhou. When questioned, Li admitted to his misconduct, explaining that since the seventh night of the first month, he had been burning incense at night after learning of a matter. Asked what it was, he replied: "Last year, I vowed to devote my broker’s earnings for a full year to sponsor a jiao offering to the Heavenly Court, in gratitude for the source of my sustenance, and to host a vegetarian feast. Suddenly, a wandering Daoist—his robes disheveled, his bearing free and untrammeled—entered seeking alms, carrying a scroll painting. It was a silk portrait of the True Warrior. I wished to enshrine it, and the Daoist agreed, asking only for two strings of cash, then partook of the meal. Midway through, a gust of wind howled, and he vanished, leaving behind on the table a living tortoise no larger than a peach pit. I knew then I had encountered a divine manifestation, receiving sacred incense and this wondrous small tortoise, which I treasured and enshrined.

On the seventh night of the first month this year, I prepared paper offerings to burn in worship of the True Warrior. Then, the Daoist who had sold me the scroll years before reappeared, carrying the little tortoise. I bowed to him, asking his name, but he would not say, only declaring: ‘This poor Daoist is versed in calendrical calculations. When the celestial fire star arrives on the third day of the ninth month, it will directly illuminate Zhengzhou in the Qi region, bringing a great fire that will burn ten thousand households. If you find a household surnamed Wan, regardless of the size of their dwelling, do not move a single item or coin from their home. First, record an inventory of all their possessions. At dawn on the third day of the ninth month, have a boy with his hair tied in a topknot, clad in a coarse hemp robe, carry a torch and circle the house three times from the south, then set it ablaze. Afterward, there will be no further fire. Once done, gather the people to restore the house and all its contents to the Wan family, and the calamity will be averted.’

As he departed, he transformed into a streak of white light and vanished. Though I received this divine revelation, I dared not report it. Instead, each night, I secretly offered prayers to Mars at the market’s vital crossroads, beseeching deliverance from disaster. Here is the incense burner I carried as proof."

Upon reviewing the broker’s testimony, the prefectural authorities found it consistent with the recent imperial edict. They dispatched officials to investigate households surnamed Wan, recording an inventory of their property and possessions. The residents were ordered to await the fire’s passage before restoring everything, with the documents filed for the record. Li Weixin was released to return home, where he burned incense in vigilant protection.

When the appointed day arrived, a boy clad in a hemp robe was prepared. The household of Wan Ming west of the prefectural bridge was set ablaze. A southern wind fanned the flames, splitting them into two fierce tongues. The people were seized with terror—when suddenly, a sudden downpour extinguished the blaze. In less than an hour, the fire had passed through the Wan residence. Beneath the True Warrior’s image in Li Weixin’s home, the small tortoise was gone, having vanished with the wind and rain.

chunks.original_text: 郑州承此灵验，已行遣。 次又准中书剖子，为司天台照见，九月初三日，火德已临郑州，主於寅时，烧除万家。 取问，曾不侵动官物库仗等。 时兵部侍郎参知政事昊敏古，判郑州，开拆保奏，续降指挥看详。 李惟信遇真武，救灾以显宿德，宜赐法酒百瓶，绢百匹，米十石，钙十石，钱百贯，仰於本州公使库支请。 并有万明先，肯全家代烧，克时消禳，亦给酒米例物，急令填造屋宇，财物偿还，不得迟滞。 其有国家州郡，承此真武及南方火德尊星，慈悲显济，谨，就在京玉津园，建道场七昼夜，设醮一千二百分位答谢。 折应计都 至和三年八月初一日夜，有黄气出南方，三夜而没。 据司天台朝奉郎夏询等割子，伏观黄气，现於正南，属昊国分野，其气一名天门黄道，二名土央，三名计都，现於磨竭宫天门。 黄道，主次年国有内忧，应在阴宫一人。 以土央为坟墓之象，计都是九天桥宿。 非时泛宫出现，主一方军民，至冬后疾患，人死四分。 犹得此星，於磨竭宫，踱犯亢宿，又是解灾福德之曜，伏望朝廷早赐谦禳。 时臣僚参详，事属未来，合预防之。 谨就玉津园，建内道场一月。 应名山大川，并遣降御香，投放龙简，建道场法醮，各七昼夜。 仍颁行德音，减除罪囚。 又於大内熙圣殿，别致黄箓道场四十九昼夜,每日圣驾躬幸，祷祝计都星君，及束方亢宿，并家堂真武福神，保求休证道场。 日限将毕，忽日正午时，骤起风阵，泛涌黄沙，笼罩目前，空中一金甲神人，现於庭际，称臣是监西天门葛将军，与北方真武，同管阳问，奏注善恶。 近见南方天门，黄道开现，乃是计都星君当游九天。 七百二十年一大周宫，到此遇本运，为中方土央相冲，作黄气三日，缠亢宿，磨蜴方退，主阳间内忧，从属猪阴人国长而起，不半年间，荆湖、江浙、福建、广南、淮汉路，人死四分，坟墓遍道。 可应其气，灾虽未到，奈帝德一感验，建醮投龙等事，犹未全禳，惟德音一行、臧放囚狱，承此种种功勋，感动诸天，蒙真武凭此朝奏北极，北极朝奏玉皇，特蒙劫命，天皇亲往校察，计都星君已为、官家禳解，定下二十九岁，命属猪阴人一名，新年正月初旬当死，宜往正南方二十七里外，冲黄道。 日立坟墓，当为内忧，救南国诸州四分军民死亡，为陛下折应计都之限，至时，切不得发哀，为此人命限已满，元注寿数。 今受真武嘱付，特来代报官家知悉，却返天门。 至次年正月初三日，贵妃张氏弃世。 贵妃年二十九岁，正月十九日亥时生，命宫属猪。 候黄道利日，於正南二十七里，立坟墓。 自后，更无灾忧，绿此应验，并赖真武降灵，保助天下。

The prefecture of Zhengzhou, having witnessed this divine efficacy, had already acted accordingly. Subsequently, in accordance with a memorial from the Chancellery, the Bureau of Astronomy observed that on the third day of the ninth month, the Fire Virtue would descend upon Zhengzhou, striking at the hour of *yin* to burn away the Wan household. Upon inquiry, it was confirmed that no official storehouses, armories, or other public property would be affected.

At the time, Wu Min’gu, Vice Minister of War and Participant in Determining Governmental Matters, served as prefect of Zhengzhou. Upon opening and reviewing the memorial of protection, a subsequent imperial decree was issued for further deliberation. As Li Weixin had encountered the True Warrior and averted disaster, thereby manifesting his accumulated virtue, he was to be bestowed with one hundred bottles of ritual wine, one hundred bolts of silk, ten *shi* of rice, ten *shi* of wheat, and one hundred strings of cash, to be disbursed from the prefecture’s public treasury. Wan Ming, who had previously offered his entire household to be burned in substitution, thereby effecting timely expiation, was likewise granted wine, rice, and other provisions according to precedent. He was urgently ordered to rebuild his dwelling, with compensation for his property, and no delay was to be tolerated.

Moreover, in recognition of the True Warrior’s merciful deliverance and the Southern Fire Virtue’s august stellar benevolence, a seven-day and seven-night Daoist ritual was to be conducted in the Jade Grove Park of the capital, with an offering of one thousand two hundred altar stations in gratitude. To counteract the baleful influence of *Ketu*, in the third year of the Zhihe reign, on the first night of the eighth month, a yellow vapor emerged from the south and persisted for three nights before dissipating. According to a memorial from the Bureau of Astronomy by the Court Gentleman for Attendance Xia Xun and others, the yellow vapor had appeared in the due south, corresponding to the celestial division of the Wu state. This vapor was known by three names: the Yellow Path of Heaven’s Gate, *Tuyang*, and *Ketu*, manifesting in the Celestial Gate of the *Makara* constellation. The Yellow Path foretold internal strife in the state the following year, affecting one person of the *yin* palace. *Tuyang* signified the image of tombs, while *Ketu* was the stellar bridge of the nine heavens. Its untimely appearance outside its proper palace portended that, by the winter’s end, one quarter of the military and civilian population in a certain region would perish from pestilence. However, as this star resided in the *Makara* constellation and trespassed upon the *Kang* mansion, it also served as a stellar force capable of dissolving calamity and bestowing fortune. It was thus hoped that the court would promptly undertake rites of humility and expiation.

Upon deliberation by the court officials, as the matter pertained to the future, it was deemed necessary to take preventive measures. A month-long inner Daoist ritual was accordingly conducted in the Jade Grove Park. Imperial incense was dispatched to all renowned mountains and great rivers, where dragon tablets were cast into the waters, and seven-day and seven-night ritual offerings were established. A general amnesty was proclaimed, and prisoners were to have their sentences reduced or remitted. Additionally, within the imperial palace’s Hall of Flourishing Sagehood, a separate forty-nine-day and forty-nine-night Yellow Register Daoist ritual was held. Each day, the emperor personally attended to pray to the Star Lord *Ketu*, the Eastern *Kang* constellation, and the household True Warrior and Fortune Deity, seeking auspicious confirmation through the ritual.

As the allotted days neared their end, suddenly, at high noon, a fierce wind arose, stirring up swirling yellow sand that obscured the sky. Amidst the haze, a golden-armored divine warrior appeared in the courtyard, declaring, “Your subject is General Ge, Warden of the Western Gate of Heaven, who, together with the True Warrior of the North, oversees the reckoning of good and evil in the yang realm. Recently, the Southern Gate of Heaven’s Yellow Path has opened, revealing *Ketu* as it traverses the nine heavens. Once every seven hundred and twenty years, it completes a grand cycle, and now, encountering its destined phase, it clashes with *Tuyang* of the central region, producing a three-day yellow vapor that entwines the *Kang* mansion before retreating from *Makara*. This portends internal strife in the yang realm, arising from a person of the *yin* palace born in the year of the Boar, who holds sway as a national leader. Within half a year, in the circuits of Jinghu, Jiangzhe, Fujian, Guangnan, and Huaihan, one quarter of the populace will perish, and tombs will line the roads. Though the calamity has yet to arrive, the emperor’s virtue has already elicited a response. The rituals, offerings, and casting of dragon tablets, however, have not yet fully expiated the omen. Only the proclamation of virtue and the release of prisoners have accrued sufficient merit to move the heavens. Through the True Warrior’s intercession, a memorial was presented to the North Culmen, which in turn memorialized the Jade Emperor. By special decree, the Heavenly Emperor personally conducted an investigation, and *Ketu* was pacified on behalf of the imperial house. It was determined that a person of the *yin* palace, aged twenty-nine and born in the year of the Boar, would die in the first ten days of the new year. To avert internal strife and spare the southern circuits from the death of one quarter of their military and civilian population, a tomb should be erected twenty-seven *li* due south to counter the Yellow Path. At that time, no mourning should be observed, for this person’s allotted lifespan has reached its end. I have been entrusted by the True Warrior to report this to the imperial house before returning to the Heavenly Gate.”

In the following year, on the third day of the first month, the Noble Consort Zhang passed away. The Noble Consort was twenty-nine years old, born on the nineteenth day of the first month at the hour of *hai*, her fate palace belonging to the Boar. On an auspicious day for the Yellow Path, a tomb was erected twenty-seven *li* due south. Thereafter, no further disasters occurred, and this fulfillment of the omen was attributed to the True Warrior’s descent and protection of the realm.

chunks.original_text: 感其恩宥，及西天门葛将军等神降报，宜付有司，赐在京诸宫观，各令建设罗天大醮三昼夜，报答圣恩。 天降粟麦 河北两路，自真定诸州县於建隆立军后，二载皆旱，稻粟麦豆，颗粒不收，军民饥疫，流‘移转死。 时磁州，於七月初问，据四门监守军兵互报，今有商用车乘驼马，般贩到席子粟麦等，各称投官仓寄货。 太守差官，逐门接引其客。 续承都监张静等公状，备说四门，有席袋二千粟麦，并无主者。 看守居民，尽言见西门来者，卸下席子，探迭了当，各牵驾车马，向崇明观右门入去。 余三处，无人知其去踪，但见席角上缠黄纸马。 知磁州陈庸，通判莫千之等，至西门崇明观，集道众取问客人姓名，道众对日：观门荒弊，即无车从入到本观。 庸等问曰：此观甚代建立，多少殿宇。 据称始自前唐，因天曹甘真君谪凡，教化青提道士，修学之处。 后为甘真君白日上升，青提亦化去，方赐为观。 内有三清殿，北极七元殿，甘真君殿，真武灵应殿，共四所殿。 除真武殿常积到下降日，军民施利，逐旋修营外，余皆摧损。 庸等差拨军脚，般运席子，寄着州仓。 四门粟麦，共计一万斛。 磁州民间，正乏账济，不期有此斛物，若从天降，未、敢擅耀，须奏朝廷中书门下，受磁州申奏。 又据本路真定等二十余州申到，亦有粟麦到州，与磁州无异，却称元从磁州贩到。 今将逐州数目钻合，共计粟麦一十五万余石。 先下诸州，疾速贱价出耀。 仍勘会今来进到金钱云马，显是世间烧献，真武下降，纸马分明。 遂遣御药资香祝版，前来磁州，同知通判等，就崇明观斋醮。 仍於内庭，建报恩真武御容殿，乃下河北转运司，将元耀到圣降粟麦价钱，重修一路州军真武宫观，仍改崇明观为护国圣济观，特赐真武殿为灵应，并金字御书。 所是内庭，修建真武御容家堂，亦赠北方镇国玄都殿额，用表圣恩。 田生茨 梓州梓潼山上清紫极观，是西晋叶华真人修炼，遇太上老君来教挣乐国王太子金阙先生成道之处。 净乐太子金阙先生者，即真武是也。 观内有北极紫微殿，是叶华真人未上升时，亲为真武绿化建造。 皇佑元年，梓州饥疫，死伤十至七八。 忽有一村庄老儿，推车卖蒸茨，居民竞来收买，吃者，终日不饥。

Grateful for this divine mercy and the reports from the gods—including General Ge of the Western Heavenly Gate—it was decreed that the relevant authorities should bestow upon all the abbeys and temples within the capital the task of holding three-day-and-night *luotian* grand jiao rites to repay the sagely grace.

**Grain and Wheat Descend from Heaven**

In the two circuits of Hebei, from Zhen Ding and its subordinate prefectures and counties, following the establishment of the *Jianlong* garrison, two years of drought had left not a single grain of rice, wheat, millet, or bean to harvest. Soldiers and civilians suffered from famine and pestilence, with many fleeing or perishing.

At that time, in Cizhou, during the seventh month, guards stationed at the four city gates reported to one another that merchants had arrived with carts, camels, and horses, transporting mats and sacks of grain and wheat, all claiming to seek temporary storage in the official granaries. The prefect dispatched officials to guide these travelers through each gate. Soon after, Captain Zhang Jing and others submitted an official report stating that at the four gates, two thousand sacks of grain and wheat had appeared, with no owner in sight. Local residents keeping watch all testified that those at the western gate had unloaded the mats, stacked them neatly, then led their carts and horses through the right gate of Chongming Abbey and vanished. At the other three gates, no one knew their whereabouts, though yellow paper horses were found tied to the corners of the sacks.

Prefect Chen Yong of Cizhou, along with Vice Prefect Mo Qianzhi, proceeded to Chongming Abbey at the western gate and assembled the Daoist clergy to inquire about the merchants’ names. The clergy replied: “The abbey’s gates are dilapidated; no carts or followers have entered here.” Yong and his party asked: “When was this abbey established, and how many halls does it contain?” They were told: “It dates back to the Former Tang, when the Heavenly Court’s Gan the Perfected was banished to the mortal realm. Here, he instructed the Qingti Daoist in cultivation. Later, as Gan the Perfected ascended in broad daylight and Qingti also departed, the site was granted abbey status. Within, there are four halls: the Hall of the Three Purities, the Hall of the Northern Culmen and Seven Primes, the Hall of Gan the Perfected, and the Hall of the True Warrior’s Divine Response. Apart from the Hall of the True Warrior—which receives offerings from soldiers and civilians on the days of his descent and is thus maintained—the rest have fallen into ruin.”

Yong then ordered soldiers to transport the sacks to the prefectural granary. The grain and wheat from the four gates totaled ten thousand *hu*. As the people of Cizhou were in dire need of relief, this unexpected bounty seemed to descend from heaven. Yet, unwilling to presume, they first memorialized the imperial court through the Central Secretariat.

Reports from over twenty prefectures in the same circuit, including Zhen Ding, also confirmed the arrival of grain and wheat, identical to that in Cizhou, though all claimed it had been transported from Cizhou. Compiling the figures from each prefecture, the total amounted to over one hundred fifty thousand *shi* of grain and wheat. The court promptly ordered all prefectures to sell the grain at low prices without delay. Upon investigation, the gold coins and paper horses presented as offerings were clearly the result of worldly incense-burning rituals, with the True Warrior’s descent marked by the paper horses. Thus, imperial physicians were dispatched with incense and prayer tablets to Cizhou, where they joined the prefect and vice prefect in conducting a vegetarian feast and jiao rites at Chongming Abbey. Furthermore, a Hall of the True Warrior’s Imperial Portrait was established within the palace to offer thanks. The Hebei Transport Commission was instructed to use the proceeds from the sale of the heavenly-descended grain to renovate all True Warrior abbeys and temples across the circuit’s prefectures and commanderies. Chongming Abbey was renamed the Sagely Aid and State-Protecting Abbey, with its Hall of the True Warrior rededicated as the Hall of Divine Response, inscribed with imperial calligraphy in gold. Within the palace, a family shrine for the True Warrior’s imperial portrait was also constructed, and the Hall of the Mysterious Capital of the Northern Guardian was bestowed as a mark of sagely favor.

**Tian Sheng’s Steamed Cakes**

At the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey atop Mount Zitong in Zizhou, the Western Jin Daoist Ye Hua cultivated the Dao. There, the Supreme Venerable Lord descended to instruct Prince Jinque of the King of Zhengle—later known as Master Jinque—who attained the Way. This Prince Jinque of Zhengle was none other than the True Warrior. Within the abbey stands the Hall of the Northern Culmen and Purple Tenuity, built by Ye Hua himself before his ascension to guide the True Warrior’s transformation.

In the first year of the *Huangyou* reign, Zizhou suffered from famine and pestilence, with seven or eight out of every ten people dead or dying. Suddenly, an old villager appeared, pushing a cart to sell steamed cakes. The locals rushed to buy them, and those who ate them felt no hunger all day.

chunks.original_text: 往来货卖，经月余，人祇见从良苑门入，复从旧路去。 吏部侍郎张升，为梓州刺史，差人潜地踏逐出入归处，据回报，但见近梓潼山紫极观前，自然有黑雾遮接下见。 次日，更不出来，却有人相传，从良苑门外紫极观前，计十五里路，傍田地尽生茨，应一州饥民，无不掘吃，救过六十来日，已接新粮粟豆之类出市，其田土茨，顿绝苗颗。 张升遂备香币，特诣紫极观朝谒。 因入紫微殿右厢，乃见青草狼藉，接绕真武之堂，乃令侍吏於台座侧，取其草看，尽是茨根苗。 再令人取，却化为纸灰飞散，秪有初收得连苗两颗，遂用香合封盛，备述因依，赴京进奏。 准中书回降，进到真武救民应化茨，已奉圣旨，赐入四圣观，宜下梓州，於街市要会处，期集道众，建拦街天曹大醮道场七昼夜，普设大斋。 仍诣紫极观真武殿，别修醮祭，并赐殿牌，以救化救民为额。 郑箭灭龟 北京大名府，天圣二年八月十四日，黄河燥口坝捺顿破，燥水打坏，军民卒难。 救捺时，提辖官通判华惇臣等，前去相验，燥坝基址岩穴下，有一黑壳大龟，两目俱红，若或浮起，其浪湍急，坝索冲断。 遂具中留守司。 后因宰相卫公韩琦，守镇北京，随行有指使郑圭巡辖，因到燥口，其龟复出为患。 郑圭往看，委是水怪，情知容易除灭，圭备朝服弓箭，焚香祷告天曹，一箭果中其龟，仰落岩下，波浪不起。 兵夫修垮完备。 至天圣三年正月三日，郑圭风涎候起，卒死於癣宇。 经两日，还魂往见留守卫公云：圭被鬼使二人前来，云：阎罗王急唤郑圭，不合射杀黄河燥口五百年龟精。 今负冤来诉，急要证对。 及检交籍，郑圭寿禄未尽，又令二鬼押去。 过一山下，见立一早旗，队仗纷纭，圭问：此是何处？ 鬼卒曰：是下界风坏啰山，常有天真到此，校量三界事务。 圭遥望队仗问，见石上坐者，乃是阳问供养真武。 圭趋进唱咯，真武降言：汝阳间人，安得到此。 鬼使具述事因。 真武云：韦阎罗行事躁急，不详真伪。 其龟是西蕃梦云城苑州土地，昔被先朝师父陈忠元破苑州，城隍驱牒，其神蒙天符，遣往郑都，为黄河第四燥砂水土地，属北蕃卓州。 因在彼，则别无供赛，遂化为妖龟，随水而上，至大宋界北京黄河第七燥，翻坝捺，损坏军民，计一万来口。 天道不容，合为郑圭一箭射死。 况地府未凭天文制动施行，令符吏怀吾足前小龟，同郑圭及二鬼卒，返见韦阎罗。 若鬼妖乱有抵对，即令符吏放出小龟，仍告於地府，其郑圭寿禄未终，兼圭主人，宰相卫公韩琦，乃是紫府真人，见判北京，他日宝登，虑为不便。 言讫，圭拜辞，即随符吏鬼使至阴府，果见铁笼罩其大龟，左肋带一箭，呻吟衔冤。 二鬼使具言真武教旨。 是时，阎王既闻，即下殿仰空顶戴，遂急令检到制动，指实虚牵情罪，合加所犯，堕於江海，为推潮运砂，四足无名水兽，无形饿鬼。 其妖龟犹作人言，要与郑圭执对。 符吏於怀中取出小龟，放金色光一道，置於妖龟之前，妖龟被光芒烁射为一块，更不转动，被圣龟挟散於虚空中，化为微尘。 郑圭因此还魂。 韩卫公为避紫府真人之号，以致兵马钤辖王琮，通判华惇臣等，同状保奏。 续降朝旨，下北京於黄河垛口，置立护国真武殿，建醮立碑。

The old villager continued his trade for over a month, seen only entering through the Gate of Good Gardens and departing by the same route. Zhang Sheng, Vice Minister of Personnel and Prefect of Zizhou, dispatched men to stealthily track his comings and goings. Upon their return, they reported seeing only a natural black mist descending near the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey before Mount Zitong. The next day, the old man no longer appeared. Instead, word spread that fifteen *li* outside the Gate of Good Gardens, beside the fields near the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey, *qici* had sprouted in abundance. Enough to feed all the starving people of the prefecture, the tubers sustained them for over sixty days until the new harvest of grain, millet, and beans reached the market. Then, the *qici* in the fields vanished without a trace.

Zhang Sheng prepared incense and silk offerings and personally visited the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey to pay homage. Entering the right wing of the Hall of the Northern Culmen, he found the ground strewn with green grass entwining the True Warrior’s hall. He ordered his attendants to gather the grass from beside the altar platform. Upon inspection, they discovered it was the roots and shoots of *qici*. When they sent for more, it transformed into flying paper ash, leaving only two freshly gathered tubers with their shoots intact. These he sealed in an incense casket, recording the full account before dispatching it to the capital.

By decree of the Chancellery, the memorial concerning the True Warrior’s miraculous *qici* that saved the people was returned with approval. It ordered the tubers to be enshrined in the Abbey of the Four Saints and instructed Zizhou to assemble Daoist priests at a prominent crossroads for a seven-day-and-night *Tiancao* grand jiao ritual and universal vegetarian feast. Additionally, a separate jiao offering was to be held at the True Warrior’s hall in the Supreme Purple Culmen Abbey, which was also granted an inscribed plaque reading *"Rescue and Transformation, Salvation of the People."*

**Zheng’s Arrow Slays the Turtle**

In the second year of the *Tiansheng* reign, on the fourteenth day of the eighth month, the Yellow River’s dry-mouth dam at Beijing’s Daming Prefecture burst. The surging waters wreaked havoc, endangering soldiers and civilians alike. During the emergency repairs, the supervising officials—Vice Prefect Hua Dunchen and others—inspected the breach and found a massive black-shelled turtle with crimson eyes at the base of the dam’s rocky foundation. Whenever it surfaced, the currents raged, snapping the dam’s ropes. They reported the matter to the Capital Defense Command.

Later, when Chancellor Wei, Duke Han Qi, was stationed in Beijing, his attendant Zheng Gui was patrolling the area and encountered the turtle again, still causing trouble. Zheng Gui examined it and, recognizing it as a water demon, knew it could be easily vanquished. Donning his court robes and bow, he burned incense and prayed to the Heavenly Court. His arrow struck true, felling the turtle onto the rocks below, calming the waves. The soldiers swiftly completed the repairs.

On the third day of the first month of the third year of *Tiansheng*, Zheng Gui suddenly suffered a stroke and died in his quarters. Two days later, his soul revived and appeared before Duke Han, saying: "Two ghost messengers came for me, claiming King Yama urgently summoned Zheng Gui for wrongfully shooting the five-hundred-year-old turtle spirit of the Yellow River’s dry mouth. It has come to lodge a grievance and demands a confrontation." Upon checking the registers, they found Zheng Gui’s allotted lifespan was not yet exhausted, so the two ghosts escorted him away.

Passing a mountain, Zheng Gui saw a banner planted below and a bustling procession. He asked, "What place is this?" The ghost soldiers replied, "This is the Wind-Ravaged Mountain of the lower realm, where celestial perfected ones often come to review the affairs of the Three Realms." Gazing into the distance, Zheng Gui saw a figure seated on a rock—it was the True Warrior, revered in the mortal world. Zheng Gui hurried forward and bowed, and the True Warrior descended, saying, "How has a mortal like you come here?" The ghost messengers recounted the events.

The True Warrior said, "King Yama acted hastily, failing to discern the truth. That turtle was originally the earth god of Yuanzhou in the Dream Cloud City of the Western Qiang. When the imperial master Chen Zhongyuan conquered Yuanzhou in a previous dynasty, the city god was demoted by decree and reassigned to the Yellow River’s fourth dry-sand water deity, under the jurisdiction of Zhuozhou in the Northern Qiang. With no offerings there, it transformed into a demonic turtle and followed the current upstream to the seventh dry mouth of the Yellow River in the Song territory at Beijing. There, it breached the dam, harming over ten thousand soldiers and civilians. Heaven’s Way does not tolerate such deeds, so it was rightfully slain by Zheng Gui’s arrow. Moreover, the Earth Prison acted without celestial mandate. Have the talisman officer bring the small turtle from my presence, along with Zheng Gui and the two ghost soldiers, to confront King Yama. If the ghost demon disputes this, let the talisman officer release the small turtle. Then report to the Earth Prison: Zheng Gui’s lifespan is not yet over, and his master, Chancellor Han Qi, is a Perfected One of the Purple Palace currently governing Beijing. His future ascension would be inconvenient."

After speaking, the True Warrior dismissed Zheng Gui, who followed the talisman officer and ghost messengers to the netherworld. There, he saw the great turtle caged in iron, an arrow lodged in its left flank, groaning in grievance. The two ghost messengers relayed the True Warrior’s decree. Upon hearing this, King Yama descended from his throne and bowed to the heavens. He immediately ordered the celestial mandate reviewed, verifying the false accusations and the turtle’s crimes. The turtle was condemned to be cast into the rivers and seas, to serve as a tide-pushing, sand-shifting creature—a nameless water beast and formless hungry ghost. The demonic turtle still spoke, demanding a confrontation with Zheng Gui. The talisman officer drew the small turtle from his sleeve, releasing a golden light that struck the demonic turtle, reducing it to a motionless mass. The sacred turtle then scattered its remains into the void, turning them to dust. Zheng Gui thus revived.

To avoid the title of "Perfected One of the Purple Palace," Duke Han had the military commissioner Wang Cong, Vice Prefect Hua Dunchen, and others jointly submit a memorial. A subsequent imperial decree ordered the construction of the Protector-State True Warrior Hall at the Yellow River’s dam breach in Beijing, where a jiao ritual was held and a stele erected.
