**Pei the Sword-Wielder Drives Away Tigers**
In the Heng Mountains of Fenzhou, during the Jiayou era, a tiger suddenly appeared, preying on travelers at dawn and dusk. Whenever officials or hunters attempted to capture it, the beast would multiply into five or seven, resisting them in turn. As this was a vital route from Hedong to the capital, the harm grew severe. When Yang Zongdao, the newly appointed magistrate of Sanshui County, passed through Heng Mountain with his family en route to his post, one of his daughters was devoured. The prefectural and circuit authorities dispatched local patrol officers to guard the roads, increased the bounty for its capture, and called for hunters to slay the beast. At that time, a wandering Daoist named Pei arrived, claiming he could subdue the tiger. The prefecture granted his request, and after seven days, he returned, declaring that the tiger was no true beast but the vengeful spirits of seven members of the Zhang Yi household—a noble family of Zhao during the Han—massacred by Chu soldiers on this mountain. Woodcutters had once discovered their corpses, failing to recognize them, and buried them together behind the mountain’s spirit shrine in a secluded spot where no one trod. Thus, they became spectral beings. On a day of celestial amnesty, they had consumed dew from the Jade Pool of the Jasper Lake, transforming into ferocious tigers that craved human flesh and blood.

When the Daoist requested the prefectural officials to witness his exorcism, Prefect Li Xiangyun and Vice Censor Shao Tang, along with soldiers, proceeded to the slopes of Heng Mountain. The Daoist ventured alone into the wilderness. Suddenly, the sky darkened, and windswept mist rose. Through the clouds, Pei the Daoist appeared, hair unbound and sword in hand, calling out: "Li Xiangyun and the others, do not fear. I have already driven out the seven demonic tigers." The officials prostrated themselves, recognizing him as the True Warrior (Zhenwu), who had once descended into the Pei household during the reign of Empress Wu of Tang, leaving behind this surname. The seven tigers, as if bound by ropes, coiled on the ground, roaring several times before perishing. Then, seven figures appeared in the air, bowing and leaping to address the officials: "We are the Zhang Yi household of the Han, slaughtered by Chu soldiers and long transformed into malevolent beasts, harming countless lives. We deserved annihilation. Now, by the grace of the True Warrior, our sins of devouring lives as tigers have been absolved by celestial pardon. We leave these tiger pelts as offerings to the officials. By imperial mercy, we have been dispatched to the Eastern Peak to await judgment and rebirth." With that, Pei the Daoist vanished into the clouds.

The hunters were ordered to skin the tigers and present the pelts to the authorities. The Fenzhou prefectural and circuit offices memorialized the throne, and by imperial decree from the Chancellery, a True Warrior shrine was established on Heng Mountain. Three Daoist priests were selected to maintain the rites, with the prefecture providing monthly stipends of money and grain to ensure the site’s perpetual guardianship and unbroken incense offerings. A stele was also erected to record the event.

**Testing Magic Before the Court**
During the reign of Empress Wu of Tang, He Quanlong, the Palace Attendant and Military Observer of Nan’an, trained five hundred young boys in the heretical arts of the Fox Woman, claiming they were possessed by the Seven Celestial Spirits of the North and could be commanded at will. He repeatedly demonstrated their powers before the court, summoning clouds, hail, and gales through their incantations. Empress Wu favored him, and many officials fell from grace due to his slanderous accusations.

When the Western Rong tribes rebelled under Zhao Hong’s leadership, their armies clashed with imperial forces. Dark clouds would gather above the battlefield, unleashing fire and lightning, or manifesting dragons, tigers, and grotesque apparitions to scatter the troops. Officials petitioned Empress Wu to employ the celestial arts of the Heavenly Principle School to counter Zhao Hong. She granted He Quanlong a seal of command and dispatched him with two thousand soldiers. However, in the ensuing battle, all two thousand imperial troops and five hundred of He’s sorcerer-boys were wounded, many maimed.

He Quanlong returned to plead for clemency, which the Empress granted. Soon after, Zhao Hong’s forces advanced further. Deeply troubled, Empress Wu was approached by the Vice Director of the Chancellery, Pei Tao, who petitioned: "Your subject has a son, Zhongfang, aged sixteen. Since the age of three, he has spoken in perfect prose, and at nine, he was visited by a celestial being who taught him archery and horsemanship. I humbly offer my entire household as surety and request to lead five hundred foot soldiers to exterminate the rebel Zhao Hong." The Empress interrogated Zhongfang, then appointed him as a Sacrificial Official of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices and temporarily granted him the rank of Gentleman of the Palace Treasury. She entrusted him with command of the troops.

Zhongfang marched directly to Zhao Hong’s encampment. With a mere flash of his sword, he quelled thousands of enemy soldiers and captured Zhao Hong alive. Without slaughtering a single soul, he brought the rebel leader back to the capital and reported: "Zhao Hong’s demonic defenses have been broken by a minor display of my arts. The culprit now stands before Your Majesty."

Empress Wu dismissed her attendants and addressed Zhongfang: "It is revealed that you are the Northern Dipper’s True Warrior, incarnated in mortal form to manifest your divinity. I wonder, how effective were the Seven Celestial Arts employed by He Quanlong before the court?" Zhongfang replied: "He Quanlong trained his boys in the heterodox Fox Woman sorcery, inscribing their soles with vermilion talismans to enable them to ascend clouds and summon hail. Yet his powers pale beside Zhao Hong’s. His favor with the throne has led to the unjust demotion of loyal ministers. If left unchecked, this will fester into outright treason. I propose that He Quanlong and I demonstrate our arts before the court to dispel Your Majesty’s doubts."

The Empress promptly ordered He Quanlong and Pei Zhongfang to perform their magic on the palace steps. He Quanlong commanded his five hundred sorcerer-boys to charge forward in a frenzied display, leaving the assembled civil and military officials in awe.

chunks.original_text: 然后，仲方用净水一喷，其妖童五百，於空中敛迹，皆擂入仲方随身剑鞘内。 全龙无所措手，於殿前叫云：告留全龙残喘。 则天急起焚香，语仲方曰：念全龙是国母之亲幸，免杀戮。 仲方遂放贺全龙一命，其五百妖童，於剑鞘中发真火，焚为灰烬。 仲方奏告，所有前后黜责臣僚，仍旧复官。 特赐仲方神应将军，所收赵弘等，仲方亦奏请放还西域。 聚厅禁妖 太平兴国四年，武安军节度使尚书左仆射石光嗣，移镇洪州，因闻本地性好邪法妖术，虽曾禁约，终不能绝。 切知侠道山祖圣观，有持法戒洁之士，请到罗浮洞法师凌居．邈来问，因知洪衡潭鼎鄂一带供养者，尽是南神。 分差官员，搜捉到习左道邪术，马用成等一百十六人，当厅聚官取问。 据马用成执覆，本非齐学左道，因为江南荆湖地水接连，蛮貊常被七十二候伤魂神杀，行热疫，令人作事淹滞不利，惟信左道法术，施刀刃油火金刚法事驱镇，稍愈。 石光嗣令逐人资出行卫刀棒油铛火熬等物，并行毁，纳责状疏放。 至当年七月，洪州果有伤魂为祸，居民皆患狂热，食瓦屑磁石之类，或缘悬屋梁，或上挂林木，或赴水入沟，口称秽言。 光嗣召法师凌居邈，普施符水，救治患人，尽皆较损。 又虑后来狂患再作，乃镂板印真武灵应圣号牌子一万余道，偯散与人供养，遇每月下降日，诵《真武妙经》。 积有岁月，竟绝其灾。 从此，去邪归正。

Then Zhongfang sprayed a mist of pure water, and the five hundred sorcerer-boys vanished from the air, all drawn into the scabbard at his side. Quanlong, left helpless, cried out before the throne: "Spare me, that I may draw one last breath!" The Empress swiftly rose to burn incense and said to Zhongfang: "Out of consideration for Quanlong’s favor with the Queen Mother, spare his life." Zhongfang thereupon released He Quanlong, but the five hundred sorcerer-boys, trapped within the scabbard, were consumed by true fire and reduced to ashes. Zhongfang memorialized the throne, requesting that all officials previously demoted or punished be restored to their posts. He was specially appointed General of Divine Response, and those such as Zhao Hong whom he had captured were also petitioned for release and sent back to the Western Regions.

**Suppressing Sorcery in the Prefecture**
In the fourth year of Taiping Xingguo, Shi Guangsi, Military Commissioner of Wu’an and Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs, was transferred to Hongzhou. Having heard that the region was rife with heterodox arts and sorcery, which persisted despite repeated prohibitions, he learned of a master of the precepts and pure discipline at Xiadao Mountain’s Ancestral Sage Abbey. He invited Master Ling Jumiao of Luofu Grotto to consult on the matter and discovered that the worshippers along the Hong, Heng, Tan, Ding, and E river basins all venerated southern spirits. Officials were dispatched to arrest 116 practitioners of left-handed sorcery, including Ma Yongcheng, who were brought before the assembly for interrogation. Ma Yongcheng pleaded in his defense that he had not originally studied left-handed arts, but because the lands of Jiangnan, Jinghu, and the surrounding waters were plagued by the seventy-two seasonal spirits that harmed souls, spread febrile epidemics, and obstructed all undertakings, he had resorted to left-handed arts—performing rituals of blades, oil, fire, and *vajra* rites—to suppress the afflictions, which brought slight relief. Guangsi ordered that all implements—blades, staffs, oil cauldrons, and fire-woks—be confiscated and destroyed, and the offenders were reprimanded and released after submitting written confessions.

By the seventh month of that year, Hongzhou was indeed struck by a soul-harming calamity. The populace suffered from raging fevers, consuming shards of tile and porcelain, or climbing to hang from roof beams, clinging to trees, or plunging into water and ditches, all while uttering foul words. Guangsi summoned Master Ling Jumiao, who distributed talismanic water to heal the afflicted, and the suffering gradually abated. Fearing future outbreaks, he had over ten thousand plaques inscribed with the sacred title of Zhenwu, the Numinous and Responsive, and distributed them for veneration. On the days of the deity’s monthly descent, the *Mysterious Scripture of Zhenwu* was recited. Over time, the disaster was entirely eradicated, and the people turned from heresy to the true Way.

chunks.original_text: 石光嗣申奏：洪州自南唐以前，虽有宫观，而真武殿宇香火，至今未有。 三司礼部详定，合下洪州，於天庆观旧来真武殿去处，专委守臣，如法盖造。 仍赐御书殿牌，以护国感应为额。 石光嗣后往侠道山，谒法师凌居邈，受持真武法式。 遂求致政归赵州治，幽居简尘，崇奉真圣香火，寿至九十九岁，无疾而终。 妖惑柴邈 眉州防御使柴逊，有弟柴邈，年三十一岁，为右侍，禁婚娶。 涤王宅观察女，夫妇不睦，别置寝房。 其柴邈，忽得患廷赢，医卜皆云邪气入心。 才见妻入房供应汤药，便生．憎怨。 偶一夜，兄逊潜往看观，闻邈房内，似有妇人笑语之声，遂令家人守候，天明入邈房，开帐看，俱无形影，情知弟邈，显被妖孽迷惑。 再三询问，然后云：二年前，到圣水观，为见西廊有梁昭王堂殿，壁上画执笛神女一人，容格媚态，曾用手摸其面手，笑谓同行人曰：待寻求惫地一人为偏室。 此亦作戏，何期此夜来谓邈曰：你与我手眼来去为定。 因兹，契合一处。

Stone Guangsi memorialized: "In Hongzhou, though Daoist temples and abbeys existed before the Southern Tang, no halls or incense offerings had yet been dedicated to Zhenwu. The Three Departments and the Ministry of Rites deliberated and determined that Hongzhou should be instructed to construct a proper hall at the former site of the Zhenwu shrine within Tianqing Abbey. chunks.original_text: 至今，每夜二更初来，五更初去。 见有此人襕带上香囊一个表照。 将出验认，委是异物，亲属收之。 继来圣水观梁昭王堂，寻见其壁，委有执笛彩女，容貌绝色，栏抹一角，彩画消落，寻将上件香囊辏依，缝脉相合。 柴逊具析情由，从登闻鼓院，经由中书，得达圣聪，奉圣旨，送开封府施行。 蒙府司行牒下圣水观，令烧与本观土地，驱遣其祟，为患如故。 再行请到都道录钱君平，用法造符录文牒，并金钱云马，同龙图阁学士知开封府包拯，亲至圣水观，祷告真武，将符牒望北烧之。 当夜，柴邈房中不闻有人语笑声。 经半月，其圣水观，每二更时，人闻西角，如牢狱行杖拷囚，有妇人声叫，彻响于外。 忽夜於柴逊门首大哭，而唤柴邈言：被尔误我一身，因真武受词，搜捉我去勘问，送京都土地，经半月凌拷，吃尽无限痛楚。 今蒙真武慈悲，兔我铁杖之罪，押往阴山，为无辜女鬼，三百劫限满，却还阳间，神中受生。 今来报尔知委。 柴邈从此平复。 府尹包拯具述，面奉圣旨，宣柴邈，引见据奏：臣愿受差遣，积蓄俸料，普设罗天大醮，上酬真宰。 除依奏外，赐玉津园内，修建法醮，普设大斋，答谢真武护国救民之恩。 魅缠安仁 复州观察使孙渐，有男安仁，年十七，赐三班借职，授凤州龙门镇监税兼巡检。 到任半年，形神昏耗，语言颠错，公务乖疏，致被州府差官替罢。 寻医归家，其患不退。 父渐夜闻安仁房内，妇人言笑不已，方知是妖怪魅惑。 明早，敦逼询问，不兔说出。 安仁被凤州龙门镇侯家山土地湘花女相缠，每至三更时即来，直候日出时，化为尘影潜藏。 父渐闻此，面奏御前，奉宣差翰林书禁全科师巫，行持法事，凡经半月，不能驱除。 再入奏进，还其科，遂至宰执公卿奏议，孙渐家庭不曾供养镇宅神祇，却有他州山邪为祸。 当发心，速往道观中，求恳真武救护。 孙渐依察圣旨，亲自写疏，诣四圣观，许愿虔恳，仍借真武圣帧，归家供养。 将满七日，一夜更初，祇闻安仁房内，双声动泣。 至晓，安仁如大醉方苏，言语全不颠错。 安仁称：自赴龙门任，巡辖马铺，夜宿侯家山驿。 是夜三更，不觉外林前灯火再明，帐前见一美女，冠衣异俗敛袂低声云：奴非鬼怪，不须惊怕，与安仁是宿缘，合注定於此相候。 奴是湘浦龙君之女，因为思凡，蒙东岳降谪为管山土地，人皆呼为湘花神女，有半仙之分。 从此相慕，岂忍相拆。 今来，为君父母请到真武降宅，有无限天丁力士，日游神道，随从舍宅搜检，奴若遭检录，必受铁杖驱断，永罚为下鬼，不能得处尘寰，从此弃别，归侯家山。 临行洒泪，就髻取下碌玉小梳一只，令安仁藏於发髻，候奴再会，欲此照证。 寻令取看，委非凡物。 乃赍玉梳呈奏，赐入内库神器局收掌。 又奏，愿就于四圣观设罗天大醮，并设大斋报恩。 宰执等谓孙渐曰：当时未信，今乃果应，委知供养真武之家，灵应不可思议。 陆传招诬 朝奉郎尚书司勋员外郎，差充广东提刑裴宗元，因经韶州花兰山，得患如店疾，夜无停睡，言语失次。 将理医药，莫测其疾。 有一官员云：向闻提刑到花兰山来，窃知此处，并是屈死冤魂滞魄结聚於此山，铁风洞五道判官拘管，在彼不少。

To this day, she would arrive at the second watch of the night and depart at the fifth. She wore upon her robe a fragrant pouch, its surface shimmering. When brought forth for examination, it proved to be no ordinary object, and the family kept it. Later, they returned to the Hall of King Liang Zhao at Shengshui Abbey, where upon the wall they found the painted figure of the flute-playing maiden—her beauty unmatched—with one corner of the railing smudged and the colors faded. When the fragrant pouch was held against it, the seams aligned perfectly.

Chai Xun laid out the circumstances in full, submitting his case through the Drum of Direct Appeal. It passed through the Secretariat and reached the imperial ear. By imperial decree, the matter was referred to the Kaifeng Prefecture for action. The prefectural authorities dispatched an official document to Shengshui Abbey, ordering the local earth god to burn the pouch and expel the malevolent spirit, yet the affliction persisted. Another petition was made, and the Daoist Registrar Qian Junping was summoned. He prepared talismans and ritual documents, along with paper money and horses of gold foil. Together with Bao Zheng, Academician of the Dragon Diagram Pavilion and Prefect of Kaifeng, they journeyed to Shengshui Abbey. There, they prayed to Zhenwu and burned the talismans and documents toward the north.

That very night, no laughter or voices were heard in Chai Miao’s chamber. Half a month later, at Shengshui Abbey, every night at the second watch, sounds of flogging and interrogation—like those of a prison—echoed from the western corner, along with the cries of a woman. Suddenly, one night, she wailed outside Chai Xun’s gate, calling out to Chai Miao: *"You have ruined me! Because Zhenwu accepted your complaint, I was seized and interrogated. Sent to the earth god of the capital, I endured half a month of brutal torture, suffering endless agony. Now, by Zhenwu’s mercy, I am spared the punishment of the iron rod and banished to Mount Yin, to serve as an innocent female ghost for three hundred kalpas before returning to the world of the living to be reborn among the spirits. I have come to tell you this."*

From then on, Chai Miao recovered. Prefect Bao Zheng reported the matter in full and presented it to the throne. Chai Miao was summoned and, upon audience, petitioned: *"I humbly request an assignment to accumulate my salary and hold a grand *luotian* ritual, offering it to the Supreme Divinity in repayment."* The emperor approved, granting the Jade Ford Garden for the construction of a ritual altar and the holding of a grand vegetarian feast to give thanks for Zhenwu’s protection of the state and salvation of the people.

**The Bewitchment of Anren**
Sun Jian, Observator of Fuzhou, had a son named Anren, aged seventeen. Granted the title of *Sanban Jiezhi* and appointed Tax Supervisor and Patrol Inspector of Longmen Town in Fengzhou, he took up his post. After half a year, his spirit waned, his speech became erratic, and his duties neglected, leading the prefecture to dispatch an official to replace him. Seeking medical treatment at home, his condition did not improve.

One night, Sun Jian heard women’s laughter and conversation in Anren’s chamber and realized he was bewitched by a malevolent spirit. The next morning, he pressed his son for answers, who at last confessed: *"The earth goddess Xianghua of Mount Hou in Longmen Town has been entangling me. She comes every night at the third watch and remains until sunrise, when she vanishes like dust."*

Sun Jian presented the matter at court. By imperial decree, a master of the Hanlin Academy’s Exorcism Bureau was dispatched to perform rituals, but after half a month, the spirit remained. Another memorial was submitted, and the matter was referred to the chief ministers. They deliberated that Sun Jian’s household had not properly worshipped the protective deities of the home, allowing a mountain spirit from another region to bring misfortune. He was advised to hasten to a Daoist abbey and earnestly beseech Zhenwu for protection.

Following the imperial suggestion, Sun Jian personally wrote a petition and journeyed to the Abbey of the Four Saints, where he made a vow and borrowed a sacred portrait of Zhenwu to enshrine at home. On the seventh night, as the first watch began, sounds of weeping were heard from Anren’s chamber. By dawn, Anren awoke as if from a deep intoxication, his speech no longer erratic.

Anren recounted: *"Upon arriving at my post in Longmen, I was patrolling the horse stations and spent a night at the post station on Mount Hou. At the third watch, I suddenly saw lanterns glowing before the outer woods. Before my tent appeared a beautiful woman, her attire and manner unlike any mortal. Lowering her sleeves, she spoke softly: ‘I am no ghost or demon—do not fear. Our bond was fated long ago, and here we were destined to meet. I am the daughter of the Dragon Lord of Xiangpu, but for my longing for the mortal world, the Eastern Peak demoted me to serve as the earth goddess of this mountain. People call me the Xianghua Goddess, for I possess the essence of a half-immortal. How could I bear to part from you?’

‘Now, because your parents have invited Zhenwu to descend upon your home, countless celestial soldiers and day-patrolling spirits have surrounded the house to search for me. If I am seized, I will be beaten with iron rods and condemned to the lowest ranks of ghosts, forever barred from the mortal world. Thus, I must take my leave and return to Mount Hou.’ With tears, she took a small jade comb from her hair and gave it to me, saying, ‘Hide this in your hair. When we meet again, it will serve as proof.’"*

When examined, the comb was no ordinary object. It was presented to the throne and placed in the Divine Instruments Bureau of the Inner Treasury. Sun Jian further petitioned to hold a grand *luotian* ritual and a grand vegetarian feast at the Abbey of the Four Saints to repay the debt of gratitude. The chief ministers said to him: *"At first, we did not believe, but now the truth is manifest. Truly, households that worship Zhenwu receive responses beyond all imagining."*

**The False Accusation of Lu Chuan**
Pei Zongyuan, Gentleman for Court Service and Vice Director of the Ministry of Merit, was dispatched as Judicial Commissioner of Guangdong. While passing through Mount Hualan in Shaozhou, he fell ill as if afflicted by a miasma. He could not sleep at night, and his speech became disordered. Despite medical treatment, the cause of his illness remained unknown.

An official remarked: *"I have heard that when Your Excellency arrived at Mount Hualan, it was known that this place is haunted by the lingering souls of those who died unjustly, their spirits bound to this mountain. The Fivefold Dao Magistrate of Iron Wind Cave oversees them in great numbers..."*

There was, however, a divine practitioner named Du Guli from the city below, skilled in ritual and healing. He was summoned without delay. No sooner had Du Guli entered the second gate of the Judicial Commissioner’s office than he declared: *“I see an official in green robes, his face twisted with grievance and injustice, clinging to the Commissioner’s life.”*

The assembled officials asked: *“What deity is this?”*

Du Guli explained: *“I was once a scholar, but the True Lord Zhenwu, taking pity on my humble station and my devotion to the Dao, transformed me into a wandering physician. He anointed my eyes with medicine and bestowed upon me a scroll of exorcistic arts. Since then, my remedies have never failed to heal. I set up an altar with fragrant flowers, pure water, and incense to honor Zhenwu, establishing a ritual precinct. I used a bolt of yellow silk twelve feet long, inscribed with cinnabar the talismans of Shangqing, and burned them facing north while reciting invocations. I arranged ritual swords, hung the talismans of the Five Directions and the Six Ding spirits, girded myself with the sash of the altar’s straightway, and prepared forty-nine earthen vessels and forty-nine lamps. I consecrated the brush and ink of the Judicial Commissioner’s scribe, recited the *Willow Sprig* and *Pure Water* incantations, and invoked Zhenwu to descend in spirit. I commanded the attendant talisman-spirits to bear my petition upward and report to Heaven.”*

Once the ritual was complete, he instructed the Commissioner’s household: *“If Zhenwu descends, do not be alarmed.”*

On the third invocation, the deity suddenly manifested. From within, a maidservant was seized and brought before Zhenwu’s altar. Through her, the spirit spoke: *“I am Lu Fu, Judicial Officer of Dezhou. Commissioner Pei Zongyuan was once the Prefectural Judge of my district. Due to a feud with my late father, the Assistant Minister, he conspired with his subordinates to exact vengeance. Under false pretenses, they accused me of administering improper medicine on an imperial mourning day, imprisoned me, and tortured me without cause until I confessed to treason. I died under duress, my grievance unredressed. As my allotted lifespan was not yet spent, I was consigned to Iron Wind Cave on Mount Hualan for custody. I had no means to plead my case—until Pei Zongyuan passed through this mountain and encountered my wronged soul, which has clung to him ever since. Only because his fortune and lifespan remain vigorous have I not yet taken his life. Now that Zhenwu, the Fortune God, has descended to your residence to expel this malevolent affliction, I beg you to take pity on my unjust death. Do not send me back to Iron Wind Cave. Let me be cleansed with ritual water and receive Zhenwu’s decree. I shall face east and pay homage to my original master, the Most High Lord Lao, the Celestial Master of the Golden Portal. Thereafter, I shall be reborn into a prosperous family as a son, and I shall also serve in office. A talisman-spirit will be dispatched to Iron Wind Cave on Mount Hualan to strike my name from the register of wrongful dead, so that no further confrontations may occur.”*

The moment the maidservant was released, Pei Zongyuan immediately recovered. He then took gold, silver, and other valuables from his household and traveled to Tianqing Abbey in Guangzhou, where he sponsored seven days and nights of repentance rites and thanksgiving offerings. He also provided for the abbey’s Daoist priests and rewarded Du Guli. A memorial was submitted to the throne, and an imperial edict soon followed, appointing Du Guli as Assistant Instructor of his home prefecture. Pei Zongyuan, from that time forward, maintained the worship of Zhenwu without fail for the rest of his life.

Wang Hu fell into the scheme.

chunks.original_text: 约是酉时，见姚孜披发，从卧房大叫一声，奔走出来，香案下跪膝通传云：本舒州桐城县主簿王虎，庆历初年，姚孜为太湖令，因受差，同往大云仓，般量上供米麦。 姚孜却受专监金银，计嘱虚抬，欠折正数小麦八十石。 时王虎不知，柢随情於赤历日，同签押，申本州并转运司讫。 后来，姚孜先知事发，从太湖差人来送书，并人事黑漆琴光铁崇六只，遂问来人索书，却称渡江遭浪损坏，及将信物看验，委是水浸浪迩。 其书浸坏，不任开览。 来人告覆，且留下崇子，客急回太湖，别换书来，请领回文。 虎不知是计，从此留下。 自后，不见换书人到，蓦被寿州勘院准动，前来追摄，入狱鞠勘，与姚孜等对认。 同情受过大云仓般量专监金银，遂往王虎家，取到姚孜人事崇子六只，洗刷辨认，一只是金，五只是银。 王虎在狱，方知阴中姚孜之计，无由分辨，因而气塞冲心，不明身死，被姚孜推逃，亡王虎承当，却全出姚孜，罪犯阳间。 秪谓王虎身亡，照证无凭。 奈为东岳阴府禄寿簿上不注，王虎枉死，不当收管，柢在尘劫，无由解脱。 三年前，於埘州夹岸，遇见冤家姚孜，相缠至今，须要同往束岳执对。 幸遇真武今日下降，已荷授记，为虎解脱冤魂，得与姚孜相离。 蒙给赐照证文字，往阴府注生，从今更无俨执。 姚孜良久苏醒，延年等具奏朝廷，姚孜遂罢官，归湖州，舍钱二千贯，入舒州灵仙观，添盖真武阁。 陈妻附魂 淳化二年六月二十一日，束头供奉官阁门柢侯秦中立，受差秦凤路提点军器。 秦中立一生侍奉真武不违，寅夕香火。 中立既受差遣，将绢彩画真武，帧轴随身，到京兆府参见。 判府陈俨言：有子景仁，见年二十四岁，曾婚张氏。 方一年，张氏染疗疾死； 景仁传染其患，时似颠狂，或喜或悲，自歌自语。 有时，闻得与其妻往来房内，鬼哭神言，敲打惊响。 遍求医禁，略无效验。

At approximately the hour of *you* (5–7 p.m.), Yao Zi was seen with disheveled hair, bursting from his bedchamber with a great cry and rushing out. He knelt beneath the incense altar and transmitted in a spirit-possessed voice:

"I am Wang Hu, formerly Registrar of Tongcheng County in Shuzhou. In the early years of the Qingli reign, Yao Zi served as Magistrate of Taihu. While on official duty, we were both dispatched to Dayun Granary to supervise the weighing of tribute grain. Yao Zi, however, was solely responsible for overseeing the silver and gold. He colluded to falsify the records, shortchanging the official tally of wheat by eighty *shi*. At the time, unaware of his scheme, I merely followed procedure, countersigning the vermilion registers and submitting them to the prefectural and transport authorities.

Later, Yao Zi learned the matter had been exposed. He sent a messenger from Taihu bearing a letter and gifts—six black-lacquered, gilt-iron *chong* vessels. When I asked for the letter, the messenger claimed it had been ruined by waves while crossing the river. Upon inspecting the gifts, I saw they were indeed water-damaged and salt-encrusted. The letter was soaked beyond legibility. The messenger pleaded for me to keep the vessels temporarily while he hurried back to Taihu to fetch a replacement, promising to return with a reply. Unsuspecting, I agreed.

Afterward, no replacement messenger arrived. Suddenly, the Shouzhou Investigation Bureau issued a summons, and I was arrested, imprisoned, and interrogated alongside Yao Zi. We were both charged with colluding to embezzle gold and silver from Dayun Granary. Officials then went to my home and retrieved the six *chong* vessels Yao Zi had sent. After washing and examining them, they found one to be gold and five silver.

Only then did I realize I had been ensnared by Yao Zi’s scheme. With no means to defend myself, I was overwhelmed by rage, which struck my heart. I died in obscurity, and Yao Zi shifted the blame entirely onto me, escaping punishment in the mortal realm. They claimed I had died, leaving no evidence. Yet in the registers of the Eastern Peak’s netherworld, my lifespan was unmarked—I had died wrongfully and was not fated to be taken. Thus, I remained bound in the dusty kalpa, with no way to escape.

Three years ago, I encountered my enemy Yao Zi on the banks of the river in Shuzhou. We have been entangled ever since, and I demanded he accompany me to the Eastern Peak to confront the matter. Fortunately, Zhenwu has descended today. I have received his decree, which will liberate my wronged soul and sever my ties with Yao Zi. By his grace, I am granted documentary proof to register my rebirth in the netherworld. From now on, there will be no further disputes."

After a long while, Yao Zi regained consciousness. Yan Nian and others reported the matter to the throne. Yao Zi was subsequently dismissed from office and returned to Huzhou, where he donated two thousand strings of cash to Shuzhou’s Lingxian Abbey to expand the Zhenwu Pavilion.

---

**Chen’s Wife Attaches Her Spirit**
On the twenty-first day of the sixth month in the second year of the Chunhua reign, Qin Zhongli, a Court Gentleman for Ceremonial Service and Gatekeeper of the Watch, was dispatched to oversee military equipment in the Qin-Feng Circuit. Zhongli had served Zhenwu faithfully all his life, maintaining morning and evening incense offerings without fail.

Upon receiving his commission, he carried with him a silk scroll painting of Zhenwu. Arriving in Jingzhao Prefecture, he paid his respects to the prefect, Chen Yan, who said:

"I have a son, Jingren, now twenty-four years old. He was married to a woman of the Zhang clan, but after just one year, she died of consumption. Jingren contracted the same illness. At times, he seems deranged—laughing or weeping, singing or muttering to himself. Occasionally, he claims his wife is with him in the chamber, their voices mingling with ghostly wails and spectral speech, accompanied by eerie knocks and crashes. We have sought physicians and exorcists, but to no avail."

chunks.original_text: 中立曰：今且归驿，当为斋心，明晨来看。 中立夜就馆驿，焚香，挂随身真武供养，先具诚恳奏知。 次日天明，中立遂亲手擎帧，步趋入府堂，将真武帧像，就陈景仁房室前，净设供养，令陈俨合家虔诚捻香祈祷。 然后，中立手携香炉，入房看观，问景仁年几生月，受病时日，因依，录奏状一通。 当日，於真武前，用符吏纸马烧奏。 至第四日，中立在绾舍内，夜至四更，闻人叩门云：念奴是京城故侍郎张升孙女，因嫁陈景仁为妻、未满一年，染却劳气，沉顿着林，被医人将作血隔调理，误投汤药，枉坏性命。 因此，孤魂不收，游扬尘中－日夜衔冤。 忽因景仁前三月间，出城游猎，得与附托魂魄在身，免在荒野，遭界分土地驱逐。 今阁使带真武入宅，对定景仁房供养，奴被圣威逼逐，无处港藏。 蒙真武慈德，差使丁神搜奴魂魄，面见尊神，悯奴冤枉，赐以杨枝净水洗涤身魂，仍得授记，解释冤债，更不历转阴司。 今得托生，鼎来罗宗傅太尉家，依前为女身，特来报谢而去。 中立逐一记录，往见陈俨，其陈景仁遂已痊复如故。 陈俨，其陈景仁遂已痊复如故。 陈俨表奏事因，甘退三资本职，并男景仁覃恩诰动，保明举转秦中立出官，除授东上阁门使雄州防御使，及男景仁，本授太庙室长，并不追降。 陈俨施财五千贯，盖造上清紫极宫真武立身功德殿。 奏请劫额，续奉圣旨，特赐通灵普慈之殿为额。 王氏怀鬼 舒州金部员外郎王尧年，有女年三十一岁，肚怀鬼胎二年求医，皆莫能治。 不惟父母忧虑，其女常自疑惑，欲往后园自缢，空中闻人叫云：不得乱弃性命，是汝五百年宿债，何不去告宅神。 女子回顾，又无一人，遂归家说与母。 所谓宅神者，本家柢有真武，别无圣像。 乃请灵仙观法师陈居巽，就家堂结持坛戒，遣发符使，特诣天曹，恳求圣降，愿为王氏消除宿业，免其胎腹。 合家虔诚，守候法师报应。 时十月二十一日午时，忽有碗口大小红光晕，遍散屋外，盘旋坛前，遂降附王氏，而言、．前生曾与药婆货毒药，与人打取胎孕，内有贵命寄胎，遭其所毒，又复沉坠，卒无出期。 此罪当永劫罚为恒沙毒蛇。 汝缘有此一世人身，又遇负杀冤家在於腹中，饮食血肉，胀塞心胸，欲害其命。 因后园取死之际，遇吾队仗。 今有香火感吾下降，吾当为汝永除此冤，更无执对。 於今夜二更一点，就汝外林前，地点轮灯，七七四十九碗，替代一身，用名香净水纸马供养。 至四更尽，就彼呼女子小字，年月日时，连替代金纸，烧与前生冤魂，其胎不过月日，自然消散。 居巽礼谢，红光渐散，乃知真武回驭。 尧年烧奏了毕，立下疏契，候女子胎患消散，愿将此宅并后园，舍为真武降圣行宫。 其女果应月日平安。 於外，有人传播王金部女子遇真武救济，其身必贵。 尧年见授襄州通判，迁改新宅。 才办承舒州太守谢方平，为次男景祥议亲，遂纳礼成结。 尧年面将宅并园，兴盖殿宇，计会舒州及监司等处，保奏朝廷，颁赐名额。 准中书剖子，取问王尧年，所舍园宅为宫，一力难圆，又奉圣旨，国为添造三清宝殿，并北极七元殿。 仍赐降真慈救观为额。 玄天上帝启圣录卷之五竟 玄天上帝启圣录卷之六

Zhongli replied, "For now, return to the post station. I shall purify my heart, and come to examine the case tomorrow morning."

That night, Zhongli took lodging at the post station. He lit incense and hung the silk scroll painting of Zhenwu he had brought with him, first offering sincere prayers. At dawn the next day, Zhongli personally carried the scroll, hastening on foot to the prefectural hall. He set up the painting of Zhenwu before Jingren’s chamber, arranging pure offerings, and instructed Prefect Chen and his entire household to devoutly hold incense and pray. Then, Zhongli entered the room with an incense burner in hand to observe Jingren. He asked about Jingren’s birth year and month, the duration of his illness, and recorded the details in a memorial. That same day, before the image of Zhenwu, he burned talismans, spirit-money, and paper horses as an offering.

On the fourth day, while Zhongli was in his quarters, at the fourth watch of the night, he heard someone knocking at the door. A voice said: "I am Niannu, the granddaughter of the late Vice Minister Zhang Sheng of the capital. I married Chen Jingren, but before a year had passed, I contracted consumption and grew gravely ill. The physician mistook my condition for blood stasis and prescribed the wrong medicine, which wrongfully took my life. Thus, my lonely soul remained ungathered, drifting in the mortal realm—day and night bearing this grievance. Three months ago, Jingren went hunting outside the city, and I was able to attach my spirit to his body, sparing myself from wandering the wilds and being driven away by the local earth deities. Now, with the arrival of Your Honor bearing Zhenwu into this residence and setting up offerings before Jingren’s chamber, I have been pressed by the divine might and have no place to hide. By the mercy and virtue of Zhenwu, his envoys seized my soul and brought me before the august deity. Moved by my grievance, he granted me willow-branch purifying water to cleanse my spirit and bestowed a prophecy, absolving my karmic debt so that I need not pass through the courts of the underworld. Now, I am to be reborn in the household of Marshal Luo Zongfu, once more as a woman. I have come to express my gratitude before departing."

Zhongli recorded every word and went to inform Prefect Chen. Jingren had already recovered as if nothing had ever ailed him. Chen, deeply moved, submitted a memorial detailing the events. He willingly relinquished three ranks of his official position, and both he and his son Jingren were granted imperial grace to retain their titles. Chen further recommended Zhongli for promotion, who was then appointed East Upper Gate Attendant and Defense Commissioner of Xiongzhou. Jingren, originally appointed as an attendant of the Imperial Ancestral Temple, was not demoted. Chen donated five thousand strings of cash to construct the Hall of Zhenwu’s Manifest Merit within the Supreme Clarity Purple Ultimate Palace. He petitioned for an inscribed plaque, and by imperial decree, it was bestowed the name "Hall of Universal Compassion and Divine Response."

---

**The Ghostly Fetus of the Wang Clan**

Wang Yaonian, Gold Department Staff Supervisor of Shuzhou, had a daughter aged thirty-one who had carried a ghostly fetus for two years. Despite seeking physicians, none could cure her. Not only were her parents deeply worried, but the daughter herself was constantly distressed, even attempting to hang herself in the rear garden. Suddenly, she heard a voice from the air calling out: "Do not recklessly cast away your life. This is your five-hundred-year-old karmic debt. Why not appeal to the household deity?"

The girl looked around, but saw no one. Returning home, she told her mother. The so-called household deity was Zhenwu, though the family had no sacred image of him. They then invited Master Chen Juxun, a Daoist priest from the Lingxian Abbey, to set up a ritual altar in their home. He dispatched talismanic envoys to the celestial courts, beseeching divine descent to absolve Wang’s past karma and relieve her of the ghostly fetus. The entire household waited devoutly for the priest’s response.

On the twenty-first day of the tenth month, at noon, a red glow the size of a rice bowl suddenly filled the house, swirling before the altar. It descended upon the daughter, who spoke: "In a past life, I sold poison to an old medicine woman, who used it to induce abortions. Among those harmed was a noble life, which I destroyed, leaving it with no hope of rebirth. For this sin, I was condemned to be endlessly reborn as a venomous serpent. This lifetime, you encountered this vengeful spirit in your womb, which fed on your blood and flesh, swelling your chest and threatening your life. When you sought death in the rear garden, you encountered my retinue. Now, moved by your family’s devotion, I have descended. I shall permanently remove this grievance, and there will be no further reckoning. Tonight, at the first quarter of the second watch, set out forty-nine lamps in a circle on the ground before the outer grove. Offer fine incense, purifying water, spirit-money, and paper horses as substitutes for your body. At the end of the fourth watch, call out your childhood name, birth year, month, day, and hour, and burn the substitute gold paper for the vengeful spirit of your past life. The fetus will naturally dissipate within days."

Master Chen bowed in gratitude. The red glow gradually dispersed, signaling Zhenwu’s departure. Yaonian burned memorial papers and drew up a vow: once his daughter’s affliction was resolved, he would donate their residence and rear garden to serve as a palace for Zhenwu’s divine descents. Indeed, his daughter’s condition improved within the promised time.

Word spread of how Wang’s daughter had been saved by Zhenwu, and it was said her destiny was now noble. Yaonian was appointed Vice Prefect of Xiangzhou and moved to a new residence. Soon after, Prefect Xie Fangping of Shuzhou, seeking a match for his second son Jingxiang, formally betrothed him to Wang’s daughter.

Yaonian then converted the donated house and garden into a temple complex. Coordinating with local officials and the provincial surveillance commission, he petitioned the court for an inscribed plaque. The Secretariat’s response instructed that as Yaonian’s personal donation was insufficient to complete the project, an imperial decree was issued to construct the Three Pure Ones’ Precious Hall and the Northern Culmen’s Seven Primes Hall. The temple was bestowed the name "Temple of Divine Mercy and Salvation."

chunks.original_text: 奏录延寿 仁宗皇帝於至和二年，染患不豫，据三司礼部，校定到南岳嵩阳观法师王伯初剖子，欲上奏北极，审其寿历，须是遇庚申日，皇帝御札奏章。 於是夜戌时，躬亲析恳於星斗之下。 来早，伯初必知奏章细因。 后至庚申日，皇帝令宫仪副纸笔，代写奏录。 至戌时，露天烧化。 次早，宣问伯初，却云：夜来不曾有奏录到天界，恐皇帝不曾亲札，奏章不专，以致难达天阙。 乃用旧意，至诚御札奏录，於是夜，恳祷烧奏。 次早，伯初· 才宣唤，便称庆贺，臣已见夜来章奏，传到北极中天大帝殿下披阅，见送真武佑圣院保明，更俟七日，终获是验。 伯初亲见奏章，纸共七幅，从头暗念，并无一字异同，圣意喜悦。 至七日，伯初复见，屏退左右，奏皇帝：臣适在牛女宫冲接圣仗，已蒙真武保明仁德，合展圣寿一纪之数。 回至西天门，见葛将军伸重，望皇帝不可忘之。 绿此圣候平复，赐王伯初充在京两街都道录，住持五岳观，赐紫乾元洞神法师。 因而，圣意思慕真武垂恩，显应事边非常，再行催促监当官，疾速建换内庭家堂殿阁。 仍令三司礼部，关报合属去处，搜寻真武事边保奏，检类施行。 所有延寿感应事，兼西天门葛将军，系皇帝留恩之故，今就真武殿右畔，亦盖报恩殿，焚修香火。 施经救灾 南京应天府，有上清鸿福宫，系太祖兴隆建极，报天启圣功德第一处。 兼大中祥符中，真宗束封，曾宿是宫，夜遇北方真武降现，云为官家护驾。 蒙真宗特赐真武立身金相宝阁，及赐御书金字牌。 至和中冬月，军民瘟疫，於鸿福宫兴建道场，未获感应，人皆惶惑。 忽夜真武托梦，与住持道士任亢之云：吾观南京冬疫，宜令印造《太上说真武妙经》，沿门施与患人，供养受持。 任亢之既受圣梦，即以散之，患者并安。 适值朝廷有征南事，抽差兵马，人数无阙。 其留守司参政谏议大夫沈立，具奏朝廷，准中书剖降看详，鸿福宫於前朝，因显圣，建真武宝阁。 自今，此冬疫托梦，令施经，救军民大灾，及得应副南事。 今再赐本阁三年恩泽一道，与道士任亢之，充管香火道童披戴。 及委南京提点，或宫殿损漏，即行修整。 灵功既水
chunks.translated_text:
In the second year of the Zhihe era, Emperor Renzong fell gravely ill. According to the Ministry of Rites’ verification, the memorial submitted by Master Wang Bochu of Songyang Abbey on Mount Song was to be presented to the Northern Culmen. To ascertain the emperor’s lifespan, the petition had to be offered on a *gengshen* day, with the emperor personally inscribing the memorial. That night at the hour of *xu*, the emperor knelt in earnest supplication beneath the stars. The following morning, Bochu would surely know the details of the memorial.

On the appointed *gengshen* day, the emperor ordered palace attendants to prepare paper and brush, transcribing the petition on his behalf. At the hour of *xu*, it was burned under the open sky. The next morning, when Bochu was summoned, he reported: "Last night, no memorial reached the celestial realm. I fear the emperor did not inscribe it himself, and the petition lacked devotion, thus failing to reach the heavenly court." The emperor then redoubled his sincerity, personally inscribing the memorial and burning it that night in solemn prayer.

The next morning, Bochu was summoned and immediately offered congratulations: "I witnessed the memorial from last night, delivered to the court of the Great Emperor of the Northern Culmen in the Central Heaven. Upon review, it was sent to the Divine Protector Zhenwu’s abbey for verification. After seven days, the outcome will be confirmed." Bochu personally saw the memorial—seven sheets in all—and recited it silently from memory, finding not a single discrepancy. The emperor rejoiced.

Seven days later, Bochu again appeared, dismissing all attendants to report: "Just now, at the Oxherd and Weaver constellation, I encountered the imperial procession. The Divine Protector Zhenwu has graciously extended Your Majesty’s lifespan by one *ji* (twelve years). Upon returning to the Western Gate of Heaven, I saw General Ge stretching his arms, reminding Your Majesty not to forget his merit."

Once the emperor’s health was restored, Wang Bochu was appointed Supervisor of the Two Streets in the capital, abbot of the Five Marchmounts Abbey, and bestowed the title "Purple-robed Master of the Divine Dharma of the Qianyuan Grotto." The emperor, deeply moved by Zhenwu’s manifest grace, ordered the supervising officials to swiftly renovate the ancestral halls and pavilions within the palace. He further instructed the Ministry of Rites to compile and disseminate records of Zhenwu’s protective interventions. In gratitude for the extension of his lifespan and General Ge’s intercession, a Hall of Repaying Grace was erected beside the Zhenwu Hall, where incense and prayers were offered.

**Relieving Disasters Through Scripture Distribution**
In the Southern Capital’s Yingtian Prefecture stood the Supreme Clarity Hongfu Abbey, originally established by Emperor Taizu to honor the first merit of heaven’s favor. During the Dazhong Xiangfu era, Emperor Zhenzong, while on a ritual progress, lodged there and witnessed the nocturnal descent of the Northern Zhenwu, who declared himself the emperor’s guardian. Zhenzong later bestowed upon the abbey a golden statue of Zhenwu and an inscribed plaque in his own calligraphy.

In the winter of the Zhihe era, as plague ravaged the military and populace, a ritual was held at Hongfu Abbey, yet no response was felt, causing widespread unease. One night, Zhenwu appeared in a dream to the abbot, Daoist Ren Kangzhi, saying: "I have observed the winter plague in the Southern Capital. Print and distribute the *Sutra of the Supreme’s Exalted Teachings on Zhenwu* to afflicted households, instructing them to venerate and recite it." Ren Kangzhi complied, and the sick recovered.

Coincidentally, the court was then mobilizing troops for a southern campaign, yet no soldiers were lacking. Shen Li, the capital’s Military Commissioner and Remonstrance Grand Master, memorialized the throne. The Secretariat reviewed the matter, noting that Hongfu Abbey’s Zhenwu Hall was built in response to a prior divine manifestation. Now, the winter plague’s resolution—through the dream-inspired distribution of scriptures—had averted a major disaster and supported the southern campaign. The emperor thus granted the abbey a three-year exemption of taxes and bestowed upon Daoist Ren Kangzhi the privilege of overseeing its incense and attendants. The Southern Capital’s inspector was further charged with repairing any damage to the abbey’s halls. Such was the efficacy of divine power.

chunks.original_text: 淮阳军司法陈拱臣，未仕时，收得一龟，其龟壳版青翠，上披金色绿毛，眼红尾长，如小盏大。 养之五七年，至拱臣登第，其龟忽长盆器大，好食枣子。 以竹箩盛之，偶夜月明，家人戏取其龟，却变缩身壳，约如碗，足与一赤斑小蛇蟠绕为戏。 时拱臣思惟，龟蛇二物，所谓天关地轴，属真武福神之下。 至次日，看其龟，如故长大，却不见蛇，数夜如此。 拱臣命工，销画真武圣像，设大缸净水，盛贮此龟供养。 后赴信阳，监修筑土墙，部辖人夫二千。 值冬月雨雪，役夫大半染患倒外。 一日，拱臣不觉因思似梦，而见本家大龟告云：数年承收养敬信，今为圣上来唤，即当升天。 却知司法在此，负忧人夫病患，故来报谢。 请司法备净水一瓯，以杨枝对北面天念咒，咒云：天罡天魁，立驱电雾。 施我阴功，狂灾速去。 一气念三遍，用此水洒其患者，必获安健，他日当承恩。 龟乃辞去。 拱臣依此咒咒水，洒其患者。 不移时间，皆得汗苏醒。 其大龟於拱臣得梦日，化为一阵黑风不见。 其信阳监城墙修筑既毕，军夫不失性命，其功皆承真武龟蛇应合降灵。 转运使费瓖，具录闻奏。 续降回旨，许於信阳监刊石碑，及置真武殿，修奉香火。 陈拱臣特除授卫尉寺丞，转承奉郎。 真法浸钱

Chen Gongchen, Judicial Officer of Huaiyang Commandery, had in his youth acquired a tortoise. Its shell was a lustrous green, overlaid with golden-green down, its eyes crimson, its tail long—about the size of a small cup. He kept it for five or seven years, and by the time he passed the imperial examinations, the tortoise had grown to the size of a basin. It favored jujubes and was kept in a bamboo basket. One bright moonlit night, a family member playfully lifted the tortoise, only for it to shrink its body into its shell, now no larger than a bowl, while a small crimson-spotted snake coiled around it in play. Chen pondered: the tortoise and snake were the celestial gate and earthly pivot, emblems of the True Martial Fortune Deity. The next day, the tortoise had resumed its former size, the snake nowhere to be seen. This occurred for several nights. Chen then commissioned an artisan to cast an image of the True Martial Sage, set a large vat of pure water, and placed the tortoise within as an offering.

Later, while overseeing the construction of earthen walls in Xinyang, Chen commanded two thousand laborers. During a winter of rain and snow, more than half the workers fell ill and collapsed. One day, Chen drifted into a dreamlike reverie and saw his tortoise address him: “For years, you have cared for and revered me. Now, summoned by the Son of Heaven, I am to ascend to heaven. Yet I know the Judicial Officer is burdened by the suffering of these laborers, so I come to express my gratitude. Prepare a bowl of pure water, take a willow branch, face north, and recite this incantation: *‘Celestial Stem, Celestial Pivot, dispel the storm and mist. Bestow your hidden merit—let wild calamity swiftly depart.’* Recite it three times in one breath, then sprinkle the water upon the afflicted. They will surely recover, and you shall receive imperial favor in time.” The tortoise then took its leave.

Chen followed the instructions, reciting the incantation over the water and sprinkling it upon the sick. In no time, they broke into sweat and revived. On the very day Chen received the dream, the great tortoise transformed into a gust of black wind and vanished. The Xinyang wall was completed without loss of life among the laborers, their deliverance attributed to the divine convergence of the True Martial’s tortoise and snake. Fiscal Commissioner Fei Qiang documented the event and memorialized the throne. An imperial rescript followed, permitting the erection of a stele in Xinyang and the construction of a True Martial Hall to maintain its incense and offerings. Chen Gongchen was specially appointed Vice Minister of the Court of the Imperial Regalia and promoted to Gentleman for Fostering Service. The true Dharma spread, and merit flowed like coin.

chunks.original_text: 凤翔府有豪民锺守安，全家贪财好杀，凡事欺曲。 惟玄孙进明，自恨难以谏之。 适值七月十五日，僧舍作盂兰盆会，见铺设地狱帧像，恶相因缘，从此悔悟，待诵经典，将本房钱物布施与人。 忽一日，见一道士，求化自在心钱，形貌古怪，遂召於市肆吃茶，问曰：本系何氏，贯居甚里。 道士曰：姓裴名郭，生居武当。 今到凤翔，未曾遇合一人。 进明日：愿求一诀，可救迷网。 道士於地上拾得一钱，付进明曰：牢收，牢收。 道士望西而去。 进明得此一钱，认是乾重之文，遂收结在身。 自后，又遇一人，手擎檀香雕装真武货卖，进明用钱七贯文赎下。 却为本家翁父不喜神佛，将就天庆观道士陆元质房，寄附供养，逐日早晚，亲到添换香火。 将及十年，自觉祈祷灵验。 进明一夜，状如沉醉，倒卧於本房。 明见向者付一钱道士唤云：汝收吾一钱在身，可将救取几人屈死性命。 以水浸之，见我即施，必有所应。 进明至晓方苏，遂往见道士孙筠之，问真武所出姓氏。 孙君曰：真武出身於挣乐国郭氏，授业於太上老君，修道在武当山。 至唐则天时，降生裴侍郎家，断灭妖童。 进明闻此，方悟得遇真武显化。 遂听探街坊，见有患热渴瘟疫，狂躁投井赴河者，遂将此钱往天庆观，取净水浸之，焚香於真武前祷祝，愿降灵气真法，入水施人。 方祷祝次，其圣相忽起圆光，如火焰烁，一室之中，金光罩耀。 遂将此净水，沿门散施，患人皆安。 是时，传达郡人，尽来瞻礼进明。 终为伯叔兄弟嫌妬，多要窘拾。
chunks.translated_text:
In Fengxiang Prefecture there lived a wealthy man named Zhong Shou’an, whose entire household was avaricious and bloodthirsty, perverting justice in all matters. Only his great-grandson Jinming lamented his inability to admonish them. On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, as monks held the Ullambana Festival, Jinming saw hell scrolls displayed in the monastery—depictions of karmic retribution in their hideous forms. Stricken with remorse, he began reciting sutras and donated his personal wealth to others. One day, a Daoist appeared, begging for "free-heart coins." His appearance was most peculiar, so Jinming invited him to a teahouse in the market and asked, "What is your surname and native place?" The Daoist replied, "I am Pei Guo of Wudang." He had come to Fengxiang but encountered no one receptive. Jinming said, "I wish to learn a formula to save those lost in delusion." The Daoist picked up a coin from the ground and handed it to Jinming, saying, "Guard it well, guard it well." Then he turned west and departed. Jinming examined the coin and saw it bore the inscription *qian zhong* ("weight of the firmament"). He kept it on his person.

Later, he met a man carrying a sandalwood-carved statue of the True Martial for sale. Jinming spent seven strings of cash to redeem it. Since his grandfather and father despised deities and Buddhas, he entrusted the statue to Daoist Lu Yuanzhi of Tianqing Abbey for safekeeping, visiting daily to tend its incense. After nearly a decade, he found his prayers increasingly efficacious.

One night, Jinming fell into a stupor and collapsed in his chamber. In a vision, the Daoist who had given him the coin called out: "You carry my coin—use it to save those who died unjustly. Soak it in water, and when you see me, administer it; there will be a response." Jinming awoke at dawn and sought out Daoist Sun Junzhi to inquire about the True Martial’s origins. Sun replied: "The True Martial was born into the Guo clan of Zhengle Kingdom, studied under the Most High Lord Lao, and cultivated the Dao on Mount Wudang. During Empress Wu Zetian’s reign in the Tang, he incarnated in the household of Minister Pei, vanquishing demonic youths." Hearing this, Jinming realized he had encountered the True Martial’s divine manifestation.

Thereafter, he patrolled the streets and alleys, seeking those afflicted with fever, thirst, or pestilence—those who raved and threw themselves into wells or rivers. He took the coin to Tianqing Abbey, immersed it in pure water, and burned incense before the True Martial, praying for the descent of sacred qi and true Dharma into the water to heal the suffering. As he prayed, the holy image suddenly radiated a halo of flame, filling the chamber with golden light. He then carried the consecrated water from door to door, administering it to the afflicted, who all recovered. Word spread throughout the prefecture, and the people flocked to pay homage to Jinming. Yet his uncles and cousins, consumed by envy, sought every means to harass him.

Even when more than a hundred men joined to lift it, the image remained fixed to its altar. Unexpectedly, an imperial envoy arrived at the prefecture bearing a decree from the Central Secretariat, based on a memorial from the Bureau of Astronomy: recently, a five-colored auspicious radiance had appeared, ascending to the Gate of Heaven, and was determined to have manifested within the borders of Fengxiang Prefecture—a sacred treasure of wondrous virtue and honor. The prefect, along with all officials down to the magistrates, was ordered to conduct a thorough search. After careful deliberation, the prefectural authorities concluded that only Zhong Jinming’s enshrined True Martial exhibited such divine marvels. When the small sandalwood-carved True Martial statue was unveiled before the throne, several beams of light suddenly burst forth. The emperor rose from his seat, burned incense, and paid reverence, then temporarily enshrined the image in the Upper Clarity Palace of Extended Blessings. Awaiting the deliberation of the Three Departments on the matter’s details, further actions would be taken. chunks.original_text: 内殿崇班入内内侍省任悦，奉动充秦凤路军骑安抚官。 过涤州渡黄河，於半津遇风雾昏暗，随侍吏云：此是黄河第一崖门要固燥口北岸，是游州天庆观分到香火一殿，名护国真武院，凡经过，先抛献纸马。 任悦祷祝灵空，过河别具数目，还赛发意。 才毕，云彩风色，豁然平定。 任悦与一行人，俱见一神人，现於虚空，认其形相，乃在京四圣观塑画福神真武也。 任悦就舟便拜，起受真武降言，如俗交语，乃云：此一殿，系唐太宗因功臣魏征，撰其砥柱铭建立。 至今为其处，乃是院口第一险恶疆界，从此，分吾在此为国家保镇山河。 今殿宇飧损，盖有年矣。 时复下降，按伏龙蜃，无存泊处。 吾若不来，水燥必坏，为国之害不细。 切宜记录，不得漏泄机密，除奏达圣聪外，别与谈议，立生疮痘果报。 言讫不见。 任悦回朝面奏绿由，圣意犹未信。 任悦不合再举陈於上前，当殿语声不出，继遭疮痘之报。 因而谛信，除赐任悦就注在京监宫，宜令有司立便检会大唐实录，照应选差殿使，前去同泻州守臣，重建殿宇，御赐镇安兴福为额，永作香火祀典。 现海救危 信州龙虎山福圣太极观，是汉张天师传代法录灵坛第四洞天。 昨因遗火焚烧，经七年逐旋添造，惟北极一殿广大，未有擅施。 忽一日，泉州客人到观设斋，计料北极殿材植等数，欲一力全造。 本观问及设斋造殿之意，据称：前宰相陈侍中知广州，泛海归泉州时，高碗随行，其船将近乡界，忽逆风漂荡。 侍中乃焚香祷告虚空，愿求救护。 风涛顿息，前望悬空，一髦头道者，告言：侍中到此，惊危甚矣，特为使转其风，不至漂溺。 今送侍中一行骨肉早回泉州。 侍中焚香拜谢，敢问甚处圣贤，特现救护，誓当铭心篆骨，香火仰报。 答曰：信州龙虎山太极观，火焚北极殿宇，已及七年，未得成就。 吾系天帅委来，寻有缘者。 今日幸救侍中，更不凭疏目，侍中便可发心。 遂於云中不见，遗巡之问，人船已抵泉州界。 举家思惟，髦头圣相，必是真武真君，显现救护，求造其殿。 即遣高碗前来验实。 高瑰复回，呈计料等事，前后三年，起发材植造殿，塑装了毕。 前宰相陈之纯，遂具割奏闻，望赐恩额，以救危显圣为名。 奉圣旨，除依所请，仍赐度牒十道，银五百两，添助修造，并给助本观常住。 并侍中庆忏宝殿，普设大醮大斋，仰报真武垂现救护之恩。 何诠遇会 隋有虔州厢军何诠，因随安抚使张佑之往南康，游庐山太清观谷岩洞，遇真武生辰，会父母於瑶玉天。 尝蒙申奏，拣放逐便，何诠从此，用帛彩画真武一帧供养。 合药货卖，逾五七年，凡有病者，服之皆愈。 从兹，聚蓄资财，及二千余贯。 忽告其妻，兄年幼，身卑贱，雕面作军，请天禄三十年，不曾负国背公，幸有宿绿，得遇真武生辰圣会，致蒙国家放令逐便。 今生计丰饶，有钱二千余贯，今欲留一千贯，付汝日给，并出货元药外，一千贯载往庐山天庆观，建造法堂七问。 将毕，忽有朝廷使臣陈伯虎降香，投放金龙。 殿中侍御史晏良弼，同南康军刺史到洞，因见何诠舍钱建造法堂，咸皆欢羡。 伯虎谓良弼曰：有如此事，何绿得达朝廷。 少顷，忽有一白鹿，於法堂后走上山林。 良弼令人趁踪入林寻觅，左右报言：林中白鹿不见，却有一庵，内有军人在此眠睡，闻人入林，惊起出林而去。

Rén Yuè, an Attendant of the Inner Palace of the Inner Court’s Esteemed Rank, was appointed as Pacification Commissioner of the Qinfeng Circuit’s Cavalry. While crossing the Yellow River at Dizhou, he encountered dense wind and fog at midstream. His attending officials remarked: "This is the first perilous pass of the Yellow River—the northern bank of the parched mouth at Yaomen Gorge. Here stands a hall of the Tianqing Abbey of Youzhou, allocated a share of its incense offerings, named the Protector-State True Martial Sanctuary. All who pass must first cast paper horses as tribute."

Rén Yuè prayed to the empty void, vowing to offer additional sacrifices upon crossing. No sooner had he finished than the clouds and wind abruptly stilled. He and his retinue all beheld a divine figure manifest in the sky, whose form they recognized as the True Martial of Blessing, the very image enshrined in the Four Saints Abbey of the capital. Rén Yuè prostrated himself upon the boat and, rising, received True Martial’s descent in speech akin to mortal conversation: "This hall was established by Emperor Taizong of Tang in honor of his meritorious minister Wei Zheng, who composed the *Pillar-Stabilizing Inscription* for its founding. To this day, this place remains the most treacherous frontier of the sanctuary’s domain. From henceforth, I have been stationed here to safeguard the mountains and rivers for the state. Yet the hall has long stood in disrepair, and my descents to subdue dragons and miasmic spirits find no refuge. Were I not here, the waters and droughts would surely wreak havoc, bringing no small harm to the realm. You must record this without fail, and reveal no secrets—report only to the imperial ear. Speak of this to others, and you shall suffer the karmic retribution of sores and boils." With that, the vision vanished.

Upon returning to court, Rén Yuè presented the matter to the throne, though the emperor remained skeptical. When Rén Yuè imprudently reiterated the account before the court, his voice failed him mid-speech, and he soon suffered the foretold affliction of sores and boils. Thus convinced, the court appointed him to oversee the capital’s palace affairs and ordered the relevant offices to consult the *Veritable Records of the Great Tang*, then dispatch a palace envoy to collaborate with Dizhou’s local officials in rebuilding the hall. The emperor bestowed the name *Pacifying Peace, Blessing-Bringing* as its plaque, establishing it as a permanent site for incense offerings and ritual observances.

At the Fusheng Taiyi Abbey of Longhushan in Xinzhou—a sacred precinct of the Fourth Grotto-Heaven, passed down through the lineage of Han-dynasty Celestial Master Zhang—a fire had ravaged its halls seven years prior. Though repairs had been made incrementally, the vast Northern Culmen Hall remained unfinished. One day, a merchant from Quanzhou arrived to sponsor a vegetarian feast. Calculating the timber and materials required for the Northern Culmen Hall, he pledged to fund its entire reconstruction. When the abbey inquired into his intent, he recounted: "Former Chief Minister Chen, while sailing home to Quanzhou from Guangzhou, was accompanied by his steward Gao Kui. As their ship neared their native shores, a contrary wind set them adrift. The minister burned incense and prayed to the void, vowing to seek deliverance. The storm instantly calmed, and ahead, suspended in the sky, appeared a top-knotted Daoist, who declared: 'Minister, your peril was grave. I have turned the wind to spare you from drowning. Now I shall ensure your family’s safe return to Quanzhou.' The minister burned incense in gratitude and asked which sage had manifested to save them, swearing to engrave the debt upon his heart and bones in perpetual reverence. The figure replied: 'At the Taiyi Abbey of Longhushan in Xinzhou, the Northern Culmen Hall has lain in ruins for seven years, uncompleted. I was dispatched by the Heavenly Marshal to seek one with karmic affinity. Today, having saved you, I need not rely on petitions—you may now fulfill this vow.' With that, he vanished into the clouds. Moments later, the ship reached Quanzhou’s shores. The household reflected that the top-knotted sage must have been the True Martial Sovereign, manifesting to deliver them. Thus, they sent Gao Kui to verify the abbey’s condition.'"

Gao Kui returned with the calculations, and over the next three years, the merchant funded the hall’s construction and its sculptural adornments. Former Chief Minister Chen Zhichun then submitted a memorial, requesting an imperial plaque to honor the deity’s miraculous deliverance. By imperial decree, the request was granted, and ten ordination certificates along with five hundred taels of silver were bestowed to aid the reconstruction, further endowing the abbey’s permanent endowment. The minister also sponsored a grand repentance ritual in the Precious Hall of Thanksgiving and a grand vegetarian feast to repay True Martial’s manifest grace.

During the Sui dynasty, Hé Quán, a garrison soldier of Qianzhou, accompanied Pacification Commissioner Zhāng Yòu to Nankang, where they visited the Grotto of the Great Clarity at Mount Lu’s Taiqing Abbey. There, on True Martial’s birthday, he encountered his parents in the Jasper Jade Heaven. Having received imperial permission to retire at his convenience, Hé Quán thereafter enshrined a silk painting of True Martial. He compounded medicines for sale, and over five to seven years, all who consumed them recovered. Thus, he amassed wealth exceeding two thousand strings of cash. One day, he told his wife: "My brother is young, and I, though lowly—a tattooed soldier—have served the state for thirty years without betraying its trust. By good fortune, I encountered True Martial’s birthday assembly and was granted imperial leave. Now, with ample means, I shall set aside one thousand strings for your daily needs and the sale of my medicines. The other thousand I shall take to the Tianqing Abbey of Mount Lu to construct a seven-bay Dharma Hall."

Upon its completion, an imperial envoy, Chén Bóhǔ, arrived to offer incense and present a golden dragon. Palace Censor Yàn Liángbì and the prefect of Nankang Commandery visited the grotto and, seeing Hé Quán’s donation, expressed admiration. Bóhǔ remarked to Liángbì: "Such deeds should be reported to the throne." Moments later, a white deer darted from behind the Dharma Hall into the mountain forest. Liángbì ordered men to pursue its tracks into the woods. They returned, reporting: "The white deer vanished, but within the forest stands a hermitage where a soldier was sleeping. Roused by our entry, he fled the woods."

The emperor rose from his seat, burned incense, and paid reverence, then temporarily enshrined the image in the Upper Clarity Palace of Extended Blessings. Awaiting the deliberation of the Three Departments on the matter’s details, further actions would be taken. Thus was the *Zhenhe Xingfu* [True Martial’s River-Stabilizing, Blessing-Bringing] statue established.

chunks.original_text: 道众云：此是何诠，应现白鹿也。 后使命还朝面奏，奉圣旨，令检会到昨来江西安抚使张佑之，奏何诠遇真武生辰因依。 看详，特赠何诠道号居士，仍置影堂，镌立碑记，并立谷岩洞瑶玉天为瑶玉洞天。 何诠寿八十三，於堂后山庵内善终。 道众就山烧化，聚灰骨为胎，就装塑身供养。 未及半年，准国命加赠何诠居士为应梦虚寂先生，未知朝廷有何圣验，致此封号。 吴氏缘合 汀州武平县令杜珪，因失目，归家就医，凡六年。 珪取建州昊育侍中长女。 其妻自二十七岁产难中，得道士周明晏符录，救护平安。 从此，发心供养真武，及持斋戒，看阅道经。 见夫双目全失，遂每夜人静时，置备名香净水，露天朝启北方，礼七七拜，愿真武垂慈，救珪眼患。 可及二年，时值三月三日，夜至三更，睡中见一黄衣道士，谓曰：心坚不如身净，意重不如缘合。 七日内，有人来医杜珪眼，候平复如故，却来云苍相见，与我师还却眼债。 言讫不见。 后满七日，昊氏於门前，见一道人，扇上写云苍道人攻医眼患。 昊氏召之，遂看夫眼，用二针於眼两角，并留二药，日进三服，水调，服尽见功。 道人更不受钱，出门不知所之。 遂依此服尽其药。 一夜，杜珪梦见双目被一小龟沿上面来用口舐其眼，珪用手拂之，惊觉双目俱明。 乃思，医药并小龟，显承真武降灵，垂救眼患。 后闻妻父昊育，判太原府，因拥妻至彼。 一日，出西城郊外，因至天柱观，其山名云苍。 步入其山，见一殿装塑神像，被人刮除眼目，审问，知是真武圣像。 昊氏惊悟前者云苍相见，还我师眼债之说。 逐一言与父，育乃自备钱装修，将杜珪前因患眼罢官，后遇真武应化医救情由，保明申奏，保举注差。 续降指挥，昊育装修云苍山塑像，了毕，申闻别议。 勋赠其杜珪，可转授扬州观察判官。 进明显圣 中书门下三司礼部定到凤翔府锺进明，曾因择善檀香雕銮真武，寄留天庆观道士陆元质房供养，早晚亲去，香火不缺，得遇真武，教令呎水救人疾病。 金光焕赫，上应天汉，致司天台上言，其光现於秦分，今凤翔府，主有古异功德圣像。 差人取问，今是凤翔府发遣到真武台座，奉圣旨，送上清延福宫供养外，赐锺进明除授三斑借职，即於本家，遥具礼仪，朝谢讫，不三日，染患身死。 既而乡社所谓，进明死后，圣迹显发，祈请有验。 后翰林学士刑部侍郎孙诚之，奉使西蕃，於凤翔府，路逢一道士，布袍草履，前迎诚之曰：侍郎命绿不当此，权去时，须有惊忧，迥而必夭。 诚之曰：汝是何人，故知预事。 道士曰：我本凤翔百姓锺进明，今为凤翔府三罗山琼壶洞主，监管玉峰龙潭，今乃成半仙列矣。 适见侍郎顶上有黑气，问有白气，大为不祥，必主前路惊忧，回国身夭。 诚之再问：有斯灾祸，如何消禳。 进明曰：至危难处，但念我本师真武灵应真君尊号，终获感护。 然虽救得离蕃，恐归国终有灾。 言讫，忽然不见。

The Daoist assembly remarked, "This must have been Hé Quán manifesting as the white deer." Later, the imperial envoy returned to court and reported the matter. By imperial decree, he was ordered to consult with the former Jiangxi Pacification Commissioner, Zhāng Yòu, regarding Hé Quán’s encounter with the True Warrior on his birthday. After review, Hé Quán was posthumously bestowed the Daoist title *Jūshì* (Lay Daoist). A shadow hall was established in his honor, a stele inscribed with his deeds, and the Gǔyán Grotto of Yáoyù Heaven was renamed Yáoyù Cavern Heaven.

Hé Quán lived to eighty-three and passed peacefully in the mountain hermitage behind the hall. The Daoist assembly cremated his remains on the mountain, gathered his ashes and bones as relics, and enshrined them in a sculpted likeness for veneration. Before half a year had passed, by imperial command, Hé Quán’s title was elevated to *Yìngmèng Xūjí Xiānshēng* (Master of Dream-Responding Emptiness). It remains unknown what divine sign from the court prompted this honor.

---

**The Wu Clan’s Karmic Affinity**
Dù Guī, magistrate of Wǔpíng County in Tíngzhōu, lost his sight and returned home for medical treatment, enduring six years of blindness. He had married the eldest daughter of Hào Yù, a minister from Jiànzhōu. During childbirth at twenty-seven, his wife received a talisman and scripture from the Daoist Zhōu Míngyàn, which preserved her safety. From then on, she vowed to venerate the True Warrior, uphold vegetarian precepts, and study Daoist scriptures. Seeing her husband’s blindness, she would, in the stillness of each night, prepare fine incense and pure water, face the northern sky in the open, and prostrate herself seventy times in seven cycles, praying for the True Warrior’s compassion to heal his eyes.

After two years, on the third day of the third month, at the third watch of the night, she dreamed of a Daoist in yellow robes who said: "Sincerity of heart is not as potent as bodily purity; weighty intent is not as profound as karmic affinity. Within seven days, someone will come to treat Dù Guī’s eyes. Once his sight is restored, seek me at Yúncāng to repay your master’s debt." With that, the Daoist vanished.

Seven days later, Hào’s wife saw a Daoist at her gate, his fan inscribed: *"Yúncāng Daoist, skilled in curing eye ailments."* She summoned him, and he examined her husband’s eyes, inserting two needles at the corners and leaving two medicines to be taken thrice daily with water. Once consumed, they would take effect. The Daoist accepted no payment and departed, vanishing without a trace. Following his instructions, she administered the medicine until it was exhausted.

One night, Dù Guī dreamed a small tortoise crawled onto his face and licked his eyes. He brushed it away, awakening to find his sight fully restored. Reflecting on the medicine and the tortoise, he realized the True Warrior had manifested his divine power to heal his blindness.

Later, hearing her father Hào Yù had been appointed prefect of Tàiyuán, she accompanied her husband there. One day, they ventured beyond the western city gates to Tiānzhù Abbey, located on a mountain called Yúncāng. Entering the mountain, they found a hall where a deity’s statue had been defaced—its eyes gouged out. Upon inquiry, they learned it was the sacred image of the True Warrior. Hào’s wife suddenly understood the Daoist’s earlier words: *"Meet me at Yúncāng to repay your master’s eye debt."*

She recounted the story to her father, who then funded the restoration himself. He memorialized the circumstances: how Dù Guī had resigned due to blindness, how the True Warrior’s divine intervention had healed him, and how he had been reinstated through official recommendation. An imperial edict followed, ordering Hào Yù to complete the restoration of the statue on Yúncāng Mountain before submitting a separate report. In recognition of his merit, Dù Guī was promoted to Judicial Officer of Yángzhōu.

---

**Manifestations of Divine Power**
The Central Secretariat, the Chancellery, the Three Departments, and the Ministry of Rites verified the case of Zhōng Jìnmíng of Fèngxiāng Prefecture. He had selected fine sandalwood to carve an image of the True Warrior, which he entrusted to the Daoist Lù Yuánzhì of Tiānqìng Abbey for veneration. Zhōng attended to the statue daily, ensuring incense and offerings were never lacking. The True Warrior appeared to him, teaching him to measure water for healing the sick. A radiant golden light blazed forth, aligning with the celestial river. The Bureau of Astronomy reported the phenomenon, noting its appearance in the region of Qín—present-day Fèngxiāng Prefecture—signifying the presence of an ancient, miraculous, and virtuous sacred image.

Officials were dispatched to investigate and retrieve the True Warrior’s pedestal. By imperial decree, it was sent to the Shàngqīng Yánfú Palace for veneration. Zhōng Jìnmíng was appointed to an honorary position in three ranks, and, while still at home, he performed the rites of gratitude to the court. Within three days, he fell ill and died.

Yet, as the local community attested, after Zhōng’s death, the saint’s miracles became even more manifest, with prayers answered and blessings granted. Later, Sūn Chéngzhī, Hanlin Academician and Vice Minister of Justice, was dispatched as an envoy to the Western Barbarian lands. While passing through Fèngxiāng Prefecture, he encountered a Daoist in hempen robes and straw sandals who approached him, saying: "Your fate, sir, does not align with this journey. When you turn back, you will face peril and distress, and upon returning, you will surely die."

Chéngzhī asked, "Who are you, and how do you foresee such things?"
The Daoist replied, "I was once Zhōng Jìnmíng, a commoner of Fèngxiāng. Now, I am the master of Qiónghú Cave on Sānluó Mountain, overseeing the Jade Peak Dragon Pool. I have attained the rank of a half-immortal. Just now, I saw a black aura above your head, countered by a white aura—an ominous sign. It foretells peril on your journey and death upon your return."

Chéngzhī pressed further: "If such disaster awaits, how may it be averted?"
Jìnmíng said, "In your hour of greatest danger, invoke the sacred title of my master, the True Warrior, the Spiritually Responsive Perfected Lord. You will surely receive his protection. Though you may escape the barbarians, I fear you will still face calamity upon returning home." With that, he vanished.

chunks.original_text: 诚之入蕃，受蕃王李希静燕会，因举题日月出束还没西七字短令，无对，致李希静欲令囚之。 乃於恐惧中，默念真武灵应真君数声。 有一官人力谏，希静渐息怒意，复令放还。 诚之辞蕃归京，未入界，先被随行察事使臣具奏。 忽有使臣资动前来交割，孙诚之一行从人，及蕃王回礼表苔等责降，为使入蕃辱国，特赐药酒，听动命，甘死无词。 忽有使臣资白剖来，特赐孙诚之兔死，降尽前官，责授远恶小郡，监临差使。 绿皇帝因览锺进明显应，皆获真武慈德，委令半仙护国救民，不违真武救护，故放孙诚之死罪。 下凤翔府建锺进明祠堂，为本人带三班借职，身死显圣，元遇真武授记，是谓本师弟子，其祠合以二殿先，后真武。 许依卿原装塑进明，即以白衣仪相，表半仙之位。 仍赠善导安寂仙君，及赐二辅报慈庙为额。 令本府撰立碑记，永示不朽。
chunks.translated_text:
Chéngzhī entered the barbarian lands and was received by the barbarian king Lǐ Xījìng at a banquet. There, he was asked to compose a short verse on the theme of the seven characters "the sun and moon rise in the east and set in the west," but none could match his response, provoking Lǐ Xījìng’s wrath and threat of imprisonment. In his terror, Chéngzhī silently invoked the sacred title of the True Warrior, the Spiritually Responsive Perfected Lord several times. An official then pleaded on his behalf, gradually calming Xījìng’s anger, and he was released.

Upon Chéngzhī’s departure from the barbarian lands to return to the capital, before even crossing the border, a surveillance envoy traveling with him submitted a full report. Suddenly, an imperial commissioner arrived bearing orders to take charge of the matter. Chéngzhī’s entire retinue, along with the barbarian king’s return gifts and official correspondence, was confiscated. Charged with humiliating the nation during his mission abroad, he was specially granted poisoned wine to drink, with the command to accept his fate without protest. Moments later, another imperial commissioner arrived bearing a decree: Chéngzhī was spared execution but stripped of all previous ranks and reassigned to a remote, undesirable post as a supervisory official.

As the emperor reviewed the account of Zhōng Jìnmíng’s divine intervention, recognizing how the True Warrior’s compassionate virtue had manifested, he ordered the half-immortal to be entrusted with protecting the nation and saving its people. Acknowledging that the True Warrior’s protection had spared Chéngzhī from death, the emperor commuted his sentence. He commanded the construction of a shrine to Zhōng Jìnmíng in Fèngxiāng Prefecture, appointing him an honorary post in the Three Ranks with the title of Acting Officer. After Jìnmíng’s death, his spirit manifested, and he received a prophecy from the True Warrior, confirming him as a disciple of the master. Thus, his shrine was to be arranged with two halls in the front, and the True Warrior’s hall behind. The emperor permitted the original likeness of Jìnmíng to be sculpted, depicting him in the white robes of a commoner to signify his rank as a half-immortal. He further bestowed upon him the posthumous title of *Shàndǎo Ānjì Xiānjūn* ("Virtuous Guide, Serene and Tranquil Immortal Lord") and granted the two auxiliary temples the nameplate *Bàocí Miào* ("Temples of Repaying Compassion"). The prefecture was ordered to commission and erect a stele inscription to ensure his legacy endured forever.

chunks.original_text: 邹宿契灵庆 历二年三月初五日，中书门下，据郑州保奏，本州监酒内殿崇班邹宿，在任公正，惟只供养真武，侍奉精恪。 既不曾以谄曲欺诳之事祈求，又不曾於诸事背义，贪残恣杀物命。 凡州民有水旱灾疫，先於诸处神祠无应，若邹宿斋戒於本家真武前祈祷，皆获灵验。 人皆谓邹宿曾悟圣教，密契神灵，故郑州阴受其赐。 忽一日，郑州於日午间，天降风雹，姻云四起，於北门裹，黑雾盘旋，降下无盖铜棺一具，空中但闻音乐嘹亮。 自知通以下，至於百姓，尽皆易衣入棺，并不容在内。 其后监酒邹宿穿执而来，方入其棺，忽闻振响一声，遂降其盖，轻举而上，仙诏鹤唳，瑞气天香，霭而不散，其棺冉冉向正北而去。 次据白莲山延寿院僧智仁等状申，昨晚山上，五色祥云笼罩，闻有乐声，异香芬馥，天花如雨坠。 而复收雾，垂甘露，约至更尽方息。 今早集僧众，上看其山中，元有一峰，号鹏巢，两畔有石岩，相离十五余步，今却相合。 於正北石岩接缝间，留一小石门，方圆四尺，望见裹面有一铜棺。 山之上下朽木，并发芳条，一时变为茂林，杂花竞开，乌兽飞呜，如罩护状，未委事由。 州司参详，已得昨晚天降铜棺，迎去邹宿因依，集当职官吏及道僧，前去看验，委实。 保奏，续有回降下郑州：缘邹宿近出神，到内殿朝辞云：臣蒙天符，差充北极寿限曹副判官勾当，每年一次，当随真武下降人问，计算世人善恶，校量寿限，皆承真武保合授记。 臣恩受皇帝禄赐，特来报谢。 今勘会邹宿有无子孙，承绍恩泽一道，迁注供侍骨肉。 如无，即厚给钱帛养赡外，仰就白莲山建造邹宿祠堂，以神应府君庙为额，永为祈请灵迹之处。 天锡青枣 饶州乐平县，有江州团练判官朱牧，并无男女。 牧自父亢临终时，谓云：今后莫忘真武圣堂香火，凡遇每月下降，至诚供养。 如遇三月初三，五月初五，七月初七，九月初九，此四日，每备供养三分，精虔祭献。 牧自先父嘱付，不曾有违。 一次，适遇七月七日圣降之辰，是夜，烧献毕，约三更以来，妻氏梦一黄衣道士，以石碟盛青枣一枚，劝吃。 既吃，觉满口异香，道士云：此乃天锡仙人之枣。 自后有胎，生下一男，风骨俊秀。 五岁，记诵聪敏。
chunks.translated_text:
On the fifth day of the third month in the second year of the *Lìqìng* era, the Chancellery and the Secretariat received a memorial from Zhengzhou Prefecture, reporting that Zōu Sù, the Wine-Monitor and Inner Palace Venerable Officer of the prefecture, had served with integrity in his post. He devoted himself solely to the worship of the True Warrior, his devotion sincere and reverent. He never resorted to flattery or deceit in his prayers, nor did he ever act against righteousness—greedy, cruel, or wantonly taking lives. Whenever the people of the prefecture suffered from floods, droughts, or epidemics, and their prayers to other deities went unanswered, if Zōu Sù fasted and prayed before the True Warrior in his own home, his supplications were always efficacious. The people said that Zōu Sù had awakened to the sacred teachings and secretly formed a bond with the divine, and thus Zhengzhou had received his hidden blessings.

One day, at noon, Zhengzhou was struck by a sudden storm of wind and hail, and dark clouds swirled on all sides. At the northern gate, a black mist coiled, and from it descended an uncovered bronze coffin. Ethereal music filled the air. From the magistrate down to the common folk, all changed into ceremonial robes and entered the coffin, yet none were permitted to remain within. Then the Wine-Monitor Zōu Sù arrived, clad in his official robes, and only when he stepped inside did the coffin lid suddenly close with a resounding clang. The coffin then rose lightly into the air, accompanied by the cries of cranes and the celestial decree, while auspicious vapors and heavenly incense lingered, refusing to disperse. The coffin drifted slowly toward the due north and vanished.

Later, the monks of the *Yánshòu* Monastery on White Lotus Mountain, led by the monk Zhìrén, submitted a report stating that the previous evening, the mountain had been enveloped in five-colored auspicious clouds, and celestial music had been heard, along with an extraordinary fragrance. Flowers rained from the sky, and after the mist cleared, sweet dew descended, persisting until the watches of the night had ended. The next morning, the monks gathered and ascended the mountain, where they found that a peak called *Péngcháo* ("Roc’s Nest") had two stone cliffs on either side, originally separated by over fifteen paces, now miraculously joined. At the seam where the northern cliff met, a small stone gate, four feet square, had appeared. Within, a bronze coffin was visible.

The withered trees on the mountain, both above and below, suddenly sprouted fragrant branches, transforming in an instant into a lush forest. Flowers bloomed in profusion, and birds and beasts flew and cried as if in protective vigil. The cause of these events remained unknown. The prefectural authorities deliberated and concluded that the bronze coffin that had descended from the heavens the previous night had indeed borne Zōu Sù away. They assembled the local officials, clerks, Daoist priests, and Buddhist monks to verify the matter, and it was confirmed as true.

The memorial continued, reporting that a subsequent divine decree had descended upon Zhengzhou, stating that Zōu Sù had recently departed in spirit to the Inner Palace to take his leave, saying: *"I have received the celestial mandate to serve as Vice-Judge of the Northern Culmen Longevity Bureau. Once each year, I shall accompany the True Warrior in descending to the mortal realm to tally the good and evil of the people, assess their lifespans, and receive the True Warrior’s protection and prophecies. Having enjoyed the emperor’s salary and favors, I have come to express my gratitude."*

The decree further ordered an investigation into whether Zōu Sù had any descendants to inherit his blessings and continue the line of his kin in service. If he had none, a generous stipend of money and silk was to be provided for their support. Additionally, a shrine was to be constructed for Zōu Sù on White Lotus Mountain, to be named *Shényìng Fǔjūn Miào* ("Temple of the Divinely Responsive Prefectural Lord"), to serve forever as a place for invoking his miraculous traces.

**Heaven-Bestowed Green Dates**
In Lèpíng County of Ráo Prefecture, there lived a certain Zhū Mù, a Judicial Officer of the Jiangzhou Regiment, who had no children. Before his father, Zhū Kàng, passed away, he had instructed him: *"Never forget the incense and offerings to the True Warrior’s sacred hall. On every occasion of his monthly descent, make sincere offerings. On the third day of the third month, the fifth day of the fifth month, the seventh day of the seventh month, and the ninth day of the ninth month—these four days—prepare offerings in triplicate and present them with utmost devotion."*

Zhū Mù had never once disobeyed his late father’s instructions. On one occasion, it happened to be the seventh day of the seventh month, the day of the True Warrior’s sacred descent. That night, after the offerings had been burned, around the third watch, his wife dreamed of a Daoist priest in yellow robes, who presented her with a stone dish bearing a single green date, urging her to eat it. After she did, her mouth was filled with an extraordinary fragrance. The Daoist said: *"This is a date bestowed by the immortals of heaven."* Thereafter, she conceived and gave birth to a son, whose bearing was elegant and whose memory and intelligence were exceptional. By the age of five, he was already remarkably quick-witted.

chunks.original_text: 七岁，天才通悟。 名应四方，可应神童。 乃应母氏之梦，名曰天锡。 朝廷究察得知，臣僚亦有保举，遽蒙借授大理评事，借绊，携子天锡上殿，说书史，并不误，讲论传记，如流对御题答。 赐天锡特授假承务郎，及赐买书钱一百贯，更归修读，候至十六岁赴阙，别听指挥。 并父朱牧，先借官职，更不追还，并赐朱天锡褒谕文典。 神化红缨 信州弋阳县，开丝绵铺陆中道妻阿张，年四十四不产。 中道忽告曰：窃知时人多供养北方真武，凡百祈求无不感验。 遂赎得川画真武，归家供养。 张氏晓夕哀梼，虽祁寒极暑，未尝暂忘，如是六年。 遇一夜，中道与妻，同得一梦，与丫餐仙童争抛彩球，掷上空中，夫妻仰视，不觉飞一红缨，入於张氏口中咽下，因此有妊。 经十三个月，生一女。 至十三岁，非常端正，但未曾言，人皆谓之哑女。 弋阳县承受信州公文，为淮中书札子，指挥司天台奏，近有明星，现东南陈国分野，正当弋阳县地里，招阴贵神仙托凡异相。 委知佐根间，申据本县契勘，秪有陆中道家十三岁哑女，必是异人。 寻唤到陆中道，供析因依，申州本州保奏朝廷。 时哑女闻此，忽然言语，索香汤沐浴，换衣坐於净将，告父母云：念儿本系天化宫双女宿下，善才掌籍天童天女第一名，谓之绿霞琼女，每七周年一次轮降，充北极佑胜院副判司，随所差巡游。 祇备等昨为父母日夜泣告天曹求嗣，动感真武，将因缘簿披检，母氏宿本不注胎息，蒙真武将父母在世修奉香火功，先为保明，上奏三天，然后点儿化为红缨，入母之腹，为女一纪余年，解免母氏勤求之意。 儿降胎时，曾蒙真武嘱付，处世不得出声。 虽在父母左右，未尝言话。 今既限满，又见国家文字根括，事泄天机，虑儿不便，告别而逝。 中道与妻，遂命工用灰漆封布如塑像，於真武侧，逐日香火，修持功德，设斋答谢真武恩慈。 续后，朝廷赐到衣帛，官支粮食，以表降生神圣祥瑞例物。 候本人语言，仰逐时札录申州，再具托化情由回申。 又准中书札子，径下弋阳县，仰将陆中道家哑女托化全身，於县城官地埋坟，建亭屋遮盖，别立祠堂，塑哑女素衣神仙一身，赠寂照孝女为额，委本县立碑记。 荆王双美 唐广明皇后功德玄都观，年深霹坏，道众累疏募绿，无一抄注，自叹如何有此阻障。 有道士王诤渊云：本观有真武像，因何未蒙降鉴。 净渊忽夜梦人挑到金钱入观，堆探於真武殿前交检，即五百贯，用马乘载上天。 不旬日，忽有在京燕王位内宫令官孙惟彦等，赴真武殿铺设，称为燕刑王献纸一陌，蕾买马一匹，沉香一灶，奏状一封。 为本宫仪国夫人临产忧危时，有一道士资疏，来问大王抄题重修西应镇道观。 荆王不采，云：为夫人产忧。 其道士却言，有一法，即令便产，子母双美。 刑王闻之大喜，云：果有灵验，其观宇，独舍鼎新建造。 道士将朱砂书黄纸符一道，烧灰水调，令夫人服之。 移郊间，诞下一男。 刻王题疏，道士辞谢出门，遂寻不见。 夫人云：才服符水，眼前有符吏判官交卫，暗中被一披发金甲仗剑神人一喝，其子随声而下。 又自闻得报言：此子从西应镇玄都观中来，急往彼处，保扶荆王。 因献钱马等，并验本观飧损，还有道士入京抄题否。
